Definición oficial: Oceanic, inshore and offshore waters and their open-water and bottom communities

Complex ecosystems, restricted to coastal areas of the Palaearctic region, and combining natural or seminatural habitats characteristic of units 11, 15, 16, 17 or 18 with agropastoral landscapes otherwise listed in unit 8, as well as more minor elements borrowed from other units.

Plains behind dunes especially characteristic of the western seaboard of the Outer Hebrides. Windblown calcareous sands deposited on peat support a flower-rich, and correspondingly insect-rich, dune grassland studded with shallow lochs and cultivated on a strip rotation. The grassland is dominated by [Poa pratensis] and [Festuca rubra], accompanied by [Thalictrum minus] ssp. [arenarium], [Thymus praecox] ssp. [arcticus] ([Thymus drucei]), [Bellis perennis], [Prunella vulgaris], [Erodium cicutarium], [Trifolium spp.], [Euphrasia spp.] and many orchids, among which [Dactylorhiza fuchsii] ssp. [hebridensis], [Dactylorhiza purpurella], [Gymnadenia conopsea], [Coeloglossum viride], [Platanthera chlorantha] and [Orchis mascula] are the most prominent. This grassland harbours a plant community of very restricted distribution comprising vulnerable species
Oceanic and continental shelf waters of the world ocean and its connected seas, their associated open-water and bottom communities, and marine vascular vegetation beds

Pelagic biocoenoses of the world ocean, its connected seas and coastal lagoons. They can be characterized by their planktonic communities and by the composition of their nektonic or surface-feeding faunas of cephalopods, fish, sea mammals and seabirds.

Waters beyond the continental shelf. In the Palaearctic region they occupy the greatest part of the Arctic, Atlantic and Pacific oceans, of the Barents Sea,  the Sea of Okhotsk, the Sea of Japan, the Arabian Sea, the Mediterranean Sea, the Ligurian Sea, the Tyrrhenian Sea, the Ionian Sea, as well as the central part of the Aegean Sea, the Red Sea, the Black Sea, the southern Adriatic Sea, the eastern part of the northern North Sea, the southern Bering Sea. They are absent from the Baltic Sea.

Oceanic waters of tropical and subtropical regions, generally of low productivity and high species diversity. In the Palaearctic, they include oceanic waters of the Atlantic north to about 40øN latitude, of the Mediterreanean, the Black Sea, the Red Sea, the Arabian Sea, the Pacific north to about 32øN latitude.

Oceanic waters of boreal, subarctic and arctic regions. In the Palaearctic, they include oceanic waters of the Arctic Ocean and its satellite seas, of the  Atlantic south to about 40øN latitude, of the North Sea, the Bering Sea, the Sea of Okhotsk, the Sea of Japan, of the Pacific south to about 32øN latitude.

Oceanic areas over which the warmer surface water is displaced, allowing cooler water rich in nutrients to rise to the surface. They are characterized by higher biological productivity and lower diversity.
Waters of the continental shelf, underwater plateau extending from the coast to a depth of about 100 fathoms, beyond which the continental slope falls steeply toward the ocean bottom.

Waters within the strong influence of land masses, both in terms of physical parameters and of fauna, often arbitrarily defined as waters less than 5 km from low water mark, waters between the continent and islands or islets well in sight of shore, and any seas of depth less than 6 metres. They include the inshore waters of the Eurasian and African continents and their nearshore islands, south to Mauritania in the Atlantic, Egypt in the Red Sea, the Arabian peninsula and Iran in the Indian Ocean, China in the Pacific, and of Greenland, Iceland, the Azores, the Madeiran archipelago, the Canaries, the Cape Verde Islands, Soccotra, the Bonin, Volcano and Marcus islands, the Commander Islands.
Waters of the continental shelf comprised between the limits of inshore waters and the continental slope.

Continental shelf waters of the high Arctic zone, bordering middle and northern Greenland, Spitzbergen, Franz Josef Land, Novaya Zemlya, Severnaya Zemlya, the New Siberian Islands, Wrangel Island and the nothern Siberian mainland from the north coast of the Yamal peninsula eastwards.
Continental shelf waters of the low Arctic zone.

Offshore waters of the low Arctic region of the North Atlantic and the Arctic Ocean, off southern Greenland, Iceland, Jan Mayen, Bear Island, northern Scandinavia, northwestern mainland Russia, southern and middle Novaya Zemlya.
Offshore waters of the Chukchi Sea, the Bering Strait, the Bering Sea, the Commander Islands, Kamchatka, the northern and central Kuriles, the Sea of Okhotsk and the Tatar Straits.

Continental shelf waters of the boreal (temperate, subarctic) maritime zone of the Atlantic, including the North Sea, the Baltic, the English Channel, the Irish Sea, the Bay of Biscay, bordering the coasts of Scandinavia south of the Arctic Circle, those of the Faeroes, of the British Isles and of their outlying archipelagoes, and those of mainland Europe south to Galicia, and of the Pacific, bordering the coasts of the southern Kuriles, Honshu, Hokkaido, Shikoku and continental Korea.

Offshore waters of the Atlantic temperate region, including the North Sea, the English Channel, the Irish Sea and the Bay of Biscay, bordering the coasts of Scandinavia south of the Arctic Circle, those of the Faeroes, of the British Isles and of their outlying archipelagoes, and those of mainland Europe south to Galicia.
Offshore waters of the Baltic Sea.
Offshore waters of the southern Kuriles, Honshu, Hokkaido, Shikoku and continental Korea.
Continental shelf waters of the subtropical maritime zone.

Offshore waters of the subtropical zone of the Atlantic, bordering the Canary Islands, Madeira, the Azores, the Mediterraneo-Atlantic coasts of Iberia, the Mediterraneo-Atlantic and Saharo-Atlantic coasts of Africa, south to Cap Blanc.
Offshore waters of the Mediterranean Sea.
Offshore waters of the Black Sea.
Offshore waters of peninsular Korea, the Yellow Sea, the East China Sea, Kyushu, the Ryukyu Islands.
Continental shelf waters of the tropical zone.
Offshore waters of the tropical zone of the Atlantic, bordering the Cape Verde Islands and the southern coast of Mauritania.

Offshore waters of the tropical Indian Ocean and its connected seas, comprising, in the Palaearctic region as here defined, those of the northern Red Sea, of the continental shelf of Asia in the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden,  the Arabian Sea, the Gulf of Oman, the Persian Gulf, and of the African continental shelf around Socotra.
Offshore waters of the Asian continental shelf in the northern South China Sea.
Waters situated over the continental slope, the steep descent from the continental shelf to the ocean bottom, an area where upwellings, water mixing or shearing and other anomalies often develop.
Zones of the continental shelf where the warmer surface water is displaced, allowing cooler water rich in nutrients to rise to the surface, often generating much increased biological productivity.
Coastal and offshore waters of the major upwelling areas of the world ocean.
Waters of the continental shelf off the desert and tropical coasts of northwest Africa.
Waters of the continental shelf of the southern Arabian peninsula.
Waters of the continental shelf in which local upwelling conditions are generated by features of the sea floor or the circulation of water masses.
Shallow waters over permanently submerged elevated features of the continental shelf sea-floor, whether shoals, banks or reefs.

Communities of marine animals and algae occupying the sea floor. Included are all communities of animals and algae of the infralittoral, circalittoral and deeper zones, situated below the level of average low spring tides, or of regular emergence through wind or atmospheric pressure variations. Also  included are communities of marine animals and algae occupying the mediolittoral zone, comprised between the low and high tide levels of average spring tides or within the regular range of wind or atmospheric pressure induced sea-level fluctuations, as well as marine assemblies installed in the supralittoral zone, reached only by spray, exceptional waves or exceptional high tides.
Littoral colonies of lower plants or animals resulting in concretions and encrustations.
Bathyal, abyssal, hadal and hydro-thermal benthic communities of the continental slope, the abyssal plain and its features.
Benthic communities of the continental slope, developed on blue, coral, green or red oceanic muds, and of relatively high diversity.
Benthic communities of abyssal plains and abyssal hills, large relatively level areas of the deep ocean floor, covered by thin layers of biogenic or nonbiogenic oozes.
Benthic communities of the oceanic trenches, deep elongated subduction troughs of the ocean floor.
Benthic communities occupying raised features of the deep sea-floor

Highly distinctive benthic communities inhabiting the vicinity of oceanic hydrothermal vents, mostly localized along the central rift of the mid-oceanic ridges and along submerged volcanic chains of lesser ocean basins.

Hydrothermal vent communities of the Central Atlantic Ridge, highly distinctive from those of other known ridges, distributed in widely separated areas strewn along the ridge from Iceland (Reykjanes Ridge) to the Azores and the Kane fracture zone.

Nombre oficial: Red Sea-Indian Ocean hydrothermal benthic communities
Definición oficial: Hydrothermal vent communities of the Indian Ocean Ridge, represented within the Palaearctic region as here defined, in the Red Sea.
Hydrothermal vent communities of the Marianas-Japan Ridge, represented in the Palaearctic region, as here defined, along the extreme southeastern boundaries.

Hydrothermal vent communities of the Nansen-Gakkel, Knepivich and Mohns ridges, extending in Arctic seas from the Kolbeinsey Ridge, at the northern margin of Iceland to the Laptev Shelf, separated from the Central Atlantic Ridge communities by the Iceland-Greenland and Iceland-Scotland sills.
Highly distinctive benthic communities of large bivalves, sponges and bryozoans, inhabiting the vicinity of oceanic methane-laden seeps, mostly localized in subduction trenches.
Mostly animal communities colonizing soft sediments such as mud, sand or gravel of the infralittoral and circalittoral zones.
Communities of mostly annual algae and invertebrates developing on pebble deposits of the infralittoral and circalittoral zones.

Nombre oficial: Sublittoral rocky seabeds and kelp forests
Definición oficial: Varied, strongly stratified communities colonizing underwater cliffs, reefs and rocky continental shelf seabeds.
Continental shelf colonies of lower plants or animals resulting in concretions and encrustations.
Communities forming and colonizing corallogenic concretions of calcified red algae in the circalittoral zone of the Mediterranean.
Mediterranean communities associated with mediolittoral pavements of encrusting algae ([Lithospermum tortuosum]).
Infralittoral ledges built by gastropods or polychaetes.
Communities of Atlantic, Baltic and Mediterranean mussel beds.
Communities of bacteria and invertebrates colonizing the vicinity of hot or cold gas seeps of the continental shelf, often forming encrusted tubes or chimneys.
Infralittoral communities of coral reefs of the Red Sea, the Arabian Sea, the Persian Gulf, the South China Sea and the East China Sea.
Infralittoral communities of coral reefs of the Red Sea, the Arabian Sea and the Persian Gulf.
Infralittoral communities of coral reefs of the South China Sea and the East China Sea.

Communities of marine invertebrates and algae colonizing the bottom and sides of caves (unit 12.7) situated under the sea or the sublittoral part of caves having an entirely, periodically or partly submerged opening.
Invertebrate and algal communities colonizing soft sediments such as mud, sand or gravel of the intertidal zone.
Communities of mostly annual algae and invertebrates developing on pebble deposits of the intertidal zone.
Communities of algae, invertebrates and lichens colonizing the mediolittoral and supralittoral zones of rocky shores and cliffs.
Cliffs and rocks of the lowest part of the mediolittoral zone, occupied by communities transitional to those of the infralittoral zone.
Cliffs and rocks of the lower part of the mediolittoral zone, occupied, in particular, by encrusting algae.
Cliffs and rocks of the higher part of the mediolittoral zone, occupied by communities characterized, in particular, by cirriped crustaceans and soft algae.
Communities of marine animals and lower plants colonizing mediolittoral overhangs and crevices, and the mediolittoral level of sea-caves (unit 12.7).
Permanent saline pools of the mediolittoral zone, fed by flood tides (tide pools).
Cliffs and rocks of the supralittoral spray zone, mostly occupied by lichens such as [Verrucaria].
Pools of the supralittoral spray zone, of variable salinity, fed by rainwater, spray and occasionally waves.
Beds of submerged marine vascular vegetation of the oceans, seas and coastal lagoons, except those of brackish seas and lagoons.

Eelgrass beds dominated by [Zostera marina], established between the base of the intertidal zone and a depth of about 10 metres in Palaearctic waters of the Atlantic, the North Sea, the Baltic and adjacent seas of the northern basin.

[Zostera marina]-dominated eelgrass beds of eastern Atlantic, North Sea, Irish Sea, Norway Sea and Baltic coasts of the Eurasian mainland and its continental shelf islands, north to the Faeroe Islands and northwestern Finmark.
Isolated [Zostera marina]-dominated eelgrass beds of Barents Sea and White Sea coasts of northeastern Finmark and Karelia.
[Zostera marina]-dominated eelgrass beds of Iceland, distributed in the western gulfs and in scattered fjords of the northwestern, northeastern and southeastern coasts.
[Zostera marina]-dominated eelgrass beds of southwestern Greenland.

Eelgrass beds dominated by [Zostera noltii] or [Zostera angustifolia], mostly characteristic of the low part of the intertidal zone in Atlantic, North Sea and Baltic waters, sometimes permanently submerged.
Formations of [Zostera noltii] or [Zostera angustifolia] of the Atlantic, North Sea and Baltic shores of continental Europe and of its continental shelf islands.
Very local [Zostera noltii] formations of Fuerteventura and Lanzarote.
Formations of [Zostera noltii] of the subtropical Atlantic shores of northwest Africa, south to Cap Blanc.
Beds of [Cymodocea nodosa], [Zostera noltii] or [Zostera marina] [s.l.] of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

[Cymodocea nodosa] formations of the Mediterranean, permanently submerged in waters down to 10 metres deep, often in sheltered areas behind [Posidonia] reefs, monospecific or associated with either the alga [Caulerpa prolifera] or the phanerogam [Halophila stipulacea].
Formations of [Zostera noltii] or [Zostera maritima] [s.l.] of the Mediterranean.
Usually sparse meadows formed, on muddy sands of the upper part of the infralittoral zone of Mediterranean coasts, by [Zostera noltii] and the alga [Giraudya sphacelarioides].
Formations of the Mediterranean endemic [Zostera hornemanniana], vicariant of [Zostera marina], often confined to coastal lagoons, recorded also from the Istrio-Dalmatian archipelago.
[Zostera marina] and [Zostera noltii] formations of Black Sea shores, particularly luxuriant in the limans of the northern Black Sea and the Azov Sea.
Beds of the Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic endemic, [Posidonia oceanica], permanently submerged in waters down to 100 metres deep.
Formations of [Cymodocea nodosa] of the Atlantic shores of southern Iberia, northwestern Africa and the Macaronesian Islands.

Formations of [Cymodocea nodosa] or [Cymodocea] and [Caulerpa spp.], in particular [Caulerpa prolifera], occupying large surfaces, on sandy substrates at depths of 1-15 metres, around the Macaronesian Islands.
Formations of [Cymodocea nodosa] of the southernmost Atlantic coasts of the Iberian peninsula.
Formations of [Cymodocea nodosa] of the shores of northwestern Africa.
Deep water colonies of [Halophila spp.] or [Thalassia spp.] of the Mediterranean and the Macaronesian Atlantic.
[Halophila decipiens] colonies of Tenerife, at depths between 10 and 14 metres.
Colonies of [Halophila stipulacea] invading the Mediterranean as a result of the opening of the Suez Canal

[Zostera marina], [Zostera caespitosa], [Zostera asiatica], [Zostera caulescens], [Zostera japonica] beds of the shores of the Kamchatka Basin, the Sea of Okhotsk, the Japan Sea, the Yellow Sea, the East China Sea and the low Arctic, boreal and subtropical Pacific.
[Phyllospadix iwatensis] or [Phyllospadix japonicus] sea-grass meadows of the temperate Pacific and its connected seas.
Beds of submerged vascular vegetation of tropical seas.

Beds of seagrasses of genera [Halophila], [Enhalus], [Thalassia], in particular [Halophila ovalis], [Halophila stipulacea], [Halophila ovata], [Enhalus acoroides] and [Thalassia hemprichii], of the Red Sea and Indo-Pacific continental shelf.
Formations of [Zostera marina], [Zostera noltii], [Cymodocea nodosa] and [Halodule wrightii] of the northwestern tropical Atlantic, transitional towards Mediterranean communities.

Beds of seagrasses of genera [Cymodocea], [Halodule], [Syringodium], [Thalassodendron], in particular [Cymodocea rotundata], [Cymodocea serrulata], [Halodule uninervis], [Syringodium isoetifolium] and [Thalassodendron ciliatum], of the coasts of the Red Sea and of the Indian Ocean coasts of the southern Arabian peninsula and Baluchistan. They constitute the main foraging habitat of [Dugong dugon].
[Zostera marina] formations of the South China Sea.
Beds of submerged or slightly emergent vascular vegetation of brackish seas, sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons.

Submerged beds of [Ruppia maritima], [Ruppia cirrhosa], [Zannichellia pedicellata], [Chara spp.], [Tolypella nidifica] of brackish seas, sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of the Palaearctic region.

Submerged beds of [Ruppia maritima], [Ruppia cirrhosa], [Zannichellia pedicellata], [Chara spp.], [Tolypella nidifica] of brackish seas, sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of Atlantic, North Sea and Baltic coasts of boreal and temperate Europe.

Submerged beds of [Ruppia maritima], [Ruppia cirrhosa], [Zannichellia pedicellata], [Potamogeton pectinatus], [Chara spp.], [Tolypella nidifica] of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of the temperate and boreal coasts of the temperate and low Arctic North Atlantic, from Iceland and nortwestern Norway to central Portugal, of the North Sea, the English Channel, the Irish Sea, from northern Iceland and nortwestern Norway in the north, south to central Portugal.

Submerged beds of vascular vegetation of the Baltic dominated by [Ruppia spp.] or [Zannichellia palustris]. Included are formations of the open inner Baltic, composed of [Ruppia maritima] var. [maritima] and [Najas marina], of [Ruppia maritima] var. [brevirostris], and [Zannichellia palustris] ssp. [polycarpa], or of [Ruppia cirrhosa] and [Zostera marina], as well as communities of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons

Submerged beds of [Ruppia maritima] or [Ruppia cirrhosa] and of [Chara spp.]  of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of the Mediterranean, the Black Sea and the subtropical Atlantic, north to southwestern Iberia, south to 27øN.

Submerged beds of [Ruppia maritima], including [Ruppia maritima] ssp. [rostellata], or [Ruppia cirrhosa] ([Ruppia drepanensis], [Ruppia spiralis]) and of [Chara spp.] of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats and coastal lagoons of Mediterranean coasts and of thermo-Atlantic coasts of southwestern Iberia, of norhwestern Africa, south to 27øN, and of the Macaronesian islands.

Submerged beds of [Ruppia maritima] or [Ruppia cirrhosa], accompanied by [Zannichellia palustris], [Potamogeton pectinatus] and [Chara spp.]  of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of the Black Sea.

Submerged beds of [Ruppia maritima] or [Ruppia cirrhosa] and of [Chara spp.]  of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of the desert coasts of the North Atlantic, between 27øN and 18øN, and of the Indian Ocean and its connected seas.

Submerged beds of [Ruppia spp.] and [Chara spp.]  of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of the boreal, temperate and subtropical western Pacific and its connected seas, distributed along all coasts, north to the northern coasts of the sea of Okhotsk and northern Kamtchatka in the Bering Sea.
Submerged beds of [Ruppia spp.] and [Chara spp.]  of sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons of tropical coasts of west Africa and of the Indo-Pacific.

Emergent [Eleocharis parvula] or [Eleocharis acicularis] formations of brackish seas, sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons, occurring in the open sea only in the Baltic, limited to coastal waterbodies elsewhere, and very rare.

Emergent [Eleocharis parvula]-dominated formations of brackish seas, sea inlets, estuaries, permanent pools of mud or sand flats, and coastal lagoons. They occur in the open sea only in the inner Baltic, in particular in middle Sweden, southern Finland and Estonia
Emergent [Eleocharis acicularis]-dominated formations of the open Baltic in the Gulf of Bothnia (Bothnia Sea, Bothnia Bay) and the Gulf of Finland.

[Ranunculus spp.]-dominated communities developed in shallow-waters of very low salinity of coastal lagoons, coastal basins and coastal waters of the Palaearctic region, including the Atlantic, North Sea, Baltic Sea, Mediterranean Sea and Black Sea. The most widespread characteristic species is [Ranunculus baudotii]. Locally, other crowfoots may be typical, as, in particular, in the Gulf of Bothnia, [Ranunculus trichophyllus] ([Ranunculus confervoides]).
Ice formations floating on sea water, usually constituting an incomplete cover, variable in form and structure, unstable and dynamic under the influence of surface air and water currents.
Semicontinuous ice sheets covering the sea throughout the year, limited to the Arctic Ocean.

Semicontinuous ice sheets forming on the sea for part of the year, characteristic of the Arctic Ocean, Baffin Bay, Davis Strait, the Greenland Sea, the Denmark Strait, the Norwegian Sea, the Barents Sea, the Kara Sea, the Laptev Sea, the East Siberian Sea, the Chukchi Sea, Bothnia Bay, the Bothnia Sea, and coastal areas of the Aland Sea, the Gulf of Finland and the Gulf of Riga, exceptional in other areas.
Discontinuous formations of floating ice blocks, rafts and hummocks detached from the sea pack, remaining after the break-up of seasonal ice packs or drifting to more southern regions.
Floating and drifting blocks of ice detached from coastal glaciers (unit 63.3).

Bays and narrow channels of the oceans and their connected seas, including sea lochs or loughs, fiords or fiards, rias and straits but excluding estuaries and lagoons. Detailed habitats can be coded by combining subdivisions of unit 11 with the relevant physiographic subdivisions of unit 12.
More or less straight coasts, devoid of deep indentations, characteristic of concordant coasts, of soft-sediment coastlines, and of the contour of isolated promontories.
Coastlines of wide, curved indentations of the sea into the land, with a wide or fairly wide opening, including bays and gulfs.
More or less narrow stretches of water connecting two larger bodies of water
Bodies of water, such as coves, communicating with the sea by a relatively narrow but unobstructed opening.
Sea inlets dug by glacial action, usually characterized by the presence of an entrance moraine.

Deep, long, narrow inlets in the coast, with high, rocky, parallel sides, smoothed by ice action, and a rocky floor often deeper than the sea floor and separated from it by a sill near the entrance, formed by the submergence of glacial valleys.
Irregular, often branched or islet-studded, shallow or deep, inlets in the coast, with low banks and a usually narrow entrance.
Sea inlets of glacial origin, communicating more broadly with the sea than fiords or fiards and lacking a shallow entrance sill.
Funnel-shaped sea inlets formed, in particular, by drowned river valleys, particularly along discordant coasts, as a result of a rise in sea-level.

Caves situated under the sea or opened to it, at least at high tide. Their marine part harbours benthic communities of units 11.26 and 11.294. They may be connected to terrestrial cave systems (unit 65) or to the underground water network through anchihaline environments (unit 65.451).
Sea-caves situated entirely below low-tide level.
Sea-caves situated in part above low-tide level, comprising mediolittoral (unit 11.294), and, in some cases, supralittoral (units 12.72 x 11.296, 12.72 x 11.297), communities

Broadening of rivers entering the oceans or their connected seas and river channels below the tidal limit. Included are all marine or marine-related pelagic and benthic communities, which can be specified by use of subdivisions of unit 11, and all river course and riverbed communities, which can be specified by subdivisions of unit 24. The belts of fringing vegetation are excluded and indicated separately by use of units 53, 44, 15 and their subdivisions.

Portions of rivers subject to the tide, upstream from the estuary. Their banks may be colonized by communities of units 24.52, 37.71, 44.12, 53.1, in particular of units 37.711, 37.712, 44.121, 53.114, 53.13, 53.16, 53.17.
Brackish portions of rivers subject to the tide, upstream from the estuary.
Freshwater sections of rivers subject to the tide.
Broadening of rivers entering the sea. Detailed habitats can be coded by combining subdivisions of prefix 11 with the relevant physiographic subdivisions of unit 13.2.
River-dominated, allochthonous deltaic estuaries formed by rivers accumulating sediments beyond the river mouth, often complex and constituted by many channels, with a salt wedge in the main channel

Wave- and current-dominated autochthonous estuarine systems constituted by shallow, often extensive, embayments separated from the sea by offshore bars of current-transported sand and with a very reduced tidal range

Composite river- and sea-dominated estuarine systems, including estuaries of macrotidal shorelines, subjected to tide-currents, devoid of protective littoral bars, and often accompanied by very developed tidal flats.

Extensive, flat or nearly flat, surfaces of sands, muds or rocks of the coasts of the oceans, their connected seas and associated lagoons, submerged for part of every tide or for part of the annual cycle, devoid of terrestrial vascular plants. They are of particular importance as feeding grounds for wildfowl and waders. The diverse intertidal communities of invertebrates and algae that occupy them can be precised by use of the subdivisions of units 11.27 to 11.2A, phanerogamic marine vegetation communities that may be exposed for a few hours in the course of every tide by use of those of unit 11.3, brackish water vegetation of permanent pools by use of those of unit 11.4.

Sands and muds of the coasts of the oceans, their connected seas and associated lagoons, submerged for part of every tide or for part of the annual cycle, devoid of terrestrial vascular plants, but usually coated by blue algae and diatoms. They are particularly well developed in the Wadden Sea, in the large bays of the North Sea, Atlantic and Channel coasts, in estuaries, in the Mediterranean Gulf of Gabes and along some subtropical coasts, among others, those of Mauritania.

Bedrock platforms or terraces washed by the tides, broad wave-cut rock platforms situated in the intertidal zone, but nearer low tide, with a more or less plane surface, rough in detail, dotted by tidepools.

Communities of phanerogamic plants, for the most part halophytes, colonizing sites submerged by high tides at some stage of the annual tidal cycle of oceans and their connected seas. Similar halophyte communities colonizing the fringes and emersed beds of inland permanent or temporary saline, hypersaline or brackish waterbodies, including inland closed seas, lakes, pools, sebkhas, rivers, springs, seeps. By extension, azonal, strongly differentiated, communities developing on habitually dry, alkali, chlorid or gypseous soils of the nemoral, middle Eurasian steppe, Irano-Anatolian, Mediterranean, Saharo-Mediterranean and Macaronesian zones. Zonal communities of the desert and semidesert areas, composed, to varying degrees, of halophytes or gypsophytes, are listed under 7. Some saline communities with strong physionognimic similarity to fresh water ones into which they may merge, have been listed in other sections, together with their freshwater counterparts

Salt steppes and their associated saltmarsh herbaceous, suffrutescent or frutescent communities developed in the middle Eurasian steppe, the Irano-Anatolian and the Saharo-Mediterranean zones, under continental or mediterraneo-continental climatic regimes

Salt steppes and saltmarsh meadows of the Pannonic plain and its satellite basins. Large expanses of salt steppe form an open landscape of short-grass swards on slightly elevated ground (unit 15.A11) and of rills (units 15.A13, 15.A14), eroded shallow depressions with bare or sparsely vegetated saline soils, dry or moist in spring and prone to white salt efflorescences. Deeper rills, with less ephemeral water, support medium-tall saline meadows (unit 15.A12). Waterholes that dot the surface harbour brackish aquatic vegetation (unit 23.23) and are fringed by tall emergents (unit 53, in particular halophile communities of 53.17)

[Festuca pseudovina] swards of the slightly elevated natron shoulders and low benches of the Pannonic puszta, on saline but permanently dry soils with a thin humic layer. Together with the low-lying rills that score them, they constitute the main landscape of the saline Pannonian steppes

Dominant salt-steppe communities of dry soils of the Pannonic plain, capable of covering vast surfaces, with [Festuca pseudovina], [Achillea collina], [Achillea setacea], [Trifolium subterraneum], [Trifolium pallidum], [Trifolium strictum], [Trifolium retusum], [Lotus tenuis], [Centaurea pannonica], [Scilla autumnalis].
Salt-steppe communities of the northern and central parts of the Pannonian basin.
Salt-steppe communities of the southern parts of the Pannonian basin, with [Trifolium subterraneum], [Scilla autumnalis].
Rare local salt-steppe formation of the Hortobagy, invaded by the tall, physiognomically dominant [Elymus elongatus] ssp. [ponticus] ([Agropyron ruthenicum]).

Salt-steppe communities developed on sandy soils of the Pannonic plain, usually occupying much smaller surfaces than those of 15.A11, with [Festuca pseudovina], [Achillea collina] and [Achillea asplenifolia]. They are locally a refuge for tall grass loess-steppe and sand-steppe species such as [Astragalus varius], [Astragalus austriacus], [Astragalus aster], [Orchis ustulata], [Iris pumila].

Saline steppe communities of the Pannonic plain, of strong middle Asian affinities, developed on more low-lying surfaces than those of unit 15.A111, often on the periphery of rills, usually inundated in early spring, dominated by sward-forming [Festuca pseudovina] with a variable admixture of emergent [Artemisia], often physiognomically dominant, and patchy mass-occurrences of [Limonium]. Characteristic species include [Artemisia santonicum] ssp. [santonicum], [Artemisia maritima] ssp. [maritima], [Festuca pseudovina], [Limonium gmelinii], [Trifolium retusum] ([Trifolium parviflorum]), [Sedum caespitosum], [Taraxacum bessarabicum] and the endemic [Plantago schwarzenbergiana].

Salt steppes or semideserts of the Transsylvanian basin, with [Festuca pseudovina], [Achillea collina] and species of Pontic and middle Asian affinities, such as [Artemisia santonicum] ssp. [patens], [Goniolimon tataricum], [Petrosimonia triandra].

Medium tall meadow communities of the Pannonic basin characteristic, in particular, of clearings and edges of oak forests on saline soils covered by water in early spring, species-rich and with an admixture of species of mesophile grasslands, dry grasslands and salt steppes, in particular, [Peucedanum officinale], [Peucedanum alsaticum], [Scutellaria galericulata], [Vicia narbonensis] var. [serratifolia], [Aster sedifolius] ([Aster punctatus]), [Aster linosyris], [Artemisia pontica], [Dianthus pontederae], [Rumex pseudonatronatus], [Iris spuria], [Orchis morio], [Festuca pseudovina], [Alopecurus pratensis], [Agrostis stolonifera].

Communities dominated by [Limonium gmelinii] and [Artemisia santonicum], with [Aster tripolium], [Spergularia media], [Hordeum hystrix], [Gypsophila muralis] var. [stepposa], of the Transylvanian basin of eastern Pannonia, transitional to formations of the [Puccinellion limosae] (unit 15.A13).

Salt-meadow communities of medium tall often tussock-forming grasses, developed on summer-dry carbonate-poor clay soils ([Beckmannion] communities) or on carbonate-rich or sandy soils ([Scorzonero-Juncion gerardii] communities) of the Pannonic plain. The [Scorzonero-Juncion gerardii] formations are well represented in particular in western Pannonia, in the Neusiedler See (Lake Ferto) basin and in the Danube-Tisza interfluvial region.

Medium-tall saline meadow communities of the central and eastern Pannonic plain, developed on less alkaline soils, poor in halophytic species, with [Agrostis stolonifera], [Alopecurus pratensis], [Glyceria fluitans] ssp. [poiformis], [Lysimachia nummularia], [Lythrum hyssopifolia], [Sium sisaroideum] and the Pannonic endemic [Cirsium brachycephalum].

Medium tall salt-meadow communities of the central and eastern Pannonic plain and the Transylvanian basin, developed on more alkaline soils, richer in halophytic species but poorer in overall species richness than the communities of unit 15.A121, with [Agrostis stolonifera], [Beckmannia eruciformis], [Bupleurum tenuissimum], [Pholiurus pannonicus], [Puccinellia limosa].

Medium-short salt-meadow communities of the central and eastern Pannonic plain and the Transylvanian basin, developed on silt accumulations, in particular of drift lines of larger marshes and along rills, with [Agrostis stolonifera], [Eleocharis palustris], [Eleocharis uniglumis], [Myosotis palustris], [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], [Alopecurus geniculatus].

Pannonic salt-meadow communities of tussock-forming species installed on higher ground and less alkaline soils, subject to brief periods of water cover, with [Scorzonera parviflora], [Juncus gerardi], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Carex distans], [Taraxacum bessarabicum]

Nombre oficial: Pannonic vipers grass saltmarsh rush saline meadows
Definición oficial: Salt-meadow communities of the Pannonic basin, mostly developed on the margin of depressions, subject to brief periods of water cover, with [Scorzonera parviflora], [Juncus gerardi], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Triglochin maritima], [Eleocharis uniglumis] and the moss [Drepanocladus polycarpus], sometimes harbouring [Orchis palustris].

Nombre oficial: Pannonic dandelion distant sedge saline meadows
Definición oficial: Salt-meadow communities of the Pannonic basin, developed around depressions, usually in conjunction with meadows of unit 15.A1241, but on somewhat lower, damper ground, with  [Carex distans], [Taraxacum bessarabicum], [Juncus gerardi], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Lotus glaber], [Plantago maritima].

Nombre oficial: Pannonic silverweed rye sedge saline meadows
Definición oficial: Communities of the Pannonic basin forming a transition between salt-meadows, humid meadows and flood swards, developed on mostly small surfaces and strongly nitrified grounds, dominated by creeping herbs, in particular [Potentilla anserina], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Ranunculus repens], carpet-forming grasses such as [Agrostis stolonifera], tussock-forming sedges, in particular, [Carex secalina], [Carex hordeistichos], rushes, notably [Juncus articulatus] and [Juncus gerardi].
Salt-meadow communities of the western Pannonic plain, dominated by [Eleocharis quinqueflora], with [Agrostis stolonifera], [Carex distans], [Blysmus compressus].

Salt-meadow communities of low-lying, mostly long-inundated, areas of the Alf¿ld of Hungary and southern Slovakia, with strongly alkaline soil, dominated by [Carex divisa], accompanied by [Triglochin palustris], [Triglochin maritima], [Orchis coriophora], [Orchis palustris] and, on the highest surfaces, [Ophrys sphegodes].

Short-grass salt-meadow communities installed on high chloride soils that remain damp to very damp year-round, surrounding endoreic depressions of the Transylvanian basin of eastern Pannonia, composed of central Asian species such as [Peucedanum latifolium], together with [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], [Triglochin maritima], [Plantago cornuti], [Agrostis stolonifera].

Short-grass saline meadows of the Transylvanian basin, dominated by [Triglochin palustris] and [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], with [Spergularia marina], [Cyperus pannonicus] ([Acorellus pannonicus]), [Crypsis aculeata], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Taraxacum bessarabicum], [Puccinellia distans], [Suaeda maritima].

Short-grass salt-meadow communities of the Transylvanian basin, rich in hygro-mesophile meadow species, and with [Plantago cornuti], [Scorzonera parviflora], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], [Triglochin maritima], [Juncus gerardi].
Rill communities, mostly characteristic of the eastern part of the Pannonic basin, developed on lime-poor sandy or clayey solonetz soils.

Communities of moist rills, mostly characteristic of the eastern Pannonic salt steppes, with a 50% to 80% cover, dominated by the small tussocks of [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa] with [Mentha pulegium], [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], [Atriplex littoralis], [Atriplex tatarica], [Kochia prostrata], [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [distans], [Chenopodium botryodes].

Communities of dry rills, sparse and species-poor, mostly characteristic of the eastern Pannonic salt steppes, though extending west to the Neusiedlersee (Lake Ferto), dominated by [Camphorosma annua], with [Chamomilla recutita], [Matricaria perforata], and, on more silty soils [Spergularia rubra], [Spergularia marina], [Spergularia media].
Rare formations of dry rills of the eastern Pannonic salt steppes, characteristic of extreme dry conditions, with [Bassia sedoides].

Communities of moist rills, wet until the beginning of summer, mostly characteristic of the eastern Pannonic salt steppes, with [Pholiurus pannonicus], [Plantago tenuiflora], [Myosurus minimus] and the blue alga [Nostoc commune]. They reach their western limit at the Neusidlersee (Lake Ferto) where they are extremely rare and endangered.

Halonitrophile, zooanthropogenous formations of the Pannonic salt steppes dominated by [Hordeum hystrix] ([Hordeum geniculatum]) and [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa] with [Agrostis stolonifera], [Elymus repens], [Lotus tenuis] ([Lotus glaber]), [Artemisia santonicum] ssp. [santonicum], [Scorzonera cana].
Poolside and rill communities, mostly characteristic of the western part of the Pannonic basin, developed on lime-rich sandy or clayey solonchak soils.

Rill formations of the Alf¿ld and of the Danube-Tisza interfluve, with large tussocks of [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa] surrounding bare low-lying surfaces.  Characteristic species include [Lepidium cartilagineum] ssp. [crassifolium], [Tetragonolobus maritimus], [Plantago maritima], [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus] and the extinct [Puccinellia pannonica].

Endemic community of the Seewinkel, in the eastern Neusiedlersee (Lake Ferto) basin, developed along the shores of salt pools on solonchaks that remain wet until the beginning of summer, with [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [intermedia] ([Puccinellia peisonis]), [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], [Cerastium diffusum] ssp. [subtetrandrum], [Plantago maritima].

Sparse communities of hollows of the western Pannonic salt steppes, in particular of the Neusiedlersee (Lake Ferto) basin, of eastern Transdanubia and of the Danube-Tisza interfluve, developed on higher, drier ground than those of units 15.A141 and 15.A142.

Endemic community of the Seewinkel, in the eastern Neusiedlersee basin, developed along the shores of salt ponds, where it occupies higher ground or more landward locations of the solonchak belt than the [Puccinellia] swards of unit 15.A142, and is submitted to more extreme conditions of high saltiness and summer soda efflorescences resulting from a briefer annual period of soaking and less frequent inundations. [Lepidium cartilagineum] ssp. [crassifolium] dominates alone or in association with [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [intermedia] ([Puccinellia peisonis]).

Interior halophile communities of the southwestern Balkan peninsula, isolated southwestern outlyers of the Ponto-Pannonic formations, developed in the low rainfall areas of the Vardar-upper Morava trough and and of associated or neighbouring small intermontane basins, in particular, within the Pelagonian and Moeso-Macedonian mountains.

Salt-meadow communities of medium tall often tussock-forming grasses of the intermontane basins of the southwestern Balkan peninsula, recorded, in particular, from the northern Vardar and Strumica basins in the F.Y.R. of Macedonia and from Albania.

Rill communities of interior salt-steppe and saltmarsh complexes of intermontane basins of the southwestern Balkan peninsula, in particular, of the Vardar trough of the F.Y.R. of Macedonia, with [Camphorosma annua], [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], [Pholiurus pannonicus], [Plantago tenuifolia].

[Camphorosma monspeliaca]-dominated formations of saline flats of intermontane basins of the southwestern Balkan peninsula, recorded, in particular, from the  Vardar trough in the F.Y.R. of Macedonia.
Salt steppes of the central F.Y.R. of Macedonia developed in the Vardar trough between Titov Veles, Stip and Negotino.

Salt steppes and saltmarshes of the western and northern Black Sea and Sea of Azov plain, of the basins of the lower Danube, the Prut, the Dniester, the Dnieper, the Don, and of the southern Russian hills, north of the Caspian depression and west of the Volga-Kama trough, associated with the steppes of unit 34.92. Coastal saltmarshes of the Black Sea and Azov Sea.

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and saltmarshes of the plain of the western Black Sea, west of the Dniester, of the basin of the lower Danube and of the northern Thracian basin of the middle Maritsa and the Tundzha, associated with the steppes of unit 34.921. Saltmarshes of the western Black Sea coast, from the Dniester to the Bosphorus, and adjacent inland waterbodies.

Communities dominated by low tufted grasses and subshrubs, in particular [Festuca pseudovina] and [Artemisia spp.], occupying higher, drier solonetz ground in salt steppes of the western Black Sea and lower Danube plains.

Haloxerophile grassland communities dominated by [Festuca pseudovina], [Achillea collina] and [Achillea setacea] accompanied by [Alopecurus pratensis], [Trifolium strictum], [Trifolium retusum] (Trifolium parviflorum]), of the lower Danube basin.

Salt steppes of the western Pontic region dominated by [Artemisia santonicum] ssp. [patens] and [Festuca pseudovina], accompanied by [Limonium gmelinii], [Camphorosma annua], [Camphorosma monspeliaca], [Bromus hordeaceus], [Poa bulbosa].
Salt steppes of the lower Danube basin, with  [Artemisia santonicum] ssp. [patens], [Goniolimon tataricum], [Petrosimonia triandra], [Festuca pseudovina], [Achillea collina].

Communities of weakly saline soils of salt steppes of the western Black Sea and lower Danube plains dominated by [Festuca pseudovina] and [Peucedanum latifolium], accompanied by [Aster sedifolius], [Aster linosyris], [Achillea collina], [Bupleurum tenuissimum], [Potentilla argentea], [Alopecurus pratensis], [Poa pratensis], [Carex praecox].

Communities of [Limonium gmelinii] and [Artemisia santonicum] with [Aster tripolium], [Spergularia media], [Hordeum hystrix], [Gypsophila muralis] var. [stepposa], of the lower Danube basin and of northern Thrace.

Salt-meadow communities of medium tall often tussock-forming grasses, sedges or rushes of the western Black Sea and lower Danube plains, with local representatives in the northern Thracian middle Maritsa and Tundzha basins.
Saline meadows of Oltenia harbouring the Valacho-Anatolo-Caucasian [Zingeria pisidica] and the sub-Mediterranean [Trifolium resupinatum], [Trifolium michelianum], [Medicago arabica].
Western Pontic [Beckmannia eruciformis] saline meadows, with [Oenanthe silaifolia], [Rorippa kerneri], [Carex melanostachya], [Peplis portula], [Aster tripolium], [Ranunculus lateriflorus].

Medium-short salt-meadow communities of Muntenia and Oltenia, developed on silt accumulations, in particular of drift lines of larger marshes and along rills, with [Eleocharis palustris], [Alopecurus geniculatus], [Glyceria fluitans], [Cerastium dubium], [Rorippa sylvestris] ssp. [kerneri].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic saltmarsh rush saline meadows
Definición oficial: Saline meadows of carbonate-rich or sandy soils of the western Black Sea and Danube plains, dominated by or rich in [Juncus gerardi].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic vipers grass saltmarsh rush saline meadows
Definición oficial: Saline meadows of the western Black Sea and Danube plains, dominated by [Juncus gerardi], with [Trifolium fragiferum], [Centaurium pulchellum], [Teucrium scordium], [Triglochin palustris], [Mentha pulegium].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic dandelion distant sedge saline meadows
Definición oficial: Saline meadows of Muntenia and Moldavia dominated by [Taraxacum bessarabicum] with [Juncus gerardi], [Carex distans], [Puccinellia distans], [Spergularia marginata].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic rye sedge saline meadows
Definición oficial: Communities of the western Pontic region forming a transition between salt-meadows, humid meadows and flood swards, developed on mostly small surfaces and strongly nitrified ground, dominated by creeping herbs, in particular [Potentilla anserina], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Ranunculus repens], carpet-forming grasses such as [Agrostis stolonifera], tussock-forming sedges, in particular [Carex secalina], [Carex hordeistichos], rushes, notably [Juncus articulatus] and [Juncus gerardi].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic bent-grass distant sedge saline meadows
Definición oficial: Saline meadows of Muntenia, Moldavia and the Dobrogea, occupying slightly higher ground than the communities of the [Scorzonero-Juncetum gerardi], dominated by [Carex distans], with [Triglochin palustris], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Ononis spinosa], [Plantago cornuti], [Plantago maritima], [Juncus gerardi], [Cirsium canum], [Scirpus holoschoenus].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic divided sedge saline meadows
Definición oficial: Saline meadows of Muntenia, Oltenia, the Dobrogea and the Danube delta, occupying moderately saline soils, dominated by [Carex divisa], with [Taraxacum bessarabicum], [Cirsium alatum], [Juncus littoralis], [Schoenus maritimus], [Halimione pedunculata], [Spergularia media].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic arrow-grass sea-aster saline meadows
Definición oficial: Saline meadows of Muntenia, dominated by [Triglochin palustris] and [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], developed on soils that remain damp to very damp  year-round, with [Spergularia marina], [Cyperus pannonicus] ([Acorellus pannonicus]), [Crypsis aculeata], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Taraxacum bessarabicum], [Puccinellia distans], [Suaeda maritima].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic tall grass and rush saline beds
Definición oficial: Formations of western Black Sea saltmarshes and of saline depressions of the western Pontic plains, dominated by tall rushes of the [Juncus maritimus] group or tall grasses, in particular [Phacelurus digitatus] and [Elymus elongatus].

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic tall rush saline beds
Definición oficial: Formations of western Black Sea saltmarshes dominated by [Juncus maritimus], [Juncus acutus] or [Juncus littoralis], with [Limonium latifolium], [Puccinellia distans], [Plantago maritima], [Juncus gerardi], [Aster tripolium].

Saline meadows of the saltmarshes of the southern Bulgarian Black Sea coast, dominated by the andropogonid grass [Phacelurus digitatus] ([Rottboellia digitata]), with [Limonium latifolium], [Elymus elongatus]

Saline meadows of Muntenia, the Dobrogea, the northern Thracian middle Maritsa and Tundzha basins, the Danube Delta and the edges of western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes, dominated by [Elymus elongatus] ssp. [elongatus] ([Agropyron elongatum]), with [Limonium latifolium], [Puccinellia distans], [Cynodon dactylon] and an admixture of halophytes and nonhalophytes.

Nombre oficial: Western Pontic tall fescue saline beds
Definición oficial: Saline meadows of maritime sands of the Danube delta and the western Pontic coast dominated by [Festuca arundinacea], with [Juncus littoralis], [Juncus gerardi], [Carex distans], [Centaurium spicatum], [Agrostis pontica], [Hordeum maritimum].
Saline meadows of the northern Thracian middle Maritsa and Tundzha basins and of the edges of western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes, dominated by [Cynodon dactylon].

Communities dominated by grasses, chenopods or sea-lavenders, formed on solonetz or solonchak-solonetz soils in the rills of salt steppes and other inland saline flats subject to inundation and dessication of the western Black Sea plain, as well as on the higher ground of western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes, with outposts in the lower Danube valley and the northern Thracian middle Maritsa and Tundzha basins.

Grassy formations of western Black Sea coastal and inland solonetz and solonchak-solonetz soils, constituted by [Puccinellia festuciformis] and its subspecies ([Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [intermedia]) or [Puccinellia distans] ([Puccinellia limosa]), in monospecific swards or accompanied by other halophytes including [Hordeum hystrix], [Crypsis aculeata], [Suaeda maritima], [Camphorosma monspeliaca], [Camphorosma annua], [Salicornia spp.], [Limonium spp.], [Spergularia spp.]

[Camphorosma annua] formations with [Puccinellia limosa], [Aeluropus littoralis], [Cyperus pannonicus] ([Acorellus pannonicus]), [Bassia sedoides], [Lepidium crassifolium], [Spergularia media], [Taraxacum bessarabicum] of the Black Sea and lower Danube plain of eastern Romania, and of northern Thrace in the middle Maritsa and Tundzha basins, the Studena River valley, the Veliko Tarnovo, Yambol and Burgas districts.
Rare formations of dry rills of the western Pontic salt steppes of Muntenia, Moldavia and the Danube delta, characteristic of extreme dry conditions, with [Bassia sedoides].

Formations of western Pontic solonetz and solonchak-solonetz soils, with outposts in the northern Thracian basin, composed by [Pholiurus pannonicus] and/or [Plantago tenuiflora], with [Myosurus minimus], [Puccinellia limosa], [Puccinellia distans], [Matricaria chamomilla], [Lepidium ruderale].

Grassy solonetz or solonchak-solonetz formations of the western Black Sea coast and lower Danube plain and of the northern Thracian basin, dominated by [Hordeum hystrix], often accompanied by [Poa bulbosa], [Crypsis spp.], [Trifolium neglectum], [Cynodon dactylon], [Lepidium ruderale].

Communities dominated by Ponto-Pannonic perennial grasses and herbs, or by Ponto-Caspian steppe and semidesert zone annuals and perennials, developed on solonchak or solonchak-solonetz soils of the western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes and of the salt basins of adjacent lowlands.

Solonchak swards, of Ponto-Pannonic affinities, of the eastern Walachian plains, from Muntenia to southern Moldavia, massively dominated by [Lepidium cartilagineum] ssp. [crassifolium], with [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa] ([Puccinellia limosa]), [Camphorosma annua], [Agropyron elongatum], [Plantago maritima], [Spergularia media], [Dianthus guttatus].

Communities dominated by Ponto-Caspian steppe and semidesert zone annuals and perennials, developed on solonchak or solonchak-solonetz soils of the western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes and of the salt basins of adjacent lowlands.

Halophile solonchak or solonetz-solonchak formations of western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes and of the lower Danube plain of Muntenia constituted by [Petrosimonia triandra] or [Petrosimonia brachiata], often with [Salsola soda], [Suaeda maritima], [Bassia hirsuta], [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], [Puccinellia distans], [Artemisia santonicum], [Artemisia austriaca].
[Frankenia hirsuta] halophilous meadows on solonchaks of the western Pontic region.

Sea lavender-dominated moderately saline steppes of the lower Danube basin, including [Limonium latifolium]-dominated formations of the Studena river valley of northern Bulgaria and [Limonium vulgare]-dominated formations of Muntenia.

[Camphorosma monspeliaca]-dominated formations of sulphate-rich saline flats of Northern Thrace, in particular in the basins of the middle Maritsa and Tundza and, locally, of the Black Sea plain and lower Danube plain of Oltenia, Muntenia and northern Bulgaria, with [Poa bulbosa], [Hordeum hystrix], [Gypsophila muralis], and in some local variants, [Artemisia santonicum] or [Genista sessilifolia] ([Genista trifoliolata]).
[Halimione pedunculata]-dominated formations of the lower Danube plain of eastern Muntenia, with [Puccinellia distans], [Spergularia media], [Salicornia europaea], [Juncus gerardi].

Formations of [Aeluropus littoralis], [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa], [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [distans] of western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes and adjacent inland areas.

Formations of [Aeluropus littoralis], often accompanied by [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa], [Crypsis aculeata], [Salicornia europaea], [Suaeda maritima], [Spergularia spp.], [Juncus gerardi], [Cirsium alatum], [Taraxacum bessarabicum], [Plantago maritima] of sandy, strongly saline solonchaks or solonetz-solonchaks of western Black Sea coastal saltmarshes and of the Braila plain.

Formations of [Aeluropus littoralis] and [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa] of very damp saline sands of the western Black Sea coast, with [Limonium gmelinii], [Limonium bellidifolium], [Plantago maritima], [Salicornia europaea], [Spergularia media], [Rumex maritimus].

[Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta] meadows of western Black Sea coastal areas, with [Puccinellia distans], [Crypsis alopecuroides], [Crypsis aculeata], [Salicornia europaea], [Suaeda maritima], [Spergularia marina], [Spergularia media].

Scrubby formations of [Halimione verrucifera], [Halocnemum strobilaceum] and [Nitraria schoberi], accompanied by [Artemisia spp.], [Limonium spp.], [Petrosimonia spp.], colonizing saltmarshes and salt basins of western Black Sea coastal areas and of the lower Danube valley.

Salt scrubs of Muntenia, Moldavia and the Dobrogea, dominated by [Halimione verrucifera], with [Artemisia santonicum], [Artemisia maritima], [Lotus angustissimus], [Puccinellia limosa], [Carex distans], [Camphorosma annua], [Plantago cornuti], [Taraxacum bessarabicum], [Suaeda maritima], [Salicornia europaea], [Limonium gmelinii].

Subarbustive halophile formations of the western Black Sea coastal lagoons, in particular of the Sinoe, Golovita, Razelm and Smeica lagoons of the Dobrogea, dominated by [Halocnemum strobilaceum], with [Halimione verrucifera], [Petrosimonia oppositifolia], [Limonium bellidifolium], [Lotus tenuis], [Plantago maritima].

Very local, more or less mesophile saline shrubby steppe of the vicinity of the mud volcanos of the Muntenian foothills of the extreme southeastern Carpathians, at Policiori-P¿clele (Buzau), formed by the spiny zygophyllaceous shrub [Nitraria schoberi], at the westernmost limit of its range, with [Halimione verrucifera], [Artemisia maritima], [Camphorosma monspeliaca].
Salt steppes and saltmarshes of the southern edge and valleys of the Podolian, Central Russian and Volga plateaux, north of the Pontic and Caspian plains, associated with the steppes of unit 34.922

Communities dominated by low tufted grasses and subshrubs, in particular [Festuca pseudovina] and [Artemisia spp.], occupying higher, drier solonetz ground in salt steppes of the southern periphery of the Podolian plateau, of the Central Russian and the Volga plateaux, north of the Pontic and Caspian plains, west to the upper Prut basin and east to the Volga-Kama.

Halophilous communities of shady slopes of the Sarmatic steppe region composed of [Artemisia santonicum] ssp. [patens], with [Halimione pedunculata], [Aster tripolium], [Bassia sedoides], [Puccinellia distans].

Salt steppes of the Sarmatic region, west to Romanian Moldavia, with [Festuca pseudovina], [Achillea collina], [Artemisia santonicum] ssp. [patens], [Goniolimon tataricum], [Petrosimonia oppositifolia].
[Festuca pseudodalmatica], [Festuca pseudovina] and [Limonium tomentellum] saline steppes formed on deeply columnar solonetz of loess river terraces of the Ukrainian forest-steppe and steppe zones.
Sarmatic humid meadow communities of the [Puccinietalia], particularly of the [Beckmannion] and [Scorzonero-Juncion gerardii], developed on moderately saline, permanently humid soils.
Communities occupying small, permanently humid, weakly saline depressions of the Sarmatic salt-steppes and saltmarshes.

Meso-hygrophile hay meadows of Moldavia, developed on weakly saline soils, with [Leuzea salina], [Peucedanum latifolium], [Iris halophila], [Aster sedifolius], [Scorzonera austriaca] var. [aucronata], [Lotus tenuis], [Taraxacum bessarabicum], [Juncus gerardi], [Aster tripolium] ssp. [pannonicus], [Plantago schwarzenbergiana], [Limonium gmelinii].

Sarmatic saline meadows formed on alluvial sandy, weakly saline soils, with a high diversity of halophile species, with [Iris halophila], [Camphorosma annua], [Juncus gerardi], [Puccinellia distans], [Atriplex littoralis].
Communities of [Juncus gerardi] with [Aster tripolium], [Puccinellia limosa], [Spergularia media], [Lotus tenuis], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Centaurium pulchellum].
Sarmatic formations dominated by [Carex distans], of soils with low humidity and very low salinity.
Communities dominated by grasses, chenopods or sea-lavenders, formed on solonetz or solonchak-solonetz soils in the rills of salt steppes of the Sarmatic region.

Grassy formations of Sarmatic solonetz and solonchak-solonetz soils constituted by [Puccinellia distans] ([Puccinellia limosa]) or [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], accompanied by [Plantago maritima], [Spergularia media], [Aster tripolium], [Juncus gerardi], [Scorzonera austriaca] and [Camphorosma annua].

Communities of solonetz or solonchak-solonetz soils of river terraces of the Sarmatic region dominated by [Camphorosma annua], often accompanied by [Puccinellia distans] or [Puccinellia festuciformis].

Communities of solonetz or solonchak-solonetz soils of the Sarmatic region dominated by [Carex distans], with [Aster tripolium], [Juncus compressus], [Taraxacum bessarabicum] and [Agrostis stolonifera] ([Agrostis stolonizans]).
Communities dominated by perennial grasses and herbs or by steppe and semidesert zone annuals, developed on solonchak soils of the Sarmatic region.

Solonchak swards, of Ponto-Pannonic affinities, of northern Moldavia, massively dominated by [Lepidium cartilagineum] ssp. [crassifolium], with [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa] ([Puccinellia limosa]), [Camphorosma annua], [Agropyron elongatum], [Plantago maritima], [Spergularia media], [Dianthus guttatus].
Communities of solonchak depressions of the Sarmatic region dominated by [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta] ([Puccinellia bilykiana]).

Communities of solonchak depressions of the Sarmatic region, with a strongly fluctuating water regime that may include acute periods of drought, dominated by [Beckmannia eruciformis], [Agrostis stolonifera] ([Agrostis stolonizans]), [Puccinellia distans], [Juncus compressus], characteristic, in particular, of the middle Don region.

Nombre oficial: Eastern Pontic salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and saltmarshes of the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain, of the basins of the Dnieper, the Don, the Kouban, the Manytch, the upper Kuma and upper Terek, associated with the steppes of unit 34.923. Coastal saltmarshes of the northern Black Sea and the Sea of Azov, except those of southern Crimea, of mediterranean affinities and included in unit 15.A24.

Communities dominated by low tufted grasses and subshrubs, in particular [Festuca pseudovina] and [Artemisia spp.], occupying higher, drier solonetz ground in salt steppes of the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain.
Salt-meadow communities of medium tall often tussock-forming grasses, sedges or rushes of the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain.

Communities dominated by grasses, chenopods or sea-lavenders, formed on solonetz or solonchak-solonetz soils in the rills of salt steppes and other inland saline flats subject to inundation and dessication of the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain, as well as on the higher ground of northern Black Sea coastal saltmarshes.

Communities dominated by Ponto-Pannonic perennial grasses and herbs, or by Ponto-Caspian steppe and semidesert zone annuals and perennials, developed on solonchak or solonchak-solonetz soils of the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain and of northern Black Sea coastal saltmarshes.
Scrubby formations colonizing saltmarshes and salt basins of the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain.

Saltmarshes of the southern Black Sea coast, west and north to the seaward fa¿ade of the Istranca-Stranja, of the eastern Black Sea coast, northwest to the northern limit of the peri-Caucasian deciduous woodland zone in the Kouban basin, and of the mediterranean or submediterranean woodland zone of extreme southern Crimea.

Nombre oficial: Central Eurasian salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and saltmarshes of the steppe and wooded steppe belts of extreme eastern Europe and western Siberia, extending from the Volga-Kama system in the west to the Tarbagatai and western Altai in the east, associated with the Transvolgan (Orenburg and Bachkiria), Kurgan, Ishim, Baraba, Kulunda, Barnaul, Kirgiz, Kazakh, Tarbagatai and Altai steppes of unit 34.93. Saltmarshes of the Caspian Sea, the Aral Sea and other inland waterbodies of the northern Aralo-Caspian, Kura basin, western Kazakh, Dzungarian, Oust-ourt, Kyzyl Koum and Kara Koum middle Asiatic deserts and semideserts.

Communities dominated by low tufted grasses and subshrubs, in particular [Festuca pseudovina] and [Artemisia spp.], occupying higher, drier solonetz ground of extreme eastern European and western Siberian salt steppes, from the Volga-Kama system in the west to the Tarbagatai and western Altai in the east.

Salt-meadow communities of medium tall often tussock-forming grasses, sedges or rushes of extreme eastern European and western Siberian salt steppes, from the Volga-Kama system in the west to the Tarbagatai and western Altai in the east.

Communities dominated by grasses, chenopods or sea-lavenders, formed on solonetz or solonchak-solonetz soils in the rills of salt steppes and other inland saline flats subject to inundation and dessication of extreme eastern European and western Siberian salt steppes, from the Volga-Kama system in the west to the Tarbagatai and western Altai in the eastas well as on the higher ground of saltmarshes of the Caspian Sea, the Aral Sea and other inland waterbodies of the northern Aralo-Caspian, Kura basin, western Kazakh, Dzungarian, Oust-ourt, Kyzyl Koum and Kara Koum middle Asiatic deserts and semideserts.

Communities dominated by steppe perennial grasses and herbs, or by steppe and semidesert zone annuals and perennials, developed on solonchak or solonchak-solonetz soils of the saltmarshes of the Caspian Sea, the Aral Sea and other inland waterbodies of the northern Aralo-Caspian, Kura basin, western Kazakh, Dzungarian, Oust-ourt, Kyzyl Koum and Kara Koum middle Asiatic deserts and semideserts, and of the salt basins of extreme eastern European and western Siberian salt steppes, from the Volga-Kama system in the west to the Tarbagatai and western Altai in the east.

Scrubby formations of [Halimione verrucifera], [Halocnemum strobilaceum] and [Nitraria schoberi], accompanied by [Artemisia spp.], [Limonium spp.], [Petrosimonia spp.], colonizing saltmarshes and salt basins of of the saltmarshes of the Caspian Sea, the Aral Sea and other inland waterbodies of the northern Aralo-Caspian, Kura basin, western Kazakh, Dzungarian, Oust-ourt, Kyzyl Koum and Kara Koum middle Asiatic deserts and semideserts, and of the salt basins of extreme eastern European and western Siberian salt steppes, from the Volga-Kama system in the west to the Tarbagatai and western Altai in the east.

Nombre oficial: East Asian salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and saltmarshes of Transbaikalia, Outer Mongolia, Inner Mongolia, the Songnen Plain of Northeast China, the western Loess Plateau of North China, of the Tien Shan, from the rim of the Naryn and Isyk-K¿l basins eastwards, of the Sayan and Tannu mountains, associated with the steppes of unit 34.94. Saltmarshes of the inland waterbodies of the Gobi, Takla Makan, Tarim, Lop-nor, Bei-shan, Ala-shan, Ordos, Tsaidam and Pamyro-Tibetan Central Asiatic deserts and semideserts.

Salt steppes and saltmarshes of steppic areas of the Anatolian Plateau, of Transcaucasia, of the eastern cis-Caucasian hills of Daghestan and the Terek basin, of the Iranian Plateau, the Kopet Dagh, the Pamir-Alai, the extreme western Tien-Shan, around the rim of the Ferghana basin and along the spur of the Karatau, and of northern Mesopotamia, associated with the steppes of unit 34.95. Saltmarshes of the cold desert or subdesert areas of the Iranian Plateau.

Nombre oficial: Western Anatolian salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and saltmarshes of the western Anatolian Plateau, mostly characteristic of Lycaonia, particularly around Tuz Golu and in the region of Nigde. They are rich in endemic as well as Asiatic species.
Almost monospecific formations of [Halocnemum strobilaceum] forming the inner belt of vegetation around western Anatolian salt lakes.

Formations of [Artemisia fragrans], [Aeluropus lagopoides], [Camphorosma monspeliaca], [Limonium iconium], [Salsola inermis], [Salsola anatolica], [Salsola kali] forming the outermost belt of vegetation of western Anatolian halophile complexes, in contact with nonhalophile [Artemisia] steppes.

Communities of rosette-forming sea-lavenders, prostrate perennial [Frankenia], annual [Petrosimonia] and related genera occupying clearings of Anatolian grassy or shrubby salt steppes, in particular on hypersaline soils with extreme regimes of inundation and dessication.
Communities of [Frankenia hirsuta], [Limonium iconium], [Limonium gmelinii], [Camphorosma monspeliaca] forming on gently sloping rises in the vicinity of Anatolian salt lakes.
Formations of [Petrosimonia nigdeensis], [Petrosimonia brachiata], [Halanthium kulpianum] ([Petrosimonia birandii]) occupying muddy sand soils in the vicinity of Anatolian salt lakes.
Communities [Puccinellia distans] [s.l.], [Limonium gmelinii], [Limonium globuliferum] of western Anatolian halophile complexes, forming on sandy clay soils with brief periods of inundation.

Saltmarsh meadows of water-logged depressions, puddles and small waterbodies of Anatolia, with [Juncus maritimus] dominant, [Limonium globuliferum], [Aeluropus lagopoides], [Puccinellia distans], [Halimione portulacoides], [Lepidium cartilagineum].

Nombre oficial: Central Irano-Anatolian salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and saltmarshes of Transcaucasia, the eastern cis-Caucasian hills of Daghestan and the Terek basin, eastern Anatolia and northwestern Iran, including the communities of the edges of Lake Van and Lake Urmia.

Salt steppes and saltmarshes of steppic areas of the Central and Eastern Iranian Plateau in Iran and Afghanistan, of the Kopet Dagh, the Pamir-Alai and the extreme western Tien-Shan, around the rim of the Ferghana basin and along the spur of the Karatau, associated with the steppes of unit 34.953. Communities of saltmarshes and temporary waterbodies of the cold desert or subdesert areas of Iran and Afghanistan, in particular the Dasht-i-Kewir and Dasht-i-Lut.

Nombre oficial: Northern Mesopotamian salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and saltmarshes of the Mesopotamian steppic region bordering the Near Eastern Saharo-Sindian deserts, extending north to southeastern Turkey and Khuzestan in western Iran. Among characteristic species are [Suaeda palaestina], [Seidlitzia rosmarinus], [Alhagi maurorum], [Bassia eriophora], [Suaeda fruticosa], [Atriplex leucoclada], [Atriplex halimus], [Suaeda aegyptiaca], [Juncus maritimus] var. [arabicus].

Nombre oficial: North African salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt steppes and interior saltmarshes of the steppic regions of the North African transition zone between the Mediterranean region and the Sahara (Mauritanian Steppe).

Nombre oficial: Yakutian boreal salt steppes and saltmarshes
Definición oficial: Salt meadows, salt steppe meadows, swamp meadows, alases and salt marshes of the middle Lena basin of eastern Siberia, formed in regions of extreme continentality near the southern edge of the permafrost and the northern limit of the taiga belt, associated with the steppes of unit 34.96.

Coastal saltmarshes of the Arctic zone, along the coasts of Greenland, the Norwegian Sea, Greenland Sea, Barents Sea, Kara Sea, Laptev Sea, East Siberian Sea, Chukchi Sea and Glacial Ocean coasts of northern Iceland, Jan Mayen, Spitsbergen, Bear Island, Finnmark in northern Norway, Franz Josef Land, northern continental Russia, Kolguyev Island, Novaya Zemlya, continental Siberia and the Siberian archipelagoes.
Species-poor communities of the lower shores of arctic Eurasia and Greenland, submitted to winter sea ice.

Open, sparse communities of the lower, intertidal, sector of saltmarshes of arctic coasts of Eurasia, from northern Troms and Finnmark eastwards, of the archipelagoes of the Eurasian polar basin, including Spitzbergen, Nova Zemlya,  and the New Siberian archipelago, of Jan Mayen and of Greenland, dominated by [Puccinellia phryganodes] [s.l.]

Lower shore salt meadow communities of northwestern Greenland, northeastern Greenland, Iceland, Spitzbergen, arctic Norway, the Kola peninsula, Yakutia, developed on clay substrates, dominated by [Carex subspathacea], often accompanied by [Puccinellia maritima] and [Puccinellia phryganodes]. In Iceland, [Puccinellia phryganodes] is absent and [Puccinellia capillaris] may codominate with [Carex subspathacea].
Salt meadows of the lower and middle shores of the coasts of arctic Eurasia, in particular, of western Iceland, western Finnmark, the Kola peninsula and Yakutia, dominated by [Puccinellia maritima].
Salt meadow communities of the lower and middle shores of arctic coasts, in particular of northeastern Greenland, Spitzbergen, Nova Zemlya, Yakutia, dominated by [Carex ursina].
Coastal saltmarshes of the upper shores of arctic Eurasia and Greenland submitted to winter sea ice.

Upper shore salt meadow communities of arctic coasts of northern Norway, the Kola peninsula, Iceland and Greenland, extending locally along boreal-Atlantic coasts in Iceland and northwestern Norway, as well as in the Gulf of Bothnia, dominated by [Carex glareosa] and [Festuca rubra], often with [Gentianella detonsa], [Potentilla egedii], [Stellaria humifusa], [Carex subspathacea] and with abundant [Drepanocladus uncinatus] in the ground layer.
Middle and upper shore communities of Iceland dominated by [Kobresia myosuroides], with [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum] often very prominent, occupying relatively dry, high, stony areas of coastal banks.

Usually open saltmarsh communities of upper shores of arctic Eurasia dominated by [Puccinellia capillaris] ([Puccinellia distans] ssp. [borealis]) with [Festuca rubra] and [Cochlearia officinalis], characteristic, in particular, of exposed wet shingle beaches with little fine material in northern Norway and northern Iceland.
Saltmarsh communities of upper shores of arctic Eurasia, in particular, of northern Norway and northern Iceland, constituting a fescue-dominated facies of unit 15.B23.

Communities of arctic coasts dominated by [Dupontia fisheri], [Dupontia pelligera] or [Dupontia psilosantha], characteristic, in particular, of brackish upper shores of Greenland, Spitzbergen, the New Siberian archipelago, Yakutia.
Salt meadow communities of brackish upper shores of Finnmark dominated by [Carex rariflora], often with [Carex salina], [Calamagrostis stricta].

Saltmarsh communities of northern Norway, northern Russia and northern Iceland dominated by [Carex mackenziei] with [Agrostis stolonifera], accompanied by [Drepanocladus aduncus], [Drepanocladus uncinatus], characteristic of brackish basins of the upper shore.

Low swards of middle and upper shores of northern Iceland, northern Norway and the Kola peninsula dominated by [Carex salina], developed, in relatively exposed situations, on substrates of coarse material.
Communities of the arctic coasts of Eurasia developed in brackish water on sulphurous gleys, in particular, [Hippuris tetraphylla] beds of brackish shores of Finnmark and northern Iceland.

Frutescent and herbaceous halophilous communities of inland saltmarshes and temporary waterbodies of the Saharo-Sindian zone, and of coastal saltmarshes and lagoon fringes of the desert coasts of the African Atlantic, of the extreme southeastern Mediterranean, of the Red Sea, of the Arabian Sea and of the Persian Gulf.

Frutescent and herbaceous halophilous communities of coastal saltmarshes, lagoon fringes and inundatable depressions of the Sinai coasts of the extreme southeastern Mediterranean and of the adjacent northern Sinai plain.

Frutescent halophilous communities of coastal saltmarshes, lagoon fringes and inundatable depressions of the northern Sinai dominated by [Halocnemum strobilaceum], usually occupying the wettest ground.

Frutescent halophilous communities of coastal saltmarshes, lagoon fringes and inundatable depressions of the northern Sinai dominated by [Arthrocnemum glaucum], usually forming a girdle on the drier side of [Halocnemum] formations.

Frutescent halophilous communities of coastal saltmarshes, lagoon fringes and inundatable depressions of the northern Sinai dominated by [Nitraria retusa], associated with [Suaeda vermiculata], [Suaeda vera], [Limoniastrum monopetalum], [Frankenia hirsuta], [Halogeton alopecuroides], [Limonium pruinosum], usually forming on higher ground adjacent to [Halocnemum] and [Arthrocnemum] communities.

Frutescent halophilous communities of coastal saltmarshes, lagoon fringes and inundatable depressions of the northern Sinai dominated by [Zygophyllum album], usually forming on the lower parts of dune scarps.

Tall rush communities of coastal saltmarshes, lagoon fringes and inundatable depressions of the northern Sinai dominated by [Juncus rigidus] ([Juncus maritimus] var. [arabicus]), often occupying the central, wettest parts of less salty depressions, surrounded by [Halocnemum] and [Arthrocnemum] belts.
Frutescent and herbaceous halophilous communities of coastal saltmarshes and lagoon fringes of the desert coasts of the African Atlantic.
Frutescent and herbaceous halophilous communities of coastal saltmarshes and lagoon fringes of the Red Sea, of the Arabian Sea and of the Persian Gulf.
Frutescent and herbaceous halophilous communities of inland saltmarshes and temporary waterbodies of the Sahara.
Frutescent and herbaceous halophilous communities of inland saltmarshes and temporary waterbodies of the Arabian Desert.
Formations of [Paspalum vaginatum], [Sesuvium portulacastrum], [Sporobolus virginicus], [Philoxerus vermicularis] of intertidal or inundatable areas of tropical coasts of the Palaearctic region.

Formations composed mostly or prominently of annuals, in particular Chenopodiaceae of genus [Salicornia] or grasses, colonizing periodically inundated muds and sands of marine or interior saltmarshes of the Palaearctic.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.], [Microcnemum coralloides]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]), or sometimes saltwort ([Salsola spp.]), formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of coastal saltmarshes and inland salt-basins of the Palaearctic.
Swards of annual [Salicornia spp.] and [Suaeda maritima] of the coastal saltmarshes of the North Sea, the Baltic, the northern Atlantic and the western Eurasian polar basin.

Colonies of nonreddening tetraploid glassworts [Salicornia dolichostachya], [Salicornia fragilis], [Salicornia decumbens] and of [Suaeda maritima] ssp. [flexilis], occupying the lowest, dampest areas of northern and western European coastal flats.

Colonies of often much-branched, diploid glassworts [Salicornia ramosissima], [Salicornia europaea], [Salicornia obscura] [i.a.] and/or of [Suaeda maritima], occupying higher, drier areas of European coastal flats.

Swards of annual [Salicornia spp.] of the coastal saltmarshes of the western Eurasian polar basin, in particular, [Salicornia dolichostachya] ssp. [pojarkovae] swards of northern Norway and northern Russia.
Glasswort formations of inland saltmarshes of nemoral middle Europe, in particular of Germany, Poland, France and England (unit 15.4).
Colonies of the orange-turning [Salicornia emerici] var. [vicensis], of unstable, fluid, seeping muds of inland western European saltmarshes.
Colonies of the reddening [Salicornia ramosissima] or of [Salicornia europaea], of firmer muds of inland western and central European saltmarshes.

Glasswort swards of saltmarshes, lagoons and deltas of the coasts and coastal regions of the Mediterranean and of the subtropical Atlantic, including those of southwestern France, the Iberian peninsula, mediterranean North Africa south to the Oued Tensift at 32øN and mediterraneo-Saharan Africa between 32øN and 27øN.

Glasswort swards occupying long-inundated basins of coastal saltmarshes of the western Mediterranean basin, including those of Spain, southern continental France, the Gulf of Tarento, Corsica, Sardinia and Sicily, with Atlantic representatives in southwestern Europe, between southern Brittany and central Portugal, dominated by the reddening tetraploid glasswort [Salicornia emerici].
Endemic, threatened [Salicornia veneta] swards of long-inundated muds of basins of the Venice lagoon.
