[Salicornia spp.], [Suaeda spp.], [Salsola spp.], [Halopeplis amplexicaulis]  swards, often monospecific, occupying muds of coastal saltmarshes of the Mediterranean Sea and of the warm-temperate Atlantic, from central Portugal to 27øN, restricted, in the western Mediterranean basin, to firmer, drier muds with shorter inundation periods than those occupied by the communities of unit 15.1131.

Glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) swards occupying muds of coastal saltmarshes of the Mediterranean Sea, including both western and eastern basins, and of the Atlantic, from central Portugal to 27øN, dominated by diploid glassworts, in particular, by the reddening [Salicornia patula], also by [Salicornia ramosissima] and probably other diplo¿d taxa of the [Salicornia europaea] aggregate, limited in the western Mediterranean basin to firmer, drier muds than those colonized by the tetraploid [Salicornia emerici].

Nombre oficial: Mediterranean annual seablite and saltwort swards
Definición oficial: [Suaeda spp.] or [Salsola spp.]-dominated swards of exposed muds of coastal saltmarshes of the Mediterranean Sea and the warm-temperate Atlantic, mostly characteristic of the eastern Mediterranean basin and of muds on which organic material, in particular detritus of marine phanerogams, has accumulated

[Halopeplis amplexicaulis] swards, often monospecific and ephemereal, occupying hypersaline long-inundated muds of saltmarshes of arid Mediterranean coasts, appearing at the beginning of severe summer dessication, distributed in Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, northwestern Algeria and, very locally, in Morocco,  Sicily, Sardinia (Cagliari) and southern Italy (Metaponto). The formation is threatened in Europe.
Annual [Salicornia spp.] and [Microcnemum coralloides] formations of interior Iberian salt basins.
Formations of the endemic [Microcnemum coralloides] ssp. [coralloides], associated or not with [Salicornia europaea] [s.l.], of interior salt basins of central and east-central Spain.
Formations of [Salicornia europaea] [s.l.] of interior salt basins of Iberia.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.], [Microcnemum coralloides]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) solonchak formations, colonizing periodically inundated muds of Black Sea coastal saltmarshes and of inland salt-basins of central Eurasian and Irano-Anatolian steppe and cold desert zones. Annual glasswort communities of salt steppes and saltmarshes of areas of extreme continentality within the boreal zone of Siberia.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola soda]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of inland salt-basins associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the Pannonic Plain (unit 15.A1) and its satellite basins. Similar communities restricted to isolated intermontane basins of the southwestern Balkan peninsula, related to both the Pannonic and western Pontic formations, are included in this unit, to parallel the treatment of the steppes and saltmarshes of unit 15.A1.

Formations dominated by the reddening [Salicornia prostrata] or [Salicornia simonkaiana] colonizing periodically inundated muds of salt-basins associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the Pannonic Plain.

Formations dominated by [Suaeda pannonica], [Suaeda maritima] ssp. [prostrata] or [Suaeda maritima] ssp. [salsa] colonizing periodically inundated muds of salt-basins associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the Pannonic Plain.
Formations of [Salsola soda] colonizing periodically inundated silty, nitrogen-rich muds of the lower levels of salt-basins of the Pannonic Plain.

Annual formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of inland saltmarshes of isolated intermontane basins of the southwestern Balkan peninsula, in particular, of the middle Vardar trough, northwest of the Pelagonian mountains, with [Suaeda maritima].

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola soda]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the coastal saltmarshes of the Black Sea and Azov Sea, and of the inland salt-basins associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the western and northern Black Sea and Sea of Azov plain, of the basins of the lower Danube, the middle Maritsa and the Tundzha, the Prut, the Dniestr, the Dniepr, the Don, and of the southern Russian hills, north of the Caspian depression and west of the Urals.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola soda]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the saltmarshes of the western Black Sea coast and adjacent inland waterbodies and of the inland salt-basins associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the western Black Sea plain, west of the Dniestr, of the basin of the lower Danube, and, in very fragmentary form, of the northern Thracian basin of the middle Maritsa and the Tundzha. Typical species include [Salicornia prostrata], [Suaeda maritima], [Bassia hirsuta], [Limonium gmelinii].

Formations dominated by [Salicornia prostrata] ([Salicornia ramosissima] auct. eur. orient., non J. Woods) or [Salicornia europaea], often in association with [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], [Crypsis aculeata], [Puccinellia distans], colonizing periodically inundated muds of saltmarshes and salt-basins of the western Black Sea coast, the western Black Sea plain, west of the Dniestr, and the lower Danube plain.

Formations, often monospecific, of [Suaeda maritima], colonizing periodically inundated muds of saltmarshes and salt-basins of the western Black Sea coast, the western Black Sea plain, west of the Dniestr, the lower Danube plain and, in very fragmentary form, the northern Thracian basin of the middle Maritsa and the Tundzha.

Formations, often monospecific, of [Salsola soda], colonizing periodically inundated muds of saltmarshes and salt-basins of the western Black Sea coast, the western Black Sea plain, west of the Dniestr, the lower Danube plain and, in very fragmentary form, the northern Thracian basin of the middle Maritsa and the Tundzha.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia europaea]) and seablite ([Suaeda maritima]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of inland salt-basins associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the southern edge and valleys of the Podolian plateau, of the Central Russian plateau, of the Volga plateau, of Orenburg and of Bachkiria north of the Pontic and Caspian plains.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) and seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the coastal saltmarshes of the northern Black Sea and the Sea of Azov and of the inland salt-basins associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain, of the basins of the Dniepr and the Don.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) and seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of saltmarshes of the southern and eastrn Black Sea coasts, south of the Kuban basin limit between the steppe zone and the peri-Caucasian submediterranean broad-leaved deciduous woods.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of salt steppes and saltmarshes of the Transvolgan, Kazakh, Kourgan, Ichim, Koulounda, Baraba, Barnaul steppe regions and of saltmarshes of the Caspian Sea, the Aral Sea and other inland waterbodies of the northern Aralo-Caspian, Kura basin, western Kazakh, Dzungarian, Oust-ourt, Kyzyl Koum and Kara Koum middle Asiatic deserts and semideserts.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the salt steppes and saltmarshes of Transbaikalia, Outer Mongolia, Inner Mongolia, the Songnen Plain of Northeast China, the western Loess Plateau of North China and of the saltmarshes of the inland waterbodies of the Gobi, Takla Makan, Tarim, Lop-nor, Bei-shan, Ala-shan, Ordos, Tsaidam and Pamyro-Tibetan Central Asiatic deserts and semideserts.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the salt steppes and saltmarshes of steppic areas of the Anatolian Plateau, of the Iranian Plateau and of northern Mesopotamia, as well as of the saltmarshes of the cold desert or subdesert areas of the Iranian Plateau.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.], [Microcnemum coralloides]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the western Anatolian Plateau.
Formations of the endemic [Microcnemum coralloides] ssp. [anatolicum] of interior salt-basins of western-central Anatolia.
Formations of annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) colonizing periodically inundated muds of the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the western Anatolian Plateau.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of salt steppes and saltmarshes of eastern Anatolia and northwestern Iran.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the salt steppes and saltmarshes of steppic areas of the Central and Eastern Iranian Plateau in Iran and Afghanistan, and of the saltmarshes and temporary waterbodies of the cold desert or subdesert areas of Iran and Afghanistan.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]), [Halopeplis amplexicaulis], seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) and saltwort ([Salsola spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the salt steppes and saltmarshes of the Mesopotamian steppic region bordering the Near Eastern Saharo-Sindian deserts, extending north to southeastern Turkey and to Khuzestan in western Iran.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of the salt  meadows, salt steppe meadows, swamp meadows, alases and salt marshes of the middle Lena basin of eastern Siberia.

Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) and seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) formations developed on periodically inundated muds of inland saltmarshes and temporary waterbodies of the Saharo-Sindian subtropical desert belt and of coastal saltmarshes and lagoon fringes of desert and subdesert coasts of Africa and western Asia, including the oceanic desert coasts of the Atlantic Sahara between 27øN and 18øN, the extreme southeastern Mediterranean coasts of the Sinai peninsula, the coasts of the Red Sea, the Arabian Sea and the Persian Gulf.
Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) and seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) formations developed on periodically inundated muds of inland salt-basins of the Far Eastern nemoral and warm-temperate humid zones.
Annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) and seablite ([Suaeda spp.]) formations colonizing periodically inundated muds of Pacific coastal saltmarshes.
Formations of annual glasswort ([Salicornia spp.]) and other Chenopodiaceae colonizing periodically inundated muds of coastal and inland saltmarshes of tropical regions.

Formations of halonitrophilous annuals ([Frankenia pulverulenta], [Suaeda splendens], [Salsola soda], [Cressa cretica], [Parapholis incurva], [Parapholis strigosa], [Hordeum marinum], [Sphenopus divaricatus], [Polypogon maritimus], [Spergularia spp.], [Vella annua]) colonizing salt muds of Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coastal regions, of Iberian and North African endoreic basins, susceptible to temporary inundation and extreme drying

Halophile and weakly to moderately nitrophile, predominantly non-gramino¿d, communities of annuals developing throughout the period of vegetation on solonchaks of Iberia, the Mediterranean basin and interior North Africa, dominated by [Frankenia pulverulenta], with [Suaeda splendens], [Salsola soda], [Cressa cretica], [Parapholis incurva], [Parapholis strigosa], [Hordeum marinum], [Sphenopus divaricatus].

Halophile and weakly nitrophile predominantly gramino¿d swards developing usually in early summer on long-inundated solonchaks of Iberia, the western Mediterranean and North Africa, dominated by relatively small grasses, particularly [Sphenopus divaricatus], also [Parapholis filiformis], [Parapholis incurva], [Polypogon maritimus] ([Polypogon subspathaceus]) with [Hymenolobus procumbens], [Frankenia pulverulenta], [Hordeum marinum].

Halophile and weakly to moderately nitrophile aestival and postaestival solonchak communities of coastal, mostly endoreic or percolation, lagoons, coastal saltmarsh ponds and interior endoreic basins of Sicily, the Maltese Islands, Sardinia, Corsica, Iberia, North Africa and, very locally, Mediterranean France, Calabria, Mediterranean western Asia, dominated by the Convolvulaceae [Cressa cretica].

Dense halonitrophilous meadows dominated by robust, spring-developing annual grasses, among which [Hordeum marinum] is often prevalent, forming at the upper margin of Iberian and North African endoreic depressions and of Mediterranean and warm-temperate Atlantic saltmarshes.

Halonitrophilous, often polyspecific, annual communities dominated by Chenopodiaceae ([Chenopodium spp.], [Suaeda splendens]) colonizing solonchaks of Iberian and North African endoreic basins and of western Mediterranean and warm-temperate Atlantic coasts.

Formations of annual pioneers, small geophytes and sometimes sparse chamaephytes occupying, in the Mediterranean basin, on thermo-Atlantic shores and around Iberian and North African endoreic basins, sands subject to variable salinity and humidity, notably in the transition zone between salt scrubs and dry grasslands. Dominant species include [Sagina maritima], [Spergularia spp.], [Mesembryanthemum crystallinum], [Mesembryanthemum nodiflorum], [Evax rotundata], [Evax pygmaea]

Formations of annual pioneers occupying sands subject to variable salinity and humidity, on the coasts, in the dunal systems and in the saltmarshes of the Atlantic, the North Sea and the Baltic. They are usually limited to small surfaces and best developed in the zone of contact between dune and saltmarsh.  Characteristic species include [Sagina maritima], [Sagina nodosa], [Cochlearia danica], [Gentiana uliginosa], [Centaurium littorale], [Bupleurum tenuissimum].

Sparse solonchak formations of annual grasses of genus [Crypsis] ([Heleochloa]), accompanied by [Cyperus pannonicus] ([Acorellus pannonicus]), [Spergularia media] ([Spergularia marginata]), [Spergularia marina] ([Spergularia salina]), [Salicornia spp.], [Lepidium latifolium], [Chenopodium spp.], [Atriplex spp.], colonizing drying muds of humid depressions of the salt steppes and saltmarshes (15.A) of Eurasia, from Pannonia to the Far East.

Pioneer community of the salt basins of the Pannonic Plain, of Muntenia, the Danube delta, the Dobrogea, the northern Black Sea and Azov Sea coastlands and steppes, characteristic of sandy soils, with [Cyperus pannonicus] ([Acorellus pannonicus]).

Sparse formations of annual grasses of genus [Crypsis], [Crypsis aculeata], [Crypsis schoenoides] ([Heleochloa schoenoides]), [Crypsis alopecuroides] ([Heleochloa alopecuroides]), accompanied by [Cyperus fuscus], [Cyperus difformis] and other monocotyledonous species, colonizing drying silty or clayey muds of humid depressions of the salt steppes and saltmarshes (unit 15.A) of Eurasia, from Pannonia to the Far East.

Formations of often prostrate [Atriplex] and [Chenopodium] species colonizing drying muds of humid depressions of the salt steppes and saltmarshes (unit 15.A) of Eurasia, from Pannonia to the Far East.  Western formations are dominated by [Atriplex prostrata] ([Atriplex hastata] agg.) or by [Chenopodium chenopodioides], accompanied by [Chenopodium glaucum], [Suaeda maritima] ssp. [prostrata], [Crypsis aculeata].

Open or almost closed formations dominated by [Spergularia media] ([Spergularia marginata]) or [Spergularia marina] ([Spergularia salina]), colonizing small depressions inundated or humid in late spring, dessicated, often with salt efflorescences in summer, associated with the salt steppes and saltmarshes (unit 15.A) of Eurasia, in particular in the eastern Pannonic and western Pontic regions.

Formations of [Bassia hirsuta] colonizing very humid, highly chloridic muds of saltmarshes and salt-basins of the western Black Sea coast and the lower Danube plain, often on the outskirts of [Salicornia europaea] and [Suaeda maritima] communities.

Formations of halonitrophilous annuals ([Frankenia pulverulenta], [Suaeda confusa], [Salsola acutifolia], [Parapholis incurva], [Hordeum marinum], [Cressa cretica]) colonizing solonchak salt muds susceptible to temporary inundation and extreme drying, caracteristic of lagoon systems of the western Black Sea coast and of the Danube Delta, somewhat similar ecologically and in species composition to the Mediterranean formations of the [Frankenietea pulverulentae].

Formations of halonitrophilous annuals dominated by [Frankenia pulverulenta] colonizing salt muds susceptible to temporary inundation and extreme drying in openings within [Artemisio austriacae-Poetum bulbosae] or [Obionetum pedunculatae] communities of lagoon systems of the Black Sea, the Azov Sea and the Danube Delta.

Saltmarsh formations constituted by [Cressa cretica], often accompanied by [Crypsis spp.], [Puccinellia festuciformis] ssp. [convoluta], [Aster tripolium], [Salicornia spp.] of western Black Sea coastal areas.

Closed halonitrophilous annual communities dominated by [Hordeum marinum], with [Plantago coronopus], [Lotus tenuis], [Juncus gerardi], [Lepidium latifolium], [Spergularia media], [Puccinellia distans], colonizing moderately salted muds of the western Black Sea coast and the Danube delta, susceptible to heavy autumn and spring inundation.

Formations of small annual caryophyllid pioneers, in particular [Sagina maritima] and [Cerastium spp.], notably [Cerastium gracile] ([Cerastium ramosissimum]) or [Cerastium dubium] ([Cerastium anomalum]), of the western Black Sea coast and the Danube delta, developed on sands subject to variable salinity and humidity, in particular in the zone of contact between dune and saltmarsh.
Perennial pioneer grasslands of coastal salt muds of the Palaearctic, formed by [Spartina spp.] or similar grasses.

Perennial pioneer grasslands of coastal salt muds dominated by flat-leaved [Spartina maritima] ([Spartina stricta]), [Spartina townsendii], [Spartina anglica], [Spartina alterniflora], distributed along Atlantic and North Sea coasts of middle Europe north to Denmark and south to northwestern Iberia, with outposts on the Atlantic coast of Africa around Tangier, Rabat and Cap Blanc, extending east to the Danish archipelago and with isolated areas of occurrence in the Mediterranean basin, located in the northern Adriatic, in the Venice Lagoon and nearby coasts, from the mouth of the Po to Trieste and Slovenia, and in estuaries of the coasts of northwestern Africa.
Perennial pioneer grasslands of southern Iberian coastal salt muds, dominated by the junciform-leaved [Spartina densiflora].

Salt meadows of the shores of the Atlantic and Pacific oceans and connected seas, including the Baltic, the North Sea and the English Channel, within the nemoral and boreal zones. [Aster tripolium] can be present or abundant in most western subdivisions.
Nitrophilous tall grass communities of Pacific saltmarshes.
Annual formations of pioneers colonizing driftlines forming within Pacific saltmarshes.

Communities of the lower and middle schorre of the shores of the Atlantic ocean and connected seas with an overwhelming dominance of [Puccinellia maritima], often in almost monospecific stands forming bright green lawns characteristic, in particular, of pioneer stages of the lowest levels and of intensely grazed areas.
Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas codominated by [Puccinellia maritima] and other physiognomically important species.
Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas codominated by [Puccinellia maritima] and [Halimione portulacoides].
Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas codominated by [Puccinellia maritima] and [Aster tripolium].
Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas codominated by [Puccinellia maritima], annual [Salicornia spp.] and [Suaeda maritima].

Formations dominated by the rare, threatened [Halimione pedunculata], developing very locally in the [Puccinellion maritimae] of Denmark, Germany, Poland, the Netherlands, Belgium and France, extinct in the British Isles.

Species-poor salt meadows restricted to the shores of northern Norway and southwestern Iceland in the vicinity of the Reykjanes peninsula, codominated by [Puccinellia maritima] and the brown alga [Pelvetia canaliculata], accompanied by [Agrostis stolonifera].

Salt meadows of Iceland and northern Norway, mostly of the lower shore, dominated by [Puccinellia maritima], with [Catabrosa aquatica], [Carex mackenziei], [Carex subspathacea], [Stellaria crassifolia], [Glaux maritima], [Gentianella detonsa].
Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas codominated by [Puccinellia maritima] and [Glaux maritima].
Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas codominated by [Puccinellia maritima] and [Plantago maritima].

Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas codominated by [Puccinellia maritima] and [Limonium vulgare], characteristic of undrained depressions on lightly grazed salt meadows of the Netherlands and the British Isles.

Often relatively species-rich, grassy, flowery formations characteristic of the upper levels of the salt meadows of the Atlantic and its connected seas, with [Armeria maritima], [Glaux maritima], [Plantago maritima], [Frankenia laevis], [Artemisia maritima], [Festuca rubra], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Juncus gerardi], [Carex extensa], [Blysmus rufus], [Eleocharis spp.]. Similar communities occupying the lower levels of brackish meadows, in particular of the Baltic, are included, while formations restricted to brackish conditions are listed under unit 15.34. The dominance of various species induces distinctive facies, the most important of which are individualised in subunits.

Saltmarsh communities of the Atlantic, the North Sea and the southern Baltic, dominated by, or rich in, [Juncus maritimus], with [Oenanthe lachenalii] and, locally, in Poland in particular, [Samolus valerandi], mostly characteristic of the upper shore, in moderately salty or brackish conditions, of the sandy-clayey transition to green beaches, also occurring, in the southern Baltic, on brackish lower shores.
Atlantic saltmarsh communities dominated by, or rich in, [Artemisia maritima].

Upper saltmarsh communities of the Atlantic and its connected seas dominated by, or rich in, [Potentilla anserina], including both [Potentilla anserina] ssp. [anserina], and, in Fennoscandia, Iceland and Greenland, [Potentilla anserina] ssp. [egedii].

Atlantic upper saltmarsh communities of the English Channel and the Franco-Iberian coasts of the Atlantic, with an isolated station on Anglesey, dominated by, or rich in, [Frankenia laevis], associated with [Limonium spp.], in particular with [Limonium lychnidifolium] in France, or [Limonium vulgare] in southern England, characteristic of the sandy transition zone between saltmarshes and dunes.

Nombre oficial: Atlantic upper schorre sea aster beds
Definición oficial: Atlantic upper schorre communities dominated by [Aster tripolium].
Atlantic upper saltmarsh communities dominated by [Trifolium fragiferum].
Atlantic upper saltmarsh communities dominated by [Carex nigra].

Upper and middle saltmarsh communities of the Baltic and the northwest Atlantic, dominated by [Schoenus nigricans] or [Schoenus ferrugineus], with [Molinia caerulea] and [Campylium polygamum], developed on calcareous substrates.
Upper shore swards of northern Norway, Iceland and the Faeroes dominated by [Agrostis stolonifera], [Festuca rubra], [Plantago maritima] and [Leontodon autumnalis].

Upper saltmarsh tall graminoid communities of the Gulf of Bothnia and the northern Atlantic coasts of Scandinavia, south of Finnmark, dominated by [Calamagrostis stricta], [Carex aquatilis], [Carex juncella], [Eriophorum angustifolium], rich in arctic halophytes, transitional towards fens which form flood belts near fresh water. This unit is replaced northwards by the truly arctic formations of unit 15.B26.

Communities of the middle levels of exposed shores of the southern Baltic dominated by [Carex scandinavica] ([Carex serotina] ssp. [pulchella], [Carex pulchellum], [Carex oederi] ssp. [pulchella], [Carex viridula] var. [pulchella]), characteristic, in particular, of southeastern Sweden.

Often species-rich, closed, flowery, upper level salt meadows of the Atlantic and its connected seas, dominated by, or rich in, [Juncus gerardi]. [Glaux maritima] can dominate facies, forming thick carpets, in particular, in pioneer situations.
Communities of upper saltmarshes of the Atlantic, the North Sea and the Baltic, dominated by [Plantago maritima] or [Plantago maritima] and [Bupleurum tenuissimum].
Upper saltmarsh communities of the Atlantic and its connected seas dominated by, or rich in, [Festuca rubra] and [Agrostis stolonifera].
Communities of salt meadows of the Atlantic and its connected seas dominated by, or rich in, [Armeria maritima].
Communities of Atlantic salt meadows dominated by [Carex distans].
Upper saltmarsh communities of the Atlantic and its connected seas dominated by, or rich in, [Carex extensa].
Upper saltmarsh communities of the Atlantic and its connected seas dominated by, or rich in, [Limonium vulgare].
Upper saltmarsh communities of the Atlantic and its connected seas dominated by, or rich in, [Blysmus rufus].

Atlantic saltmarsh or brackish marsh communities dominated by [Eleocharis uniglumis] or [Eleocharis palustris], associated with [Agrostis stolonifera] or [Carex paleacea]. They constitute a common upper shore community in Scotland

Communities of saltmarshes of the Atlantic and its connected seas developed in areas of varying salinity and humidity, such as estuaries, in coastal basins with fresh water input and along brackish seashores, such as those of the inner Baltic.

Communities of saltmarshes of the Atlantic, North Sea and Baltic coasts of Europe, from the Iberian peninsula to Scandinavia, developed in areas of varying salinity and humidity, in particular, in estuarine saltmarshes, in saltmarsh inner basins, in dike-enclsoed saltmarshes, with [Spergularia marina], [Puccinellia distans], [Puccinellia fasciculata], [Puccinellia retroflexa], [Puccinellia maritima], [Triglochin maritima], [Potentilla anserina] and [Halimione portulacoides].
Formations of the brackish shores of the inner Baltic, dominated by [Carex paleacea], with [Eleocharis uniglumis] and [Agrostis stolonifera], accompanied by [Triglochin maritima].
Communities of brackish lower shores of the northern and eastern Baltic dominated by [Carex mackenziei].
Baltic [Agrostis stolonifera]-[Triglochin palustre] formations of depressions submitted to marine salt precipitation.

Communities of the lower levels of the brackish marshes of the Gulf of Bothnia, characteristic of exposed coasts, dominated by the endemic [Deschampsia cespitosa] ssp. [bottnica] ([Deschampsia bottnica]).

Nombre oficial: Atlantic saltmarsh and drift rough grass communities
Definición oficial: Nitrophilous tall grass communities of Atlantic saltmarshes, green beaches and beach drift accumulations, dominated by [Elymus pycnanthus] ([Agropyron pungens]), [Elymus repens], [Festuca arundinacea] or sometimes tall perennial forbs.

Nombre oficial: Saltmarsh and drift sea couch beds
Definición oficial: Saltmarsh rough tall grass beds formed by [Elymus pycnanthus] ([Agropyron pungens]), limited to the coasts of Iberia, France and southern Britain.

Nombre oficial: Saltmarsh and drift common couch beds
Definición oficial: Rough tall grass beds formed by [Elymus repens] in saltmarshes, on green beaches and on northern sand, gravel or pebble beaches of the coasts of the Atlantic, the North Sea and the Baltic, in areas of accumulation of organic material.

Nitrophilous communities of older accumulations of organic drift on sand, gravel or pebble beaches of southern Norway dominated by [Calystegia sepium], [Elymus repens] and [Galeopsis bifida], accompanied by [Potentilla anserina], [Rumex crispus], [Cirsium arvense], [Vicia cracca], [Galium aparine], [Geranium pratense], [Sonchus arvensis].

Beds of tall [Festuca arundinacea] colonizing shores of southern Baltic and Baelts coasts and archipelagoes on pebble or sand substrates rich in drift material, often forming a belt along high water line, above saltmarsh communities of unit 15.33. Accompanying grasses and forbs include [Agrostis gigantea], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Elymus repens] ([Elytrigia repens]), [Festuca rubra], [Potentilla anserina].

Uncommon [Lepidium latifolium]-dominated communities of the shores of southern Scandinavia and the Baltic States, developed on older drift banks and sands with diffuse drift layers. [Elymus repens] ([Elytrigia repens]) is sometimes subdominant. Accompanying species include [Galium aparine], [Galium verum], [Linaria vulgaris], [Rumex crispus], [Solanum dulcamara].
Annual formations of pioneers colonizing driftlines forming within Atlantic saltmarshes, with [Atriplex littoralis], [Atriplex hastata], [Beta maritima], [Matricaria maritima].
Communities of the lower part of the coastal saltmarshes of the Pacific and its connected seas.
Communities of the upper levels of the salt meadows of the Pacific and its connected seas.

Communities of saltmarshes of the Pacific and its connected seas developed in areas of varying salinity and humidity, such as estuaries, in coastal basins with fresh water input and along brackish seashores.

Salt meadows of inland salt basins of the nemoral zones of western Europe and eastern Asia. Continental saltmarshes of interior middle Europe are remarkable, extremely threatened communities occurring in a few isolated stations of Saxony and Lower Saxony, Schleswig-Holstein, Thuringe, Hesse, Lorraine, Auvergne, the Midlands and southeastern Poland (lower Nida valley). They comprise this unit and continental glasswort swards (unit 15.112).
Meadows of [Puccinellia distans] occupying the lower levels of inland salt basins of the nemoral zone of western Europe, with fairly extended periods of inundation.

Nombre oficial: Interior European saltmarsh rush and couch beds
Definición oficial: Formations dominated by [Juncus gerardi] or [Elymus repens], with [Triglochin maritima], [Glaux maritima], [Melilotus dentata], of the upper levels of inland salt basins of the nemoral zone of western and central Europe, on damp, less saline soils.
Formations dominated by the threatened [Halimione pedunculata] restricted to saltmarshes east and south of the Harz.

Closed halo-hygrophile swards of [Scirpus pumilus], [Triglochin maritima], [Glaux maritima], [Centaurium littorale] ssp. [uliginosum], [Plantago maritima] ssp. [salsa] with [Pinguicula vulgaris], [Parnassia palustris], [Primula farinosa], endemic to the inner Carpathian Zipser valley of Slovakia, where they colonize travertine concretions permanently washed by mineralized spring waters.
Salt meadows of inland salt basins of the nemoral zone of eastern Asia.

Salt meadows of saltmarshes, lagoons and deltas of the coasts and coastal regions of the Mediterranean and of the subtropical Atlantic, including those of southwestern France, the Iberian peninsula, the Macaronesian Islands, mediterranean North Africa south to the Oued Tensift at 32øN and mediterraneo-Saharan Africa between 32øN and 27øN, and of endoreic interior basins of mediterranean Iberia and mediterranean North Africa.

Beds of tall [Juncus maritimus], [Juncus rigidus] ([Juncus maritimus] var. [arabicus], [Juncus arabicus]) or [Juncus acutus] of saline grounds of Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coastlands and of endoreic interior basins of mediterranean Iberia and mediterranean North Africa, forming, in particular, in periodically inundated depressions , where they may associate with [Carex extensa], [Iris spuria], [Gladiolus communis], [Aster tripolium], [Sonchus maritimus], [Sonchus crassifolius] or other elements of units 15.52 and 15.54, and in sandy dunal depressions, where they may alternate with stands of [Schoenus nigricans] or other formations of unit 15.53.

Beds of [Juncus maritimus] or [Juncus acutus] of saltmarshes, periodically inundated saline basins and humid dunal depressions of the Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts and coastlands of Europe and western Asia.
Beds of [Juncus maritimus] or [Juncus acutus] of periodically inundated depressions of the endoreic interior basins of Mediterranean Iberia.

Beds of tall rushes, mostly [Juncus rigidus] ([Juncus maritimus] var. [arabicus], [Juncus arabicus]), sometimes [Juncus maritimus] or [Juncus acutus], of saltmarshes, periodically inundated saline basins and humid dunal depressions of the Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts and endoreic interior basins of North Africa.

Humid meadows of low vegetation dominated by [Juncus gerardi], [Carex divisa], [Carex extensa], [Schoenus nigricans], [Triglochin maritima], [Hordeum marinum] or [Trifolium spp.] and [Lotus spp.] of the edges of brackish lagoons of Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts of Europe, western Asia and North Africa.

Drier, dense formations of sandy soils at the foot of dunes, or between dunes and lagoons of the Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts of Europe and North Africa, and of the endoreic interior basins of Mediterranean Iberia, with [Plantago crassifolia], [Schoenus nigricans], [Juncus littoralis], [Spartina versicolor] ([Spartina patens], [Spartina juncea]), [Elymus elongatus], [Inula crithmoides], all of which may dominate and form physiognomically distinct, sometimes almost monospecific, facies.

Psammo-halophile swards of the foot of dunes and of dune hollows of the Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts of Europe. [Plantago crassifolia], [Schoenus nigricans], [Juncus littoralis], [Spartina versicolor] ([Spartina patens], [Spartina juncea]), [Scirpus holoschoenus] may associate in communities or dominate stands that occur alone or in mosaics, often interspersed with psammophile tall [Juncus] stands of unit 15.51.
Psammo-halophile swards of endoreic interior basins of Mediterranean Iberia, with [Plantago crassifolia] and [Schoenus nigricans].

Psammo-halophile swards of the foot of dunes and of dune hollows of the Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts of North Africa. [Plantago crassifolia], [Schoenus nigricans], [Spartina versicolor] ([Spartina patens], [Spartina juncea]), [Sporobolus pungens] are important elements of various communities.

Nombre oficial: Interior Iberian salt basin grass and small rush swards
Definición oficial: Salt meadows peculiar to the lowest, wettest parts of interior Iberian depressions, dominated by [Puccinellia fasciculata] or [Aeluropus littoralis] in the very lowest areas, or, slightly higher, by [Juncus gerardi]. The higher, drier ground that surrounds them is occupied either by other salt meadow communities that are less differentiated from the coastal communities (units 15.512, 15.532) or by salt scrubs (unit 15.615).
Dense formations of perennial halophile grasses, in particular, [Puccinellia festuciformis] ([Puccinellia palustris]) or [Aeluropus littoralis], of Mediterranean coasts and their coastal lagoons.

Communities of annuals forming on accumulations of organic debris in saltmarshes and saline depressions of the Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts and of endoreic basins of the Mediterranean interior, in particular, of mediterranean Iberia, with [Atriplex hastata], [Suaeda splendens], [Suaeda maritima], [Bassia hirsuta], [Salsola soda], [Rumex pulcher].
Formations of [Elymus] or [Artemisia] fringing Mediterranean and interior Iberian saline wetlands.
Formations of [Elymus] of Mediterranean and interior Iberian saline wetlands.
Formations of [Artemisia] fringing Mediterranean and interior Iberian saline wetlands.
Medium-tall [Juncus subulatus] beds, often forming facies within [Arthrocnemum] scrubs of Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic coasts.

Scrubby formations of woody glassworts ([Arthrocnemum]), seablites ([Suaeda]), [Halimione], [Halocnemum] or [Limoniastrum] of saltmarshes and salt basins of mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic regions of the western Palaearctic, distributed in coastal saltmarshes of the Mediterranean, in endoreic interior basins of Iberia and mediterranean North Africa, and in warm temperate Atlantic coastal saltmarshes of Iberia, mediterranean and Saharo-mediterranean North Africa, the Macaronesian Islands and southwestern France, north locally to the English Channel and the southern North Sea. Scrubby formations of saltmarshes of the temperate coasts of the western Pacific and its connected seas.

Low shrubby expanses of woody glassworts, seablites, sea purslanes or [Halocnemum], characteristic of temporarily inundated saltmarshes of Mediterranean coasts, southwestern Iberian and northwestern African Atlantic coasts and interior Iberian basins. They can be further subdivided according to dominant species, generally associated with patterns of inundation. [Cistanche lutea] characterises many southern formations.
Low shrubby carpets of prostrate [Arthrocnemum perenne] of wettest areas of coastal marshes of Mediterranean, southwestern Iberian and northwestern African Atlantic coasts.
Stands of robust [Arthrocnemum fruticosum], capable of forming extensive low, dense thickets in coastal marshes of Mediterranean, southwestern Iberian and northwestern African Atlantic coasts.
Shrubby formations of [Arthrocnemum glaucum]. Along northern Mediterranean shores, they often occupy somewhat drier sites such as shell banks in saline lagoons
Shrubby formations of [Suaeda vera] occupying drier elevations of coastal saltmarshes of Mediterranean, southwestern Iberian and northwestern African Atlantic coasts.
Formations of woody glassworts and seablites of Iberian interior salt basins.
[Suaeda pruinosa] ([Suaeda fruticosa] var. [brevifolia]) formations of Iberian interior salt basins.
[Arthrocnemum glaucum] formations of Iberian interior salt basins.
[Arthrocnemum perenne] formations of Iberian interior salt basins.
[Halimione portulacoides]-rich facies within [Arthrocnemum] communities of coastal saltmarshes of Mediterranean, southwestern Iberian and northwestern African Atlantic coasts.

Salt scrubs of Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes dominated by [Halocnemum strobilaceum], characteristic of arid African coasts, with a few outposts on dry coasts of European peninsulas and islands. Formations of the desert coasts of the Sinai Mediterranean and the Red Sea and of endoreic basins of the Anatolian and North African transition regions between Mediterranean and desert or steppe zones are included under units 15.A and 15.C.

Rare and local formations dominated by the often sparse clumps of [Halocnemum strobilaceum], usually associated with [Arthrocnemum glaucum], sometimes with [Arthrocnemum fruticosum], limited to southeastern Spain, southern Sardinia, western Sicily, Toscany, Emilia-Romagna, Albania, Greece and Cyprus, apparently extinct in the Maltese Islands.

Salt scrubs of saltmarshes of the North African coasts of the Mediterranean dominated by [Halocnemum strobilaceum], characteristic of arid coasts between Egypt and Tunisia, occuring west to Tunis. Formations of the desert coasts of the Sinai Mediterranean and of endoreic basins of the North African transition regions between Mediterranean and desert or steppe zones are included under units 15.A and 15.C.

Salt scrubs of hypersaline Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes dominated by the leafless scaly [Limonium ferulaceum], characteristic of northwestern Africa, with irradiations in Algarve and western Andalucia and in Sicily, at Trapani and on the Isola Grande of the Marsala marshes.
Sea purslane, glasswort and seablite scrubs of northern Atlantic and North Sea coasts.
Shrubby [Halimione portulacoides] communities of middle levels of Atlantic schorres.
[Arthrocnemum perenne]-dominated formations of the British Isles, the Atlantic coasts of France and of Iberia, except for the extreme southwest of the peninsula.

[Suaeda vera]-dominated formations of the British Isles, where they are limited to the coast of Norfolk, and of the Atlantic coasts of France and of Iberia, except for the extreme southwest of the peninsula.
[Suaeda vera]-dominated formations of the Atlantic coasts of France and of Iberia, except for the extreme southwest of the peninsula.

[Suaeda vera]-dominated formations of the British Isles, limited to the coast of Norfolk, with [Halimion portulacoides], [Limonium binervosum], [Limonium bellidifolium], [Frankenia laevis], [Puccinellia maritima], [Armeria maritima].
[Arthrocnemum fruticosum]-dominated formations of the Atlantic coasts of France and of Iberia, except for the extreme southwest of the peninsula.

Formations of often large, silver-glaucous shrubs of [Limoniastrum monopetalum] with showy pink flowers in late spring, of drier parts of Mediterranean and Iberian saltmarshes, distributed locally in North Africa, the Iberian peninsula, the southern Italian peninsula, western Sicily, Lampedusa, Sardinia and Crete.
Low shrubby expanses of woody glassworts, seablites, sea purslanes or [Zygophyllum], characteristic of temporarily inundated saltmarshes of Canary Island coasts.
Formations of [Arthrocnemum perenne] occupying the lowest level of the saltmarshes of the coasts of Fuerteventura, Lanzarote and Isla de Lobos.

Formations of the Canario-Saharan halophyte [Zygophyllum fontanesii], associated with [Arthrocnemum glaucum], of the higher level of the saltmarshes of the eastern islands and, very locally, of Alegranza and La Graciosa.
Formations of [Salsola longifolia], often dense and sometimes up to 2 metres high, of Canary Island coastal marshes, barranco openings and lagoons.
Scrubby formations of saltmarshes of the temperate coasts of the western Pacific and its connected seas.

Halophile shrub formations of dry ground in low-precipitation areas of the mediterranean zone, in particular, the Iberian peninsula and Sicily, and of the Macaronesian Islands. Xerohalophile scrubs of the steppe zones are listed under unit 15.A, of the desert and semidesert regions under 7.
Shrubby formations of [Zygophyllum fontanesii], [Chenoleoides tomentosa], sea-heath, saltworts and seablites of the vicinity of the coasts of the Canary Islands.

Formations of [Chenoleoides tomentosa], [Suaeda vermiculata], [Frankenia laevis], [Zygophyllum fontanesii], [Polycarpaea nivea], [Atriplex halimus], [Atriplex glauca] and [Limonium spp.] forming a halophile belt in the littoral zone of the larger Canary Islands and, with somewhat modified composition, of the islets.
Formations of [Zygophyllum fontanesii] of sandy stone fields and black sands of the coastal zone of the Canary Islands.
Formations of [Salsola oppositifolia] ([Salsola longifolia]) of dry coastal areas of the Canary Islands.
Shrubby formations of [Suaeda vera] of the Selvagens, with [Limonium papillatum] var. [callibotryum].

Nitrophilous scrubby formations typically of dry soils and arid climates, often greyish-white and semidesert-like, sometimes including taller, denser brushes. They are most frequent in the eastern Iberian peninsula, where characteristic shrubs include [Peganum harmala], [Artemisia herba-alba], [Lycium intricatum], [Capparis ovata] and the Chenopodiaceae [Salsola vermiculata], [Salsola genistoides], [Salsola verticillata], [Suaeda pruinosa], [Atriplex halimus], [Atriplex glauca], [Camphorosma monspeliaca], [Anabasis articulata] and [Haloxylon articulatum].
Interior, extensive and varied, halonitrophilous scrubs of the Ebro basin, comprising both dry ground sisallares proper, as well as various more hygrophile communities of edges of salt lagoons.
Halonitrophilous scrubs of La Mancha, in the central Iberian peninsula, formed of communities related to those of the Ebro.
Local halonitrophilous scrubs of the coasts of Catalonia, Valencia and the Balearics.

Halonitrophilous scrubs, matojares and related communities, of the arid zone of southeastern Spain, forming, with predesert scrubs (unit 32.25) and localized gypsum scrubs (unit 15.93), the unique vegetation of this highly distinctive region.

Halonitrophilous scrubs of southwestern Sicily, with [Salsola verticillata], [Suaeda pruinosa], [Reaumuria vermiculata], [Capparis ovata] and the endemics [Limonium opulentum] and [Herniaria fontanesii] ssp. [empedocleana].

Associations rich in perennial, rosette-forming [Limonium spp.] or esparto grass, [Lygeum spartum], occupying, in Mediterranean coastal regions and on the fringes of endoreic interior salt basins of arid mediterranean Iberia and North Africa, soils temporarily permeated (though not inundated) by saline water and subject to extreme summer drying, with formation of salt efflorescences. These formations constitute a Mediterranean equivalent of the more continental formations of 15.A
Mediterranean salt steppes dominated by rosette-forming species of [Limonium]. Aegean and eastern Mediterranean coastal saltmarsh formations of [Camphorosma monspeliaca] or [Petrosimonia].
Communities of salt basins of Iberia and of northwestern Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes and saline dunal depressions subject to extreme summer drying, dominated by rosette-forming [Limonium].

[Limonium] steppes of the Almerian, Murcian and Alicantian coastal regions of the arid Iberian southeast dominated by [Limonium angustibracteatum], [Limonium delicatulum], [Limonium caesium], [Limonium supinum], characteristic of hypersaline depressions not submitted to temporary inundation.
[Limonium] steppes of interior salt basins of La Mancha with [Limonium latibracteatum], [Limonium delicatulum] ssp. [tournefortii] ([Limonium tournefortii]), [Limonium supinum].
[Limonium] steppes of interior salt basins of the Ebro valley, with [Limonium catalaunicum].

[Limonium] steppes of northwestern Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes and saline dunal depressions, recorded from northeastern Iberia, southern continental France, Corsica, Sardinia, Sicily, Lampedusa, the Egadi Islands, with [Limonium oleifolium] ([Limonium virgatum]), [Limonium girardianum], [Limonium narbonense], [Limonium binervosum], [Limonium auriculae-ursifolium], [Limonium diffusum], [Limonium duriusculum], [Limonium ramosissimum] and a number of threatened narrow endemics, among them [Limonium insulare], [Limonium intermedium], [Limonium laetum], [Limonium lilybaeum], [Limonium aegusae], [Limonium pachynense], [Limonium pseudolaetum], [Limonium pulviniforme].

Communities of Adriatic and Ionian coasts dominated by rosette-forming species of [Limonium] or [Goniolimon], developed in coastal basins, coastal saltmarshes and saline dunal depressions subjected to extreme summer drying.
[Limonium] steppes of Puglia, with [Limonium oleifolium] ([Limonium virgatum]), [Limonium vulgarae] ssp. [serotinum] ([Limonium serotinum]).

[Limonium] steppes of the northern Adriatic coast of Italy and Slovenia, with [Limonium oleifolium] ([Limonium virgatum]), [Limonium vulgare] ssp. [serotinum] ([Limonium serotinum]), [Limonium densissimum] ([Limonium ramosissimum]).
[Limonium] steppes of the Dalmatian coast, dominated by [Limonium caspicum], [Limonium oleifolia] or [Limonium angustifolia].
Formations of the Dalmatian coast dominated by the rosette-forming [Goniolimon dalmaticum].
Communities of southeastern Adriatic and eastern Ionian coasts dominated by rosette-forming species of [Limonium] or [Goniolimon].

Formations of Aegean and eastern Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes, of a somewhat intermediate character between Mediterranean and Central Eurasian salt steppes, with rosette-forming [Limonium] and [Goniolimon] or the Chenopodiaceae [Petrosimonia] and [Camphorosma monspeliaca].
Formations of Aegean and eastern Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes dominated by rosette-forming [Limonium] and [Goniolimon].
Formations of Aegean and eastern Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes dominated by the reddening carpets of the Chenopodiaceae [Petrosimonia].
Formations of Aegean and eastern Mediterranean coastal saltmarshes dominated by [Camphorosma monspeliaca].

North African coastal salt steppes dominated by, or rich in, rosette-forming species of [Limonium], colonizing depressions subjected to short periods of inundation by salt or brackish water and intense dessication, often on partly gypseous substrates, with [Limonium pruinosum], [Limonium tunetanum], [Frankenia thymifolia], [Aeluropus lagopoides].
Saltmarsh and saltmarsh fringe formations of [Lygeum spartum] of coastal Crete, coastal and interior Iberia.
[Lygeum spartum] swards of saltmarshes and salt pan or saltmarsh fringes of arid coastal regions and interior endoreic basins of Iberia.

[Lygeum spartum] swards, with [Limonium spp.], occupying micro-elevations and the fringes of saltmarshes and salt pans of arid coastal regions and interior endoreic basins of the arid Iberian southeast.
Saltmarsh and saltmarsh fringe formations of [Lygeum spartum] of interior Iberian basins of La Mancha.
Saltmarsh and saltmarsh fringe formations of [Lygeum spartum] of interior Iberian basins of the Ebro depression.
Saltmarsh and saltmarsh fringe formations of [Lygeum spartum] of Crete.
Saltmarsh and saltmarsh fringe formations of [Lygeum spartum] of coastal North Africa.

Garrigues occupying gypsum-rich soils of the Iberian peninsula and of mediterranean North Africa, usually very open and floristically characterised by the presence of numerous gypsophilous species, among which [Gypsophila struthium], [Gypsophila hispanica], [Centaurea hyssopifolia], [Teucrium libanitis], [Ononis tridentata], [Lepidium subulatum], [Herniaria fruticosa], [Reseda stricta], [Helianthemum squamatum]. They are often rich in thymes ([Thymus]), germanders ([Teucrium]), rockroses ([Helianthemum]), composites ([Centaurea], [Jurinea], [Santolina]), [Frankenia].

Low garrigues dotted with occasional tall bushes, developed on gypseous soils which are often covered by a crust of lichens, generally rich in [Centaurea hyssopifolia] and often in [Gypsophila struthium], [Lepidium subulatum], [Thymus zygis] or [Jurinea pinnata]. They are limited to the meseta and eastern Andalusia.
Formations of the central meseta dominated by, or rich in, [Centaurea hyssopifolia].
Formations of eastern Andalusia (Armeria, Granada) dominated by, or rich in, [Centaurea hyssopifolia], [Jurinea pinnata] or [Gypsophila struthium].
Formations of the central Duero with [Linum suffruticosum] and [Lepidium subulatum].
Open low garrigues of eroded gypsiferous hills of the Ebro basin and of the upper Turia region, with [Gypsophila hispanica].
Open formations of gypsiferous hills of the Ebro basin and of the upper Turia region dominated by, or very rich in, [Gypsophila hispanica], the most widespread northeastern gypsum scrub component.
Formations of [Helianthemum squamatum] of gypsiferous hills of the Ebro basin and of the upper Turia region, often very homogeneous.
Formations of somewhat deeper calcaro-gypsiferous soils of hills of the Ebro basin and of the upper Turia region, rich in [Ononis tridentata].

Low, open thyme, germander and rockrose garrigues colonizing poorly developed gypsiferous soils of the arid southeast of the Iberian peninsula (Alicante and Murcia). Characteristic elements are [Teucrium libanitis] ([Teucrium verticillatum]), [Teucrium polium], [Teucrium pumilum], [Teucrium carthaginense], [Thymus longiflorus], [Thymus antoninae], [Helianthemum lavandulifolium] ([Helianthemum racemosum]), [Helianthemum squamatum], [Gypsophila hispanica], [Gypsophila struthium], [Astragalus alopecuroides]. Grasses ([Lygeum], [Stipa], [Brachypodium]), wormwood ([Artemisia]) and Chenopodiaceae may be locally prominent.
Garrigues occupying gypsum-rich soils of mediterranean North Africa, floristically characterised by the presence of numerous gypsophilous species.

Nombre oficial: Coastal sand dunes and sand beaches
Definición oficial: Sand-covered shorelines of the oceans, their connected seas and associated coastal lagoons, fashioned by the action of wind or waves. They include gently sloping beaches and beach-ridges, formed by sands brought by waves, longshore  drift and storm waves, as well as dunes, formed by eolian deposits, though sometimes refashioned by waves.
Gently sloping sand-covered shorelines fashioned by wave action along the coasts of the oceans of the Palaearctic region, their connected seas and associated coastal lagoons.

Sandy beaches of the oceans of the Palaearctic region, their connected seas and associated coastal lagoons, devoid of phanerogamic vegetation. Mediolittoral (intertidal) and supralittoral invertebrate communities listed under 11.27 can be combined with 16.11 to record detailed habitats.

Formations of the coasts of the Palaearctic region, composed mostly of a few annual species, occupying accumulations of drift material and sands rich in nitrogenous organic matter, usually comprising [Cakile maritima], [Salsola kali], [Atriplex spp.], [Polygonum spp.]

Annual communities of sand beaches of the low Arctic and high Arctic oceanic zones of the Palaearctic Atlantic, Pacific and Arctic oceans, with [Cakile edentula] ssp. [islandica] ([Cakile arctica]), [Atriplex lapponica].

Nombre oficial: Eurasian Arctic sand beach annual communities
Definición oficial: Annual communities of sand beaches of the Polar Basin coasts of continental Eurasia, from Finnmark eastwards, with [Atriplex lapponica] ([Atriplex longipes] ssp. [praecox] [p.]), [Polygonum norvegicum] and [Cakile edentula] ssp. [islandica] ([Cakile arctica]).

Annual communities of Icelandic sand beaches, on fine sands, with [Cakile edentula] ssp. [islandica] ([Cakile arctica]) and [Atriplex glabriuscula]. Outlying stations occur within the boreal zone in southern Iceland and the Faeroe Islands.

Nombre oficial: Middle European sand beach annual communities
Definición oficial: Annual halonitrophilous communities of the sand beaches of the temperate North Atlantic, the North Sea, the English Channel, the Irish Sea and the Baltic, with [Suaeda maritima], [Bassia hirsuta], [Cakile maritima], [Salsola kali], [Beta maritima], [Atriplex spp.], [Glaucium flavum], [Polygonum spp.], [Mertensia maratima].
Annual driftline communities of the sand beaches of the temperate North Atlantic, the North Sea, the English Channel and the Irish Sea.

Annual driftline communities of central and southern Baltic sand beaches, with [Cakile maritima] ssp. [baltica], [Atriplex littoralis], [Atriplex calotheca], [Atriplex hastata], [Salsola kali], [Polygonum aviculare], [Polygonum oxyspermum], [Senecio vulgaris], [Matricaria perforata], [Matricaria maritima].
Annual driftline communities of the sand beaches of the Gulf of Bothnia.
Annual communities of sand beaches of the Mediterranean, Black Sea and Mediterraneo-Atlantic coasts.

Nombre oficial: Western Tethyan sand beach annual communities
Definición oficial: Annual communities of sand beaches of the Mediterranean and the subtropical Atlantic, between Portugal and the southern limit of the Mediterraneo-Saharan transition zone at 27øN.

Sparse annual communities of weakly to moderately nitrogenated upper levels of sand beaches of the Mediterranean and of the subtropical Atlantic, from southwest Iberia to Safi in northwestern Africa, and in the Canary Islands, dominated by prostrate [Cakile maritima] ssp. [aegyptiaca], or, in northern areas, [Cakile maritima]  ssp. [maritima], and [Salsola kali].

Communities of sand beaches of the Atlantic coasts of northwestern Africa, between Essaouira and Tiznit, dominated by the giant annual [Cakile maritima] ssp. [susica], with [Salsola kali] and sometimes [Ononis tournefortii], [Lotus pseudocreticus], [Mesembryanthemum crystallinum], [Cyperus capitatus].

Annual communities of sand beaches of the Mediterranean and the subtropical Atlantic dominated by, or rich in, composites, in particular, formations, mostly of the Adriatic and Aegean, dominated by the anthropogenic [Xanthium strumarium] ssp. [italicum], formations of eastern Iberia dominated by tall knapweeds [Centaurea sonchifolia], [Centaurea seridis] ssp. [maritima], [Centauria aspera], [Centaurea albuferae], with [Cakile maritima] ssp. [aegyptiaca] and [Sporobolus pungens], formations of the eastern basin, including Cyprus, dominated by [Anthemis tomentosa] ([Anthemis muenteriana]) or [Centaurea aegialophila], communities of the western Mediterranean and the warm temperate Atlantic dominated by [Matricaria maritima].

Strongly nitrophile annual communities of sand beaches of the Mediterranean and of the subtropical Atlantic dominated by chenopodids, in particular, [Atriplex spp.], [Salsola kali], [Salsola soda], [Suaeda splendens], [Kochia hirsuta].

Annual halonitrophilous communities of sand beaches of the Black Sea, with [Cakile maritima] ssp. [euxina], [Salsola kali] ssp. [ruthenica], [Salsola kali] ssp. [tragus], [Atriplex hastata], [Polygonum maritimum], [Euphorbia peplis], [Euphorbia paralias], [Glaucium flavum], [Xanthium strumarium] ssp. [italicum], [Convolvulus lineatus], [Convolvulus persicus].

Halonitrophilous communities of Black Sea sand beaches dominated by perennial herbs, including [Crambe maritima] ssp. [pontica], [Argusia sibirica], [Lactuca tatarica], [Petasites spurius] or [Trachomitum venetum].
Halonitrophilous communities of Black Sea sand beaches, dominated by [Crambe maritima] ssp. [pontica].

Halonitrophilous communities of sand beaches of the southwestern Black Sea coasts of Turkey in Europe and Bulgaria, dominated by [Crambe maritima] ssp. [pontica], with [Lepidotrichum uechtritzianum], [Cakile maritima] ssp. [euxina], [Salsola kali] ssp. [ruthenica], [Euphorbia peplis], [Polygonum maritimum].
Halonitrophilous beach communities of the northwestern Black Sea coasts and the Danube delta, dominated by [Crambe maritima] ssp. [pontica] and [Eryngium maritimum].
Halonitrophilous communities of northern Black Sea and Azov Sea sand beaches dominated by [Crambe maritima] ssp. [pontica].

Halonitrophilous communities of Black Sea sand beaches dominated by [Lactuca tatarica], with [Glaucium leiocarpum], [Glaucium flavum], [Apera spica-venti] ssp. [maritima], [Salsola soda], [Euphorbia peplis].

Halonitrophilous communities of Black Sea sand beaches dominated by [Argusia sibirica] ([Tournefortia sibirica]), with [Cakile maritima], [Salsola soda], [Elymus sabulosus], [Eryngium maritimum], [Gypsophila perfoliata], [Aeluropus littoralis], [Puccinellia distans] ssp. [limosa], [Plantago maritima], [Cynodon dactylon].

Halonitrophilous communities of Black Sea sand beaches dominated by [Petasites spurius] with [Argusia sibirica], [Bromus squarrosus], [Corispermum nitidum], [Lactuca serriola], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Salsola kali] ssp. [tragus], [Eryngium maritimum].

Nombre oficial: Temperate Pacific sand beach annual communities
Definición oficial: Annual communities of driftlines of the temperate and subtropical western Pacific and its connected seas, including those of southern Amurland, Japan, Korea and China.

Perennial halonitrophilous communities of sand, gravelly sand and gravel cordons of upper beaches of the arctic and boreal sea coasts of Eurasia formed by [Leymus arenarius] ([Elymus arenarius]), [Ammophila arenaria], [Honkenya peploides], [Elymus farctus], [Elymus repens], [Mertensia maritima], accompanied by [Atriplex spp.] ([Atriplex prostrata], [Atriplex longipes] ssp. [praecox], [Atriplex glabriuscula]), [Polygonum aviculare], [Cakile maritima], [Cakile arctica], [Petasites spurius], [Potentilla anserina]. Representatives of these communities occur very locally within the nemoral zone.

Nombre oficial: North Sea sand beach perennial communities
Definición oficial: [Leymus arenarius]-dominated perennial halonitrophilous communities of upper beaches of North Sea coasts of southern Norway, Jutland, Schleswig-Holstein, Lower Saxony, the Netherlands, England, Scotland and Orkney, and of the Danish coast of the Kattegat.
[Leymus arenarius]-dominated perennial halonitrophilous communities of southern and central Baltic upper beaches, often with [Petasites spurius].
Perennial halonitrophilous communities of the upper beaches of the Gulf of Bothnia dominated by [Leymus arenarius] and [Festuca rubra] ssp. [arenaria].
Perennial halonitrophilous communities of upper beaches of Iceland dominated by [Leymus arenarius] or [Mertensia maritima].

[Leymus arenarius]-dominated perennial halonitrophilous communities of upper beaches of Iceland, with irradiations in the Faeroe Islands. Accompanying plants include [Honkenya peploides], [Potentilla anserina], [Cakile arctica], [Silene uniflora].

Upper shore communities of Iceland and the Faeroe Islands dominated by [Mertensia maritima], often in almost pure stands, characteristic of gravelly-stoney substrates. They represent an irradiation into the boreal zone of the arctic unit 16.1352.

Perennial halonitrophilous communities of upper beaches of arctic, mostly low arctic, coasts of the Polar Basin, except of those of Iceland, recorded in particular from Greenland, Lapland and Russia, dominated by [Leymus arenarius] or [Leymus mollis], by [Festuca rubra] ssp. [arenaria], or by [Mertensia maritima].

Perennial halonitrophilous communities of upper beaches of the Polar Basin, in particular of Lapland and Greenland, dominated by grasses, notably [Leymus arenarius] or [Leymus mollis] and [Festuca rubra] ssp. [arenaria].

Upper shore communities of arctic shores dominated by [Mertensia maritima], often in almost pure stands. On the arctic coasts of Scandinavia, they form a belt between annual driftline communities and the [Festuca]-[Leymus] formations of unit 16.1351
Perennial halonitrophilous communities of the boreal beaches of the Pacific Basin, including those of southern Amurland, the Kuriles, Sakhaline, Hokkaido, extending to northern Honshu.

Formations of annuals or perennials colonizing sand beaches of the desert coasts of the African Atlantic, of the extreme southeastern Mediterranean, of the Red Sea, of the Arabian Sea and of the Persian Gulf.

Communities colonizing sand beaches of the Sinai and Nile delta coasts of the extreme southeastern Mediterranean dominated by [Cakile maritima] ssp. [aegyptiaca] and [Silene succulenta], sometimes accompanied by [Convolvulus secundus], which may also compose alone a very sparse driftline belt.
Formations of annuals or perennials colonizing sand beaches of the desert coasts of the African Atlantic.

Nombre oficial: Red Sea-Indian Ocean sand beach communities
Definición oficial: Formations of annuals or perennials colonizing sand beaches of the Red Sea, of the Arabian Sea and of the Persian Gulf.

Formations of tropical beaches, comprising herbaceous, shrubby and arborescent communities, in particular those dominated by [Hippomoea pes-caprae], [Sporobolus virginicus], or the ligneous [Scaevola plumieri]. They are restricted, within the Palaearctic zone as here defined, to the southern Mauritanian coast, the Indian Ocean area and the tropical Far East.
Onshore wind-carried sand deposits arranged in cordons of ridges parallel to the coast and often colonised and stabilised by communities of coarse maritime grasses.
Coastal sand dune communities of the desert coasts of the African Atlantic, of the extreme southeastern Mediterranean, of the Red Sea, of the Arabian Sea and of the Persian Gulf.
Coastal sand dune communities of the desert coasts of the extreme southeastern Mediterranean, in the northern Sinai and the Nile delta.

Coastal sand dune communities of the desert coasts of the northern Sinai and the Nile delta, dominated by desert grasses of genus [Stipagrostis] ([Aristida]), in particular [Stipagrostis scoparia] or [Stipagrostis ciliata], or by other species of Saharo-Sindian affinities, accompanied by desert psammophytes.

Nombre oficial: Northern Sinai marram grass coastal dunes
Definición oficial: Coastal sand dune communities of the desert coasts of the northern Sinai dominated by [Ammophila arenaria].

Nombre oficial: Northern Sinai sand couch and silene coastal dunes
Definición oficial: Coastal sand dune communities of the desert coasts of the Nile delta, dominated by Elymus farctus] or by [Silene succulenta], or by both in association.
Coastal sand dune communities of the desert coasts of the African Atlantic.
Coastal sand dune communities of the desert coasts of the Red Sea, of the Arabian Sea and of the Persian Gulf.
Dune communities of tropical coasts of the Palaearctic region.
Mobile sands of the coasts of the boreal, nemoral, steppe, Mediterranean and warm-temperate humid zones, unvegetated or occupied by open grasslands

Formations of the coasts of the nemoral, steppe, Mediterranean and warm-temperate humid zones of the Palaearctic region, representing the first stages of dune construction, constituted by ripples or raised sand surfaces of the upper beach or by a seaward fringe at the foot of the tall dunes.

Embryonic dunes of the Atlantic, south to southern Iberia, of the North Sea and of the Baltic coasts of Denmark, Germany, southern Sweden, Poland, the Baltic States, Russia and southwestern Finland, with [Elymus farctus] ([Agropyron junceum]) accompanied by [Leymus arenarius] in the north, by [Euphorbia paralias] on middle and southern Atlantic shores.

Embryonic dunes of the Mediterranean coasts, on which [Elymus farctus] is accompanied by [Sporobolus pungens], [Euphorbia peplis], [Otanthus maritimus], [Medicago marina], [Anthemis maritima], [Anthemis tomentosa], [Eryngium maritimum], [Pancratium maritimum].
Embryonic dunes of the Mediterranean coasts dominated by [Elymus farctus] ([Agropyron junceum]).
[Elymus farctus] embryonic dunes of southeastern and eastern Iberia, of the Mediterranean coasts of the Maghreb and of Atlantic Africa, south to Safi.

[Elymus farctus] embryonic dunes of Tyrrhenian, Adriatic and Ionian coasts of Europe, from northeastern Iberia to the western Peloponnese, including the east coast of Corsica, and with outposts in northern Algeria, with [Echinophora spinosa] and [Anthemis maritima].
[Elymus farctus] embryonic dunes of Sardinia and the west coast of Corsica, with [Silene succulenta] ssp. [corsica].

[Elymus farctus] embryonic dunes of the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean Levant Basin, with [Diotis maritima], [Eryngium maritimum], [Euphorbia paralias], [Verbascum pinnatifidum], [Cyperus capitatus], [Leymus racemosus] ssp. [sabulosus] ([Elymus giganteus]), of Pontic affinities.
[Elymus farctus] embryonic dunes of arid Mediterranean coasts of North Africa, from Tunisia to the Nile, with [Silene succulenta] ssp. [succulenta].

[Elymus farctus] embryonic dunes of the Atlantic coast of Morocco, between Safi and Agadir, mostly characteristic of the relatively cool coast between Essaouira and Cape Rhir, southernmost outpost of the sand couch dunes, with the Macaronesian [Polycarpaea niveae].

Embryonic dunes of Mediterranean and North African Atlantic coasts dominated by [Sporobolus pungens] ([Sporobolus virginicus] ssp. [arenarius], [Sporobolus arenarius]) most characteristic of the seaward fringes of embryonic dunes on arid coasts.

Embryonic dunes and upper beaches of the Mediterranean coasts, most characteristic of the eastern Mediterranean, dominated by grasses, sedges or dicots of continental steppic, subdesert or subtropical affinities, adapted to the most severe conditions of aridity.

Embryonic dunes and upper beaches of the Mediterranean coasts dominated by [Cyperus capitatus] ([Cyperus kallii]), well developed in particular in the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean, also present, notably, in Italy, on the Maltese Islands, in Languedoc, extinct in the Bouches-du-Rh¿ne.

Embryonic dunes and upper beaches of the eastern Mediterranean, in southwestern Anatolia, Cyprus, the Levant and extreme western Crete, dominated by, or rich in, the subtropical [Ipomoea stolonifera].
Embryonic dunes of the eastern Mediterranean, in particular, of southwestern Anatolia and Cyprus, dominated by [Alhagi mannifera] ([Alhagi maurorum]).
Embryonic dunes of the Aegean dominated by [Leymus racemosus] ssp. [sabulosus] ([Elymus giganteus]), of Pontic affinities.

Formations of Black Sea coasts, transitional between Pontic white dune and driftline communities, characterized by the adjunction to [Elymion gigantei] species assemblies of [Cakile maritima] ssp. [euxina], [Salsola kali] ssp. [ruthenica], [Euphorbia peplis] and other sand beach annual species.
Embryonic dunes of the Pacific basin.
Mobile dunes forming the seaward cordon or cordons of dune systems  of the coasts of the nemoral, steppe, Mediterranean and warm-temperate humid zones of the Palaearctic region.

White dunes of the Atlantic, south to Aquitaine, of the North Sea and of the Baltic coasts of Denmark, southern Sweden, Germany, Poland, the Baltic States and Russia, dominated, when vegetated, by marram grass ([Ammophila arenaria]) accompanied by, among others, [Eryngium maritimum], [Euphorbia paralias], [Calystegia soldanella].

White dunes of the Mediterranean coasts and of the subtropical Atlantic coasts of Iberia and mediterranean North Africa, south to Safi at 32øN, dominated, when vegetated, by the marram grass [Ammophila arenaria] ssp. [arundinacea]  ([Ammophila australis]), accompanied by, among others, [Otanthus maritima], [Echinophora spinosa], [Eryngium maritimum], [Euphorbia paralias], [Cutandia maritima], [Medicago marina], [Anthemis maritima].

[Ammophila arenaria] white dunes of southeastern and eastern Iberia, of the Mediterranean coasts of the Maghreb and of Atlantic Africa, south to Safi at 32øN, where they reach the natural southern limit of marram grass. The range of marram grass dunes has been extended by plantations to Essaouira, at 31øN

[Ammophila arenaria] white dunes of Tyrrhenian, Adriatic and Ionian coasts of Europe, from northeastern Iberia to the western Peloponnese, including the east coast of Corsica, with [Medicago marina], [Echinophora spinosa], [Cutandia maritima], [Anthemis maritima], [Euphorbia paralias].
[Ammophila arenaria] white dunes of Sardinia and the west coast of Corsica, with [Silene succulenta] ssp. [corsica].

White dunes of the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean, for the most part dominated by [Ammophila arenaria], sometimes by species of Pontic or Irano-Turanian affinities, in particular [Leymus racemosus] ssp. [sabulosus] ([Elymus giganteus]).

[Ammophila arenaria] white dunes of the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean, recorded, in particular, from the northern Aegean, the western coasts of Anatolia and from the Levantine coasts, with [Cyperus conglomeratus], [Medicago marina], [Silene succulenta], [Lotus creticus], [Eryngium maritimum], [Diotis maritima].
White dunes of the Aegean dominated by species of Pontic or Irano-Turanian affinities, in particular [Leymus racemosus] ssp. [sabulosus] ([Elymus giganteus]).

White dunes of arid Mediterranean coasts of North Africa, from Tunisia to the Nile, for the most part dominated by [Ammophila arenaria], sometimes by desert grasses of genus [Stipagrostis] ([Aristida]) or [Imperata cylindrica].

[Ammophila arenaria] white dunes of arid Mediterranean coasts of North Africa, from Tunisia to the Nile, with [Silene succulenta], [Euphorbia paralias], [Pancratium maritimum], [Lotus creticus], [Lotus polyphyllos], [Cyperus capitatus], [Launea resedifolia].

Mobile dunes of arid or subdesert coasts of central and eastern North Africa, between Tunisia and Egypt, dominated by desert grasses of genus [Stipagrostis] ([Aristida]), in particular, [Stipagrostis pungens], [Stipagrostis coerulescens], [Stipagrostis scoparia], sometimes associated with [Imperata cylindrica].
[Ammophila arenaria] white dunes of the Atlantic coasts of the Iberin peninsula with [Otanthus maritimus], [Euphorbia paralias], [Polygonum maritimum].

Mobile dunes of the Canary Islands and of the mediterraneo-Saharan coasts of Atlantic North Africa, with [Traganum moquini], [Euphorbia paralias], [Polycarpaea nivea], [Cyperus capitatus], [Ononis natrix], [Convolvulus caput-medusae], [Polygonum maritimum], [Lotus spp.] and the threatened Lanzarote endemic lily [Androcymbium psammophilum].

Mobile dunes of the Black Sea coasts, with [Leymus racemosus] ssp. [sabulosus] ([Elymus giganteus]), [Elymus farctus] ssp. [bessarabicus], [Elymus pycnanthus], [Artemisia tschernieviana], [Eryngium maritimum], [Convolvulus persicus], [Petasites spurius], [Corispermum marschallii], [Lactuca tatarica], [Crambe maritima] var. [pontica], [Cynanchum acutum], [Centaurea arenaria] ssp. [odessana], [Argusia sibirica] ([Tournefortia arguzia]) and, in western formations, [Ammophila arenaria] ssp. [arundinacea], [Euphorbia paralias], [Calystegia soldanella].
Mobile dunes of the Pacific basin.

Young dunes of the arctic and boreal latitudes of the Palaearctic region colonized by halonitrophilous perennial vegetation similar to that of unit 16.13, including [Leymus arenarius] ([Elymus arenarius]), [Ammophila arenaria], [Honkenya peploides], [Elymus farctus] ([Elytrigia juncea]), [Elymus repens], [Mertensia maritima].

Halonitrophilous perennial communities of young dunes of arctic, mostly low arctic, coasts of the Polar Basin, except of those of Iceland, recorded in particular from Greenland, Lapland and Russia, dominated by [Leymus arenarius] or [Leymus mollis], by [Festuca rubra] ssp. [arenaria], or by [Calamagrostis stricta].
Halonitrophilous perennial communities dominated by [Leymus arenarius] colonizing young dunes of the coasts of Iceland, sometimes forming very broad belts, with irradiations in the Faeroe Islands.
Halonitrophilous perennial communities of young dunes of the Bothnian Gulf dominated by [Leymus arenarius] and [Festuca rubra] ssp. [arenaria].
Halonitrophilous perennial communities of young dunes of the boreal coasts of the Pacific Basin.

Fixed or semifixed dunes of the coasts of the boreal, nemoral, steppe, mediterranean and warm-temperate humid zones of the Palaearctic region, with the perennial grasslands, chamaephyte-dotted grasslands, forblands, subshrub or succulent communities that stabilize them and the therophyte communities that may occupy the grassland clearings.

Fixed or semi-fixed dunes of the Canary Islands and of the Saharo-mediterranean zone of the Atlantic coasts of North Africa, between Essaouira and Tan-Tan, dominated by the tall shrubby chenopod [Traganum moquinii] or by dwarf shrubs or subshrubs.

High dunes of the thermo-Atlantic coasts of North Africa and the Canary Islands dominated by the tall shrubby chenopod [Traganum moquinii], with [Suaeda vera], [Atriplex halimus], [Atriplex glauca] var. [ifniensis], [Salsola longifolia], [Salsola vermiculata], limited on the continent to the Saharo-mediterranean zone, between Essaouira and Tan-Tan, mostly characteristic, in the islands, of the centre and east of the archipelago, where they may form extensive systems (jables), penetrating well inland.
Fixed or semi-fixed dunes of the Canary Islands and of the Saharo-mediterranean zone of the Atlantic coasts of North Africa, between Essaouira and Tan-Tan, dominated by dwarf shrubs or subshrubs.
Fixed dunes of the coasts of the Black Sea.
Fixed dunes of the western coasts of the Black Sea, north of the Bosphorus and west of the Dniester.

Fixed dunes of the southwestern coasts of the Black Sea, between the Bosphorus and Cape Caliacra, harbouring the psammophytes [Cionura erecta], [Peucedanum arenarium], [Jurinea albicaulis] ssp. [kilaea], [Silene thymifolia], [Medicago marina], [Secale sylvestre], [Pancratium maritimum], [Convolvulus persicus], [Scabiosa argentea] ([Scabiosa ucranica]), [Euphorbia seguierana] and the Balkan endemic [Lepidotrichum uechtritzianum].
Dunes of the northwestern Black Sea coast, in particular, those associated with the mouth of the Danube.
Formations with [Ephedra distachya] and [Carex colchica] of dry fixed dunes OF the northwestern Black Sea coast, in particular, those associated with the mouth of the Danube.

Formations of windswept fixed dunes oriented perpendicularly to the shore of the northwestern Black Sea coast, in particular, those associated with the mouth of the Danube, dominated by [Alyssum borzaeanum], and [Secale sylvestre], with [Cynanchum acutum] and [Astragalus virgatus] as codominant elements.
Formations of northwestern Pontic dunes dominated by [Scirpus holoschoenus] and [Calamagrostis epigejos], of the more humid situations within fixed dune systems.
Pioneer formations of [Syntrichia ruralise] and [Carex nitida] on fixed dunes of the Danube Delta.
Fixed dunes of the northern and eastern Black Sea coasts, east of the Dniester, southeastwards to the Kuban basin.
Fixed dunes of the southern and southeastern coasts of the Black Sea.
Communities of fixed dunes of the boreal and arctic coasts of Atlantic Eurasia, characterized by the dominance of species of the [Honkenyo-Elymetea] and the presence of arcto-alpine species.

Communities of inner coastal dunes of Iceland, developed on fixed sands. They are for the most part dominated by [Festuca richardsonii] ([Festuca cryophila], [Festuca rubra] ssp. [arctica]), with [Silene uniflora], [Equisetum boreale], [Leymus arenarius], [Armeria maritima], [Potentilla anserina], [Plantago maritima], [Galium verum], [Botrychium lunaria], [Sedum acre], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Erigeron borealis], [Draba incana], [Poa alpina], [Trisetum spicatum], [Carex capillaris], [Myosotis arvensis], [Rhinanthus minor], [Gentiana aurea], [Euphrasia arctica]. They can be invaded and eventually dominated by [Kobresia myosuroides], then supporting communities very similar to those of unit 15.B22, which can be indicated by combination of the two codes.

Communities of fixed dunes of the boreal and arctic coasts of Norway and Russia, with [Leymus arenarius], [Achillea millefolium], [Campanula rotundifolia], [Oxytropis campestris], [Dianthus superbus], [Primula stricta], [Pedicularis septrum-carolinum], [Coeloglossum viride], [Pyrola minor], [Carex maritima], [Juncus arcticus], [Festuca rubra] [s.l.].

Fixed dune communities of Greenland with [Armeria scabra] ssp. [siberica], [Artemisia borealis], [Epilobium latifolium], [Carex maritima], [Calamagrostis purpurescens], [Honkenia peploides], [Leymus mollis].
Fixed dunes of the coasts of the Pacific fa¿ade of Eurasia.

Grasslands of Baltic, North Sea, English Channel and northern Atlantic fixed dunes, including those of the British Isles, the Faeroes, southern Norway, the North Sea and Baltic coasts, the Channel coasts of France.

Calciphile communities of fixed dunes of the North Sea, the English Channel, the north Atlantic and, locally, of the southwestern Baltic, with [Koeleria albescens], ([Koeleria glauca], [Koeleria arenaria]), [Galium verum] var. [maritimum], [Viola curtisii], [Ononis repens], [Festuca rubra], [Festuca polesica], [Anthyllis vulneraria] ssp. [maritima] and moss (e.g. [Tortula ruraliformis]) and lichen carpets.
