Communities of less calcareous or decalcified dunes of the North Atlantic, the English Channel, the North Sea and the Baltic north to southern Norway, northern Jutland, southern Sweden, the Kalinin district and the Gulf of Riga, often rich in [Corynephorus canescens] and [Viola canina].

Short-lived, warmth-loving communities of the dunes of the North Atlantic and its connected seas north to extreme southern Sweden, with [Cerastium diffusum] ssp. [diffusum], [Cerastium diffusum] ssp. [subtetrandrum], [Cerastium semidecandrum], [Erodium lebelii], [Phleum arenarium], [Silene conica].
Fixed dune grasslands infiltrated by dwarf bushes of French Brittany and the coasts of the Bay of Biscay, with [Helichrysum stoechas], [Artemisia campestris], [Ephedra distachya].

Fixed dunes of the western and central Mediterranean and of the thermo-Atlantic coasts of Portugal, southwestern Spain and North Africa, colonized by communities mostly composed of fruticose species, with [Crucianella maritima], [Artemisia crithmifolia], [Armeria pungens], [Armeria welwitschi], [Helichrysum decumbens], [Helichrysum italicum], [Teucrium spp.], [Ephedra distachya], [Pancratium maritimum].

Fixed dunes of the Galician, Lucitanian and Andalusian coasts of the subtropical Atlantic, with [Crucianella maritima], [Iberis procumbens], [Artemisia campestris] ssp. [maritima], [Artemisia crithmifolia], [Armeria welwitchii], [Armeria pungens], [Corema album].

Fixed dunes of the Mediterranean coasts of Spain, France, Tyhrrenian Italy, Corsica, Sardinia and Sicily, with [Crucianella maritima], [Artemisia crithmifolia], [Armeria pungens], [Helichrysum decumbens], [Helichrysum italicum], [Teucrium spp.], [Ephedra distachya], [Pancratium maritimum].

Fixed dunes of the mediterranean Maghreb and northern Atlantic Morocco with [Crucianella maritima], [Teucrium polium] var. [maritimum], [Artemisia campestris], [Calendula suffruticosa], [Lotus creticus].

Coastal dune communities of the Adriatic, the Ionian, the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean, dominated by dwarf shrubs and subshrubs of genera [Ephedra], [Ononis], [Artemisia], and, very locally, [Crucianella], by tall canes or by succulents

Fixed dune communities of the Adriatic coasts of Italy, Istria and Dalmatia, generally without [Crucianella maritima]. Dunal systems are mostly limited to the northeastern Adriatic coasts of Italy, from Ravenna to the northern Gulf of Trieste, with more isolated occurrences in the Otanto, on the north coast of Gargano, around Pescara and Conero, on the island of Rab, around Split, Kastel-Novi, the Neretva estuary and on the Montenegrine coast. Grey dune communities appear to be lacking or poorly developed in most of them, absent, in particular, in the Dalmatian ones. Italian communities, in particular northeastern Italian ones, are dominated by the ligneous, much branched biennial [Scabiosa argentea] var. [alba], with [Euphorbia paralias], [Phleum arenarium], [Silene conica] ssp. [conica], [Silene vulgaris] ssp. [angustifolia] and a more developed bryophyte cover, with [Tortula ruraliformis], then other mediterranean dunes.

Coastal dune communities of the southern Adriatic and Ionian coasts of Albania, of the Ionian coasts of the Hellenic peninsula, of the western Peloponnese, of the Ionian archipelago, dominated by [Ephedra distachya], [Euphorbia terracina], and the otherwise mostly west-Mediterranean [Silene nicaeensis].
Coastal dune communities of the Aegean coasts of continental Greece, Turkey and the archipelagoes, dominated by [Ephedra distachya], [Euphorbia terracina], [Silene conica] ssp. [subconica].

Coastal dune communities of Anatolian, Levantine, Cyprian and North African coasts of the eastern Mediterranean, west to arid Tunisia, dominated by dwarf shrubs and subshrubs of genera [Ononis], [Artemisia], locally associated with [Crucianella], by tall canes or by succulents.

Coastal dune communities of Anatolian, Levantine, Cyprian and North African coasts of the eastern Mediterranean, west to arid Tunisia, dominated by dwarf shrubs of genus [Ononis], in particular, [Ononis natrix] ssp. [hispanica] in southern Anatolia, [Ononis vaginalis] between the Nile and north-east Lybia, [Ononis angustissima] in Tunisia, associated with [Lotus creticus], [Euphorbia paralias], and with canes of unit 16.22443, or, locally, in particular in the Levantine area and Egypt, with [Crucianella maritima].
Coastal rear dune communities of Levantine and northeastern African coasts of the eastern Mediterranean dominated by [Artemisia monosperma], with [Cyperus capitatus].

Nombre oficial: Eastern Mediterranean tall cane dune communities
Definición oficial: Coastal dune communities of North African coasts of the eastern Mediterranean, west to arid Tunisia, dominated by [Imperata cylindrica], associated with elements of unit 16.22441 and sometimes with desert grasses of genus [Stipagrostis] ([Aristida]), in particular, [Stipagrostis pungens], [Stipagrostis coerulescens], [Stipagrostis scoparia].
Semi-fixed dunes of arid or subdesert coasts of central and eastern North Africa, between Tunisia and Egypt, dominated by the chenopodid [Nitraria retusa].
Dunal grasslands, in particular of northern Brittany, rich in species characteristic of dry calcareous grasslands (unit 34.32).

[Geranium sanguineum]-rich forb and grass communities, related to hem formations of unit 34.4, developed within grey dune systems of western Ireland, southwestern England, Wales, Brittany and southwestern Norway.

Sparse pioneer formations of fine grasses rich in spring-blooming therophytes characteristic of oligotrophic, superficial soils in grey dune systems of the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. They are closely related to grasslands of units 35.2 and 35.3.

Nombre oficial: Tethyan dune deep sand therophyte communities
Definición oficial: Therophyte communities of the coasts of the western Mediterranean basin and the subtropical Atlantic colonizing deep sands in clearings of perennial communities of fixed or semi-fixed dune systems, and sometimes deflation depressions of white dunes.

Communities rich in small annuals, often generating an abundant ephemeral spring bloom, with [Malcolmia lacera], [Malcolmia ramosissima], [Evax asterisciflora], [Evax lusitanica], [Anthyllis hamosa], [Linaria pedunculata], of deep sands in dry interdunal depressions of the Mediterranean coasts of Iberia, southern France, Italy, the Maghreb and of the Atlantic coasts of southern Iberia and northern northwest Africa. They are coastal dune representatives of unit 35.4.

Therophyte communities of the Saharo-mediterranean and Macaronesian coasts of the subtropical Atlantic colonizing deep sands in clearings of perennial communities of fixed or semi-fixed dunes and deflation depressions of white dunes, with [Ononis tournefortii], [Cyperus capitatus] ([Cyperus kallii]).

Therophyte communities of shallow, calcareous fixed sands of the coastal dune systems of the Mediterranean basin, coastal dune representatives of unit 34.5. Subdivisions of unit 34.5 can be used to specify the habitat.
[Empetrum nigrum] or [Empetrum hermaphroditum] colonizing dunes of the Arctic Ocean, the North Atlantic, the North Sea and the southern Baltic.
[Empetrum nigrum] heaths occupying decalcified dunes of the North Sea and the southern Baltic
[Empetrum hermaphroditum] heaths colonizing dunes of the northern boreal and arctic coasts of Europe, recorded in particular from northern Norway and Iceland.
[Erica], [Calluna] and [Ulex] heaths colonizing decalcified dunes of France, Iberia, Britain and Scandinavia.

Nombre oficial: East Anglian ling coastal dune heaths
Definición oficial: [Calluna vulgaris]-[Carex arenaria] heaths of inner coastal dunes of East Anglia.
[Calluna vulgaris]-[Carex trinervis] heaths of northern French inner coastal dunes.

Nombre oficial: British bell heather coastal dune heaths
Definición oficial: [Erica cinerea]-[Carex arenaria] heaths of decalcified coastal dunes of the western British Isles, mostly dominated by [Erica cinerea], sometimes by [Calluna vulgaris].

Nombre oficial: French bell heather coastal dune heaths
Definición oficial: [Erica cinerea]-[Festuca vasconcensis] heaths of dry coastal dunes of southwestern France.

Nombre oficial: French Dorset heath coastal dune heaths
Definición oficial: [Erica ciliaris]-[Pseudarrhenatherum longifolium] ([Arrhenatherum thorei]) heaths of more humid coastal dunes of southwestern France.

Nombre oficial: Iberian green heather coastal dune heaths
Definición oficial: [Erica scoparia]-[Ulex parviflorus] ssp. [eriocladus] ([Ulex australis]) heaths of southwestern Iberian coastal dunes, dunal fraction of the thermo-Mediterranean heaths of unit 32.2C1.

Nombre oficial: Iberian Dorset heath coastal dune heaths
Definición oficial: [Erica ciliaris]-[Ulex parviflorus] ssp. [eriocladus] heaths of more humid southwestern Iberian coastal dunes.

Open heathlands of inner coastal dunes of Denmark, of the southern and southeastern Baltic coast, of southern Scania, the Kattegat coast of Sweden, ¿land, Gotland and the land-Archipelago Sea dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], with [Empetrum nigrum], [Carex arenaria], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Hieracium umbellatum], [Lotus corniculatum], [Polypodium vulgare], [Salix repens], and a ground layer constituted mostly by [Dicranum scoparium] and [Pleurozium schreberi].

Nombre oficial: Northern bell heather coastal dune heaths
Definición oficial: Low, open heaths dominated by [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], sometimes with [Juniperus communis], of inner coastal dunes of western Norway and the Faeroe Islands.

Dense formations of large, mostly deciduous, shrubs of nemoral affinities of the coastal dunes and dune-slacks of the boreal, nemoral, steppe, mediterranean and warm-temperate humid zones of the Palaearctic region

Thickets dominated by [Hippophae rhamnoides] ssp. [rhamnoides] colonizing dry or humid dune depressions of the coasts of the North Sea, the eastern English Channel and the southern Baltic, mostly in Denmark, Germany, Poland, the Kalinin district, the Netherlands, Belgium, Northern France and southeastern and eastern England and southeastern Scotland.

Dunal preforest thickets of nemoral affinities of the coastal dunes of the western Palaearctic region formed of species of genera [Ulex], [Sarothamnus], [Rubus], [Ligustrum], [Daphne], [Sambucus]. Codes of subdivisions of unit 31.8 can be used, in addition to unit 16.252, to specify the habitat. Listed elsewhere are dunal formations of heaths (units 16.23, 16.24), sea-buckthorn ([Hippophae rhamnoides], unit 16.251) or creeping willow ([Salix arenaria], unit 16.26).

Dunal preforest thickets of nemoral affinities of the coastal dunes of the eastern Palaearctic region. Codes of subdivisions of unit 31.9 can be used, in combination with unit 16.253, to specify the habitat.
Mats of [Salix arenaria] colonizing dry or humid dune depressions of Atlantic, North Sea, English Channel, Irish Sea and Baltic coasts of western and northwestern Europe.

Juniper heaths and thickets formed by [Juniperus phoenicea], [Juniperus lycia], [Juniperus macrocarpa], [Juniperus transtagana], [Juniperus communis] in dune slacks and on dune slopes of the coasts of the boreal, nemoral, steppe, mediterranean or warm-temperate humid zones of the Palaearctic region.

[Juniperus oxycedrus] ssp. [macrocarpa] thickets and low woods of the outer belt of the juniper woods of fixed Mediterranean and Mediterraneo-Atlantic dunes. Well-developed woods and forests are placed in unit 16.29, with the habitat specified by unit 42.A92 (16.29 x 42.A92).

[Juniperus phoenicea] ssp. [lycia] thickets of the inner belt of the juniper woods of fixed Mediterranean and Mediterraneo-Atlantic dunes. Well-developed woods and forests are placed in unit 16.29, with the habitat specified by unit 42.AA12 (16.29 x 42.AA12).
Scrubs of the fastigiate [Juniperus oxycedrus] ssp. [transtagana] of the dunes of southwestern Portugal.
[Juniperus communis] scrubs of the calcareous dunes of northwest Jutland.

Dune thickets of the coasts of Sakhalin, Hokkaido, Honshu, Kyushu, formed by the prostrate [Juniperus conferta], and of Kyushu and the Bonin Islands, dominated by the spreading, procumbent [Juniperus procumbens].

Sclerophyllous, lauriphyllous or drought-deciduous scrubs, thickets and brushes established on dunes of the mediterranean or warm-temperate humid regions of the Palaearctic region. Codes of subdivisions of units 32, 33 or 15.9 may be used in addition to 16.28 to specify the habitat.

Sclerophyllous, lauriphyllous or drought-deciduous scrubs, thickets and brushes established on dunes of the mediterranean or warm-temperate humid regions of the Palaearctic region. Codes of subdivisions of units 32 and 33 may be used in addition to 16.28 to specify the habitat.

Tall sclerophyllous, lauriphyllous or drought-deciduous thickets and brushes established on dunes of the mediterranean or warm-temperate humid regions of the Palaearctic domaine. Codes of subdivisions of units 32.1, 32.2, 32.31, 32.32, 32.37, 32.8, 32.A, 32.D may be used in addition to 16.28 to specify the habitat.

Low sclerophyllous scrubs established on dunes of the mediterranean or warm-temperate humid regions of the Palaearctic domaine. Codes of subdivisions of units 32.2, 32.3, 32.4, 32.5, 32.8, 32.9, 32.B, 32.C, 32.D or 15.9 may be used in addition to 16.283 to specify the habitat.

Cushion-forming thermo-mediterranean sclerophyllous formations, often thorny and summer deciduous, established on dunes of the mediterranean regions of the Palaearctic, or of their regions of transition towards deserts. Codes of subdivisions of unit 33 may be used in addition to 16.284 to specify the habitat.

Dunes of the coasts of the boreal, nemoral, steppe, mediterranean and warm-temperate humid zones of the Palaearctic region, colonised by woodland or riparian thickets. Codes of units 41.5, 41.7, 42, 44, 45 can be used, in addition to that of unit 16.29, to specify the habitat.

Humid depressions of the coastal dunal systems of the Palaearctic region. The most important habitats are included in the subordinate units. If the divisions proposed are not sufficient, appropriate codes from units 22.4, 22.3, 54.2, 54.4, 53 can be used in conjunction with them. Humid dune-slacks are extremely rich and specialized habitats, very threatened by the lowering of water tables.
Fresh-water aquatic communities (cf. unit 22.4) of permanent dune-slack water bodies of the Palaearctic region.
Pioneer formations of humid sands and dune pool fringes of the Palaearctic region, on soils with low salinity

Calcareous and, occasionally, acidic fen formations of coastal dune-slacks of the Palaearctic region (cf. units 54.2, 54.4, in particular units 54.21, 54.2H, 54.49), often invaded by creeping willow, occupying the wettest parts of dune-slacks.

Humid grasslands and rushbeds (units 37.218, 37.21F, 37.31, 37.4 [i.a.]), wet heaths and swamp-heaths (unit 31.112 [i.a.]) of dune-slacks of the Palaearctic region, also often with creeping willows ([Salix rosmarinifolia], [Salix arenaria]).
Reedbeds, tall-sedge communities and canebeds (cf. units 53.1, 53.2, 53.3, 53.6) of dune-slacks of the Palaearctic region.
Beaches of the oceans, of their connected seas and of their associated coastal lagoons, covered by pebbles, or sometimes boulders, usually formed by wave action.

Shingle beaches devoid of phanerogamic vegetation of the Palaearctic region. Codes of mediolittoral (intertidal) and supralittoral invertebrate communities listed under unit 11.28 can be combined with code 17.1 to record detailed habitats.

Nombre oficial: Shingle beach drift lines and pioneer swards
Definición oficial: Very open formations of annuals or, particularly in Mediterranean, and mostly East Mediterranean, representatives, of annuals and perennials, occupying accumulations of drift material and gravels rich in nitrogenous organic matter

Beach and upper beach formations, mostly of annuals of the low Arctic and high Arctic oceanic zones of the Palaearctic Atlantic, Pacific and Arctic oceans, occupying accumulations of drift material and gravels rich in nitrogenous organic matter

Formations, predominantly of annuals, occupying accumulations of drift material and gravels rich in nitrogenous organic matter on nemoral and boreonemoral beaches of the Atlantic, the North Sea and the Baltic

Very open, low formations of annuals and perennials of Mediterranean, thermo-Atlantic and Black Sea gravel and shingle beaches, occupying accumulations of drift material, sandy gravels and gravels rich in nitrogenous organic matter

Formations of perennials or annuals occupying accumulations of drift material and gravels rich in nitrogenous organic matter on shingle beaches of the Pacific Basin, including those of southern Amurland, the Kuriles, Sakhaline.

Halonitrophilous perennial communities of the upper beach of the great shingle bars of temperate seas, characteristic in particular of northwestern Europe, mostly formed by [Crambe maritima], [Honkenya peploides] and a few specialized species characteristic of regional entities.

Perennial communities of the shingle beaches and bars of the southern Baltic, east to Mecklenburg, where they are represented by fragmentary, endangered formations, of the Swedish, Finnish and Estonian coasts and islands of the land-Gotland basin, of the coasts of the Kattegat, the Oresund and the Baelts, dominated by [Crambe maritima], with [Leymus arenarius] ([Elymus arenarius]), [Euphorbia palustris], [Honkenya peploides], [Angelica archangelica] ssp. [litoralis], [Atriplex spp.], [Beta vulgaris] ssp. [maritima], [Elymus repens], [Geranium robertiana] ssp. [rubricaule], [Glaucium flavum], [Isatis tinctoria], [Ligusticum scoticum], [Mertensia maritima], [Silene vulgaris] ssp. [maritima] ([Silene uniflora]), [Tripleurospermum maritimum], [Valeriana salina].

Perennial communities of the shingle beaches and bars of the southern North Sea and Channel coasts of southeastern England and, very locally, the Channel coast of France, dominated by [Crambe maritima], with [Lathyrus japonicus] and [Honkenya peploides].

Perennial communities of the shingle beaches and bars of Brittany, the Cotentin peninsula and Anglesey, dominated by [Crambe maritima], with [Crithmum maritimum] and a sparse representation of other nitrophiles, in particular, [Beta vulgaris] ssp. [maritima], [Matricaria maritima], [Rumex crispus], [Glaucium flavum], [Solanum dulcamara] var. [maritima], [Sonchus oleraceus], [Galium aparine].

Nombre oficial: Gravel bank heaths, scrubs and grasslands
Definición oficial: Grasslands, scrubs and heaths of the landward expanses of large coastal gravel banks of the Palaearctic region.
Dense perennial grasslands of boreal and nemoral coastal gravel banks of the Palaearctic region, in particular, swards of [Arrhenatherum elatius] of large Channel gravel banks.
Low heaths of boreal and nemoral coastal gravel banks of the Palaearctic region, in particular, prostrate [Cytisus scoparius] formations of large Channel gravel banks.

Nombre oficial: Tethyan gravel bank scrubs and heaths
Definición oficial: Relatively closed or closed, stable, communities of shrubs, subshrubs, forbs or grasses colonizing landward expanses of large coastal gravel banks of the Mediterranean, the subtropical Atlantic and the Black Sea, related to grey dune, garrigue, maquis or phrygana communities. Codes of units 16.22, 32 or 33 can be used to define communities.

Dense formations of large shrubs of coastal gravel banks of the Palaearctic region, in particular, thermo-mediterranean brushes of Mediterranean gravel banks. Codes from units 31.8, 32.2 can be used to specify habitats.

Gravel banks of the coasts of the Palaearctic region, colonised by woodland or riparian thickets, in particular, Mediterranean gravel banks colonized by [Quercus ilex] low woods, by [Tamarix africana] or [Vitex agnus-castus] formations. Codes of units 32.1, 41, 42, 44, 45 can be used, in conjunction with that of unit 17.6, to specify the habitat.

Rock exposures adjacent to the oceans, their connected seas and associated coastal lagoons, or separated from them by a narrow shoreline. The faces, ledges and caves of sea-cliffs and the expanses of rocky shore are important as reproduction, resting and feeding sites for seabirds, sea-mammals and a few groups of terrestrial birds, composing regionally distinct assemblies listed under unit 18.1. The presence of major sea-caves can be indicated by addition of codes of unit 12.7. Sea-cliffs may also harbour highly distinctive, specialized aerohaline plant communities with associated terrestrial faunas, listed under unit 18.2. Other terrestrial plant communities may belong to units 62, 61, 31, 32, 33, 34. The mediolittoral (intertidal or wave-washed) and supralittoral (spray) zones are inhabited by rich and diverse communities of invertebrates, fish and algae that have been listed under unit 11.29.

Palaearctic hard rock sea-cliffs, their faces, ledges and associated caves, rocky shores and isolated seaside rocks, their associated seabird, sea mammal, wader and, in a few cases, terrestrial passerine, communities. The presence of vascular aerohaline vegetation should be indicated by use of the appropriate code from unit 18.2, that of mediolittoral (intertidal or wave-washed) and supralittoral (spray) zone communities of marine invertebrates, lower vertebrates and algae, by use of codes from unit 11.29. Less salt-influenced communities, in particular of units 62, 61, 31, 32, 33, 34, may contribute to the colonisation of the cliffs.

Nombre oficial: Temperate Pacific sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs and rocky shores of the southern Kuriles, Honshu, Hokkaido, Shikoku and continental Korea.

Nombre oficial: Subtropical Pacific sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs and rocky shores of peninsular Korea, the Yellow Sea, the East China Sea, Kyushu, the Ryukyu Islands.

Nombre oficial: Tropical Pacific sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs and rocky shores of the South China Sea.

Nombre oficial: High Arctic sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs and their associated features, rocky shores and isolated seaside rocks of the High Arctic seas bordering middle and northern Greenland, Spitzbergen, Franz Josef Land, Novaya Zemlya, Severnaya Zemlya, the New Siberian Islands, Wrangel Island and the northern Siberian mainland from the north coast of the Yamal peninsula eastwards. Together with floating ice (unit 11.5), they constitute the main hauling-out places for [Odobenus rosmarus]. [Fulmarus glacialis], [Larus glaucoides], [Larus hyperboreus], [Cepphus grylle], [Plautus alle], [Uria lomvia], [Branta bernicla] are among characteristic bird species.

Nombre oficial: Atlantic Low Arctic sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs, cliff-faces, ledges and caves, rocky shores and isolated seaside rocks of the Low Arctic region of the North Atlantic and the Arctic Ocean, in southern Greenland, Iceland, Jan Mayen, Bear Island, northern Scandinavia, northwestern mainland Russia, southern and middle Novaya Zemlya. They constitute the principal breeding, resting or feeding areas of multitudes of seabirds and sea-mammals during at least part of the year.

Nombre oficial: Temperate Atlantic sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs, their faces, ledges and associated caves, rocky shores and isolated seaside rocks of the Atlantic temperate region, including the North Sea, the English Channel, the Irish Sea and the Bay of Biscay, along the coasts of Scandinavia south of the Arctic Circle, of the Faeroes, of the British Isles and their outlying archipelagoes, of mainland Europe south to Galicia. They are the breeding, resting or feeding places of great numbers of seabirds and sea-mammals, of which [Halichoerus grypus], [Sula bassana], [Uria aalge], [Alca torda], [Rissa tridactyla], [Phalacrocorax aristotelis aristotelis] are characteristic.
Sea-cliffs, their faces and ledges, rocky shores and isolated seaside rocks of the Baltic Sea.

Nombre oficial: Subtropical Atlantic sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs, their faces, ledges and associated caves, rocky shores and isolated seaside rocks of the subtropical zone of the Atlantic, including the Canary Islands, Madeira, the Azores, the Mediterraneo-Atlantic coasts of Iberia, the Mediterraneo-Atlantic and Saharo-Atlantic coasts of Africa, south to Cap Blanc. A major zone of upwelling developed along the north African coast and the Canary Islands enhances their value as important breeding and resting places for marine birds and mammals. Their caves harbour the two remaining Atlantic subpopulations of the gravely endangered Monk Seal [Monachus monachus], endemic to this region and the next, those of  Madeira and of the Cap Blanc coasts. [Calonectris diomedea borealis], [Larus cachinnans atlantis], [Phalacrocorax carbo maroccanus], [Phalacrocorax aristotelis riggenbachi] are sea-birds endemic to the region for which cliffs and rocky shores provide an important breeding habitat.

Sea-cliffs, their associated faces, ledges and caves, rocky shores and isolated rocks of the Mediterranean Sea and the Black Sea. The endangered [Monachus monachus] depends on their caves for reproduction. [Calonectris diomedea diomedea], [Puffinus yelkouan mauretanicus], [Puffinus yelkouan yelkouan], [Phalacrocorax aristotelis desmarestii], [Falco eleonorae], [Larus audouinii] are characteristic breeders. Their vascular aerohaline communities, as well as the rock communities of unit 62 that colonize their less salt-influenced reaches, are particularly diverse and rich in endemics. They are indicated by combination of appropriate units of 18.2 and/or 62 with unit 18.16.

Nombre oficial: Tropical Atlantic sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs, their faces, ledges and associated caves, rocky shores and isolated seaside rocks of the tropical zone of the Atlantic, including the Cape Verde Islands and the southern coast of Mauritania, along which extends the major upwelling zone of the Canary Current. Tropical seabirds such as [Phaethon aethereus], [Sula leucogaster], [Phalacrocorax carbo lucidus] are characteristic. [Calonectris edwardsii] is endemic.

Sea-cliffs and rocky shores of the tropical Indian Ocean and its connected seas, comprising, in the Palaearctic region as here defined, those of the Red Sea, of the Arabian peninsula coast of the Gulf of Aden, of Socotra, of the Arabian Sea, of the Gulf of Oman and of the Persian Gulf. A major area of upwellings developed along the southern coast of the Arabian peninsula and Socotra inhances their importance as breeding sites for sea-birds. [Bulweria fallax], [Puffinus persicus], [Phalacrocorax socotranus], [Larus leucophthalmus], [Larus hemprichii] are endemic or near-endemic species of the region which do or may use sea-cliffs or rocky shores as breeding sites.

Nombre oficial: Pacific Low Arctic sea-cliffs and rocky shores
Definición oficial: Sea-cliffs and rocky shores of the Chukchi Sea, the Bering Strait, the Bering Sea, the Commander Islands, Kamchatka, the northern and central Kuriles, the Sea of Okhotsk and the Tatar Straits, harbouring an exceptionally rich community of alcids, gulls and cormorants, in particular.

Nombre oficial: Sea-cliff and rocky shore aerohaline communities
Definición oficial: Palaearctic sea-cliffs, or parts of sea-cliffs, and rocky shores colonized by disjunct assemblages of aerohaline chasmophytes or by more or less closed aerohaline grasslands with associated terrestrial invertebrate and vertebrate faunal communities.
Vegetated cliffs of the northern Atlantic, the English Channel, the Irish Sea, the North Sea, the Baltic Sea, the Arctic Ocean and its seas, the northwest Pacific and its seas.

Vegetated cliffs of the nemoral middle Atlantic, the English Channel, the Irish Sea and the North Sea, along the coasts of Iberia, France, Ireland, England, Wales, southern Scotland and Helgoland, colonized by relatively thermophile communities variously formed by [Crithmum maritimum], [Armeria maritima], [Armeria pubigera], [Limonium occidentale], [Limonium ovalifolium], [Brassica oleracea] ssp. [oleracea], [Silene vulgaris] ssp. [maritima], [Plantago maritima], [Festuca rubra] ssp. [pruinosa], [Daucus carota] ssp. [gummifer], [Daucus carota] ssp. [gadecaei], [Matricaria maritima], [Asplenium marinum], [Spergularia rupicola], [Inula crithmoides], [Sedum anglicum], [Lavatera arborea], [Frankenia laevis], [Anthyllis vulneraria] ssp. [corbierei], [Anthyllis vulneraria] ssp. [iberica], [Dactylis glomerata] ssp. [marina].

Vegetated cliffs of the northern Atlantic, the northern North Sea, the Baltic, the Arctic Ocean and its seas, the Bering Sea, the Sea of Okhotsk, the northern and western Sea of Japan colonized by relatively cryophile communities.

Usually open, lacunar, relatively cryophile, moderately nitrophile aerohaline communities of sea-cliffs of the northern Atlantic and northern North Sea coasts of Scotland, the Faeroe Islands, Iceland and Scandinavia, mostly dominated by [Cochlearia officinalis], [Silene vulgaris] ssp. [maritima] ([Silene uniflora]), [Matricaria maritima], [Festuca rubra] ssp. [pruinosa], with [Armeria maritima], [Plantago maritima], [Cochlearia groenlandica], [Cochlearia fenestrata], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Poa pratensis], [Ligusticum scoticum], [Cerastium fortanum], [Rhodiola rosea], [Plantago maritima], [Sedum acre], [Asplenium marinum].

Uncommon, species-poor, often [Cochlearia officinalis]-dominated, communities occupying wet, shadowy recesses near the foot of cold, shaded cliffs in southwestern Britain and Brittany constitute extralimital, highly specialized representatives of unit 18.2121.
Species-rich, nitrophile, meadowlike or tall-herb communities colonizing seabird nesting cliffs of the northern Atlantic and the northern North Sea.
Species rich, nitrophile, often meadowlike communities of broad rock ledges and clifftops of the west coast of Norway, Iceland, the Faeroe Islands, characteristic of sites with seabird colonies

Luxuriant, nitrophile tall-herb communities of rock fissures and ledges of sea-cliffs occupied by seabirds, of Norway, southwest Sweden and the Faeroe Islands, dominated by [Angelica archangelica], [Anthriscus sylvestris], [Rumex acetosa], [Silene dioica], [Rhodiola rosea], [Achillea milletolium], with [Silene vulgaris] ssp. [maritima] ([Silene uniflora]), [Valeriana sambucifolia], [Viola tricolor], [Oxyria digyna], [Cochlearia officinalis], [Ligusticum scoticum], [Matricaria perfoliata], [Festuca rubra].

Vegetated cliffs of the Baltic Sea, with [Silene vulgaris] ssp. [maritima] ([Silene uniflora]), [Ligusticum scoticum], [Armeria maritima], [Odontites litoralis] ssp. [litoralis], [Odontites litoralis] ssp. [fennica], [Matricaria maritima], [Senecio viscosus].
Vegetated cliffs of the Arctic Ocean and its seas, the Bering Sea and the Sea of Okhotsk.
Vegetated cliffs of the northern and western Sea of Japan.
Vegetated cliffs of the southern and eastern Sea of Japan, the Yellow Sea, the northern East China Sea and the temperate West Pacific.
Vegetated cliffs and rocky shores of the Mediterranean, of the Black Sea and of the subtropical eastern Atlantic.

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of the Mediterranean, as well as of the southwestern Iberian and northwestern African Atlantic, with [Crithmum maritimum], [Plantago subulata], [Silene sedoides], [Sedum litoreum], [Limonium spp.], [Armeria spp.], [Euphorbia spp.], [Daucus spp.], [Asteriscus maritimus]. Mediterranean sea-cliffs harbour numerous endemics of of extremely local occurrence, in particular, of genus [Limonium], which comprises at least 43 and probably closer to 120-150 Mediterranean cliff species species, many of them restricted to a few stations, and several threatened, such as, for instance, [Limonium remotispiculum] of southern Italy and [Limonium strictisissimum] of Corsica and Caprera.

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of the Svilaja and Biokovo coasts of Dalmatia, between the Zrmanj and the Neretva estuaries, and of the islands of the Dalmatian archipelago from Silba to Hvar.

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of the Ragusan coast of extreme southern Croatia, from the Peljesac peninsula southwards, the coast of Montenegro and the southeastern islands of the Dalmatian archipelago, including the Mljet, Korcula, Elafiti archipelagoes, with [Limonium anfractum].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Albania, mostly limited to the southern, Keravnes, coast, western peninsular Greece, the western Peloponnese and the Ionian archipelago, with [Limonium anfractum] and [Limonium cancellatum], [Limonium oleifolium] ssp. [oleifolium].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Aegean Greece, Aegean Turkey, the Aegean archipelagoes, Crete, Karpathos and Rhodes, with [Limonium oleifolium] ssp. [oleifolium], [Limonium aucheri], [Limonium frederici], [Limonium hyssopifolium], [Limonium pigadiense], [Limonium sieberi], [Limonium sinuatum], [Centaurea huljakii], [Malcolmia flexuosa], [Sedum atratum], and a number of narrow endemics, including [Limonium graecum], [Limonium carpathum], [Limonium sitiacum].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Mediteranean southern Turkey, Cyprus, the Levant and Cyrenaica, with [Limonium oleifolium] ssp. [oleifolium], [Pancratium maritimum], [Frankenia pulverulenta], [Senecio joppensis].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Tunisia, Algeria, Mediterranean Morocco, Melilla, Ceuta and the islands of the Sea of Alboran, with [Limonium gougetianum], [Limonium minutiflorum], [Limonium oleifolium], [Limonium spatulatum], [Limonium virgulatum], [Limonium aspagoides] and [Limonium gummiferum] of northwestern Algeria, [Limonium zembrae] of Zembra Island, [Brassica radicata], [brassica scopulorum], [Crithmum maritimum], [Asplenium marinum].
Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Atlantic Morocco, south to 27øN, with [Limonium mucronatum], [Chenolea tomentosa], [Polycarpaea nivea].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of southern Portugal and southwestern Spain, north to Extremadura and east to Punta Marroqui, including, in particular, the large cliff systems of Cape San Vicente in Algarve, and of Barbate in Andalucia, with [Limonium algarvense], [Limonium emarginatum], [Limonium virgatum] ([Limonium oleifolium]), [Limonium ovalifolium], [Limonium auriculae-ursifolium].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Gibraltar, eastern peninsular Spain and its nearshore islands, Roussillon, with [Limonium malacitanum], [Limonium cossonianum], [Limonium furfuraceum], [Limonium virgatum], [Limonium gibertii], [Limonium girardianum], [Limonium dufourei], [Limonium tremolsii], [Armeria ruscinonensis].
Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of the Balearics, with [Limonium caprariense].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Provence and Liguria, and their nearshore islands, with [Limonium minutum], Provence endemic and [Limonium cordatum], Proven¿o-Ligurian endemic.

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Sardinia, Corsica, the Toscan archipelago and Mte. Argentario, in an area of very high endemism of sea-cliff colonisers, in particular, of genus [Limonium], with [Limonium hermaeum], [Limonium lausianum], [Limonium dictyocladum], [Limonium articulatum], [Limonium dolcheri], [Limonium tibulatium], [Limonium acutifolium], [Limonium obtusifolium], [Limonium nymphaeum], [Limonium tenuifolium], [Limonium herculis], [Limonium planesiae], [Limonium savianum], [Limonium gorgonae], [Limonium multiformae], [Limonium argentarium], [Limonium sommierianum], [Limonium trojae], [Limonium dianum], [Limonium ilvae], [Limonium divaricatum], [Limonium racemosum], [Limonium dictyocladum], [Limonium virgatum] var. [majus], [Limonium lausianum].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of the Circaeo peninsula, the Gulf of Gaita, the Gulf of Naples, the Sorrento peninsula, the Gulf of Salerno and their associated archipelagoes, an area of high endemism of genus [Limonium], with [Limonium joannis], [Limonium pontium], [Limonium pandatariae], [Limonium circaei], [Limonium amynclaeum], [Limonium remotispeculum], [Limonium inarimense], [Limonium tenoreanum], [Limonium virgatum] var. [majus].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Calabria, Sicily, the Lipari Islands, the Egadi Islands, Pantelleria, Linosa, Lampedusa and the Maltese Islands, an area including several centers of radiation of endemic sea-lavenders, with [Limonium parvifolium], [Limonium cosyrense], [Limonium bocconei], [Limonium syracusanum], [Limonium flagellare], [Limonium ponzoi], [Limonium tenuiculum], [Limonium minutiflorum], [Limonium calabrum], [Limonium ionicum], [Limonium furnarii], [Limonium tauromenitanum], [Limonium albidum], [Limonium panormitanum], [Limonium lopadusanum], [Limonium hyblaeum], [Limonium intermedium], [Limonium mazarae], [Limonium divaricatum], [Limonium zeraphae], [Limonium virgatum] var. [majus], [Limonium sibthorpianum].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Calabria, northeastern Sicily and the Lipari Islands, with [Limonium minutiflorum], [Limonium calabrum], [Limonium ionicum], [Limonium tauromenitanum], [Limonium sibthorpianum].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of western Sicily, Ustica and the Egadi Islands, with [Limonium bocconei], [Limonium flagellare], [Limonium ponzoi], [Limonium tenuiculum], [Limonium furnarii], [Limonium panormitanum], [Limonium mazarae].
Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Pantelleria, with [Limonium parvifolium], [Limonium cosyrense].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of southeastern Sicily and the Maltese Islands, with the sea-lavenders [Limonium syracusanum], [Limonium hyblaeum], [Limonium zeraphae], and with the Maltese endemics [Anthemis urvilleana], [Allium lojaconoi], the Hybleo-Maltese endemics [Desmazeria pignattii] and [Senecio pygmaeus].
Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of the Pelagian archipelago (Lampedusa, Linosa, Lampione), with [Limonium albidum], [Limonium lopadusanum], [Limonium intermedium].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of Puglia, the Gargano, the Tremiti Islands and the Adriatic coast of central Italy, with [Limonium peucetium], [Limonium cancellatum], [Limonium virgatum] var. [majus].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs and rocky shores of the Triestine Karst, Istria, the Velebit coast south to the Zrmanja estuary, and the Quarnero islands (Kvarner islands) of Krk, Cres, Rab, Losinj, Pag, with [Limonium cancellatum] and [Plantago scopulorum].
Communities of the cliffs of the Black Sea, the Sea of Azov and the Sea of Marmara.

Communities colonizing sea-cliffs of the western Black Sea coast, including both typical hard-rock tall cliff communities, restricted to Cape Kaliakra and the maritime fa¿ade of the Istranca-Stranja, and more widespread low-cliff formations, related to sand beach communities.

Herbaceous aerohaline communities of the sea-cliffs of the maritime fa¿ade of the Stranja and of the Cape Kaliakra area of Bulgaria, with [Limonium gmelinii], [Goniolimon collinum], [Crithmum maritimum], [Elymus pycnanthus], [Cichorium intybus], [Atriplex hastata], [Kochia prostrata], [Melilotus officinalis], [Convolvulus lineatus] and the local endemic [Silene caliacrae].
Thickets of [Ficus carica] and [Ulmus minor] of the cliffs of the western Black Sea coast.

Low cliffs and neighbouring sands of the southern Romanian Black Sea coast (between Constanta and Vama Veche), harbouring communities dominated by [Scolymus hispanicus] and [Ecbalium elaterium], with [Atriplex tatarica], [Xanthium spinosum], [Lactuca saligna], [Lolium perenne] and [Polygonum aviculare].

Aerohaline communities of the cliffs of the northern Black Sea and the Sea of Azov, with [Crithmum maritimum], [Kochia prostrata], [Elymus farctus] ssp. [bessarabicus], [Holosteum umbellatum], [Puccinellia distans], [Limonium meyeri].
Aerohaline communities of the cliffs of the southern coasts of the Black Sea.

Aerohaline communities of the sea-cliffs of the Canaries and Madeira, with [Crithmum maritimum], [Astydamia latifolia], [Schizogyne sericea], [Andryala glutinosa], [Plantago coronopus], [Tolpis fruticosa], [Aizoon canariense], [Campylanthus salsoloides], [Limonium pectinatum], [Frankenia ericifolia], [Reichardia ligulata], [Argyranthemum frutescens], [Lotus spp.], [Asplenium marinum].
Communities of the sea-cliffs of the Azores dominated by the endemic [Festuca petraea].
Aerohaline communities of the sea-cliffs of the Cape Verde Islands.
Aerohaline communities of the sea-cliffs of the coastal desert zone of northwest Africa.
Aerohaline communities of the sea-cliffs of the Saharo-Sindian subtropical desert regions, along the Red Sea, the Arabian Sea and the Persian Gulf.

Nombre oficial: Tropical sea-cliff and rocky shore communities
Definición oficial: Aerohaline communities of the sea-cliffs and rocky shores of tropical regions.  [Sesuvium portulacastrum], [Philoxerus vermicularis], [Sporobolus virginicus] are characteristic. These communities are only represented, within the Palaearctic Region as here defined, along the west coast of Africa, in the Indian Ocean region and in the tropical Far East.

Communities of vascular chasmophytes and animals colonizing the cliffs of coastal saline or hypersaline bodies of water of the Palaearctic region, listed here only when they differ very significantly from the cliff communities of unit 18.2.
Endemic [Limonium secundirameum]-dominated formations of the cliffs overlooking Bagno dell Acqua, Pantelleria.

Halocalcareous cliff communities of coastal lagoons of the Black Sea at Cape Dolosman (Romania), dominated by [Artemisia santonicum], [Limonium gmelinii], [Halimione verrucifera] ([Obione verrucifera]) and [Lepidium cartilagineum], with Irano-Turanian species such as [Camphorosma annua], [Halocnemum strobilaceum], [Leuzea salina] and [Taraxacum bessarabicum].

Sea-cliffs composed of relatively soft, unconsolidated or incompact mineral particle deposits, carved by wind and wave action, of the Palaearctic region. They often support a vegetation of dune shrubs (units 16.25, 16.26, 16.27), notably, [Hippophae rhamnoides], [Salix arenaria], [Sorbus aucuparia].

Nombre oficial: Islets, rock stacks, reefs, banks, shoals
Definición oficial: Permanently emerging, periodically uncovered, surface-breaking or near-surface raised features of the oceans, their connected seas and coastal waters, with their associated marine and terrestrial communities. The associated marine habitats can be coded by combining subdivisions of prefix 11 with the relevant physiographic subdivisions of 19, the terrestrial habitats by adding codes from units 3 and 4.
Small islands in the sea or coastal waters of the Palaearctic region, mostly important as sites for seabird colonies.

Palaearctic lithogenic reefs, raised rocky features of the continental shelf and its inshore waters, covered by shallow water or reaching and breaking the surface, or uncovered by tides or strong wave action.

Palaearctic spits, barrier beaches, barrier islands, tombolos, features formed of sands and gravels deposited by longshore drift in narrow ridges attached to the land at one end and extending into the sea at the other, or separated from land by channels and lagoons, or linking an offshore island to the coast.
Deposits of muds, sands or gravels of the continental shelf permanently covered by shallow (banks), or very shallow (shoals), water of the Palaearctic region.

Organogenic features of oceans, seas or coastal waters, formed by coral, coral sands and other coral derivatives, with a crest often rising just above low spring tide level. Characteristic of clear, warm tropical waters, they are limited within the Palaearctic region, as here defined, to the Red Sea, the Persian Gulf, the Arabian Sea, the Ryukyu Islands, Taiwan, the Pescadores, Hainan, the Gulf of Tong king and the South China Sea islands.
Coral reefs bordering the land, forming close inshore on rocky coastlines by the growth of corals and associated hydrozoans, alcyonarians and calcareous algae.
Coral reefs separated from the land by lagoons.
Annular coral reefs formed round subsiding volcanic islands, sometimes interrupted by channels, enclosing a lagoon.
Elevated features of the floor of the oceans and their connected seas (unit 11.214) raising close enough to the surface to create neritic conditions.
All inland and landlocked waters of natural origin, standing or flowing, saline, brackish or fresh, and the aquatic or amphibious, nonmarine, communities associated with them

Saline or hypersaline waters of the vicinity of the oceans and their connected seas, often formed from sea inlets by silting and cut off from the sea by more or less effective obstacles such as sand or mud banks. The presence of benthic marine invertebrate communities or vegetation can be indicated by combination of codes from units 11.2, 11.3 or 11.4 with the relevant physiographic subdivisions of unit 21
Coastal lagoons incompletely closed off from the sea, communicating with it through a channel or channels, such as those between barrier islands or around or through a barrier beach.
Coastal lagoons closed off from the sea, without communicating channels sufficient to allow significant water passage.
Coastal water bodies fed by the seeping of sea water.
Water bodies separated from the sea by sills or sluices that regulate their communication, often limiting it to entry by waves, high tides or storms.
Water bodies of the interior of atolls
Small islands in large coastal bodies of saline water, mostly important as sites for waterbird colonies. Associated terrestrial habitats can be indicated by addition of codes from units 3 and 4.

Lakes, ponds and pools of natural origin containing fresh ([i.e]. nonsaline) or slightly brackish water. Seminatural aquatic communities occupying manmade freshwater bodies, including artificially created lakes, reservoirs and canals.
Freshwater lakes, ponds, pools, or parts of such freshwater bodies, in which water is permanently retained, although its level may fluctuate
Lakes and pools with greenish to brownish clear waters, poor in dissolved bases (pH often 5-6).
Lakes and pools with waters fairly rich in dissolved bases (pH often 6-7).
Lakes and pools with mostly dirty grey to blue-green, more or less turbid, waters, particularly rich in dissolved bases (pH usually > 7).
Lakes and pools with acidic waters of high humus content and often brown tinted (pH often 3-5).
Lakes and pools with mostly blue to greenish, very clear, waters, poor (to moderate) in nutrients, base-rich (pH often > 7.5).
Lake-bottom animal, green algal or lower algal communities.

Freshwater lakes, ponds, pools, or parts of such freshwater bodies, which become periodically dry, with their associated animal, green algal or lower algal pelagic (units 22.21 - 22.25) and benthic (units 22.26, 22.27) communities. The macrophytic-based amphibious communities that may colonize them are separately listed under unit 22.3, terrestrial communities that may develop during their dry phase under unit 22.5, drawdown resistant euhydrophyte communities under unit 22.2, fringing belts or island rafts of rooted or floating tall emergent vegetation under unit 53. Permanently or almost permanently emerged features supporting terrestrial communities influenced by the presence of the water body are included in unit 22.6.  Grasslands, shrublands and woodlands which may at times be inundated but in which semicontinuous formations of grasses, shrubs or trees emerge at all times above the standing water surface are listed under units 37, 3A, 44 and 4A, not under unit 22.2.
Temporary lakes and pools with greenish to brownish clear waters, poor in dissolved bases (pH often 5-6).
Temporary lakes and pools with waters fairly rich in dissolved bases (pH often 6-7).
Temporary lakes and pools with mostly dirty grey to blue-green, more or less turbid, waters, particularly rich in dissolved bases (pH usually > 7).
Temporary lakes and pools with acidic waters of high humus content and often brown tinted (pH often 3-5).
Temporary lakes and pools with mostly blue to greenish, very clear, waters, poor (to moderate) in nutrients, base-rich (pH often > 7.5).

Unvegetated lake-bottoms or lake-shores temporarily exposed by artificial or natural fluctuations of the water level, often important as feeding grounds for migrating waders. Unvegetated lacustrine beaches, formed by wind or wave action.
Benthic communities developed in the wet phase of the cycle of temporary lakes and pools.

Macrophytic communities of the Palaearctic adapted to an alternance of emergence and complete submersion, colonizing lake bottoms or lake shores subjected to temporary exposure (unit 22.2) and other periodically or occasionally inundated muddy, sandy or stony basins. They include communities of annuals developing during the exposure phase as well as communities of perennials susceptible of temporary total immersion. Communities of prostrate plants adapted to alternances of floating on shallow water and creeping on wet muds are listed under unit 22.432, as shallow water floating communities.

Carpets of perennial vegetation submerged for a considerable part of the year in oligotrophic or mesotrophic lakes, ponds and pools of the boreal and nemoral zones of the Palaearctic and of mountains of the southern Palaearctic.

Nombre oficial: Shoreweed lawns, lobelia ponds, quillwort swards
Definición oficial: [Littorella uniflora], [Lobelia dortmanna] and [Isoetes spp.] formations of oligotrophic waters of the boreal and nemoral zones of the Palaearctic and of mountains of the southern Palaearctic.
Dense, almost monospecific [Littorella uniflora] lawns of lake shores subject to great annual variations of the water level and long emergence, and other [Littorella]-dominated associations.
[Lobelia dortmanna] colonies of shallow oligotrophic, moderately acid ponds.

Clear-water quillwort swards formed by the northern European and montane [Isoetes lacustris] and [Isoetes echinospora] or by the very local endemics [Isoetes tenuissima] of central western France and [Isoetes brochonii] of the eastern Pyrenees. Associated species may include [Lobellia dortmanna], [Sparganium angustifolium], [Littorella uniflora], [Hippuris vulgaris].

[Sparganium angustifolium]-dominated formations of small oligotrophic ponds, characteristic, in particular, of the upper montane and subalpine levels of the Alps and of the greater Hercynian ranges, locally recorded from sub-Atlantic heath regions of the Germano-Baltic plain, also capable of occurring, within the extensive Fennoscandian range of the species, and in coastal areas of Iceland, as a facies of the [Isoetes] communities of unit 22.3119.

Amphibious communities dominated by [Ranunculus reptans] and [Subularia aquatica] colonizing, sometimes on large surfaces, the bottom of water bodies of Fennoscandia, Iceland and the Faeroe Islands, mostly in situations characterized by relatively large fluctuations of the water level.

[Ranunculus reptans]-[Subularia aquatica] amphibious communities of Fennoscandian woodland water bodies with relatively large fluctuations in the water level. [Ranunculus reptans]-rich variants of unit 22.312, distributed in northern continental Europe and the Alpine periphery constitute a transition towards this nordic unit.

[Ranunculus reptans]-[Subularia aquatica] amphibious flag communities of the lowlands of Iceland and the Faeroe Islands, with [Littorella uniflora], [Alopecurus aequalis] ssp. [natans], [Ranunculus hyperboreus], [Ranunculus aquatilis] var. [diffusus].

Flag communities colonizing fine material deposits of low arctic and northern boreal lakes and ponds of the Palaearctic region, known in particular from Iceland, the Faeroes and Greenland, with [Koenigia islandica], [Sagina nodosa], [Sagina procumbens], [Montia fontana], [Cerastium fontanum], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Equisetum arvense], lakeshore and wet flat eqivalent of the flowing water-linked communities of unit 24.54.

Oligotrophic pool and pool fringe communities of the northern Palaearctic dominated by [Myriophyllum alterniflorum], characteristic of weakly acid clear waters on limestone-free substrates, sometimes with [Ranunculus reptans], [Littorella uniflora].
[Eleocharis acicularis] beds of the Palaearctic, characteristic of more organic soils and mesotrophic waters than the communities of unit 22.311.

[Eleocharis multicaulis], [Scirpus fluitans], [Juncus bulbosus], [Hypericum elodes], [Pilularia globulifera], [Deschampsia setacea], [Ranunculus flammula], [Littorella uniflora] communities of shallow acid pools of the Palaearctic and their margins susceptible to short periods of emersion.
Oligotrophic pool fringe communities of the western Palaearctic dominated by [Eleocharis multicaulis], [Deschampsia setacea].
Communities of humid sands and pool fringes in oligotrophic dunes of the Atlantic, the North Sea and the southern Baltic, with [Samolus valerandi] and [Littorella uniflora].

Oligotrophic pool fringe communities of western and central Europe, north to Denmark and southern Fennoscandia, east to Poland, the Czech Republic and the Balkan peninsula, dominated by the fern [Pilularia globulifera].
Oligotrophic pool fringe communities of sub-Atlantic Europe dominated by [Juncus bulbosus], often accompanied by [Ranunculus flammula], [Agrostis canina], [Glyceria fluitans].

Pool fringe communities dominated by [Scirpus fluitans] ([Eleogiton fluitans], [Isolepis fluitans]), characteristic of mesotrophic to dystrophic heath pools on sands or muds, particularly within the [Quercion] domaine, with periods of drying usually short, sometimes permanently inundated.

Pool fringe communities of western and central Europe dominated by [Apium inundatum], characteristic of oligotrophic to mesotrophic fluctuating pools, in particular, dune slack pools and forest pools.

Communities of the shores of shallow oligotrophic pools of the Atlantic domaine of Europe susceptible to prolonged summer dessication, usually developed on peaty or parapeaty soils, dominated by, or rich in [Baldellia ranunculoides], with [Hydrocotyle vulgaris], [Hypericum helodes]. They are recorded, in particular, from the Paris Basin, Normandy, the New Forest, Cornwall, southern Scandinavia, and, on the shores of of limestone pools, in the Burren of western Ireland.
[Deschampsia littoralis] agg. formations of peri-Alpine lakes.
[Deschampsia littoralis] swards of the shores of Lake Geneva and of a few lakes of the southern Alpine periphery (Lago di Poschiavo, Lago di Cavazzo).

Amphibious hairgrass swards of Lake Constance, formed by the endemic, endangered, [Deschampsia rhenana], also harbouring [Myosotis rehsteineri], very local, endangered, [Ranunculus reptans], local, gravely threatened, and [Armeria purpurea], near-endemic, gravely threatened, extinct in Switzerland.
Dwarf oligomesotrophic annual communities of recently emerged muds and sands of the nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal regions of the western and central Palaearctic.

Rare communities colonising the fluid muds of drying ponds of nemoral, boreonemoral, boreal, and, locally, steppic, Palaearctic Eurasia, characterised by [Eleocharis ovata], [Eleocharis carniolica], [Carex bohemica], [Lindernia procumbens], [Scirpus supinus], [Limosella aquatica], [Cyperus fuscus], [Peplis portula], [Juncus tenageia], [Elatine hexandra], [Elatine hydropiper], and [Coleanthus subtilis]

Pioneer formations of humid calcareous sands of Atlantic and sub-Atlantic Europe, recorded from the North Sea coasts of northern France, Belgium, the Netherlands, England, Germany and Denmark, and from the Baltic coast of Germany, with [Samolus valerandi], [Centaurium littorale], [Centaurium erythraea], [Centaurium pulchellum], [Gentianella amarella], [Blackstonia perfoliata], [Juncus bufonius], characteristic of humid dune slacks and dune pool fringes, on soils with low salinity.

Associations, often very limited in extent, appearing in the drying phase of temporary pools, flooded ruts of forest paths, wet heath paths, humid forest cuts, seeping mowed lawns and other sufficiently lit temporarily inundated, most often acidic, soils of nemoral, boreonemoral, boreal, and, locally, steppic, Palaearctic Eurasia, characterised by [Juncus bufonius], [Scirpus setaceus], [Cyperus flavescens], [Centunculus minimus], [Spergularia segetalis], [Centaurium pulchellum], [Blackstonia perfoliata], [Samolus valerandi], [Cicendia filiformis], [Radiola linoides] and [Illecebrum verticillatum].

Communities of temporary pools, flooded ruts of forest paths, and other sufficiently lit temporarily inundated or moist soils of nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal Palaearctic Eurasia dominated by [Juncus bufonius].
Medio-European communities dominated by the annual galingales [Cyperus flavescens], [Cyperus fuscus] and [Cyperus michelianus].
Varied communities, some very rare and threatened, of small annuals of wet ground of nemoral and boreonemoral Palaearctic Eurasia.

Taller annual communities colonizing nitrogen-rich muds of dry ponds and lakes of the boreal and nemoral zones of the Palaearctic, and locally of the Eurasian steppe zone, formed by [Bidens spp.], [Rorippa palustris], [Rorippa islandica], [Chenopodium spp.], [Polygonum spp.], [Rumex maritimus], [Rumex palustris], [Ranunculus sceleratus], [Senecio congestus], [Catabrosa aquatica], [Leersia oryzoides].
Perennial and annual communities of mediterranean, thermo-Atlantic and Macaronesian temporary ponds, river banks and spring sides.

Formations of Mediterranean, thermo-Atlantic and Macaronesian entirely or partially summer-dry ponds, pools and ditches with [Isoetes spp.], [Marsilea quadrifolia], [Marsilea strigosa], [Pilularia globulifera], [Pilularia minuta], [Mentha pulegium], [Lythrum hyssopifolia] [s.l.], [Trifolium filiforme], [Peplis erecta], [Teucrium cravense], [Serapias lingua], [Juncus bufonius], [Juncus capitatus], [Juncus pygmaeus], [Juncus fasciculatus], [Scirpus savii], sometimes (rocky edges of fast rivulets), [Spiranthes aestivalis] and [Anagallis tenella].
Formations of temporarily inundated or wet terrain, dominated by spike-rushes ([Eleocharis palustris]), accompanied by small annual herbs and grasses.
[Isoetes histrix], [Isoetes durieui] formations of Mediterranean ephemeral waters.
Communities formed by [Isoetes boryana], [Isoetes delilei], [Isoetes heldreichii], [Isoetes velata], [Isoetes azorica] or [Isoetes malinverniana] in fluctuating waterbodies.
Endemic [Isoetes azorica] communities of pools and small lakes of the Azores.
Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic formations dominated by [Cyperus fuscus], [Cyperus flavescens] or [Cyperus michelianus].
Formations dominated by [Fimbristylis bisumbellata], often with [Cyperus spp.], in particular, [Cyperus flavescens].
Formations dominated by [Chaetopogon fasciculatus].
Formations of the sandy, rocky edges of rivulets of the Mediterranean region.

Formations of Mediterranean temporarily inundated or wet terrain, including karstic pools, often highly ephemereal, dominated by annual small herbs, among which [Elatine spp.] ([Elatine macropoda], [Elatine gussonei], [Elatine pedunculata]), [Damasonium bourgaei], [Nananthea perpusilla], [Morisia monanthos], [Blackstonia perfoliata], [Samolus valerandi], [Radiola linoides], [Myosurus minimus], [Laurentia gasparrinii], [Laurentia tenella].

Formations of the Mediterranean basin occupying temporarily inundated or wet terrain, dominated by small club-rushes of section [Isolepis] ([Scirpus setaceus], [Scirpus pseudosetaceus], [Scirpus cernuus]).

Formations of Mediterranean and thermo-Atlantic entirely or partially summer-dry ponds, pools, ditches and springs, developed on terrain covered by deep waters during long periods, composed of an admixture of small annuals and of tall perennials or annuals, in particular, of genera [Mentha] ([Mentha cervina], [Mentha longifolia]) and [Eryngium] ([Eryngium corniculatum]).
Slighly halophile and nitrophile post-estival vegetation of temporarily inundated terrains, with [Crypsis schoenoides], [Crypsis aculeata], [Crypsis alopecuroides] and [Centaurium spicatum].

Meso-hygrophile grasslands of crystalline Provence, with [Carex divisa] ssp. [chaetophylla], often dominant, [Briza minor], [Oenanthe lachenalii] and numerous [Serapias] species ([Serapias lingua], [Serapias neglecta], [Serapias vomeracea]).

Annual dwarf sedges, rushes and [Elatine spp.] communities of recently emerged muds and sands, characteristic of the Pannonic plain, the Black Sea lowlands and adjacent areas of the Balkan peninsula, outside of the Mediterranean influence. Communities of units 22.321 and 22.323 occur locally in the same region.

Communities of nitrogen-rich muds and inundation zones of watercourses and lakes of the western central Eurasian steppe and presteppe zones, in particular of Pannonic and sub-Pannonic plains and hills, with [Cyperus fuscus], [Cyperus flavescens], [Cyperus michelianus] ([Dichostylis michelianus]), [Juncus bufonius], [Echinochloa crus-galli], [Filaginella uliginosa] ([Gnaphalium uliginosum]), [Elatine hungarica], [Ammannia verticillata].

Communities of rice field muds and of river and lake inundation zones of the western central Eurasian steppe and pre-steppe zones, distributed in particular in the Pannonic region, Russia, the Balkans and central Asia, with [Elatine hungarica], [Elatine triandra], [Eleocharis acicularis], [Scirpus supinus], [Lindernia procumbens], [Peplis portula], [Marsilea quadrifolia].

Communities of the western central Eurasian steppe and presteppe zones, extending from Pannonic and sub-Pannonic plains and hills to the Caucasus, developed on clayey, nitrogen-rich saline or somewhat saline soils. Characteristic species include [Lythrum hyssopifolia], [Lythrum tribracteatum], [Lythrum linifolium], terrestrial forms of [Elatine alsinastrum], [Elatine triandra], [Elatine hydropiper], [Elatine hungarica], [Mentha aquatica], [Hippuris vulgaris] and crowfoots of subgenus [Batrachium].
Fresh water amphibious communities of the tropics, the subtropical desert belt and of warm-temperate humid eastern Asia.

Communities of permanent or semipermanent fresh or slightly brackish lakes, ponds, pools or canals of the Palaearctic realm formed by free-floating, floating-leaved rooted, or submerged macrophytes and their associated epiphytic biocoenoses. Tall emergent-dominated formations, rooted in the substratum or constituting soil-retaining floating islands, are excluded and listed in unit 53.
Free-floating surface communities of more or less nutrient-rich waters of the Palaearctic realm.
Free-floating surface communities of duckweed ([Lemna], [Spirodela], [Wolffia]), small ferns ([Azolla]) or liverworts ([Riccia], [Ricciocarpus]) of  Palaearctic waters.
Free-floating surface communities of Palaearctic waters rich in [Hydrocharis morsus-ranae].
Free-floating communities of Palaearctic waters dominated by [Stratiotes aloides].
Free-floating communities of more or less nutrient-rich Palaearctic waters dominated by bladderworts ([Utricularia australis], [Utricularia vulgaris]).
Free-foating communities of Central and Eastern Europe dominated by the free-floating nonindigenous fern [Salvinia natans], often forming dense and extensive mats.

Rare aquatic formations of Central and Eastern Europe, dispersed from southern Brandenburg and Lake Constance east to the Ukraine, with a former outpost in eastern Lithuania, harbouring the carnivorous, free-floating Droseraceae [Aldrovanda vesiculosa].
Colonies of the free-floating, rosette-forming [Pistia stratiotes] of tropical and subtropical regions of the southern Palaearctic.

Formations of the introduced Neotropical [Eichornia crassipes] established in seminatural situations, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions of the southern Palaearctic, locally in west-central Portugal.
Formations of Palaearctic water bodies constituted by submerged, rooted, perennial phanerogams with often emerging flower spikes, in particular entirely immersed pondweeds of genus [Potamogeton].
Associations of large pondweeds ([Potamogeton lucens], [Potamogeton praelongus], [Potamogeton zizii], [Potamogeton perfoliatus]) characteristic of deep, open Palaearctic waters.

Formations of smaller pondweeds, in particular, [Potamogeton crispus], [Potamogeton filiformis], [Potamogeton pusillus], [Potamogeton obtusifolius], [Potamogeton berchtoldii], [Potamogeton trichoides], [Potamogeton acutifolius], [Potamogeton pectinatus], [Potamogeton nitens], [Potamogeton friesii] ([Potamogeton mucronatus]), [Groenlandia densa], waterthymes and waterweeds ([Elodea spp.], [Hydrilla spp.], [Ottelia spp.]), horned pondweeds ([Zannichellia palustris] [s.l.]), naiads ([Najas spp.]), tapegrass ([Vallisneria spiralis]), water crowfoots ([Ranunculus circinatus]) that colonize shallower, more sheltered Palaearctic waters. Eurasian formations dominated by usually free-floating hornworts of genus [Ceratophyllum], in particular by [Ceratophyllum demersum], are included because of closer ecological and physiognomic similarity with communities of this unit than with those of unit 22.41.

Submerged pondweed beds of Palaearctic waters dominated by small pondweeds of genera [Potamogeton] and [Groenlandia], in particular, [Potamogeton crispus], [Potamogeton filiformis], [Potamogeton pusillus], [Potamogeton obtusifolius], [Potamogeton berchtoldii], [Potamogeton trichoides], [Potamogeton acutifolius], [Potamogeton pectinatus], [Potamogeton nitens], [Potamogeton friesii] ([Potamogeton mucronatus]), [Groenlandia densa].
Submerged pondweed beds of Palaearctic waters dominated by waterthymes and waterweeds of genera [Elodea], [Hydrilla], [Ottelia] or by tapegrass ([Vallisneria spiralis]).
Submerged pondweed beds of Palaearctic waters dominated by naiads ([Najas spp.]).
Submerged pondweed beds of Palaearctic waters dominated by horned pondweeds ([Zannichellia palustris] [s.l.]).
Submerged pondweed beds of Palaearctic waters dominated by water crowfoots ([Ranunculus circinatus]).
Submerged pondweed beds of Palaearctic waters dominated by usually free-floating hornworts of genus [Ceratophyllum], in particular by [Ceratophyllum demersum].
Formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by rooted aquatic plants with floating leaves.

Formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by rooted aquatic plants with large floating leaves, often with a stratum of submerged species ([Ceratophyllum], [Myriophyllum], [Potamogeton]) and occasionally free-floating [Utricularia spp.], characteristic of large, permanent water bodies.
Floating-leaved formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by magnonymphaeids of family Nymphaeaceae, in particular of genera [Nymphaea], [Nuphar], [Euryale].
Floating-leaved formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by magnonymphaeids of genus [Nuphar], in particular [Nuphar pumila] and [Nuphar lutea], characteristic of temperate and cold regions.
Dense communities of the large thick-leaved [Nuphar lutea] characteristic of nutrient-rich waters of ponds, lakes and canals with depths up to 4 metres.

Relict communities of arctic-continental distribution mostly characteristic of relatively oligotrophic acid ponds surrounded by, or adjacent to, bogs or woods, dominated by small-leaved [Nuphar spp.], mostly [Nuphar pumila] or [Nuphar intermedia], often accompanied by [Potamogeton natans].

Floating-leaved formations of boreal, temperate and Mediterranean Palaearctic waters dominated by magnonymphaeids of genus [Nymphaea], in particular [Nymphaea alba], [Nymphaea candida], [Nymphaea tetragona], [Nymphaea pygmaea].
Formations of [Nymphaea lotus] of geo-thermal waters (unit 66.94) of Petea Lake, western Romania.
Formations of [Nymphaea lotus], [Nymphaea caerulea], [Nymphaea maculata] of the subtropical desert belt of the Palaearctic region and of the Sahel.
[Nymphaea] formations of warm-temperate humid, subtropical and tropical regions of the Far Eastern Palaearctic.
Large-leaved [Euryale ferox] formations of China.
Floating-leaved formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by the trapid [Trapa natans].
Floating-leaved formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by magnonymphaeids of genus [Nymphoides], in particular by [Nymphoides peltata] or [Nymphoides indica].
Floating-leaved formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by the parvonymphaeid [Potamogeton natans].
Floating-leaved formations of Palaearctic waters dominated by the parvonymphaeid [Polygonum amphibium].
Formations of [Nelumbo nucifera], occurring in the Volga delta and from the south Caspian lowlands to the Far East, with a naturalized population in Romania.
Aquatic formations of the boreal zone dominated by species of genus [Sparganium] with long, strap-like floating leaves.
Aquatic formations of oligotrophic boreal woodland and mire lakes of Fennoscandia, Russia, the Baltic States and Belarus dominated by [Sparganium gramineum], with 1- to 2-metre long floating leaves.

Aquatic formations of mesotrophic small, shallow heath and mire lakes of low alpine and northern lowland regions of Iceland, dominated by [Sparganium hyperboreum], with 10- to 20-cm long floating leaves.

Communities of Palaearctic waters dominated by water starworts ([Callitriche]), water crowfoots ([Ranunculus spp.], subgenus [Batrachium]) or water violet ([Hottonia palustris]), characteristic mostly of shallow waters with fluctuating water levels, susceptible to occasional drying.

Communities dominated by water crowfoots, [Ranunculus peltatus], [Ranunculus aquatilis], [Ranunculus trichophyllus] ([Ranunculus confervoides], [Ranunculus aquatilis] var. [diffusus]), [Ranunculus baudotii], [Ranunculus hederaceus], [Ranunculus rionii], [Ranunculus ololeucos], [Ranunculus omiophyllus] ([Ranunculus lenormandi]), [Ranunculus tripartitus], with both submerged and floating leaves, characteristic mostly of shallow Palaearctic waters with fluctuating water levels, susceptible to occasional drying. Crowfoot- dominated communities of unit 22.433 are included.
Communities of shallow stagnant Palaearctic waters with fluctuating water levels, susceptible to drying, dominated by [Callitriche spp.]
Communities of shallow Palaearctic waters dominated by [Hottonia palustris].

Sparse formations of narrow-leaved floating pondweeds, in particular, [Potamogeton polygonifolius] ([Potamogeton oblongus]), [Potamogeton gramineus], [Potamogeton alpinus], with [Callitriche spp.], [Ranunculus ololeucos], [Ranunculus omiophyllus], [Ranunculus tripartitus], [Luronium natans], [Sparganium minimum], [Apium inundatum] of shallow, oligotrophic, clean, fluctuating, but usually permanent, often small, waterbodies of the Palaearctic region. Communities of this unit often form in close proximity to those of unit 22.313 and evolve into them with regular or prolonged dessication.

Charophyte (genera [Chara], [Nitella], [Tolypella], [Nitellopsis], [Lamprothamnium], [Lychnothamnus]) algal carpets of the bottom of unpolluted, oligotrophic to mesotrophic lakes and pools of the Palaearctic region.
Charophyte carpets developed on the bottom of basic, lime-rich, unpolluted, oligotrophic to mesotrophic, lakes and pools of the Palaearctic region, formed mostly by species of genus [Chara].

Charophyte carpets developed on the bottom of unpolluted basic, lime-rich, oligotrophic to mesotrophic, deep, permanent waterbodies of the Palaearctic region, formed by, in particular, [Chara aspera], [Chara hispida], [Chara tomentosa], [Chara fragilis], [Chara strigosa], [Chara intermedia], [Nitellopsis obtusa], [Tolypella glomerata]. Many of the diverse communities formed by these species have a highly fragmented, relict range and are severely threatened.
Charophyte carpets developed in shallower, often ephemereal pools of the Palaearctic region, formed by [Chara vulgaris], [Tolypella intricata], [Tolypella prolifera].

Charophyte carpets developed on the bottom of unpolluted acid, neutral or slightly basic, lime-poor, oligotrophic to mesotrophic, lakes of the Palaearctic region, mostly formed by species of genus [Nitella].

Charophyte carpets developed on the bottom of unpolluted, slightly acid to neutral, lime-poor, oligotrophic or dystrophic, lakes and pools of oceanic and suboceanic lowland and collinar regions of the Palaearctic region, formed by, in particular, [Nitella gracilis], [Nitella capillaris], [Nitella flexilis], [Nitella translucens], [Chara braunii], [Chara fragifera], [Chara delicatula]. Many of the diverse communities formed by these species have a highly fragmented, relict range and are severely threatened.

Charophyte carpets developed on the bottom of unpolluted, neutral to slightly basic, oligotrophic to mesotrophic, lakes and pools of the Palaearctic region, mostly characteristic of premontane and moraine areas in zones of contact between siliceous and calcareous substrates, formed by, in particular, [Nitella opaca], [Nitella mucronata], [Nitella syncarpa], [Nitella tenuissima], [Nitella hyalina], [Chara coronata], [Tolypella prolifera], sometimes accompanied by the chrysophyte alga [Vaucheria dichotoma] of class Xanthophyceae. Many of the diverse communities formed by these species have a highly fragmented, relict range and are severely threatened.

Floating, in part infra-aquatic, formations of [Sphagnum spp.], [Scorpidium scorpioides], [Utricularia minor], [Utricularia intermedia], [Utricularia ochroleuca], [Utricularia bremii], [Sparganium minimum], of dystrophic, oligotrophic or sometimes mesotrophic, bog pools, fen pools, heath pools, woodland ponds of the Palaearctic region.

Floating formations of [Sphagnum spp.] ([Sphagnum auriculatum], [Sphagnum contortum], [Sphagnum cuspidatum], [Sphagnum fallax], [Sphagnum inundatum], [Sphagnum subsecundum], [Sphagnum crassicladum], [Sphagnum rufescens]), [Utricularia minor], [Utricularia ochroleuca], of dystrophic or oligotrophic, lime-poor bog pools, acid fen pools, heath pools, woodland ponds of the Palaearctic region.

Floating formations of brown mosses ([Scorpidium scorpidioides], [Calliergon stramineum], [Calliergon giganteum], [Calliergon trifarium], [Calliergon cordifolium], [Campylium stellatum], [Drepanocladus aduncus], [Drepanocladus revolvens], [Drepanocladus intermedius], [Drepanocladus exannulatus]), [Utricularia minor], [Utricularia intermedia] of basic, neutral or weakly acid, oligotrophic or sometimes mesotrophic, often lime-rich, fen pools, transition mire pools and ponds of the Palaearctic region.

Rare aquatic formations of Atlantic and sub-Atlantic Palaearctic dystrophic to mesotrophic, basic to mildly acid, rich fen, transition mire and heath pools, dominated by the rooted, floating-leaved [Sparganium minimum], usually accompanied by [Utricularia intermedia], sometimes by [Potamogeton polygonifolius], [Potamogeton gramineus], [Juncus bulbosus], [Littorella uniflora].

Terrestrial communities colonizing the bottom of waterbodies that are completely and recurrently emptied of water for part of the time, such as Irish turloughs. The characteristics of each stage of the cycle can be defined by use of codes of units 22.1, 22.2, 22.3, 22.4, and, if appropriate, those of units 37, 38, 53, 54, or 8.
Permanently or usually emergent features of the bed or shores of permanent or temporary freshwater lakes or ponds.

Permanent or almost permanent ice formations of lakes, constituting continuous ice sheets that may cover the entire surface for all of the year or recede to part of the lake during summer and be accompanied or replaced by floating ice blocks, rafts and hummocks. They may, locally, seasonally or permanently, extend to the whole depth of the lake. They are characteristic of high latitude and high altitude lakes.

Athalassal decidedly brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, pools and ditches, their features, their associated pelagic and benthic communities, their beds of macrophytic submerged or offshore vegetation. Included are the large inland seas, in particular, the Caspian Sea, the Aral Sea, the Dead Sea.

Athalassic, permanent or temporary, brackish, saline or hypersaline waterbodies and their associated animal, charophyte, green algal or lower algal pelagic and benthic communities. The macrophytic, euhydrophytic based communities that colonize them are separately listed under 23.2, the macrophytic amphibious communities and the terrestrial communities that may develop during dry phases or in drying and dried portions under 15, fringing belts or island rafts of rooted or floating tall emergent vegetation under 53.

Nombre oficial: Salt basins and salt basin pelagic communities
Definición oficial: Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools and their pelagic animal, green algal or lower algal communities, including marine mammal, bird and pelagic fish communities of the large inland seas of central Eurasia and of the big brackish lakes of the boreal zone.

Nombre oficial: Boreal, nemoral and arctic salt lakes
Definición oficial: Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools of the boreal, nemoral and arctic zones, including, in particular, the great brackish lakes of northern Europe (Ladoga), the ponds and pools associated with the inland salt communities of unit 15.4 and the waterbodies adjacent to the Yakutian salt steppes of unit 15.A7.

Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools of the Mediterranean zone, with major waterbodies limited to northern-central and southern Iberia, Sicily and Mediterranean North Africa.
Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools of the Pannonic and Ponto-Sarmatic regions, associated with the salt steppes and salt marshes of 15.A1 and 15.A2.

Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools of the Aralo-Caspian and Kazakh steppe and desert regions, including the Caspian Sea, the Aral Sea, Lake Balkash, Issyk Kul, Lake Tengiz, Ala Kul, Lake Zayzan and many other large or small waterbodies.
Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools of of the East Asian steppe and desert regions.

Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools of the Irano-Anatolian steppe and cold desert regions, including Tuz Golu, Lake Van, Lake Urmia and the great temporary khevirs of central Iran, as well as many smaller waterbodies.

Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline permanent or temporary lakes, ponds or pools of the subtropical desert belt and its transitions to the Mediterranean regions, including the great North African chotts, the Dead Sea, and many lesser waterbodies.
Athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools of sub-Saharan Africa and the tropical Far East.
Charophyte (mostly [Chara spp.]) formations of athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools.
Benthic animal, green algal or lower algal communities of permanent athalassic brackish, saline or hypersaline lakes, ponds or pools
Unvegetated bottoms or shores of athalassic saline water bodies temporarily exposed by artificial or natural fluctuations of the water level, often covered with salt efflorescences.
