Communities of athalassic brackish or saline lakes, ponds, pools or basins, formed by submerged, floating-leaved, or slightly emergent macrophytes and their associated zoocoenoses.
Communities of athalassic brackish or saline lakes, ponds, pools or basins, formed by submerged macrophytes and their associated zoocoenoses.

[Ruppia maritima], [Zannichellia spp.] and [Najas spp.] beds, with associated [Potamogeton pectinatus], [Potamogeton crispus] and other submerged macrophytes, of athalassic brackish or saline lakes, ponds, pools or basins.
[Zostera noltii] formations of the Caspian Sea.
Emergent [Eleocharis parvula] or [Eleocharis acicularis] formations of brackish lakes and inland seas, their inlets, estuaries, lagoons, mud or sand flats, and other inland brackish waterbodies.

Communities of brackish lakes, ponds and pools, formed by free-floating or floating-leaved rooted macrophytes, in particular, brackish [Lemna] and [Wolffia] carpets, brackish [Callitriche] communities and formations of inland lakes and basins of very low salinity dominated by water crowfoots such as [Ranunculus baudotii] or [Ranunculus rionii].
Permanently or usually emergent features of inland seas and of permanent or temporary saline lakes or ponds.
Beaches of inland seas and of large saline lakes, formed by wind or wave action.
Estuaries formed by rivers emptying into inland seas and large saline lakes.
All rivers and streams, permanent or temporary, fresh or saline, including rivers, streams, brooks, rivulets, rills, torrents, wadis or oueds, waterfalls, cascades and rapids.

Flowing water courses of the Palaearctic region, permanent or temporary, and their associated animal and microscopic algae pelagic and benthic communities. Rivers, streams, brooks, rivulets, rills, torrents, wadis or oueds, waterfalls, cascades and rapids are included. The macrophytic, euhydrophytic communities that colonize them are separately listed under unit 24.4. Features of the river bed, uncovered by low water or permanently emerging, such as gravel, sand, mud or rock islands and bars are listed under units 24.2, 24.3, 24.5 and 24.6. The macrophytic amphibious communities and the terrestrial communities that may develop on them are listed under the relevant sections when specific to watercourses, are otherwise indicated by codes from units 15, 22.3, 3 or 4. The fringing belts of tall or short emergent vegetation are listed under unit 53, the spring vegetation under unit 54.1, the riverside veils of tall herbs and lianas under unit 37.71, riverine arbustive and arborescent vegetation under unit 44. The subdivisions of this unit are based on slope, width and water temperature, according to usual ichthyological practice. Classifications based on flora, such as that of Holmes (1983) for British streams, give broadly similar results. For each of the divisions below, subdivisions can be introduced to take into account regional characteristics, as well as the morphodynamics of the stream, as proposed, for instance, by Malavoi (1989).

Gushing springs (rheocrenes), spring basins (limnocrenes), seepages (helocrenes) and crenal streams, rivulets formed in and near the source area of streams, characterized by high stability of temperature, near the annual average of the ground water, best developed in mountain situations. The presence of specialized vegetation associated with the spring is indicated by use of divisions of unit 54.1.

Upper and middle reaches of Palaearctic mountain streams (Gebirgsbach, alpine, mountain and upland streams), characterized by turbulent, irregular flow, by diurnal and annual temperature variations higher than in the crenon, and, by aquatic biocoenoses largely dominated by Turbellaria, Ephemeroptera, Plecoptera, Trichoptera, Diptera, by Bryophyta and epilithic Bacillariophyta, Cyanophycaea, Rhodophyta and Chlorophyta algae, with few, specialized, immerged macrophytes (unit 24.3). The unit corresponds to the Trout zone or Salmonid zone of western European ichthyological classifications.

Lower reaches of Palaearctic mountain streams (Gebirgsbach, alpine, mountain and upland streams), often representing the middle course of rivers. The unit corresponds to the Grayling zone of western European ichthyological classifications.

Upper reaches of Palaearctic lowland streams (Niederungsbach, lowland and plain streams), characterized by calmer flow, higher annual temperature variation and aquatic biocoenoses comprising more standing water species, among them immerged macrophytes (unit 24.3). The unit corresponds to the Barbel zone of western European ichthyological classifications.

Middle and lower reaches of Palaearctic lowland streams (Niederungsbach, lowland and plain streams), with aquatic biocoenoses very similar to those of standing water. The unit corresponds to the Bream zone of western European ichthyological classifications.
Palaearctic watercourses of which the flow is interrupted for part of the year, leaving a dry bed or pools
More or less vertical descent of a water course over irregularities of the streambed.
Deposit beds of Palaearctic streams formed of pebbles, gravels, boulders or a mixture of gravels and finer sediments, with the communities that occupy them.

Deposit beds of Palaearctic streams formed of pebbles, gravels, boulders or a mixture of gravels and finer sediments, occupying the edges of the stream, forming islands in the channel or supporting the arms and rivulets constituting the stream, together with their associated animal communities. The presence of vascular vegetation is indicated by use of the appropriate code from unit 24.22. Water-fringing communities, in particular of units 53, 37.7, 37.8, 37.9, may contribute to the colonisation of the deposits.
Deposit beds of Palaearctic streams formed of pebbles, gravels, boulders or a mixture of gravels and finer sediments strewn along the sides of the stream or constituting islands in its channel.

Large beds of gravels, pebbles, boulders or mixed coarse and fine sediments constituting outwash fans, alluvial fans, sandar (sandur), deposited and criss-crossed by braided rivers of the Palaearctic region, characteristic, in particular, of boreal and arctic lands with intense fluvio-glacial deposition.

Vascular plant communities occupying gravel deposits of Palaearctic rivers, including pioneer vegetation and subsequent stages in the colonization sequence. Early-stage communities of Alpide, boreal and Mediterranean watercourses are specialized, those of nemoral lowlands and hills are related to other formations, in particular those of unit 37.

Open assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants, rich in alpine species, colonizing gravel beds of Palaearctic streams with an alpine, summer-high, flow regime, formed in northern boreal and lower arctic mountains, hills and sometimes lowlands, as well as in the alpine and subalpine zones of higher, glaciated, mountains of more southern regions, sometimes with abyssal stations at lower altitudes.

Open assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants colonizing  alluvial and glacial gravels and sands inundated by rivulets and streams of the alpine and subalpine levels of the Alps. Characteristic plants include [Epilobium fleischeri], [Saxifraga bryoides], [Gypsophila repens], [Rumex cutatus], [Trifolium pallescens], [Astragalus sempervirens], [Rhacomitrium canescens].
Open assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants colonizing gravel beds of streams of northern boreal and lower arctic Eurasian mountains, hills and sometimes lowlands.

Low open assemblies of grasses and herbs colonising the lower parts of stony, boulder-strewn shingle banks of rivers in the mountains of boreal and arctic Scandinavia and in Iceland dominated by [Oxyria digyna] and [Cerastium alpinum] or by [Calamagrostis stricta], [Deschampsia cespitosa] and [Oxyria digyna]. There are very few lichens and mosses present, except in the [Calamagrostis] communities, in which [Hypnum lindbergii] may be abundant, and in the Norwegian and Icelandic representatives of the [Cerastium] communities, in which they play an important part, in particular the mosses [Rhacomitrium canescens] and [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum].

Often sparse and lacunar assemblies of herbaceous plants dominated by the spectacular, low-growing, [Epilobium latifolium], a species restricted in the Palaearctic to Iceland, Greenland and Siberia, variously accompanied by [Silene uniflora], [Festuca richardsoni], colonizing shingle, gravel and sand deposits of river beds of lowlands and lower mountains of Iceland.

Extremely dry, level, gravelly and stony terraces situated above the water line of rivers of Iceland and of the alpine and arcto-alpine regions of Scandinavia, colonized by a continuous moss and lichen cover dominated by [Rhacomitrium canescens], [Stereocaulon spp.], and, in Iceland, [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], with few vascular plants.

Nombre oficial: Central Eurasian alpine river gravel communities
Definición oficial: Open assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants colonizing  alluvial and glacial gravels and sands inundated by rivulets and streams of the alpine and subalpine levels of central Eurasian mountains.

Nombre oficial: Far Eastern alpine river gravel communities
Definición oficial: Open assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants colonizing  alluvial and glacial gravels and sands inundated by rivulets and streams of the alpine and subalpine levels of mountains of eastern Eurasia.

Open or closed assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants, colonizing, within the montane or submontane levels, gravel beds of streams with an alpine, summer-high, flow regime, born in high mountains of the Alpine system.

Open and often unstable assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants, rich in casual immigrants from higher altitudes, colonizing gravel beds of the montane reaches of unregulated Alpine streams, with [Chondrilla chondrilloides], often accompanied by [Erucastrum nasturtiifolium], [Gypsophila repens], [Dryas octopetala], [Aethionema saxatile], [Epilobium dodonaei], [Erigeron acer], [Leontodon berinii], [Buphthalmum salicifolium], [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Fumana procumbens], [Agrostis gigantea], [Anthyllis vulneraria] ssp. [alpestris], [Campanula cochlearifolia], [Hieracium piloselloides], [Calamagrostis pseudophragmites], [Conyza canadensis], [Pritzelago alpina], and seedlings of [Salix elaeagnos], [Salix purpurea], [Salix daphnoides] and [Myricaria germanica].  Because of widespread interference with natural flow regimes, these formations are gravely endangered.

Closed or lacunar assemblies of often large herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants colonizing montane and submontane gravel beds loaded with finer sands or silts of unregulated streams of the Alpine system and its vicinity.  [Calamagrostis pseudophragmites] is usually dominant, seedlings of montane and dealpine willows, characteristic of 24.2221, often absent.

[Calamagrostis pseudophragmites]-dominated communities of rivers originating  in the Alpine and Carpathian arcs complex. Characteristic plants include [Epilobium dodonaei], [Agrostis gigantea], [Phalaris arundinacea], [Tussilago farfara]. Like those of unit 24.2221, these communities are gravely threatened by widespread watercourse alterations affecting natural flow regimes.

Assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants colonizing gravel beds of streams with an alpine, summer-high, flow regime in the montane zone of the Pyrenees and the Cantabrian chain, with [Calamagrostis pseudophragmites] and [Erucastrum nasturtiifolium].

Thermophile pioneer communities of river gravels, mostly characteristic of the upper Rhine, with [Scrophularia canina], [Epilobium dodonaei], [Hieracium piloselloides], [Silene prostrata], [Inula conyza], [Centaurea stoebe] ssp. [stoebe], [Arenaria serpyllifolia], [Echium vulgare], [Salix elaeagnos] seedlings.

Open or closed assemblies of herbaceous or suffrutescent pioneering plants, colonizing, within the montane or submontane levels, gravel beds of streams with an alpine, summer-high, flow regime, born in the high Ponto-Caucasian mountains.

Communities of low shrubby pioneers invading the herbaceous formations of units 24.221 and 24.222 on gravel deposits rich in fine silt of mountain and northern boreal Palaearctic streams with an alpine, summer-high, flow regime. [Myricaria germanica] and [Salix spp.] are characteristic. Precise communities can be indicated by use of codes from unit 44, in particular unit 44.11.

Thickets or woods of, among others, [Salix spp.], [Hippophae rhamnoides], [Alnus spp.], [Betula spp.], on stream gravels of mountain and northern boreal Palaearctic streams with an alpine, summer-high, flow regime. Precise communities can be indicated by use of codes from unit 44, in particular unit 44.11.

Communities colonizing gravel deposits of Palaearctic rivers with a Mediterranean, summer-low, flow regime, with, in particular, [Myricaria germanica], [Erucastrum nasturtiifolium], [Glaucium flavum], [Oenothera biennis].

Communities, less specialized than those of high mountain, boreo-arctic and Mediterranean watercourses, colonizing river gravels of lowland and hill rivers of the Palaearctic nemoral, boreonemoral and adjacent zones. Precise formations can be indicated by use of codes from unit 3, in particular unit 37.1, and from unit 44.
Sand deposits of Palaearctic streams, with the communities that occupy them.

Sand deposits of Palaearctic streams, occupying the edges of the stream, forming islands in the channel or supporting the arms and rivulets constituting the stream, together with their associated animal communities. The presence of vascular vegetation is indicated by use of unit 24.32. Water-fringing communities, in particular of units 53, 37.7, 37.8, 37.9, may contribute to the colonisation of the deposits.
Sand deposits of Palaearctic streams formed along the sides of the stream or constituting islands in its channel.

Large sand deposits constituting outwash fans, alluvial fans, sandar (sandur), deposited and criss-crossed by braided rivers of the Palaearctic region, characteristic, in particular, of boreal and arctic lands with intense fluvio-glacial deposition.
Sparsely-vegetated to wooded sand banks of large Palaearctic rivers. Appropriate codes from units 22.3, 31 and 44 can be used to specify habitats.

Beds of water crowfoots, pondweeds, water starworts and other euhydrophytes, including mosses and macroscopic algae, of Palaearctic streams, comprising in particular [Butomus umbellatus] f. [valisneriifolius], [Callitriche cophocarpa], [Callitriche hamulata], [Callitriche obtusangula], [Callitriche stagnalis], [Groenlandia densa], [Potamogeton coloratus], [Potamogeton helveticus], [Potamogeton natans] var. [prolixus], [Potamogeton nodosus], [Ranunculus fluitans], [Ranunculus penicillatus], [Ranunculus trichophyllus], [Sagittaria sagittifolia] var. [vallisneriifolia], [Schoenoplectus lacustris] var. [fluitans], [Sparganium emersum] ssp. [fluitans].

Euhydrophyte communities of Palaearctic streams poor in nutrients and in lime, with, in particular, [Myriophyllum alternifolium], [Potamogeton polygonifolius], [Callitriche hamulata], [Littorella uniflora], [Juncus bulbosus], [Scirpus fluitans] or acidophilous mosses and algae. In Iceland, [Montia fontana], [Potamogeton filiformis], [Ranunculus trichophyllus] ([Ranunculus confervoides], [Ranunculus aquatilis] var [diffusus]) and [Fontinalis antipyretica] characterize the community in clear, slowly flowing waters.
Euhydrophyte communities of Palaearctic streams poor in nutrients but rich in lime, characterized in particular by [Potamogeton coloratus] and [Chara hispida] or by tufa-forming mosses and algae.
Euhydrophyte communities of Palaearctic streams poor in nutrients but rich in lime, in which tufa formation is absent or very limited, with [Potamogeton coloratus] and [Chara hispida].
Euhydrophyte moss and algae communities of Palaearctic streams poor in nutrients but rich in lime, forming infra-aquatic tufa deposits.

Euhydrophyte moss and algae communities of Palaearctic streams poor in nutrients but rich in lime, forming large, structuring, tufa deposits, with a complex arrangement of subcommunities, characteristic, in particular, of the karst region of the eastern Adriatic.

Euhydrophyte communities of Palaearctic streams moderately rich in nutrients, characterized in particular by [Berula erecta] ([Sium erectum]), [Mentha aquatica] f. [submersa], [Potamogeton perfoliatus], [Potamogeton natans], [Groenlandia densa], [Ranunculus peltatus], [Ranunculus penicillatus], [Ranunculus trichophyllus], [Ranunculus fluitans], [Ranunculus aquatilis], [Callitriche truncata], [Callitriche stagnalis], [Nymphaea alba], [Myriophyllum spicatum].

Euhydrophyte communities of Palaearctic streams rich in nutrients, characterized in particular by [Ranunculus fluitans], [Ranunculus circinatus], [Zannichellia palustris] f. [fluviatilis], [Potamogeton nodosus], [Potamogeton lucens], [Potamogeton pectinatus], [Potamogeton crispus], [Sparganium emersum], [Sagittaria sagittifolia], [Callitriche obtusangula], [Nuphar lutea] and the moss [Fontinalis antipyretica].
Silt and mud deposits of Palaearctic streams, with the communities that occupy them.

Silt deposits of Palaearctic streams occupying the edges of the stream, forming islands in the channel or supporting the arms and rivulets constituting the stream, together with their associated animal communities. The presence of vascular vegetation is indicated by use of the appropriate codes from units 24.52, 24.53 or 24.54. Water-fringing communities, in particular of units 53, 37.7, 37.8, 37.9, may contribute to the colonisation of the deposits.

Pioneer formations of tall annuals colonizing nitrogen-rich muds of lowland rivers of the boreal and nemoral zones of the Palaearctic, and locally of the Eurasian steppe zone, with [Bidens spp.], [Rorippa spp.], [Chenopodium spp.], [Polygonum spp.], [Xanthium spp.]

Nitrophilous annual and perennial grass and sedge formations of the alluvial banks of Mediterranean permanent or temporary water courses, most characteristic of great Mediterranean rivers, with [Paspalum paspalodes], [Paspalum vaginatum], [Polypogon viridis] ([Agrostis semiverticillata]), [Cyperus fuscus], [Catabrosa aquatica].
Communities colonizing fine material deposits of low arctic and northern boreal rivers and springs of the Palaearctic region.
Communities colonizing fine material deposits of arctic and northern boreal rivers of Iceland, the Faeroe Islands and Greenland with [Koenigia islandica] and [Sedum villosum].

Communities colonizing fine material deposits of Icelandic and Faroese rivers and springs with [Koenigia islandica], [Sedum villosum], [Spergula arvensis], [Polygonum viviparum], [Epilobium palustre], [Euphrasia frigida], [Juncus biglumis], [Juncus triglumis], [Triglochin palustre], [Limosella aquatica], [Deschampsia alpina].

Communities colonizing fine material deposits of arctic rivers, springs and seeps of Greenland with [Koenigia islandica], [Juncus triglumis], [Sagina intermedia], [Ranunculus glacialis], [Saxifraga hirculus], [Saxifraga aizoides], [Eriophorum scheuchzeri].
Communities colonizing fine material deposits of low arctic and northern boreal rivers of continental Europe and Siberia.
Hard rock features permanently emerging from, or temporarily uncovered by, Palaearctic water courses.

Shrub-, grass- or forb-dominated communities constituting either zonal climax communities under nondesert climates unsuitable for forest, or zoogenic or anthropogenic, regressive or progressive, transitional stages in forest successions on well-drained, seasonally inundatable or poorly drained but nonmarshy soils. Included are deciduous, ericaceous, sclerophyllous or lauriphyllous shrub communities of boreal, temperate, mediterranean, tropical and high mountain climates, steppes, alpine and other orogenous grasslands, secondary dry, mesophile or humid grasslands and forblands of boreal, temperate, mediterranean and tropical climates, shrub and grass communities of permafrost.

Savannah grasslands, tropical seasonally flooded grasslands, tropical permanently flooded grasslands and tropical steppes, communities dominated by mostly tall grasses or grasslike species of tropical regions, limited within the Palaearctic, as here defined, to the Sahelian zone of Mauritania, to the lowlands of the Cape Verde Islands, to the southern fringe of the Saharo-Sindian zone, and to tropical China.

Communities dominated by deciduous or evergreen shrubs of tropical regions, limited within the Palaearctic, as here defined, to the Sahelian zone of Mauritania, to the southern fringe of the Saharo-Sindian zone, and to tropical China.

Formations of the very high altitudes of high tropical mountains, composed of tall tussock-forming grasses, rosette and cushion plants, sclerophyllous shrubs and arborescent scapeous phanerophytes, limited within the Palaearctic, as here defined, to the mountains of Yemen. Scrubs and grasslands of the high altitudes of tropical Far Eastern mountains of southern central mainland China and of Taiwan are outposts of temperate communities and have been listed under 31 and 36.

Shrub communities of nemoral affinities. They include winter-deciduous scrubs or brushes of the subarctic, subantarctic, nemoral, steppe, warm-temperate humid and mediterranean zones, ericoid or coniferous scrubs of the subarctic, subantarctic, nemoral, steppe and warm-temperate humid zones and scrubs, heaths, cushion-heaths or brushes of the cold, extrasylvatic or supradesertic altitude belts of subarctic, subantarctic, nemoral, mediterranean and subtropical high mountains. In the Palaearctic realm, Atlantic heaths, high montane and boreomontane heaths and conifer scrubs, subalpine bush communities, oro-Mediterranean and Irano-Turanian tragacanthic communities, deciduous forest and temperate conifer forest recolonisation communities belong to this unit.

Wet or humid ericoid-shrub dominated heaths of the Atlantic and sub-Atlantic domaines of the western Palaearctic region, developed on peaty or semipeaty soils, waterlogged for at least part of the year, sometimes temporarily inundated, and usually moist even in summer.

Wet heaths of the northern Atlantic and sub-Atlantic domaine and of boreal enclaves in the southern Atlantic and sub-Atlantic domaine. They mostly comprise wet and humid heaths of anmoors, gleypodzols and thin peats of the British Isles, the Germano-Baltic plains and neighbouring Hercynian hills, northern and northwestern France, southern Scandinavia, dominated by [Erica tetralix] or [Calluna vulgaris], sometimes in association with [Scirpus cespitosus] or [Molinia caerulea], usually accompanied by nonpeatbuilding sphagna, in particular, [Sphagnum compactum], [Sphagnum molle], [Sphagnum tenellum]. They also include peaty heaths of more southern regions, in western France, the periphery of the Paris Basin and northwestern Iberia, mostly developed in the central, most humid, part of depressions, often in contact with somewhat less humid formations of unit 31.12.

Wet heaths and humid heaths of the British Isles, the Germano-Baltic plains and northern France, with principal areas of occurrence in the drier, eastern, lowlands of Britain and in the North Sea plain between northern Belgium and Schleswig-Holstein, extending to southwestern Belgium and northwestern France, to the confines of Normandy, to the montane level of the western Hercynian hills, in particular, the Ardennes, and, in the northeast, to the Prignitz, the Lausitz and western Poland, always rich in, and generally dominated by, [Erica tetralix], sometimes by [Calluna vulgaris], often in association with [Molinia caerulea], accompanied by nonpeat-building sphagna, in particular, [Sphagnum compactum], [Sphagnum molle], [Sphagnum tenellum], and by [Zygogonium ericetorum]

Wet heaths or swamp-heaths of wet depressions of the acidified coastal dunes of the Wadden Sea islands of the Netherlands, Lower Saxony and Schleswig-Holstein, and of the southern Baltic coasts, east to eastern Germany, dominated by [Erica tetralix], accompanied by [Empetrum nigrum], [Salix repens], [Calluna vulgaris], [Carex trinervis], [Juncus balticus] ([Juncus arcticus] ssp. [balticus]), [Juncus anceps] ([Juncus alpinoarticulatus] ssp. [atricapillus]), [Calamagrostis epigeios], [Vaccinium macrocarpum] ([Oxycoccus macrocarpus]), [Drosera rotundifolia], [Sphagnum compactum], [Sphagnum molle].

Wet heaths of Ireland, western and northern Britain, western Norway, southern Norway and Sweden, western, northern and northeastern Jutland, mostly developed on shallow peats, sometimes on peaty mineral soils, under highly oceanic climates, dominated by [Erica tetralix] and/or [Calluna vulgaris], in association with [Scirpus cespitosus] or [Molinia caerulea], accompanied by, in particular, [Potentilla erecta], [Polygala serpyllifollia], [Narthecium ossifragum], [Eriophorum angustifolium], [Drosera rotundifolia], [Carex panicea], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Myrica gale], [Cornus svecica], [Sphagnum palustre], [Sphagnum capillifolium], [Sphagnum subnitens], [Dicranum scoparium], [Hypnum jutlandicum], [Leucobryum glaucum], [Cladonia spp.].

Wet and humid heaths of anmoors of middle European Hercynian hills and their periphery, in particular, of the Black Forest and the Vosges, at the continental limit of the range of the Western European wet heaths, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] in association with [Scirpus cespitosus] ssp. [germanicus] accompanied by [Juncus squarrosus], [Sphagnum compactum], [Sphagnum tenellum], [Leucobryum glaucum], [Scirpus cespitosus] ssp. [cespitosus], [Molinia caerulea]. Facies may be dominated by [Scirpus cespitosus] with little or no [Calluna vulgaris] and constitute oligotrophic humid grasslands included in unit 37.32.

Tall heaths of moist, shallow depressions of the Lizard in Cornwall, dominated by [Erica vagans] and [Schoenus nigricans] with [Erica tetralix], [Molinia caerulea], [Serratula tinctoria] and often [Ulex gallii].

Peaty heaths of western France, the periphery of the Paris Basin and northwestern Iberia, mostly developed in the central, most humid, part of depressions, often in contact with somewhat less humid formations of unit 31.12.

Humid and meso-hygrophile heaths of gley-podzols and semipeaty soils of the northwestern Iberian peninsula, Atlantic France, the Paris Basin and its periphery, extreme southern England, dominated by [Erica tetralix] or [Erica ciliaris], with [Erica scoparia], [Erica ciliaris], [Calluna vulgaris], [Ulex minor], [Ulex gallii] or [Genista anglica]. They may, in particular, form transition belts between peaty heaths of unit 31.11 and dry heaths of unit 31.2.

Wet heaths and humid heaths of the northwestern Iberian peninsula, in the Atlantic and Carpetano-Iberico-Leonese provinces and, very locally, in the Luso-Extremadurian province, particularly characteristic of the beech and deciduous oak levels of the Cantabrian chain and Galicia, dominated by [Erica tetralix], [Erica ciliaris] or [Erica mackaiana] with [Genista anglica], [Genista micrantha], [Ulex gallii], [Calluna vulgaris], [Erica cinerea], [Daboecia cantabrica], [Juncus squarrosus], [Cirsium filipendulum], and sometimes [Euphorbia polygafolia].

Humid and meso-hygrophile heaths of gley-podzols with hydromor of Aquitanian and Ligerian France north to Brenne and the Le Mans region, dominated by [Erica tetralix], [Erica scoparia] or [Erica ciliaris], with [Molinia caerulea], [Scorzonera humilis], [Carum verticillatum], [Ulex minor], [Genista anglica], [Pseudarrhenatherum longifolium] ([Arrhenatherum thorei]).

Humid and meso-hygrophile heaths of semipeaty gley podzols of eastern Britanny, Normandy, the southern Paris Basin, the Morvan, extending very locally to England in southern Dorset, dominated by [Erica tetralix] or [Erica ciliaris], generally with [Ulex minor], accompanied by [Calluna vulgaris], [Genista anglica], [Salix repens], [Ulex europaeus], [Molinia caerulea], [Scirpus cespitosus], [Danthonia decumbens], [Carex panicea], [Polygala serpyllifolia], [Potentilla erecta], [Drosera rotundifolia], [Lobelia urens], [Carum verticillatum], [Scorzonera humilis], [Pedicularis sylvatica], [Ajuga occidentalis], [Sphagnum compactum], [Cladonia spp.]

Humid and meso-hygrophile heaths of semipeaty gley podzols of hyper-Atlantic lower Brittany, Cornwall and Devon, dominated by [Erica tetralix] or [Erica ciliaris], generally with [Ulex gallii], accompanied by [Genista anglica], [Salix repens], [Molinia caerulea], [Scirpus cespitosus], [Juncus squarrosus], [Potentilla erecta], [Drosera rotundifolia], [Pinguicula lusitanica], [Viola palustris], [Narthecium ossifragum], [Lobelia urens], [Wahlenbergia hederacea], [Anagallis tenella], [Hydrocotyle vulgaris], [Cirsium dissectum] ([Cirsium anglicum]), [Carum verticillatum], [Dactylorhiza ericetorum] ([Dactylorhiza maculata] ssp. [ericetorum]), [Sphagnum spp.] and sometimes [Myrica gale].
Degraded facies of wet heaths, humid heaths and swamp-heaths of the Atlantic and sub-Atlantic domaines of the western Palaearctic region, dominated by [Molinia caerulea].
Xerophile or meso-xerophile heaths on siliceous, podsolic soils in moist Atlantic and sub-Atlantic climates of the plains and low mountains of Western and Central Europe.

Submontane, or sometimes lowland or coastal, heaths rich in [Vaccinium spp.], usually with [Calluna vulgaris], of the northern and western British Isles, of the North Atlantic islands, of Fennoscandia, of the Hercynian ranges and the lower levels of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Pyrenees and the Cordillera Cantabrica.

Low altitude heaths of boreomontane affinities developed under euoceanic climates along the coasts of low Arctic and northern temperate North Atlantic islands and of boreal and arctic Scandinavia, generally characterized by the prominence of [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum] or [Vaccinium vitis-idaea].

Low altitude heaths of boreomontane affinities of the Faeroe, Shetland and Orkney islands, mostly characteristic of exposed headlands under euoceanic conditions, with [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Calluna vulgaris], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum]. They are floristically closely related to montane heaths of unit 31.45, in particular, the Scottish Highland heaths of units 31.451 and 31.452.

Low altitude prostrate, open, moss-rich heaths of boreomontane affinities of the coasts and islands of oceanic southern boreal, oceanic middle boreal and arcto-alpine Norway, dominated by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum] and [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], accompanied by [Calluna vulgaris], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Eriophorum vaginatum], [Cladonia spp.], [Sphagnum spp.]

Moss-rich, closed [Vaccinium uliginosum]-[Vaccinium myrtillus]-[Empetrum hermaphroditum] heaths of Iceland, of boreomontane affinities, developed under humid euoceanic climate conditions at mostly low altitudes, typically from sealevel to 460 m. The three erico¿d shrubs dominate in any combination and may be accompanied by [Calluna vulgaris] or [Loiseleuria procumbens]. Common nonerico¿d vascular plants include [Alchemilla alpina], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Polygonum viviparum] ([Bistorta vivipara]), [Salix herbacea], [Viola palustris], [Galium boreale], [Galium normanii], [Thalictrum alpinum], [Carex bigelowii], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Avenella flexuosa]. Orchids include [Dactylorhiza islandica], [Coeloglossum viride], [Listera cordata]. The moss layer is very developed, with a cover of 20% to 70%, and a rich and diverse bryophyte and lichen cort¿ge in which [Rhacomitrium canescens], [Drepanocladus uncinatus], [Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus], [Rhytidiadelphus loreus], [Hylocomium splendens], [Dicranum scoparium], [Polytrichum alpinum] may be particularly prominent.

[Vaccinium]-dominated, [Vaccinium]-rich and [Empetrum]-rich heaths of boreomontane affinities characteristic of northern and western uplands of Britain and of western and southern Scandinavia, with extensions in the Germano-Baltic plain, particularly in Jutland, Poland, southern Finland and the Baltic States. [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Empetrum nigrum], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Pleurozium schreberi] and [Hylocomium splendens] are strongly represented among the associates of [Calluna vulgaris].

Usually low, relatively open submontane or subboreal heaths of the uplands of northern and western Britain, of southern Fennoscandia and Denmark, usually dominated by [Vaccinium myrtillus], in association with [Empetrum nigrum], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Calluna vulgaris], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] or [Vaccinium uliginosum] and with a moss-rich or grass-rich cort¿ge.

Usually low, relatively open submontane heaths of the uplands of northern and western Britain, particularly widespread in the central and eastern Highlands, usually dominated by [Vaccinium myrtillus], often in association with [Empetrum nigrum] or [Empetrum hermaphroditum], variously accompanied by [Calluna vulgaris], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Vaccinium uliginosum] and with a generally moss-rich or grass-rich cort¿ge that includes, in particular, [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Festuca ovina], [Agrostis capillaris], [Nardus stricta], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Danthonia decumbens].

[Vaccinium myrtillus] heaths of the Highlands, with outposts in the Southern Uplands, the Lake District, and northern Wales, with abundant [Empetrum hermaphroditum] and bryophytes, mostly associated with large shallow snow beds at relatively high altitudes.

[Vaccinium myrtillus] heaths of the western and central Highlands, with outliers in the Southern Uplands and Wales, with [Alchemilla alpina] and abundant grasses, characteristic of lower altitudes, sunnier stations and lesser snow cover than those of unit 31.21211.

[Vaccinium myrtillus]-[Empetrum spp.] heaths of the southern Highlands, the Southern Uplands, the Lake District, the Bowland Fells, the Pennines, Wales and Dartmoor, with [Cladonia] lichens, [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], [Galium saxatile], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Festuca ovina], [Carex bigelowii].

Usually low, relatively open, subboreal heaths of southern Fennoscandia and Denmark, usually dominated by [Vaccinium myrtillus] and [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], in association with [Calluna vulgaris] and mosses or with [Deschampsia flexuosa].

Open [Vaccinium myrtillus]-[Vaccinium vitis-ideae]-[Calluna vulgaris] heaths characteristic of southern Scandinavia, distributed in Denmark, along the coast of Norway, north to central Norway, and in southwestern Sweden, developed under somewhat humid, mild-winter climates, with a field layer species cort¿ge comprising [Galium saxatile], [Maianthemum bifolium], [Potentilla erecta], [Trientalis europaea], [Danthonia decumbens], [Deschampsia flexuosa], and a ground layer dominated by [Pleurozium schreberi] accompanied by [Dicranum polysetum], [Hypnum cupressiforme], [Hylocomium splendens], [Rhytidiadelphus triquetum] and lichens of genus [Cladonia]

Grass-rich [Vaccinium myrtillus]-[Vaccinium vitis-ideae] heaths of central Sweden and southwestern Finland, with a species cort¿ge comprising [Deschampsia flexuosa], which may codominate with the ericoid shrubs, [Calamagrostis arundinacea], [Luzula pilosa], [Lathyrus linifolius], [Melampyrum spp.], [Viola riviniana], occupying dry, lightly grazed patches within birch-oak pastures often on boulder-strewn moraine land.

Subboreal and upland [Calluna vulgaris]-dominated heaths of northern and western Britain, southern Scandinavia and Denmark, more or less rich in [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] or [Empetrum nigrum] and sometimes with [Erica cinerea], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], grasses or lichens.

Subboreal, upland, [Calluna vulgaris]-dominated heaths of northern and western Britain, more or less rich in [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Erica cinerea] or [Empetrum nigrum], accompanied by grasses or by pleurocarps and lichens.

Submontane and collinar heaths of the Highlands, the Southern Uplands, Orkney, Shetland, the Lake District, the Pennines, the North York Moors, Wales, the South-West Peninsula dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] associated with [Vaccinium myrtillus], which may sometimes be codominant, accompanied by [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Empetrum nigrum] and, sometimes, [Erica cinerea], and often by pleurocarps and lichens.

Grassy submontane and collinar heaths of the eastern Highlands, the Southern Uplands, Orkney, the Lake District, Wales, the South-West Peninsula dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] associated with [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Festuca ovina], [Festuca rubra], [Nardus stricta], [Anthoxanthum odoratum] and with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Empetrum nigrum], [Erica cinerea]. Grassy [Calluna]-[Vaccinium] heaths, in particular, those rich in [Nardus stricta] and associated grasses, or in [Juncus squarrosus], include communities transitional to grasslands of units 35 and 37.

Subboreal [Calluna vulgaris]-dominated heaths of southern Scandinavia and Denmark, rich in [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] or [Empetrum nigrum], in mosses and lichens, and sometimes grasses.

Very open heaths of Denmark, southern Sweden, southern Norway and, very locally, southwestern Finland, developed on podzols in humid, mild-winter climates, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], [Empetrum nigrum] and [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], with a rich moss and lichen cort¿ge usually dominated by [Pleurozium schreberi], sometimes with a prominent occurrence of [Molinia caerulea].

Open heaths of western and northern Jutland, northern Zealand, Scania, the coasts and near-coastal hills of southern Sweden and southern Norway, of oceanic Norway north to the oceanic middle boreal zone, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] accompanied by [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] and/or [Vaccinium myrtillus], and with [Pleurozium schreberi] usually dominant in the moss layer
Subboreal heaths of the Faeroe Islands, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris],  [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] and [Empetrum nigrum] or [Vaccinium myrtillus], accompanied by [Pleurozium schreberi].

Tall [Calluna vulgaris]-[Vaccinium myrtillus] heaths with a ground layer dominated by bryophytes, in particular, leafy liverworts, hypnaceous mosses and sphagna, mostly [Sphagnum capillifolium], sometimes [Sphagnum quinquefarium], [Sphagnum russowii], [Sphagnum girgensohnii], [Sphagnum tenellum], characteristic of the northwest Highlands, with outliers in the southwestern Southern Uplands, in the Lake District and in Orkney.

Heaths of the east-central Highlands of Scotland, Jutland, western Norway, the coastlands of the Skagerrak and Kattegat, the southeastern and central Baltic regions dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] and [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], often with [Erica cinerea], [Genista anglica], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] or [Vaccinium myrtillus], accompanied by a distinctly boreal species cort¿ge.

Moderately tall heaths of base-poor to near-neutral soils and moderate altitudes of the east-central Highlands, usually dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], usually accompanied by prominent [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi] and [Erica cinerea], often with [Genista anglica], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Vaccinium myrtillus] and a rather boreal species cort¿ge.

Heaths of Jutland, of oceanic southern boreal Norway, of the Swedish and Norwegian coasts of the Skagerrak and Kattegat, of the Baltic coastlands of boreonemoral Sweden and Finland, of the Baltic plains of northeastern Germany, northern and central Poland and of the Baltic States, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi] and [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], with [Carex ericetorum], [Peucedanum oreoselinum], [Trientalis europaea].

Montane or submontane [Calluna]-[Vaccinium] heaths of the Hercynian ranges of northern and middle Western and Central Europe and of their surrounding regions. They mostly include secondary heaths of the beech level of the Vosges, of the Black Forest, of the Ardennes and the Eifel, of the mid-German Hercynian ranges, of the Bohemian Quadrangle, including the Erzgebirge (Metallic Mountains), the Sudeten, the Bohemian Forest (Sumava) and the Czecko-Moravian Hills, of the Massif Central and, locally, the Morvan, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Vaccinium uliginosum] and montane lycopodes ([Diphasiastrum spp.]). They also comprise partly primary and sometimes threatened local formations of extrasylvatic areas, in particular the [Calluna vulgaris] heaths enclaved in alpine and subalpine [Pinus mugo] scrub and acidophilous grassland complexes of the high slopes and plateaux of the Giant Mountains (Sudeten), or the [Calluna vulgaris], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] heaths of the Brocken summit in the Harz with [Anemone micrantha] and [Hieracium alpinum].
[Vaccinium spp.] heaths of the collinar and montane levels of the Alps with, [Calluna vulgaris], [Artemisia alba], [Silene otites], [Campanula spicata] and other thermophile species.
[Vaccinium]-rich heaths of the collinar and montane levels of the Pyrenees and the Cordillera Cantabrica.
[Vaccinium myrtillus]-[Vaccinium vitis-ideae] and [Vaccinium]-rich [Calluna vulgaris] heaths of the collinar and montane levels of the Carpathians.

[Vaccinium myrtillus]-[Vaccinium vitis-ideae] heaths of the collinar and montane levels of the western and northern Carpathians of Moravia, Slovakia, Poland, with [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Melampyrum pratense], [Melampyrum sylvaticum], [Calamagrostis arundinacea].

[Calluna vulgaris] heaths of the beech and spruce levels of the eastern Carpathians, most widespread in the Apuseni mountains, rich in [Vaccinium myrtillus] and [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], with [Lycopodium clavatum], [Genista sagittalis], [Bruckenthalia spiculifolia], [Campanula abietina], [Campanula serrata], [Scorzonera rosea], [Viola declinata], [Nardus stricta], [Potentilla erecta], [Hieracium pilosella], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Agrostis capillaris], [Festuca rubra].

Low [Calluna vulgaris] heaths often rich in [Genista spp.], mostly of the Germano-Baltic lowlands. Similar formations occurring in British upland areas, montane zones of high mountains of the western Mediterranean basin and high rainfall Adriatic influenced areas are most conveniently listed here.
[Calluna vulgaris]-[Chamaespartium sagittale] ([Genista sagittalis]) heaths of the southwestern Alps, the Vosges, the Black Forest, the Jura, the Bavarian plateau and the southeastern Carpathians.
[Calluna vulgaris]-[Chamaespartium sagittale] ([Genista sagittalis]) heaths of the southwestern Alps, the Vosges, the Black Forest, the Jura and the Bavarian plateau.
[Calluna vulgaris]-[Chamaespartium sagittale] ([Genista sagittalis]) heaths of the southeastern Carpathians, with [Bruckenthalia speculifolia], [Viola declinata], [Scorzonera rosea].

Heaths of calcareous or somewhat calcareous substrates, and of low-precipitation continental enclaves, in particular, in Hercynian hills and on Pleistocene inland dunes, of Germany, the Czech Republic, Austria, Poland, southern Scandinavia, with southern representatives in the northern Dinarides of Croatia, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Cruciata glabra], [Peucedanum oreoselinum], [Prunella vulgaris], [Juniperus communis], [Carex caryophyllea], [Carex ericetorum], [Carex humilis], [Koeleria pyramidata].

Relatively species-rich heaths of Scania, southeastern Sweden, ¿land and Gotland, central G¿taland, eastern Svealand, the central Baltic archipelagos, extreme southern Finland, northern Germany and northern Poland, with outposts in southwestern Norway, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Hieracium pilosella], [Cladonia spp.]

Heaths of calcareous or somewhat calcareous substrates, and of low-precipitation continental enclaves, in particular, in Hercynian hills and on Pleistocene inland dunes, of Germany, the Czech Republic, Austria, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Hieracium pilosella], [Carex caryophyllea], [Carex ericetorum], [Carex humilis], [Koeleria macrantha], [Koeleria pyramidata], [Koeleria gracilis], [Cladonia alcicornis], [Cladonia rangiformis], [Cladonia foliacea], [Cladonia uncialis].

Heaths of calcareous or somewhat calcareous substrates of the northern Dinarides of Croatia, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Genista germanica], [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Cruciata glabra], [Juniperus communis], [Carex caryophyllea].

Heaths, often extensive, of the Stranja-Istranca mountains and of the coasts of the Sea of Marmora, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Erica arborea], [Erica manipuliflora], [Cistus incanus], [Cistus salvifolius], [Genista carinalis], [Teucrium polium].

Heaths of the northern Germano-Baltic plain and neighbouring regions, in Denmark, southern Sweden, Germany, northern Poland and the Netherlands north of the Rhine, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], with [Genista pilosa] and, in the west, [Genista anglica], and with a species cort¿ge that reflects boreal influences, marked, in particular, by the frequent presence of [Empetrum nigrum] or [Vaccinium spp.] These formations have their main area of occurrence in northwestern Germany, Jutland and the Netherlands in Friesland, the Drente, and the Hoge Veluwe, extending northward to northern Jutland and coastal Halland, eastward to the Prignitz and to Poland. Outliers occupy restricted surfaces in the Hercynian upper Rhine hills, the Rhine Valley and middle Franconia.

Relatively thermophile, subcontinental [Calluna vulgaris] heaths of Central Europe, in central and southern Germany, eastern France, the Czech Republic, Austria, with [Genista germanica], [Genista tinctoria], [Chamaespartium sagittale] ([Genista sagittalis]), [Vaccinium myrtillus] and, in peri-Alpine habitats, [Lembotropis nigricans] ([Cytisus nigricans]), [Chamaecytisus supinus] ([Cytisus supinus]), [Polygala chamaebuxus], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae]. They have their main area of distribution in the Thuringian and Franconian ranges, the Upper Palatinate hills, the Danube-Isar hills, the Swabian Alb, the Baar plateau, the eastern Black Forest, the Rhenano-Burgondian hills, the foothills of the Bayerischer Wald, the hills and low mountains of the Bohemian uplands, in the Bavarian and Austrian Danube basin, in the southeastern foothills of the Alps, in Carinthia and Styria

Heaths of the southwestern Germano-Baltic plain, in the Netherlands, south of the Rhine, Belgium and northwestern France, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], with [Genista anglica], [Genista pilosa] and a species cort¿ge that reflects Atlantic influences, marked, in particular, by the frequent presence of [Erica cinerea].

[Erica cinerea]-dominated heaths of the southern Netherlands and Belgium, facies of the [Calluna]-[Genista] heaths of unit 31.223. They represent a transtition to the northern Atlantic heaths of unit 31.25.
Species-poor [Calluna vulgaris] lowland and hill heaths of England, limited to base-poor substrates in areas of local relative contintality.

Lowland, species-poor [Calluna vulgaris] heaths of East Anglia and adjacent areas, now very local, characteristic mostly of the Breckland and East Anglian coast, extending to Lincolnshire, and southwards into the Home Counties, limited to base-poor, sandy soils under relatively continental climates, with [Festuca ovina] and the mosses [Hypnum cupressiforme], [Dicranum scoparium]

Species-poor [Calluna vulgaris] heaths of the Pennine foothills, around polluted industrial areas, of the North Yorkshire Moors and of the West Midlands, developed on acid, impoverished soils, under less oceanic climates than those to which heaths of unit 31.23 are exposed, with [Deschampsia flexuosa] and [Pohlia nutans]

Thermophile [Calluna vulgaris] heaths of the montane zone (beech forest level) of the Central Massif, the Pyrenees and the southwestern Alps, with [Genista anglica], [Genista pilosa], [Vaccinium myrtillus] and, often, [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi].

Subboreal heaths of the Netherlands and northern Germany, occupying enclaves within the range of heaths of unit 31.22, rich in [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], or in [Empetrum nigrum], characteristic, in particular, of the Hoge Veluwe, Drente and Friesland.

Subboreal heaths of the Netherlands and northwestern Germany rich in [Vaccinium myrtillus] and [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], characteristic of cool enclaves, in particular, of north-facing hill and inland dune slopes, extending southwest to the Hoge Veluwe in the central Netherlands.

Subboreal heaths of the Netherlands and northern Germany rich in [Empetrum nigrum], characteristic, in particular, of shady slopes, shrubby heaths, woodland edges and inland dunes, southwest to southern Friesland and Drente in the Netherlands.

Heaths of the southern periphery of the Pannonic basin and the lower montane level of the Dinarides, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Erica herbacea], [Genista germanica] ssp. [heteracantha], [Genista pilosa], [Juniperus communis], [Prunella laciniata], [Hieracium murorum] ([Hieracium silvaticum]), [Serratula tinctoria], [Nardus stricta], [Carex pilulifera].

[Calluna vulgaris] heaths of the fluvioglacial terraces that constitute the high plains of the Po river system, with [Genista pilosa], [Genista tinctoria], [Cytisus scoparius], [Polygala chamaebuxus].
Heaths rich in gorse ([Ulex spp.]) of the Atlantic margins of Europe.

Wind-swept heaths with prostrate, cushiony gorse or broom ([Ulex europaeus] f. [maritimus], [Ulex gallii] f. [humilis], [Cytisus scoparius] ssp. [maritimus]), [Erica vagans], [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris], and numerous other maritime ecotypes, of cliff tops of promontories and islands of Brittany, Cotentin, southern Ireland, Cornwall, Wales, the Cantabrian coast and Galicia.

Oceanic heaths of Ireland, Wales, the Isle of Man, the South-West Peninsula and, locally, the Pennines and the coasts of East Anglia, dominated by [Ulex gallii], [Calluna vulgaris] and [Erica cinerea]. Basicline heaths, somewhat homologous to the continental formations of unit 31.22B, may form in zones of transition between some communities of this unit and calcareous grasslands of unit 34.
Western Irish heaths comprising the northern, isolated, populations of [Erica mackaiana].

Heaths of well drained soils of the coasts and offshore islands of Ireland, Cornwall and Brittany, other than cushiony maritime formations, dominated by or rich in [Erica vagans], constituting isolated northern outposts of occurrence of the species.

Heaths of well drained soils of the coasts and offshore islands of Brittany, other than cushiony maritime formations, dominated by or rich in the uncommon and local [Erica vagans], almost limited to the islands of Belle-Ile and Groix.

Heaths of well drained soils of the Lizard, in Cornwall, with a mixed canopy usually formed by [Erica vagans], [Ulex europaeus], [Erica cinerea], [Ulex gallii], with [Carex flacca], [Viola riviniana], [Filipendula vulgaris], [Agrostis canina], [Stachys officinalis] ([Stachys betonica], [Betonica officinalis]), [Hypochoeris radicata], [Polygala vulgaris], [Potentilla erecta], [Dactylis glomerata], [Scilla verna].

Heaths of well drained soils of Brittany, the Cotentin peninsula, the South-Western Peninsula and the south coast of Wales, dominated by [Ulex gallii], [Erica cinerea] and [Calluna vulgaris], often rich in grasses, in particular, [Agrostis curtisii].
Heaths with [Ulex gallii], [Erica mackaiana], [Erica cinerea], [Daboecia cantabrica] of well drained soils of the beech level of the Pyrenees and the Cantabrian chain and, very locally, of Galicia.

Heaths with [Ulex gallii], [Erica vagans], [Erica cinerea], sometimes [Erica aragonensis], and [Pseudarrhenatherum longifolium] of the French and Spanish Basque coast and of the beech level of the Atlantic Pyrenees and of the Cantabrian chain, mostly on mildly acid or sightly calcareous soils.
Heaths of sub-Atlantic France and of southern and southeastern England formed by [Ulex minor], [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris] and [Ulex europaeus].

Heaths of well drained soils of interior and oriental Brittany, the Perche, Normandy, the Paris Basin, the Sologne, the southern Morvan, dominated by [Erica cinerea], [Ulex minor], [Calluna vulgaris] and [Ulex europaeus].

Heaths of southern and southeastern England, from east Dorset to Kent, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] and [Ulex minor], accompanied by [Erica cinerea] and usually by [Deschampsia flexuosa], sometimes by [Vaccinium myrtillus] or [Molinia caerulea]
Heants of Dorset and Hampshire dominated by [Ulex minor], [Erica cinerea] and [Agrostis curtisii], on relatively well drained soils
Heaths of well drained soils of Aquitaine, Saintonge, Poitou, Sologne and the Loire region formed by [Ulex minor] and [Erica cinerea], sometimes with [Erica scoparia].

Aquitanian heaths with rock-roses. Iberian heaths with numerous species of heathers (notably [Erica umbellata], [Erica aragonensis]) and brooms, rock-roses and often [Daboecia]. When the rock-roses and other Mediterranean shrubs become dominant they should be classified under sclerophyllous scrubs (unit 32).
Coastal and collinar [Erica]-[Ulex]-[Cistus] heaths of the periphery of the Bay of Biscay and of the slopes of the Garonne Gap.
[Erica cinerea] and [Cistus salvifolius] heaths of the Aquitanian coast, with irradiations in the Landes and to the Montagne noire and Minervois.
Arid [Erica cinerea] heaths of interior sandy hills and dunes of the Landes of Gascony and of Sologne gravels, with [Halimium alyssoides].

Tall, dense heaths of the coasts, hills and lower montane areas of the Atlantic slope of Cantabria, the Asturias and Galicia, formed by [Erica vagans] and [Ulex europaeus], with [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris] and [Daboecia cantabrica].
Atlantic Galician and Portuguese [Erica cinerea], [Erica umbellata] and [Ulex europaeus] heaths.

Coastal and collinar, thermo-Atlantic Galician and northern Portuguese heaths with [Erica cinerea], [Erica umbellata], [Ulex minor], [Ulex europaeus], [Ulex micranthus], [Cistus salvifolius] and [Halimium alyssoides].
Cushiony heaths with [Ulex europaeus] ssp. [latebracteatus] f. [humilis] and [Erica cinerea] of cliff tops of Galicia, north and central Portugal (southern vicariant of unit 31.231).
Low [Calluna vulgaris]-rich heaths of interior northwestern mountains, limited to the Sierra de la Cabrera and the neighbouring Sierra Segundera, Pena Trevinca and Sierra del Teleno.
Open, cushiony formations of [Calluna vulgaris], [Erica umbellata], [Genista sanabrensis], [Halimium umbellatum], [Halimium alyssoides] occupying dry, superficial soils.
Formations of [Calluna vulgaris], [Genista carpetana], [Genista anglica], [Genista micrantha] and [Thymelaea coridifolia] ([Thymelaea dendryobryum]) of wetter stations.
[Erica aragonensis] or [Erica umbellata] heaths of the interior slopes of the Cordillera Cantabrica, of interior Galicia and of the Leonese mountains.

Supra-Mediterranean [Erica aragonensis] heaths with [Chamaespartium tridentatum], [Calluna vulgaris], [Halimium alyssoides] of the interior slopes of the Cantabrian Cordillera, eastern Galician ranges, Leon mountains and the Sierra de Cabrera.

Lower altitude heaths on the confines of Galicia and Leon dominated by [Erica umbellata] accompanied by [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris], [Chamaespartium tridentatum], [Halimium alyssoides], [Genista triacanthos], [Lavandula stoechas] ssp. [luisieri].

Lower altitude heaths on the confines of Galicia and Leon, characteristic of slightly more uniform and humid climates than those of unit 31.2442, dominated by [Erica cinerea], accompanied by [Calluna vulgaris], [Chamaespartium tridentatum], [Erica umbellata], [Halimium umbellatum] and Mediterranean elements such as [Lavandula stoechas] ssp. [pedunculata], [Thymus mastichina].
[Erica aragonensis] heaths of the Cordillera Central and the summits of the Montes de Toledo.

[Erica aragonensis] formations of the western Cordillera Central (Serra da Estrela, Sierra de Gata, Sierra de Pena de Francia) with [Erica umbellata], [Halimium alyssoides] and sometimes [Juniperus nana].
[Erica aragonensis] formations of the Sierra de Ayllon with [Halimium viscosum], [Halimium ocymoides], [Genista pilosa] and, sometimes [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi].
Isolated summital [Erica aragonensis] heaths of the Montes de Toledo (Villuercas).
[Erica aragonensis] and [Calluna vulgaris] heath communities of the northern Iberian Range, often with [Genista pilosa] or, on wetter soils, [Genista anglica] and [Genista micrantha].
[Calluna] heaths of high peaks, with [Viola montcaunica].
Beech-zone [Erica aragonensis] heaths with [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi].
Formations of lower beech zone, with [Erica vagans].
[Erica arborea], [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris] formations of the acidophilous oak zone.
[Erica aragonensis] heaths of the southern Iberian Range (Valdemeca, Serrania de Cuenca) with [Thymelaea subrepens].

Formations rich in [Erica umbellata], or sometimes [Erica aragonensis], of the meso-Mediterranean and occasionally thermo-Mediterranean zones of the western parts of the Iberian peninsula, intermediate between heath and maquis.
Formations rich in [Erica umbellata] of the meso-Mediterranean and occasionally thermo-Mediterranean zones of the western parts of the Iberian peninsula, intermediate between heath and maquis.
Formations rich in [Erica aragonensis] of the Serra de Monchique in Algarve.
Formations constituted by the local endemic [Erica andevalensis] on soils rich in heavy metals of the rio Odiel basin in western Andalusia.
Low, open heaths of northern hyper-Atlantic Europe, north of the range of gorses, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] and [Erica cinerea].

Low, open heaths of the oceanic southern boreonemoral zone of southern Norway and western Sweden, along the inner Skagerrak, with [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], sometimes with [Juniperus communis].
Low, open heaths of the Faeroe, with [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris], [Hypericum pulchrum], sometimes with [Juniperus communis].

Submontane heaths of Scotland, northern England, Wales and Devon, dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], with varying amounts of [Erica cinerea], sometimes with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Empetrum nigrum], accompanied by [Potentilla erecta], [Carex binervis], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], [Festuca ovina], [Anthoxanthum odorantum].

Maritime heaths of cliff tops of the South-West Peninsula, western Wales, Cumbria, western Scotland, the Hebredes, northern Scotland, the Orkneys, the Shetlands, northeastern Scotland and, very locally, northeastern England, very low, open, formed by [Calluna vulgaris] and, usually, [Erica cinerea] with [Festuca ovina], [Scilla verna], [Lotus corniculatus], [Thymus praecox], [Plantago maritima], [Hypochoeris radicata], [Holcus lanatus].

Species-rich basicline heaths of the Central Highlands, the Northern Pennines, the Inner Hebrides and the Orkneys dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], with [Erica cinerea], [Danthonia decumbens] ([Sieglingia decumbens]), [Festuca ovina], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Thymus praecox], [Linum catharticum], [Viola riviniana], [Carex pulicaris], [Carex panicea], [Prunella vulgaris], [Primula vulgaris], [Potentilla erecta], [Lotus corniculatus], [Agrostis canina], and sometimes with [Galium boreale], [Lathyrus montanus], [Viola lutea], [Pyrola media], [Rubus saxatilis].
Oceanic heaths of Ireland, with [Erica cinerea], [Calluna vulgaris] and [Carex binervis].
Heaths of the Canary Islands, Azores and Madeira.
Low and medium-tall ericaceous formations of the cloud belt of the Canary Islands.
Humid low heaths of high elevations of Tenerife (Anaga) and La Gomera (Incherada), with [Erica scoparia] ssp. [platycodon].
Low and medium-tall stages of the [Erica arborea], [Myrica faya] and [Ilex canariensis] formations (tall forest-like formations are listed as 45.9).
Sometimes fairly tall, 2-3 metre high, [Erica arborea], [Myrica faya], [Erica scoparia], [Laurus azorica], [Clethra arborea] and [Pteridium aquilinum] heaths of the cloud zone of Madeira.
[Erica cinerea] var. [maderensis]-dominated heaths of the highest peaks of Madeira.
[Erica azorica], [Myrica faya] and [Laurus azorica] heaths of the lower altitudes of the Azores.
Heath facies of the [Erica azorica] and [Juniperus brevifolia] upper woods of the Azores.
[Calluna vulgaris], [Daboecia azorica] and [Thymus caespititius] communities of the highest altitudes of the Azores (1200-1500 m).
Small, dwarf or prostrate shrub formations of the alpine and subalpine zones of the mountains of Eurasia, dominated by ericaceous species, [Dryas octopetala], dwarf junipers, brooms or greenweeds

Nombre oficial: Alpide high mountain dwarf bilberry heaths
Definición oficial: [Vaccinium]-dominated dwarf heaths of the subalpine belt of southern mountains, in particular, of the northern and central Apennines, the Balkan Range, the Hellenides, the Pontic Range and the Caucasus, with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium uliginosum] [s.l.], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea]  and, locally, [Empetrum nigrum]. They are richer in grassland species than the communities of unit 31.44 and often take the appearence of alpine grassland with dward shrubs. [Vaccinium myrtillus] also plays a much more dominant role, in lieu of [Vaccinium uliginosum] and [Empetrum hermaphroditum].

Nombre oficial: Central Mediterranean subalpine dwarf bilberry heaths
Definición oficial: [Vaccinium] dwarf heaths of the subalpine or lower alpine belt of mountains of the Italian peninsula and of the large Tyrrhenian islands formed by [Vaccinium myrtillus] and [Vaccinium uliginosum] [s.l.], with a large admixture of alpine or subalpine grassland species and sometimes of megaforb elements.

[Vaccinium]-dominated dwarf heaths of the subalpine or lower alpine belt of the northern and central Apennines, with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium uliginosum] [s.l.], and, locally, [Empetrum nigrum], mostly dwarf-shrub rich facies of alpine or subalpine grasslands.

[Vaccinium myrtillus] heath-grasslands of ubacs of the lower subalpine level of Corsica, limited to cliff-bordered corridors, ledges at the foot of high cliffs, ravines, torrent banks, the fringe of humid sweet alder brush, in cool shady situations with prolonged snow cover.

Communities of [Vaccinium myrtillus] and/or [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], rich in grass and herb species, of the subalpine level of the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Pelagonides, the Pindus, the Thessalian mountains.
Communities of [Vaccinium myrtillus] and/or [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] of the Pontic Range.
Communities of [Vaccinium myrtillus] and/or [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] of the Caucasus.

Low [Genista spp.] or [Chamaecytisus spp.] heaths of the subalpine, low alpine or montane belts of high southern nemoral mountains, in particular of the southern Alps, the Apennines, the Dinarides, the southern Carpathians, the Balkan Range, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Pelagonides, the northern Pindus, the Rhodopides, the Thessalian mountains.

[Genista radiata], [Genista holopetala], [Genista hassertiana] heaths of the montane, subalpine and alpine belts of the southeastern Alps, in particular the Bergamesque Alps, the Dolomites, the Carnic Alps, the Julian Alps, of the Dinarides, with more localized stations in the Novarese Alps, the northern and central Apennines, the southern Carpathians, the Pelagonides, the northern Pindus, the Thessalian mountains.

Low shrub formations dominated by the Balkan peninsula endemic [Chamaecytisus eriocarpus] ([Chamaecytisus absinthioides]) characteristic of the subalpine and montane belts of the Balkan Range, of the Rhodopides (Rila, Pirin, Orvilos, Vrondous, Pangeon, Falakron, Rhodope) and of the Moeso-Macedonian mountains south to the Belasitza-Kerkini.
[Chamaecytisus hirsutus] heaths of the mountains of the southern Balkan and Hellenic peninsula, in particular, of the Pelagonides.

Very low, single-stratum, carpets of trailing azalea, [Loiseleuria procumbens], prostrate [Vaccinium spp.] or other prostrate ericoid shrublets, accompanied by lichens, of windswept, mostly snowfree, localities in the alpine belt of the high mountains of the Alpine system.
Dwarf alpine heaths of the western Alpides dominated by [Loiseleuria procumbens], often accompanied by [Vaccinium spp.], and rich in lichens.
[Loiseleuria procumbens]-dominated dwarf heaths of the Alps.
[Loiseleuria procumbens]-dominated dwarf heaths of the Pyrenees.

Local formations of the lowel alpine level on windswept localities in the eastern and southern Carpathian Mountains (Rodnei, Bucegi, Fagaras, Retezat, Tarcu), dominated by [Loiseleuria procumbens], with some regional species including [Senecio carniolicus], [Sesleria coerulans], [Potentilla aurea] ssp. [chrysocraspeda] and [Rhododendron myrtifolium].

Very low, single-stratum, carpets of prostrate [Vaccinium spp.] and lichens, of windswept, mostly snowfree, localities in the alpine belt of the high mountains of the Alpine system, for the most part [Vaccinium]-dominated facies of the trailing azalea communities, in which [Loiseleuria procumbens] often accompanies [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] or [Vaccinium uliginosum], the latter represented, as in 31.411, 31.44 and 31.4A, by the distinctive low, small-leaved, creeping, mat-forming entity variously referred to as [Vaccinium gaultherioides], [Vaccinium uliginosum] ssp. [microphyllum], [Vaccinium alpina], [Vaccinium pubescens], [Vaccinium uliginosum] ssp. [pubescens].
Prostrate [Vaccinium spp.] and lichen carpets of windswept localities in the alpine belt of the Alps.

Very local prostrate [Vaccinium spp.] and lichen carpets of high windswept summits and peaks, in the lower alpine belt of the Eastern and Southern Carpathians, dominated by [Vaccinium gaultherioides] ([Vaccinium uliginosum] ssp. [microphyllum]) and [Cetraria islandica] with [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Juncus trifidus], [Festuca airoides] and [Cetraria islandica].

Nombre oficial: Rhodopide and Balkan dwarf [Vaccinium] wind heaths
Definición oficial: Communities of prostrate [Vaccinium uliginosum] and lichens of the alpine level of the mountains of the Rhodopide system and of the Balkan Range.
Communities of prostrate [Vaccinium uliginosum] and lichens of the alpine level of the Rila and Pirin mountains.
[Vaccinium uliginosum] and lichen mats occupying windswept localities in the alpine belt of the Balkan Range, local and fragmented representatives of the Rhodopide communities of unit 31.41231.
Prostrate [Vaccinium uliginosum] ssp. [microphyllum], or rarely [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], and lichen mats of high windswept localities in the Pontic Range.
Prostrate [Vaccinium spp.] and lichen mats of high windswept localities in the Caucasus.
Prostrate [Vaccinium spp.] and lichen mats of high windswept localities in the Himalayas and associated ranges.

Carpets of prostrate shrubs of the ericaceous genus [Gaultheria], in particular [Gaultheria nummularioides], [Gaultheria trichophylla], [Gaultheria pyroloides], accompanied by lichens, of windswept, mostly snowfree, localities in the alpine belt of the Himalayas, up to altitudes of 4500 metres.

[Rhododendron spp.]-dominated heaths of acid podsols in the Alps, the Pyrenees, the Dinarides, the Carpathians, the Balkan Range, the Pontic Range, the Caucasus and the Himalayan system, often with [Vaccinium spp.], sometimes with dwarf pines.
[Rhododendron ferrugineum]-dominated heaths of acid podsols in the Alps, often with [Vaccinium spp.], sometimes with [Pinus mugo]. They often alternate in mosaic with units 31.431 and 31.44.
[Rhododendron ferrugineum]-dominated heaths of acid podsols in the Pyrenees, often with [Vaccinium spp.] and alternating in mosaic with units 31.431 and 31.44.
[Rhododendron ferrugineum]-dominated heaths of the Dinarides.

Heaths of the subalpine and lower alpine levels (1700-2000 m) of the eastern and southern Carpathian Mountains, common and widespread, but occupying small surfaces, dominated by [Rhododendron myrtifolium] ([Rhododendron kotschyi]), [Vaccinium gaultherioides] and [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], with some regional species such as [Soldanella hungarica] ssp. [major], [Potentilla aurea] ssp. [chrysocraspeda], [Melampyrum saxosum], [Campanula abietina] and [Campanula serrata].

Nombre oficial: Rhodopide and Balkan Kotschys alpenrose heaths
Definición oficial: [Rhododendron myrtifolium]-dominated heaths of the subalpine belt of the Balkan Range and the Rila.
[Rhododendron myrtifolium]-dominated heaths of the subalpine belt of the central Balkan Range.
[Rhododendron myrtifolium]-dominated heaths of the subalpine belt of the eastern Rila.

Heaths of the Pontic Range, formed, mostly above treeline, by [Rhododendron caucasicum], [Rhododendron smirnovii], [Rhododendron ungernii], [Rhododendron x sochadzeae], sometimes with [Rhododendron ponticum], [Rhododendron luteum].
Rhododendron heaths of the Caucasus, dominated, for the most part, by [Rhododendron caucasicum].

Rhododendron heaths of the alpine zone of the Himalayas dominated by [Rhododendron lepidotum], [Rhododendron setosum], [Rhododendron anthopogon], [Rhododendron nivale], [Rhododendron litangensis], [Rhododendron open-shawianum], [Rhododendron thymifolium], [Rhododendron capitatum], and of the lower transition zone to mountain woodland, with [Rhododendron campanulatum].

Nombre oficial: Southern Palaearctic mountain dwarf juniper scrub
Definición oficial: Usually dense formations of prostrate junipers of the higher levels of southern Palaearctic mountains.

Thermophile [Juniperus nana]-dominated heaths of the upper levels, mostly of the subalpine or equivalent levels, of the Alps, mostly in the central and southern chains, of the northern and central Apennines, the Corsican and Sardinian mountains, the Forez, the Pyrenees, the Carpathians, the Dinarides, the Balkan Range, the Rhodopide Mountains, the Moeso-Macedonian Mountains, the Caucasus, the high mountains of the Iberian and Hellenic peninsulas, the Pontic Range, the Taurus, the Himalayan system, the temperate Far Eastern mountains.

[Juniperus sabina] heaths of Iberia, the Alps, the Apennines, the Tell of North Africa, the southeastern Central European mountains, the Pontic Range, the Anti-Taurus, the western Caucasus, Crimea, the Elburz, the Altai.
Rare [Juniperus sabina] heaths of limestone and dolomite crests of the Djurdjura.
[Juniperus sabina] heaths of the Altai.
Oro-Mediterranean [Juniperus sabina] heaths of Iberia north to the Pyrenees, where they are limited to south-facing slopes in the montane and subalpine belt of the central part of the range.
[Juniperus sabina] heaths of the montane level of inner Alpine valleys with sporadic fragmentary occurrence in the alti-Mediterranean subalpine level of the southwestern Alps.
[Juniperus sabina] heaths of rare stations in the Marcho-Abruzzian Apennines.
[Juniperus sabina] heaths of the Dinarides.

Thermophile [Juniperus sabina]-dominated formation on limestone in the montane belt of the Apuseni Mountains of the southeastern Carpathians, accompanied by regional species [Rhamnus saxatilis] ssp. [tinctorius] and [Sesleria rigida], [Thymus comosus], and [Rhamnus catharticus]. Sporadic fragmentary [Juniperus sabina] formations of the Balkan Range and the Rila mountains.
[Juniperus sabina]-dominated scrubs of the Anatolian plateau.
[Juniperus sabina]-dominated scrubs of the Caucasus.
[Juniperus sabina]-dominated scrubs of Crimea.
[Juniperus sabina]-dominated scrubs of the Elburz.
[Juniperus hemisphaerica] heaths of Iberia, the southern Apennines, Sicily (Madonie, Nebrodi, Etna), Greece, the Caucasus and North Africa.
[Juniperus oxycedrus] heaths of high mountain slopes of Greece, the Near East and the Caucasus.
[Juniperus squamata] heaths of high altitudes of the Himalayan system, west to Afghanistan, and of the mountains of China.
[Juniperus recurva] heaths of high altitudes of the Himalayan system, west to Afghanistan, and of the mountains of China.
[Juniperus indica] heaths of dry iner valleys of the Himalayan system, east to Yunnan, ascending to an altitude of 5200 m.

Prostrate scrub facies of the open juniper steppe-forests of high arid slopes of the Elburz, the mountains of Transcaucasia and of Tadzhikistan, the Zagros, the Irano-Afghan plateau, the western and eastern Himalayas and the southeastern and southwestern Arabian peninsula, dominated by junipers of the [Juniperus excelsa] group, often united in an eastern species, the Persian juniper [Juniperus macropoda], or divided into several closely related species, [Juniperus macropoda], [Juniperus seravschanica], [Juniperus turcomanica], but by some taxonomists judged undistinguishable from [Juniperus excelsa]. [Juniperus semiglobosa] may also accompany the other forms or dominate the community in Tadzhikistan, Uzbekistan and Afghanistan.

Dwarf heaths dominated by [Empetrum hermaphroditum] and [Vaccinium uliginosum], with [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], lycopodes ([Huperzia selago], [Diphasiastrum alpinum]), mosses ([Barbilophozia lycopodioides], [Hylocomium splendens], [Pleurozium schreberi], [Rhythidiadelphus triquetrus]) and lichens ([Cetraria islandica], [Cladonia arbuscula], [Cladonia rangiferina], [Cladonia stellaris], [Cladonia gracilis], [Peltigera aphthosa]) of the subalpine belt of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Dinarides, the Pyrenees, the Central Massif, the Sudeten, the Jura, the Northern Apennines, characteristic of relatively windswept, snow-free stations, in frost-exposure situations that are, however, less extreme than those prevailing where communities of unit 31.41 dominate. Unlike the formations of 31.41, those of 31.44 are clearly two-layered.

Alpine and high-montane heaths of the highlands and islands of Scotland and, very locally, of the Lake District and of Ireland, alpine and lowland boreal heaths of Iceland, alpine heaths of boreal mountains, in particular of the mountains of Scandinavia, of the Urals, of the mountains of Siberia, alpine heaths of Far Eastern mountains at, or just south of, the limits of the boreal zone, with [Juniperus nana], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Phyllodoce caerulea], [Betula nana] and elements of alpine flora.

Prostrate alpine and high-montane [Calluna vulgaris] or [Vaccinium myrtillus] heaths of windswept summits and ridges, with little snow cover, of the Highlands, the Inner Hebrides and, very locally, of the uplands of Ireland, England and Wales, with [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Arctostaphylos alpinus].

Dwarf, prostrate, matted, wind-clipped, low-alpine [Calluna vulgaris] heaths, often with lichen mats, of windswept summits, ridges and mountain passes exposed to cold, continental climates, in the Highlands of Scotland, particularly the east-central Highlands, with very few fragmentary outposts in isolated upland areas of England and Wales, with [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Empetrum hermaphroditum].

Prostrate, wind-clipped, open, low-alpine [Calluna vulgaris] heaths of moderate to fairly high altitude windswept plateaux and ridges of the northwest Highlands of Scotland, with outposts in the Grampians, descending locally to lower altitudes on Skye, with an abundance of [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], and with [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Arctostaphylos alpinus],[Arctostaphylos uva-ursi].

Prostrate, open, low-alpine [Calluna vulgaris]  heaths of windswept ridges and crests of the northwest Highlands of Scotland, generally at slightly higher altitudes than those of unit 31.4512, though also extending locally to low altitudes, in particular, along the northern Scottish coast, with [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Empetrum hermaphroditum],[Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Empetrum nigrum], [Erica cinerea], sometimes [Salix herbacea]

Prostrate [Vaccinium myrtillus]-[Empetrum hermaphroditum] heaths, with abundant [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], of fairly exposed slopes and summits at moderate to high altitudes of the northwestern Highlands of Scotland, with scattered representatives in the Grampians, and lower altitude occurrences along the west coast of Scotland and on Skye, with [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Alchemilla alpina], [Carex bigelowii].

Subboreal [Calluna vulgaris]-[Vaccinium myrtillus] heaths of windswept summits and ridges of Ireland, with [Empetrum nigrum], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum] and sometimes [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Salix herbacea], [Diphasiastrum alpinum] ([Lycopodium alpinum])

Low- to very low-growing low alpine and subalpine [Vaccinium myrtillus] heaths of the Highlands of Scotland, Skye, and, locally, the Southern Uplands and northern England, characteristic of somewhat more protected stations with longer snow cover than those of unit 31.451, with [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Rubus chamaemorus], [Cornus suecica], [Carex bigelowii], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum].

Very low, matted, low alpine heaths of moderately sheltered and snowbound slopes of the Grampians and, more locally, of the northwestern Highlands, with fragmentary outposts in the Southern Uplands and the Lake District, formed by [Vaccinium myrtillus] with [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Empetrum hermaphroditum] and abundant lichens, in particular, [Cladonia arbuscula], [Cladonia uncialis], [Cetraria islandica]. [Carex bigelowii], [Deschampsia flexuosa] and [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum] are often abundant.

Low, subalpine heaths of the central and northwestern Highlands, with outposts in the Moffat-Tweedsmuir hills and in the Cheviots, within the Southern Uplands, developed on peaty ground under oceanic climates with prolonged snow cover, formed by [Vaccinium myrtillus] with [Calluna vulgaris], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], and sometimes [Vaccinium uliginosum], associated with a moist carpet of bryophytes. [Rubus chamaemorus], [Cornus suecica] and [Carex bigelowii] are characteristic of the species cort¿ge.

Prostrate [Juniperus nana] mats of the Highlands of Scotland, restricted to a limited number of stations on the west side of mountains in the northwest Highlands and on Skye, with [Calluna vulgaris], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Arctostapylos alpina], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Cladonia uncialis], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum] and oceanic hepatics.

Alpine heaths of the boreal mountains of Scandinavia, with [Juniperus nana], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Vaccinium spp.], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], dwarf [Salix spp.], [Betula nana] and elements of alpine flora.

Open, scattered heaths of the mountains of Fennoscandia with [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Diapensia lapponica], [Arctostaphylos alpinus] and many lichens, occurring in variable species dominance, installed on patches in snow fields swept bare by the wind in winter, often on dry gravel, sometimes on solifluction, and with high insolation. Maritime and continental types can be identified by the lichen cover.

Heaths of the alpine belt of Fennoscandia, dominated by [Betula nana] and [Empetrum hermaphroditum], with [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Arctostaphylos alpina], [Salix glauca], [Salix lapponum] and a ground layer often rich in lichens, growing on poor, gravelly and sandy soils, with a low pH.
