Xerophilous low heaths of the subalpine and lower alpine levels of Fennoscandia dominated by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Betula nana], with a richly developed lichen layer and few vascular plants. [Juncus trifidus] and [Luzula spicata] are also characteristic. There is little or no snow cover.

Subalpine and alpine heaths of the mountains of Fennoscandia under rather continental climate, composed of thick (up to 20 cm) lichen carpets, dominated by [Cladonia alpestris]. During periods of drought, lichen carpet often cracks into polygons and mosses and scattered vascular plants appear. Lichen heaths can carpet large areas in lower situations

Lower alpine heaths of southern Norway, with low, prostrate, [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum], accompanied by  [Antennaria dioica], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Euphrasia frigida], [Betula pubescens], [Vacinium vitis-idaea], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Carex vaginata] with mosses and lichens. Occurs on dry, poor, sandy or gravelly soils containing richer elements, though not on pure limestone, with a thin humus layer, in localities with strong insolation and early thaw.

Often low heaths of lower alpine levels of Fennoscandia dominated by [Phyllodoce caerulea] and [Vaccinium myrtillus], with [Betula nana], [Betula pubescens], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Juniperus nana], [Alchemilla alpina], [Trientalis europaea] and many mosses and lichens, on moist soils with a humus layer, protected by snow for short periods.

Heaths of the boreal and arctic zones of Fennoscandia, mostly under maritime climate, dominated by [Cornus suecica] and [Vaccinium uliginosum] accompanied by [Solidago vigaurea] and [Trientalis europaea], with [Calluna vulgaris], [Carex bigelowii] often covering extensive areas in alternance with grass heaths, on relatively poor soils, normally snow protected.

Lower alpine heaths of western Fennoscandia, dominated by [Gymnocarpium dryopteris] and [Vaccinium myrtillus], with [Salix herbacea], [Trientalis europea], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Rumex acetosa], occurring over small surfaces within the dwarf cornel-northern bilberry heaths of unit 31.4547, in the shelter of stones.

Lower alpine heaths of Fennoscandia, dominated by low scrub (0.5-1m) of [Betula nana], [Juniperus nana], [Vaccinium myrtillus], with very common [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], on dry to mesic ground with low pH, somewhat snow protected.

Lowland and alpine boreal heaths of Iceland, Spitzbergen and Greenland formed by low, compact or mat-forming shrubs of Ericaceae, [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Betula nana], [Juniperus nana] and [Salix spp.] and alpine flora elements.

Lowland and alpine boreal heaths of Iceland formed by low, compact or mat-forming shrubs of Ericaceae, [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Betula nana], [Juniperus nana] and [Salix spp.] and alpine flora elements.

Heaths of Iceland, often low-growing, dominated by [Vaccinium uliginosum] and [Phyllodoce caerulea], with many mosses, developed in most lowland and lower alpine regions on moist soils with a humus layer. Northern bilberry heaths require less snow protection than the [Phyllodoce]-bilberry heaths of unit 31.45516 and often covers larger areas.

Dwarf heaths of Iceland, often sparse, dominated by [Loiseleuria procumbens], usually associated with [Empetrum hermaphroditum] and [Vaccinium uliginosum]. The ground layer is well developed, with a cover of the order of 30% to 50%, often dominated by [Rhacomitrium canescens] or [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], accompanied by a diverse cort¿ge of lichens. The community is characteristic of the lower alpine zone of northern and eastern Iceland, usually developed on shallow soils, in wind-exposed situations with reduced snow cover.

Dwarf heaths of Iceland dominated by [Betula nana], usually associated with [Salix phylicifolia], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], with [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Salix lanata], [Salix herbacea], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Kobresia myosuroides], [Juncus trifidus]. The muscinal layer is moderately developed, with a cover of the order of 30%. These heaths are mostly developed in the lowland and lower alpine zones, in wind-exposed situations with low snow cover, often on loess deposits.

Xerophilous dwarf heaths of Iceland dominated by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], variously associated with [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Calluna vulgaris], [Betula nana], [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Salix lanata], [Salix herbacea], [Polygonum viviparum], [Kobresia myosuroides], [Carex bigelowii], [Festuca vivipara], [Festuca richardsonii], [Poa alpina], [Equisetum variegatum], with an often richly developed lichen layer. They are developed in the lowlands and lower alpine levels on a variety of substrates, including lavas, with relatively shallow soils. Where they occur alongside [Empetrum]-[Vaccinium] heaths of unit 31.2113 they occupy more wind-exposed, more snowfree surfaces, and differ by the lower stature of the erico¿ds, the often more open structure of the shrub layer and the lesser prominence of [Vaccinium spp.].

Heaths of Iceland dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], usually associated with [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Salix herbacea], [Rubus saxatilis], [Polygonum viviparum], [Galium boreale], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Carex bigelowii], [Luzula multiflora], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Equisetum pratense] and, often, with [Thymus praecox] ssp. [arcticus], [Galium normanii], [Platanthera hyperborea], [Dactylorhiza islandica], [Festuca vivipara], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Agrostis tenuis]. The mucinal layer is poorly to moderately developed, with a total cover ranging between 0 and 40%. [Rhacomitrium canescens], [Lophozia sudetica], [Ptilidium ciliare], [Drepanocladus uncinatus], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], [Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus], [Rhytidiadelphus loreus] are the most common species. They are mostly limited to the lowlands, best developed in the central northern lowlands, apparently absent from parts of the northwestern peninsula, often developed on loess deposits.

Heaths of Iceland dominated by [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], accompanied by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Calluna vulgaris], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Rubus saxatilis], [Thymus praecox] ssp. [arcticus], [Festuca vivipara], [Carex bigelowii], [Kobresia myosuroides]. The muscinal layer is practically nonexistent. These heaths are characteristic of steep, dry, sunny slopes in the lowland and lower alpine zones.

Heaths of Iceland, often low-growing, dominated by [Vaccinium myrtillus] and [Phyllodoce caerulea], with [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Betula nana], [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Juniperus nana], [Rubus saxatilis], [Alchemilla vulgaris], [Galium verum], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Polygonum viviparum], [Ranunculus acris], [Pyrola minor], [Carex bigelowii], and many mosses and lichens, developed in the lowlands and lower alpine zone of northern and eastern Iceland, on moist soils with a humus layer, moderately protected by snow.

Heaths of Iceland dominated by [Cornus suecica] and [Vaccinium uliginosum], accompanied by, among others, [Calluna vulgaris], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Carex bigelowii], limited to four areas of northern Iceland, the northwestern fjords, the Snaefell peninsula, the north coast around the mouth of Eyjafj¿rdur, north of Akureyri, and the northeastern coast between Vopnafj¿rdur and Herads. They are developed at generally low altitude, in strongly oceanic sectors, usually in snow protected sites.

Heaths of Iceland dominated by [Gymnocarpium dryopteris], associated with [Vaccinium myrtillus] or [Vaccinium uliginosum], mostly limited to small surfaces in the shelter of stones, within lowland heath complexes, in particular, of the northwestern peninsula.

Heaths of Iceland dominated by [Betula nana], [Juniperus nana] and [Vaccinium myrtillus], with [Vaccinium uliginosum] and, sometimes, in the east and northeast, [Vaccinium vitis-idea], forming scrubs 0.5 to 1 m high on dry to mesic ground of the lowlands and the lower alpine zone, in somewhat snow-protected situations.

Boreoarctic heaths of Greenland, with [Salix glauca] ssp. [callicarpea], [Betula glandulosa], [Betula nana], [Alnus crispa], [Sorbus groenlandica], [Juniperus nana], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum] ssp. [microphyllum], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] ssp. [minus], [Phyllodoce caerulea], [Rhododendron lapponicum].

Mountain heaths of the Urals, with [Betula nana], [Salix glauca], [Salix pulchra], [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia], [Cassiope tetragona], [Cassiope hypnoides], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Vaccinium uliginosum] ssp. [microphyllum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Phyllodoce caerulea], [Ledum palustre] ssp. [decumbens].
High mountain dwarf shrub communities of the Sayan mountains (Korotkov), as well as of the northeastern Siberian highlands, the Altai and possibly the Khangai.
Alpine heaths of Far Eastern mountains, south of the main lowland taiga zone, including prostrate [Vaccinium spp.] and lichen mats of high windswept localities of the mountains of China and Japan.
Heaths of arctic mountains, coasts and islands of the Palaearctic zone, mostly dominated by or rich in [Cassiope tetragona], often associated with [Dryas] heaths of unit 31.494.

Alpine heaths restricted to mostly oceanic climates of northwestern boreal and arctic Fennoscandia, dominated by dense carpets of [Cassiope tetragona], [Empetrum hermaphroditum] and [Dryas octopetala] with wax-leaved and cushion plants
Heaths of Spitzbergen dominated by [Cassiope tetragona], with [Dryas octopetala] var. [minor], [Carex rupestris], [Silene acaulis] var. [arctica], [Drepanocladus uncinatus].

Heaths of Greenland dominated by [Cassiope tetragona], with [Dryas octopetala], [Carex bigelowii], [Silene acaulis], [Vaccinium uliginosum] ssp. [microphyllum], [Phyllodoce caerulea], [Drepanocladus uncinatus].

Formations of [Bruckenthalia spiculifolia], often accompanied by [Juniperus nana], [Vaccinium myrtillus] and herbaceous alpine grassland species, occupying damp, noncalcareous substrates of high mountains of the Balkan peninsula and northern Anatolia.
[Bruckenthalia spiculifolia] heaths of the alpine and subalpine belts of the Vitosha, the Rila, the Pirin, the Slovianka, the Rhodopes, the Vrondous, the Menikion and the Pangeon.

[Bruckenthalia spiculifolia] formations of the subalpine, alpine and  locally, montane, belts of the Pelagonian mountains, south to the Varnous, the Vitsi, the Piperitsa, the Voras, the Pinovon, the Tzena, of the Moeso-Macedonian mountains south to the Kerkini (Belles range), and of the Pieria in the northern Thessalian mountains.
[Bruckenthalia spiculifolia] formations of the Balkan Range, with northern representatives in the southeastern Carpathians.
[Bruckenthalia spiculifolia] formations of the subalpine, alpine and locally, montane, belts of the Balkan Range.

Sporadically distributed formations in the Apuseni Mountains and the southern Carpathians, dominated by [Bruckenthalia spiculifolia], accompanied by [Juniperus nana], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] and the endemic or near-endemic [Campanula patula] ssp. [abietina] ([Campanula abietina]), [Campanula serrata] and [Potentilla aurea] ssp. [chrysocraspeda].
Scattered dwarf shrub formations dominated by [Bruckenthalia spiculifolia], of the alpine and subalpine belt of high mountains of northern Anatolia.

Mats of [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi] or [Arctostaphylos alpinus] of the alpine, subalpine and locally, montane, belts of the Alps, the Pyrenees, the northern and central Apennines, the Dinarides, the Carpathians, the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides (south to the Slavianka-Orvilos, the Menikion, the Pangeon, the Falakron and the Rhodopi), the Moeso-Macedonian mountains (including Athos), the Pelagonides (south to the Greek Macedonian border ranges Tzena, Pinovon and Kajmakchalan) and Olympus, in the Thessalian mountains, mostly on calcareous substrates.

Forest substitution heaths, treeline fringe formations and alpine heaths or mats of calcareous soils in the Alps and the Dinarides, with [Rhododendron hirsutum], [Rhododendron intermedium], [Rhodothamnus chamaecistus] and [Erica herbacea], often accompanied by [Clematis alpina], [Daphne striata], [Daphne mezereum], [Globularia cordifolia], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi]. [Rhododendron hirsutum] and, mostly in the Austrian Alps, [Erica herbacea] are the most frequent dominants

Forest substitution heaths, treeline fringe formations and alpine heaths or mats dominated by [Rhododendron hirsutum], of calcareous soils in the Alps and the Dinarides. [Rhododendron intermedium], [Rhodothamnus chamaecistus] and [Erica herbacea] may participate in the constitution of the heath, often accompanied by [Clematis alpina] and [Daphne mezereum].

Species-rich montane, subalpine and low alpine heaths of calcareous soils of the Alps and the Dinarids, dominated by [Erica herbacea] ([Erica carnea]), mostly characteristic of the Austrian northern and southern calcareous Alps, south to the Dolomites and the Karawanken, with [Sesleria albicans], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Daphne striata], [Globularia cordifolia], [Globularia nudicaulis], [Polygala chamaebuxus]. Small shrubs other than [Erica herbacea], in particular [Globularia cordifolia], may locally dominate communities. Distinctive formations also exist on siliceous and on serpentine substrates. They are provisionally included in this unit.
Dwarf heaths formed by mats of the woody [Dryas octopetala] in high Palaearctic mountains, in arctic and boreal regions and in isolated Atlantic coastal outposts.
Mats of [Dryas octopetala] of the high levels of the mountains of the western Alpine system, the Jura and the Central Massif, in calcicolous alpine grasslands and on high mountain rocks.
[Dryas octopetala] mats of the high levels of the Alps, widespread pioneering communities on calcareous substrates.

[Dryas octopetala] mats of the high levels of the Pyrenees and Central Massif, relatively uncommon pioneering communities of calcareous substrates distributed in the Corbi¿res (pic dOurthizet), in the eastern and central Pyrenees, and, very locally, on high summits of the Cental Massif ranges of Monts-Dore and Cantal.

[Dryas octopetala] mats of the high levels of the western Jura, mostly above 1300 metres, on, in particular, la D¿le, le Reculet, le Creux-du-Van, le Chasseral, le Mont-dOr, le Suchet, la Dent de Vaulion.

Rare [Dryas octopetala] mats of the high levels of the Apuan Alps, the Pistoiese Apennines (Mandromini), the Central Apennines (Sibillini, Terminillo, Mount Viglio) and the Abruzzian and Campanian Apennines (Monte Cassino, Monte Cairo).
Communities dominated by [Dryas octopetala], scattered in calcicolous subalpine and alpine grasslands of the Carpathians and the Balkan Range.
[Dryas octopetala] mats of calcareous substrates in the subalpine and alpine belts of the western Carpathians.

[Dryas octopetala] communities widespread in calcicolous subalpine and alpine grassland of the Romanian Carpathians, having as endemics [Achillea oxyloba] ssp. [schurii] ([Achillea schurii]), [Oxytropis carpatica], and [Cerastium transsilvanicum].
Calciphile communities dominated by [Dryas octopetala] of subalpine and alpine grasslands of the Balkan Range, west to the Gethian mountains of eastern Serbia (Suva Planina).
[Dryas octopetala] mats of calcareous substrates of the high levels of the Dinarides and the Pelagonides south to Mount Tzena.
[Dryas octopetala] communities of the Rila, the Pirin, the Slavianka-Orvilos and the Falakron.

[Dryas octopetala] dwarf heaths of the oceanic lowlands of northern Scotland, the Inner Hebrides and western Ireland, associated with Durness, Jurassic or Carboniferous limestone outcroppings and karstic pavements, or with shell sands blown over rocky or peaty headlands, with [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Thymus praecox], [Carex flacca], [Viola riviniana], [Plantago maritima], [Lotus corniculatus], [Festuca ovina], [Calluna vulgaris], [Carex rupestris].
[Dryas octopetala] dwarf heaths of the oceanic lowlands of northern Scotland, developed on Durness limestone outcroppings and karstic pavements, or on shell sands blown over headlands.
[Dryas octopetala] or [Dryas octopetala]-[Arctostaphylos uva-ursi] dwarf heaths of the Inner Hebrides, recorded from Skye, Raasay and Rhum, associated with Durness or Jurassic limestone outcroppings.

[Dryas octopetala] or [Dryas]-[Arctostaphylos] dwarf heaths of western Ireland, characteristic of the Burren, where they cover extensive surfaces of bare or thinly peat-covered Carboniferous limestones.
[Dryas octopetala] heaths of the boreoalpine and arctoalpine levels of northern Palaearctic mountains of Scotland and Fennoscandia.
High-altitude species-rich [Dryas] cliff-ledge communities of the mica-shist hills of the central Highlands of Scotland, with fragmentary outposts in Lakeland and Snowdonia.
[Dryas octopetala] heaths of the boreoalpine and arctoalpine levels of the mountains of Fennoscandia.

Dense, closed, low heaths of Fenoscandian mountains dominated by [Dryas octopetala], with [Diphasiastrum alpinum], [Carex brunnescens] and [Omalotheca supina] ([Gnaphalium supinum]), installed on dry calcareous gravels, sands and rock pavements. Accompanying species vary over the very broad range of this habitat and include [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Arctostaphylos alpina], [Betula nana], [Juniperus nana], [Salix reticulata], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Astragalus alpinus], [Campanula rotundifolia], [Cerastium alpinum], [Draba norvegica], [Silene acaulis], [Minuartia stricta], [Parnassia palustris], [Pedicularis flammula], [Pedicularis oederi], [Potentilla nivea], [Pyrola norvegica], [Viola rupestris] ssp. [relicta], [Polygonum viviparum] ([Bistorta vivipara]), [Leucorchis albida] ssp. [straminea] ([Leucorchis straminea]), [Oxytropis lapponica], [Carex atrata], [Carex capillaris], [Carex rupestris], [Kobresia myosuroides], [Thalictrum alpinum]. The [Dryas] sometimes is so dense that no other species are present. A ground layer is often absent

Very low, open heaths of boreal mountains dominated by [Dryas octopetala] and [Kobresia myosuroides] occupying weathered calcareous gravels or pavements on windswept exposures with a thin humus layer, negligible snow cover and early thaw. Codominating species include [Carex fuliginosa], [Carex nardina] and, locally, [Festuca ovina], acompanied by [Draba fladnizensis], [Draba nivalis], [Draba norvegica], [Saxifraga cespitosa], [Saxifraga nivalis], [Saxifraga opositifolia], [Arnica alpina], [Campanula uniflora], [Diapensia lapponica], [Euphrasia lapponica], [Gentianella tenella], [Minuartia rubella], [Potentilla nivea], [Poa glauca], and, locally, [Carex glacialis], rich in lichens.

Sparse [Dryas octopetala] heaths of the low to midalpine level of Fennoscandian mountains, with an abundant, often continuous ground cover of mosses, particularly [Tomentypmum nitens] and [Sphagnum warnstorfii], developed on calcareous substrates that are permanently moist or subjected to periodical near-surface ground water flow. [Viola biflora], [Carex norvegica], [Minuartia biflora], [Thalictrum alpinum] have a preference for this habitat.
Maritime or submaritime [Dryas octopetala] heaths of the arctic lowlands of the Palaearctic continent and of the low arctic and subarctic islands of the North Atlantic and the Northern Ocean.

Low, open, heaths of the western and northern coasts of arctic Scandinavia developed on sandy, calcareous soils in exposed coastal climates, dominated by [Dryas octopetala] and [Empetrum hermaphroditum], accompanied by short sedges and grasses, usually without a mucinal layer.

[Dryas octopetala]-dominated heaths of Iceland. [Empetrum hermaphroditum] often dominates with the [Dryas]. Other accompaniers may include [Calluna vulgaris], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Thymus arcticus], [Silene acaulis], [Armeria maritima], [Cerastium alpinum], [Draba incana], [Rhinanthus minor], [Euphrasia frigida], [Parnassia palustris], [Tofieldia pusilla], [Kobresia myosuroides], [Carex bigelowii], [Carex capillaris], [Carex glacialis], [Carex rupestris], [Carex vaginata], [Festuca vivipara], [Festuca richardsonii], [Luzula multiflora], [Luzula spicata], [Thalictrum alpinum], [Botrychium lunaria], [Equisetum pratense], [Equisetum boreale]. The moss layer can be variously developed and include, in particular, [Rhacomitrium canescens], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], [Drepanocladus uncinatus]. [Dryas] heaths occupy a variety of substrates, in particular, loess deposits, gravels, moraines, sands, in mostly somewhat wind-exposed situations.

[Dryas] heaths of Spitzbergen developed on shallow, well drained soils, dominated by [Dryas octopetala] var. [minor] or by [Dryas octopetala] and sedges ([Carex rupestris]), [Carex nardina], with [Salix polaris], [Luzula confusa], [Pedicularis dasyantha], [Polygonum viviparum] ([Bistorta vivipara]), [Saxifraga oppositifolia], [Drepanocladus uncinatus], [Stereocaulon alpinum].
[Dryas] heaths of Greenland.
Dwarf heaths formed by mats of the woody [Dryas octopetala] or [Dryas punctata] in high mountains of the far eastern Palaearctic.

[Pinus mugo] brushes of the dry eastern inner Alps, of the northern and southeastern outer Alps, of the southwestern Alps and the Swiss Jura, of the eastern greater Hercynian ranges, of the Carpathians, of the Apennines, of the Dinarides and the neighbouring Pelagonides, of the Pirin, the Rila and the Balkan Range

Nombre oficial: Inner Alpine dwarf mountain pine scrub
Definición oficial: [Pinus mugo] brushes of the dry eastern inner Alps, of local occurrence throughout the area, accompanied by [Rhododendron hirsutum], [Erica herbacea], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Rhodothamnus chamaecistus], or, on siliceous ground, [Rhododendron ferrugineum] and [Vaccinium myrtillus].

Nombre oficial: Outer Alpine dwarf mountain pine scrub
Definición oficial: Main range [Pinus mugo] brushes of well-drained, mostly calcareous, soils of the northern and southeastern outer Alps, usually with [Rhododendron hirsutum], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Arctostaphylos alpinus], [Sorbus chamaemespilus], [Lonicera caerulea], [Lonicera alpigena], [Calamagrostis varia], sometimes with [Erica herbacea] or [Rhodothamnus chamaecistus] and, in acidophilous variants, known in particular from the Karawanken, [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Rhododendron ferrugineum], [Empetrum hermaphroditum].

Very local [Pinus mugo] brushes of the southwestern Alps (Moyen-Valais, Haute-Roya, Ligurian Alps), with [Juniperus nana], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Daphne striata], [Erica herbacea], [Carex firma] and, in some stations, [Rhododendron hirsutum]
Rare and local Apennine formations of the Parmian Apennines, the Abruzzi and the Campanian Apennines.
[Pinus mugo] brushes of the Sudeten, the Erzgebirge, the Bayerischerwald, the B¿hmerwald, with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Salix silesiaca] [s. l.], [Trientalis europaea], [Homogyne alpina].
[Pinus mugo] brushes of the Carpathians.

[Pinus mugo] brushes forming an extensive belt in the upper subalpine zone of the higher mountains of the northwestern, eastern and southeastern Carpathians with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Ribes petraeum] var. [carpaticum], [Sorbus aucuparia] var. [glabrata], [Rosa pendulina], [Homogyne alpina], [Soldanella hungarica] ssp. [major] in siliceous stations, with tall herbs in calcareous ones. The southeastern Carpathian formations, particularly those of the Apuseni Mountains, harbour the regional endemic [Campanula patula] ssp. [abietina] ([Campanula abietina]).
Widespread formations of [Pinus mugo] accompanied by the regional endemic [Rhododendron myrtifolium], on shallow-soil slopes of the subalpine level of the southeastern Carpathians.

[Pinus mugo]-dominated formations of the Dinarides and of neighbouring chains of the Pelagonides, in particular the Jakupica range, with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Rubus saxatilis], [Rubus idaeus], [Sorbus aucuparia], [Rosa pendulina], [Veratrum album] and [Polygonatum verticillatum].

[Pinus mugo]-dominated formations of the Pirin and the Rila, with remnants in the Balkan Range, including the Suva Planina. This habitat has been severely reduced by clearance for pastures, and its dirtribution area has regressed

Nombre oficial: Far Eastern dwarf Siberian pine scrub
Definición oficial: Scrubs of eastern Siberia, northeastern China, Korea and the Japanese archipelago formed by [Pinus pumilio].

Bushy facies of the tall herb communities of moist, rich soils of Eurasian mountains, mostly characteristic of the subalpine zone of the higher ranges of the Alpine system and its satellites, and of the slopes of lesser ranges in the boreal zone (cf. unit 37.8).
Dense thickets of bushy alders characteristic of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Dinarides, the Balkan Range, Vitosha, Rila, Corsica and the mountains of northeastern Asia.
Green alder ([Alnus viridis] ssp. [viridis])-dominated formations of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Dinarides and the Balkan Range, Vitosha, Rila, rich in tall herbs.

Green alder ([Alnus viridis] ssp. [viridis])-dominated formations, rich in tall herbs, of the subalpine and lower alpine belts of the Alps, on slopes with a good water-holding capacity, mostly on siliceous soils.
[Alnus viridis]-dominated formations of the Carpathian mountains, with, in some communities, [Pulmonaria filarszkyana], [Cirsium waldsteinii], [Rumex arifolius] ssp. [carpaticus].
[Alnus viridis]-dominated formations of the Dinarides.
[Alnus viridis]-dominated formations, often with [Rumex alpinus], [Ligusticum mutellina], [Salix silesiaca], [Geum coccineum], [Veratrum album], of the Balkan Range.
[Alnus viridis]-dominated brushes of the subalpine, 1300-2100 metre, level of Vitosha and Rila.

One to three metre-tall brush of the Corsican endemic [Alnus viridis] ssp. [suaveolens], sometimes accompanied by a few [Sorbus aucuparia], [Acer pseudoplatanus] or [Rhamnus alpinus], limited to the moist, cool, north-facing slopes (ubacs) and, locally, to humid torrent galleries on the south-facing slopes (adrets) of the subalpine (1600-2100 m) belt of Corsica.

Thickets of [Alnus viridis] ssp. [fruticosa], [Alnus kamtchatica], [Alnus sinuata] of the subalpine level of the Urals, of the mountains of Siberia, in particular the Putorany range, the Kamchatka range, the mountains of northern China.
Thickets of [Alnus cripa] of southwestern Greenland, distributed from Brede Fjord near Narsaq north to Evighedsfjorden near Maniitsoq, up to 2 metre, occasionnally  3-4 metre, tall.

Willow-dominated communities of higher Eurasian mountains and of the boreal zone, mostly characteristic of the subalpine zone of the higher ranges of the Alpine system and its satellites, where many constitute facies of subalpine bush and tall herb communities, of the slopes of lesser ranges in the boreal zone, including the Scandinavian mountains, of Iceland and of the northern British Isles (cf. unit 37.8).
Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the mountains of the Alpine system and neighbouring ranges.

Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane brushes and low scrubs of the Alps, the Apennines, the Jura, the western great Hercynian ranges, dominated by small shrubby, generally 0.5-2 metre tall, [Salix] species.

Willow brushes and dwarf shrub heaths of the Alps, dominated by [Salix waldsteiniana], [Salix caesia], [Salix foetida], [Salix glabra], [Salix hastata], [Salix glaucosericea], [Salix helvetica], [Salix bicolor], [Salix hegetschweileri].
Willow brushes and dwarf shrub heaths of the northern Apennines, in particular, of the Apuan Alps, dominated by [Salix hastata] or the endemic [Salix crataegifolia].
Very local willow brushes and dwarf shrub heaths of the Central Massif, the Vosges, the Harz, dominated by [Salix hastata] or [Salix bicolor].
Very local willow brush of the Central Massif dominated by the glacial relict [Salix lapponum].

Dwarf shrub heaths, very low brushes and espaliers of the alpine and subalpine belts of the Alps, formed by prostrate or near-prostrate [Salix alpina], [Salix breviserrata], [Salix reticulata], [Salix retusa], and occasionally very small forms of [Salix] species characteristic of unit 31.6211
Tall [Salix]-dominated brushes of the mountains of the subalpine, sometimes alpine and montane, belts of the Alps, the Apennines, the Jura, the western greater Hercynian ranges.
[Salix pentandra], [Salix appendiculata], [Salix laggeri], [Salix mielichhoferi], [Salix nigricans] ([Salix myrsinifolia]) thickets and tall brushes of the Alps.

Very local willow thickets and tall brushes of the subalpine and montane belts of the western great Hercynian ranges (the Central Massif, the Vosges, the Black Forest, the Bayerischerwald) and of other ranges adjacent to the western Alps, in particular, the French and Swiss Jura and the northern Apennines, dominated by [Salix pentandra], [Salix appendiculata], [Salix nigricans] ([Salix myrsinifolia]) or [Salix daphnoides].
Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the Pyrenees and the Cordillera Cantabrica.
Dwarf heaths of the subalpine and alpine levels of the Pyrenees and the Cordillera Cantabrica, dominated by the endemic [Salix pyrenaica], often accompanied by [Dryas octopetala].
Dwarf heaths and espaliers of the subalpine and alpine levels of the Pyrenees and the Cordillera Cantabrica, dominated by the prostrate or near prostrate [Salix breviserrata].
Uncommon willow brushes and dwarf shrub heaths of the Pyrenees, dominated by [Salix foetida], [Salix hastata] or [Salix bicolor].
Very local willow brush of the eastern Pyrenees dominated by the glacial relict [Salix lapponum].
Uncommon thickets and tall brushes of the Pyrenees dominated by [Salix pentandra], [Salix appendiculata], [Salix nigricans] ([Salix myrsinifolia]).
Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the Carpathians and the eastern Hercynian ranges of the Sudeten.
Willow brush of the Sudeten dominated by the glacial relict [Salix lapponum].

Subalpine and montane willow brushes of the Sudeten, in the Krkonose and Hruby Jesenik, of the Northern Carpathians, in the Babia Gora, and of the Eastern and Southern Carpathians, dominated by the small or medium-small [Salix silesiaca], variously accompanied by [Alnus viridis], [Sorbus aucuparia], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Rubus idaeus], [Luzula sylvatica], [Luzula luzuloides], [Luzula alpinopilosa], [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Calamagrostis villosa], of alpine and subalpine slopes and waterfalls, on siliceous soils with high moisture content.

Willow brushes and dwarf shrub heaths of the Carpathians and the Sudeten dominated by small willows other than [Salix lapponum] or [Salix silesiaca], in particular by [Salix hastata], [Salix bicolor] or [Salix marrubifolia],in particular, eastern Carpathian communities, of the subalpine and lower alpine level, developed on humid, calcareous slopes, dominated by [Salix hastata], with [Trisetum fuscum], [Festuca picta], [Hypericum alpigenum], [Deschampsia cespitosa] and [Rhododendron myrtifolium].
Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the Balkan Range, the Dinarides and the Hellenides.
Subalpine, alpine and montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the Dinarides.
Subalpine, alpine and montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the Balkan Range, dominated by [Salix waldsteiniana] or [Salix silesiaca].
Thickets of shrubby willows of Vitosha, Rila, Pirin and Rhodope, dominated by [Salix lapponum], [Salix waldsteiniana] or other mountain willows.
Willow brush of Vitosha and Rila dominated by the glacial relict [Salix lapponum].
Subalpine or alpine brushes of low shrubby willows of Vitosha, Rila and Pirin, dominated by [Salix waldsteiniana] or [Salix hastata], the latter limited to Rila.

Tall or medium tall subalpine, alpine or montane brushes and thickets of shrubby willows of Vitosha, Rila, Pirin and Rhodope, dominated by [Salix silesiaca], [Salix appendiculata] (Rila only) or [Salix pentandra] (Vitosha only).
Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the Pontic Range, the Caucasus and neighbouring ranges.
Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of the Himalayan system.
Subalpine, alpine and occasionally montane [Salix]-dominated brushes and low scrubs of Far Eastern mountains.

Willow-dominated brushes of boreal mountains and mountainous regions, in particular of the Highlands of Scotland, the mountains of Iceland, the boreal mountains of Scandinavia, European Russia, Siberia, northern China, Korea and Japan. Mostly characteristic of a suprasylvatic belt in the lower arcto-alpine or oroboreal zone, they may extend into the taiga belt in exposed locations and edaphic enclaves, and ascend locally into the arcto-alpine zone.
Subarctic [Salix lapponum], [Salix lanata], [Salix arbuscula] or [Salix myrsinites] formations of ungrazed cliff ledges in the central and northern Highlands of Scotland.

Willow-dominated formations of the subalpine and low alpine levels of the mountains of Scandinavia, dominated by [Salix glauca], [Salix hastata], [Salix lapponum], [Salix lanata], [Salix nigricans] ([Salix myrsinifolia]), [Salix phylicifolia].

Nombre oficial: Scandinavian montane tall herb willow brush
Definición oficial: Low (to 2 m) thickets of the sub- and low alpine levels of the southern, central and northern mountains of Scandinavia composed of various species of low, prostrate willows, with alternating dominance, and an extensive, dense, variable, often species-rich herb layer the species composition of which is independent of the shrub layer. The willows may include [Salix glauca], [Salix hastata], [Salix lapponum], [Salix lanata], [Salix nigricans] ([Salix myrsinifolia]), [Salix phylicifolia]

Nombre oficial: Scandinavian montane tufted hairgrass willow brush
Definición oficial: Dense (to 2 m) thickets of level, regularly flooded sediments in the proximity of watercourses in high-rainfall areas of the sub- and low alpine levels of the southern, central and northern mountains of Scandinavia dominated by [Salix lanata] or [Salix phylicifolia], accompanied by [Salix nigricans] ([Salix myrsinifolia]), [Salix glauca], [Salix hastata], [Salix lapponum], [Betula pubescens], with a sparse field layer, occupying mainly openings, dominated by [Deschampsia cespitosa] and [Filipendula ulmaria], with [Alchemilla glabra], [Alchemilla glomerulans], [Caltha palustris], [Paris quadrifolia], [Pedicularis sceptrum-carolinum], [Petasites frigidus], [Ranunculus auricomus], [Ranunculus repens], [Ranunculus reptans], [Rumex acetosa], [Trientalis europaeus], [Viola biflora], [Calamagrostis purpurea], [Calamagrostis stricta], [Deschampsia alpina], [Equisetum palustre].

Dense low (to 1 m) thickets of the low and middle alpine levels of the southern, central and northern mountains of Scandinavia dominated by [Salix glauca], accompanied by [Salix lapponum], [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia], with a heath and grass layer formed by [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Betula nana], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Hieracium alpinum], [Rumex acetosa], [Pyrola minor], [Trientalis europaea], [Cerastium alpinum], [Carex bigelowii], [Festuca ovina], with mosses and with lichens of genera [Cetraria] and [Cladonia]. These formations often occur as a wreath around windswept heaths, in more sheltered locations than those occupied by [Empetrum] heaths, mainly on north-facing slopes on stony, gravelly nutrient-poor sediments with some fine soil and high moisture, in conditions of some snow protection with early thaw.
Thickets, scrubs and heaths of the mountains and lowlands of Iceland dominated by the medium-sized to small willows [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia].

Willow thickets of Iceland, of low or medium stature, formed by [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia], [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii], with a tall herb, usually luxuriant, field layer. They are developed in the lowlands and in a few highland oases, colonizing in particular, small islands, islets, lake shores, river banks, streamsides, gullies, mostly in sheltered situations. The species cort¿ge includes [Geranium sylvaticum], [Erysimum hieracifolium], [Angelica archangelica], [Alchemilla vulgaris], [Coeloglossum viride], [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Deschampsia flexuosa], and, in the highlands, sometimes, [Leymus arenarius].

Dense thickets of the lowlands of Iceland dominated by [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia] and [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]) developed on frequently inundatable sediments, primarily along lake shores and rivers, mainly in drier areas of the north central and northeastern regions, with a humid meadow species cort¿ge in the herb layer, usually dominated by [Deschampsia cespitosa] or [Filipendula ulmaria], often confined to openings within the thicket.

Thickets and scrubs of the lowlands of Iceland dominated by [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia], accompanied by [Betula nana], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], relatively low-growing, usually 0.5 to 1 m high. The herb layer may be rich in gramino¿ds, notably [Carex bigelowii], [Kobresia myosuroides], [Festuca vivipara], [Festuca richardsonii], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Calamagrostis stricta]. They may also colonize lava fields, with a ground layer dominated by carpets of [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum]. Some communities are related to the [Betula nana]-[Juniperus]-[Vaccinium] heaths of unit 31.45519.

Willow-dominated dwarf heaths of the highlands of Iceland, often fairly open,  with an upper layer that may not exceed 5 cm in height, and is usually less than 50 cm. A number of distinctive communities develop on sandy, gravelly or loess substrates. [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]) or [Salix lanata] can be the dominant shrub in the upper layer, the latter, in particular, on more sandy substrates. Frequent dominants or codominants in the lower layer are dwarf [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Kobresia myosuroides], [Carex bigelowii], [Dryas octopetala], [Salix herbacea] and, in particular, on sand deposits, [Festuca richardsonii] or [Armeria maritima]. Common associates may include dwarf [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Betula nana], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Loiseleuria procumbens], [Polygonum viviparum], [Pedicularis flammea] and, in humidity-retaining areas, [Parnassia palustris], [Tofieldia pusilla], [Pinguicula alpina], [Calamagrostis neglecta], [Equisetum variegatum].

Willow-dominated formations of windswept detritic summits, slopes and plateaux of the highlands of Iceland, constituted, in a desert-like landscape, essentially of bare stony gravelly substrates, by scattered prostrate [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), associated with [Salix herbacea] and a few mostly cushion herbs, in particular, [Silene acaulis], [Thymus praecox] ssp. [arctica], [Armeria maritima], [Galium normanii].
Subarctic low-alpine willow formations of the middle and southern Urals, with [Salix glauca], [Salix lapponum], [Salix glandulifera], [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia].
Subarctic willow formations of the mountains of Siberia, with numerous species, in particular [Salix krylovii].
Thickets, scrubs and heaths of Greenland dominated by the medium-sized to small willows [Salix glauca] ([s.l.]), [Salix arctica]), [Salix arctophilia], up to 2 metre, occasionnally 3 metre, tall.

Mixed [Salix aurita], [Salix atrocinerea], [Salix repens] and [Salix caprea]  scrub, with [Rumex acetosa], [Filipendula ulmaria], [Dryopteris spp.], [Oxalis acetosella], developed on ungrazed ledges, islands and gullies of Shetland, Orkney, Hebrides and the Northern Highlands.

Communities of the subalpine zone, of the tree-limit, and sometimes of the montane zone, of higher nemoral mountains of the western Alpine system and its associated ranges, dominated by tall or medium shrubs, for the most part Rosaceae species (of genera [Rubus], [Sorbus], [Amelanchier], [Potentilla]), [Betula] or tall [Vaccinium], often accompanied by tall herbs characteristic of the subalpine tall herb communities (unit 37.8), or by subalpine heaths, such as the [Juniperus nana]-[Arctostaphylos uva-ursi] heaths.

Thickets of the subalpine zone of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Jura, the Hercynian ranges, dominated by [Sorbus aucuparia] ssp. [glabrata], [Sorbus chamaemespilus], [Sorbus mougeotii], [Sorbus ambigua], [Sorbus austriaca] or other shrubby [Sorbus] species, in particular, tree-limit formations with [Betula carpatica], [Lonicera nigra], [Prunus padus] ssp. [borealis] ([Padus petraea]).

Thickets or brushes of the subalpine zone of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Hercynian ranges, usually at the tree-limit, dominated by shrubby or krumholtz birches, in particular, [Betula carpatica], [Betula pubescens], often with [Sorbus aucuparia] ssp. [glabrata], [Lonicera nigra], [Prunus padus] ssp. [borealis] ([Padus petraea]).
Brushes of the subalpine zone of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Hercynian ranges, the Balkan Range, the Hellenides, dominated by [Rubus spp.], in particular, [Rubus idaeus], [Rubus saxatilis].

Thickets or brushes of the subalpine zone of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Jura, the Hercynian ranges dominated by shrubby species of genus [Prunus] or related genera, in particular, [Prunus padus] ssp. [borealis] ([Padus petraea]), often with [Sorbus aucuparia] ssp. [glabrata], [Betula carpatica], [Lonicera nigra].

Thickets or brushes of the subalpine zone of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Jura dominated by large [Vaccinium] shrubs, often accompanied by tall herbs characteristic of the subalpine tall herb communities (unit 37.8).
Closed formations dominated by [Potentilla fruticosa] of the 1550 metre level in the [Picea abies] and [Pinus sylvestris] belt of the west Rhodope mountains of Bulgaria.

Very low scrubs formed in exposed situations by otherwise thicket-building birches of boreal mountains and mountainous regions, in particular [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] ([Betula tortuosa], [Betula pubescens] ssp. [tortuosa], [Betula kusmisscheffii]) of Iceland, Greenland, the boreal mountains of Scandinavia, the Urals, or [Betula ermani] and [Betula middendorffii] of the Far-East, dwarf facies of the woods and thickets of unit 41.B7. Subdivisions of unit 41.B7 can be used to define precise communities.

Primary cushion heaths of the high, dry mountains of the Mediterranean and Irano-Turanian regions, with low, cushion-forming, often spiny shrubs, in particular of genera [Acantholimon], [Astragalus], [Erinacea], [Vella], [Bupleurum], [Ptilotrichum], [Genista], [Echinospartum], [Anthyllis], and various composites and labiates

Shrubby formations of the high mountains of the Peloponnese, of the southern mainland Greek mountains and of the Thessalian Olympus system, colonizing the altitudinal range immediately above that occupied by the communities of 31.79, as well as stony slopes with shallow soil, loose screes and humus-deficient soils within the main 1700-2200 m range of these communities. Included are true spiny hedgehog-heaths, cushiony formations of dwarf suffrutescents and bush-dominated facies of stripped grasslands. [Astragalus angustifolius], [Acantholimon androsaceum], [Astragalus lacteus], [Convolvulus cochlearis], [Rindera graeca], [Aster alpinus], [Globularia stygia], [Minuartia stellata], [Erysimum pusillum], [Thymus teucrioides], [Alyssum kionae], [Paronychia kapela], [Thymus hirsutus], [Anthyllis aurea], [Achillea ageratifolia], [Sideritis scardica], [Linum flavum], [Thymus boissieri], [Sesleria coerulans] are characteristic.

Shrubby formations of the high levels of the mountains of the Peloponnese, of the southern mainland Greek mountains and of the Thessalian Olympus system,  dominated by the dense tussocks of [Astragalus angustifolius].
Shrubby formations of the high levels of the Peloponnese and of the southern mainland Greek mountains, dominated by the large, domed mats of [Minuartia stellata].
Formations of the high reaches of Greek mountains, rich in dwarf suffrutescents.
Bushy facies of the high altitude stripped grasslands (36.437) of the high mountains of the Peloponnese, of the southern mainland Greek mountains and of the Thessalian Olympus system.

Hedgehog-heaths of high mountains of Crete, in the 1500-2500 m altitudinal range, with [Astragalus creticus] ssp. [creticus], [Astragalus angustifolius], [Acantholimon androsaceum], [Atraphaxis billardieri], [Berberis cretica], [Chamaecytisus creticus], [Daphne oleoides], [Prunus prostrata], [Euphorbia acanthothamnos], [Verbascum spinosum], [Sideritis syriaca], [Satureja spinosa], [Asperula idaea], [Rhamnus prunifolius], [Pimpinella tragium], [Acinos alpinus].
[Astragalus creticus] ssp. [creticus]-dominated hedgehog-heaths of the Psiloriti and Dikti mountains of central and eastern Crete.
[Astragalus angustifolius]-dominated hedgehog-heaths of the Lefka Ori, Psiloriti and Dikti mountains of Crete.
[Chamaecytisus creticus]-dominated hedgehog-heaths of Crete.

Hedgehog-heaths of the Dikti and Psiloritis mountains of Crete, in the 1500-2500 m altitudinal range, dominated by species other than [Astragalus creticus] ssp. [creticus], [Astragalus angustifolius], [Chamaecytisus creticus], in particular, by [Acantholimon androsaceum], [Satureja spinosa], [Berberis cretica].

Hedgehog-heaths of the Lefka Ori of Crete, in the 1500-2500 m altitudinal range, dominated by species other than [Astragalus angustifolius] or [Chamaecytisus creticus], in particular, by [Acantholimon androsaceum], [Satureja spinosa], [Berberis cretica].
Isolated, endemic-rich, mostly summital hedgehog-heaths of calcareous mountains of Aegean islands and Mount Athos.
Hedgehog-heaths of mountain summits of Aegean islands, characterised by large tragacanths.

Mount Kerki summit community of Samos with [Astragalus creticus] var. [samius], [Astragalus angustifolius], [Acantholimon androsaceum], [Atraphaxis billardieri], [Centaurea spinosa] var. [tragacanthoides], [Centaurea xylobasis], [Genista fasselata] var. [subsericans], [Prunus prostrata], [Silene urvillei], [Lithospermum hispidulum], [Thymus squarrosus].
Mount Ambelos summit community of Samos with [Astragalus ptilodes], [Acantholimon androsaceum], [Prunus prostrata], [Silene urvillei].
Formations with [Astragalus trojanus] var. [chius] of the highlands of Chios.
Mount Petrovuni summit community of Lesbos with [Astragalus parnassi] ([Astragalus lesbiacus]).
Mount Phanga summit community of Samothrace with [Astragalus parnassi] var. [samothracius] and [Genista fasselata] var. [subsericans].
Mount Athos communities with [Astragalus monachorum] and [Astragalus angustifolius] ssp. [pungens].
Mount Delphi community of Euboa with [Astragalus creticus] var. [euboicus], [Daphne oleoides], [Prunus prostrata].
Communities characterised by the dense tussocks of [Astragalus angustifolius].
Mount Olympus summit community of Lesbos with [Astragalus angustifolius] and [Silene urvillei].
Mount Agia Illias summit community of Thasos.
Formations dominated by hemispherical shrubs of [Genista acanthoclada] of the middle levels (about 800-1200 m) of mountains and plateaux of the Peloponnese.

[Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [sempervirens], [Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [muticus], [Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [cephalonicus] formations of the southern Alps, the eastern Pyrenees, Iberia, the Apennines and Greece, transitional between the alpine and subalpine heaths of unit 31.4 and the true Mediterranean hedgehog-heaths of unit 31.7.
Open formations dominated by broom-like plants of the montane zone (above 1900 m) of the Canary Islands, with many endemic species.

Formations of Tenerife with [Spartocytisus supranubius], [Adenocarpus viscosus] var. [viscosus], [Descurainia bourgaena], [Pterocephalus lasiospermus], [Erysimum scoparium], [Scrophularia glabrata], [Nepeta teydea], [Echium wildpretii], [Echium auberianum], [Cheirolophus teydis], [Plantago webbii], [Sideritis cretica], [Argyranthemum teneriffae], [Pimpinella cumbrae], [Arrhenatherum calderae].

Formations of La Palma with [Adenocarpus viscosus] var. [spartioides], the very rare [Genista benehoavensis] and [Descurainia gilba], [Pterocephalus porphyranthus], [Viola palmensis], [Echium wildpretii], [Echium gentianoides], [Micromeria lasiophylla] ssp. [palmensis].
Primary and secondary cushion heaths of the altimediterranean and oromediterranean levels of the Tell Atlas, the Middle Atlas, the Grand Atlas, the Anti-Atlas and the Saharan Atlas.

Summital community of the Chionistra, in the Troodos group, developed above the tree limit, at about 1900-1950 m above sealevel, with [Berberis cretica], [Sorbus aria] ssp. [cretica], [Rosa canina] ssp. [dumalis], [Juniperus foetidissima] and tragacanthic shrubs, in particular, [Astragalus echinus], [Alyssum troodii], [Teucrium cyprium], [Nepeta troodi], [Satureja troodii]. Other highly restricted endemics include [Onosma troodii], [Scorzonera troodea].

Tragacanthic communities of the Taurus, the Antitaurus, the Amanus, the Aegean ranges of western Anatolia, the Lebanon mountains, Mount Hermon, the Jebel Druz and the mountains of northern Sinai, with rich communities dominated by numerous species of genera [Astragalus] and [Acantholimon], acccompanied by, among others, [Berberis cretica], [Daphne oleoides].
Tragacanthic communities of the Taurus and the Antitaurus, dominated by several species of genus [Acantholimon] and by [Astragalus angustifolius] and [Astragalus pannosus], among others.
Tragacanthic communities of the Aegean ranges of western Anatolia, dominated by species of genera [Astragalus] and [Acantholimon], acccompanied by, among others, [Daphne oleoides].
Tragacanthic communities of the Amanus, extremely rich in species, in particular of genus [Astragalus].
Tragacanthic communities of the Lebanon mountains, Mount Hermon, the Jebel Druz, dominated by over 15 species of genus [Astragalus], several species of genus [Acantholimon] and by [Berberis cretica].
Tragacanthic communities of the mountains of northern Sinai, dominated by a very limited number of species of genus [Astragalus].
Hedgehog-heaths of hills, plateaux and mountains of the steppe and substeppe zones of western central Eurasia, west to eastern Bulgaria and central Anatolia.

Endemic [Astragalus aitosensis] ([Astragalus arnacantha], [Astracantha aitosensis]) formation of Bulgaria, restricted to a few sites of the xerothermic oak belt, on steep, south-facing slopes of the Aitoska hills, southeastern spur of the Balkan Range onto the Northern Thracian plain.
Hedgehog-heaths of hills, plateaux and mountains of the steppe and substeppe zones of central Anatolia.
Hedgehog-heaths of hills, plateaux and mountains of the steppe and substeppe zones of northeastern Anatolia, Iran, Irak and Afghanistan.
Primary and secondary cushion heaths of high, dry mountains and plateaux of the Himalayan system and its Palaearctic periphery.
[Echinospartum horridum] formations of dry slopes of the supra-Mediterranean zone of the southern Pyrenees
Formations of the Cordillera Central and adjacent areas dominated by diverse forms of [Echinospartum].
Oro-Mediterranean heaths of the Sierra de Gredos dominated by the endemic [Echinospartum lusitanicu] ssp. [barnadesii].
Oro-Mediterranean heaths of the Sierra de Bejar and Pe?a de Francia dominated by [Echinospartum ibericum] ssp. [pulviniformis].
Relict heaths of highly xeric upper supra-Mediterranean and oro-Mediterranean stations of the Serra da Estrela dominated by [Echinospartum ibericum] ssp. [pulviniformis].
Secondary [Echinospartum lusitanicum-Genista histrix] hedgehog-heaths developed on skeletal soils of the supra-Mediterranean zone of the western Cordillera Central and surrounding areas.

Highly developed hedgehog formations of the Sierra Nevada with [Erinacea anthyllis], [Vella spinosa], [Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [nevadensis], [Astragalus granatensis] ssp. [granatensis] ([Astragalus boissieri]), [Ptilotrichum spinosum], [Bupleurum spinosum], [Genista baetica]. Associated dwarf suffrutescent formations of high slopes and crests.

Supra-Mediterranean (lower xeroacanthic) hedgehog-heaths occupying mainly the 1700-2000 m altitudinal range, often rich in [Bupleurum spinosum], with [Vella spinosa], [Erinacea anthyllis] or [Echinospartum boissieri].

Oro-Mediterranean (higher xeroacanthic) hedgehog-heaths occupying mainly the 2000-2300 m altitudinal range, with [Vella spinosa], [Erinacea anthyllis], [Ptilotrichum spinosum], [Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [nevadensis], [Astragalus granatensis] ssp. [granatensis].

Upper oro-Mediterranean hedgehog-heaths occupying mainly the 2300-2600 m altitudinal range, with [Erinacea anthyllis], [Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [nevadensis], [Astragalus granatensis] ssp. [granatensis], [Juniperus nana] and [Juniperus sabina] ssp. [humilis].
Dwarf suffrutescent formations of windswept crests and slopes on very superficial soils.
Formations of base-rich siliceous soils at 2600-2900 m with [Sideritis glacialis], [Arenaria pungens], [Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [nevadensis].

Formations of white-tomentose dwarf cushions developed on calcareous soils (Trevenque, Dornajo, Dilar) with [Andryala agardhii], [Erodium boissieri], [Scabiosa pulsatilloides], [Santolina elegans], [Globularia spinosa], [Pterocephalus spathulatus], [Helianthemum pannosum].
[Genista baetica]-dominated hedgehog-heaths, often with [Juniperus nana] and [Genista purgans], of siliceous soils.
Oro-Mediterranean and montane hedgehog-heaths of other Iberian ranges and of southern France.
Oro-Mediterranean [Erinacea]-dominated and related hedgehog-heaths.

Hedgehog-heaths of the Baetic and sub-Baetic ranges and of the southern Iberian Range, dominated by [Erinacea anthyllis] and/or by [Vella spinosa], [Astragalus granatensis] ssp. [granatensis], [Astragalus sempervirens] ssp. [nevadensis], [Bupleurum spinosum], [Ptilotrichum spinosum], developed in particular in the sierras de Segura, de Cazorla, de Alcaraz, Tejeda, Harana, Magina, de Baza, La Sagra, de Gador, Maria and on a few summits of the Serrania de Ronda.
[Erinacea anthyllis]-dominated hedgehog-heaths of the Iberian Range (Teruel, Cuenca, Guadalajara, Soria), often in altitudinal contact with [Genista pumila] formations.
Hedgehog-heaths with [Genista hispanica] ssp. [hispanica] and/or [Erinacea anthyllis] of the Maestrazgo, eastern spur of the Iberian Range under maritime influence.
Hedgehog-heaths with [Genista lobelii] ssp. [longipes], [Erinacea anthyllis], [Vella spinosa] of the sub-Baetic Aitana and Mariola ranges in the arid southeast.
Formations with [Daphne oleoides] ssp. [hispanica] of the mountains of the arid souteast.
Oro-Mediterranean, and sometimes supra-Mediterranean, formations of dwarf white-tomentose, cushion-forming suffrutescents of the high sub-Baetic and Baetic ranges
Formations of the Sierras de Cazorla, Segura, Alcaraz, Taibilla of the high Guadalquivir basin, with [Erodium cazorlanum], [Scorzonera albicans].

Formations of the sierras Tejeda, Almijara, la Torrecilla, Harana, Baza, la Sagra, Cazulas, Lapeza and of the Serrania de Ronda with [Anthyllis vulneraria] ssp. [argyrophylla], [Anthyllis tejedensis], [Helianthemum viscidulum].
Formations of the Sierra de Magina with [Helianthemum pannosum] ssp. [frigidulum], [Lithodora nitida] and [Viola cazorlensis].
Formations of the sierras Maria and Maimon with [Centaurea baetica], [Sideritis stachydioides], [Alyssum cadevallianum].

Mostly supra-Mediterranean hedgehog-heaths colonizing superficial, eroded soils and windswept stations of calcareous Baetic and sub-Baetic ranges, comprising many cushion plants and generally physiognomically dominated by the large hemispherical shrubs of [Echinospartum boissieri].
Formations of the Sierra de Alcaraz, sometimes including [Erinacea anthyllis].
Formations of the 1300-1900 m altitudinal range in the Sierra de Gador, often with [Erinacea anthyllis] or [Ulex parviflorus].
Formations developed in the 800-1400 m altitudinal range of other Baetic and sub-Baetic ranges, often, in the higher mountains, immediately below [Erinacetalia] communities.

Unommon hedgehog-heaths with [Erinacea anthyllis] and [Anthyllis montana], and related cushion plant formations, colonizing windswept stations with skeletal soil of the Mediterranean mountains of northeastern Spain (Montsant, Llaveria, Cardo, Maestrazgo septentrional, Beceite
Mostly supra-Mediterranean hedgehog garrigues and heaths physiognomically dominated by small, hemispherical [Genista spp.].

Cushion-heaths dominated by [Genista hispanica] ssp. [occidentalis] or [Genista hystrix] ssp. [legionensis], often with [Erica vagans], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi] ssp. [crassifolia] or [Lithodora diffusa], characteristic of the Pyreneen-Cantabrian system, where they may occur from the collinar to the subalpine level.
Heaths dominated by the cushions of [Genista sanabrensis], with [Erica umbellata] and [Calluna vulgaris], occupying crests of southern Galicio-Leonese mountains at about 1800 m (cf. 31.2431).
Cushion heaths dominated by [Genista pumila] ssp. [pumila] of windswept plateaux and crests of the Meseta and of the northern and southern Iberian Range.
Meseta hedgehog-heaths with [Genista scorpius], rich in cushion-forming small shrubs.
Unarmed [Genista pseudopilosa]-dominated hedgehog-heaths with [Erinacea anthyllis] and other cushion plants of the sierras de Alcaraz and Segura.
[Genista lobelii] and [Genista pulchella] hedgehog-heaths of windswept hilltops of southeastern France.
Local meso- and supra-Mediterranean [Astragalus] formations of the Spanish Meseta.

Supra-Mediterranean [Astragalus granatensis] ssp. [granatensis] ([Astragalus boissieri]) formations of pastoral runs of the left bank of the middle Duero (Soria, Segovia) and of the highlands of Atienza (Guadalajara).

Meso- and supra-Mediterranean hedgehog-heaths with [Astragalus clusii] ([Astragalus tumidus]) of the southern Meseta, from La Mancha to the Baetic hills of eastern Andalusia (Orce, Sagra, Baza, Maria), with [Paronychia aretioides], [Genista pumila] ssp. [mugronensis], [Genista scorpius].
Cushion-forming communities of high altitudes and wind-exposed plateaux of the Balearics, dominated by [Teucrium subspinosum].

Cushion-forming communities of the high altitudes of the Sierra Tramuntana of Mallorca, rich in endemics, among them [Teucrium subspinosum], [Teucrium asiaticum], [Pastinaca lucida], [Thymelaea velutina] and [Paeonia cambessedesii].
Cushion-forming communities of wind-exposed plateaux and hills of Menorca with [Cistus creticus] and [Teucrium subspinosum] var. [spinescens].

Expanses of small, compact bushes with [Astragalus sirinicus] ssp. [genargenteus], [Rosa serafinii], [Anthyllis hermanniae], [Thymus herba-barona], [Cerastium boissieri], [Genista salzmannii], [Genista corsica], [Berberis aetnensis], [Prunus prostrata] and [Daphne oleoides], of Sardinian and Corsican mountains.
Oro-Mediterranean [Astragalus sirinicus] ssp. [genargenteus] hedgehog-heaths of the Gennargentu and Monte Albo in Sardinia and of the high mountains of Corsica.
Formations of windswept crests of Corsica and Sardinia dominated by the low spiny cushions of [Euphorbia spinosa].
Formations of the mountains of Corsica and Sardinia dominated by the hemispherical cushions of the endemic [Thymus herba-barona].

Hedgehog-heaths of high mountains of Corsica and Sardinia and secondary heaths of the montane level dominated by [Genista salzmannii] (including [Genista salzmannii] var. [lobelioides]) or [Genista corsica].
Formations of the mountains of Corsica and Sardinia dominated by [Berberis aetnensis].
Formations of the mountains of Corsica and Sardinia dominated by [Anthyllis hermanniae].

Lava-colonising hedgehog-heaths of Mount Etna formed by cushions of [Astragalus granatensis] ssp. [siculus], with [Berberis aetnensis], [Juniperus hemisphaerica], [Genista aetnensis], [Adenocarpus bivonae], [Viola aethnensis].
Hedgehog-heaths formed by [Astragalus spp.] or [Genista spp.], of the mountains of the southern Italian peninsula and Sicily, except Etna.
Oro-Mediterranean hedgehog-heaths of the Madonie with [Astragalus granatensis] ssp. [nebrodensis].
Oro-Mediterranean hedgehog-heaths of the Sila and Aspromonte with [Astragalus parnassi] ssp. [calabrus].
Hedgehog-heaths with [Astragalus sirinicus] ssp. [sirinicus] of the central and southern Apennines, south to northern Calabria.
Montane [Genista cupanii]-dominated hedgehog-heaths of the Madonie.
Montane hedgehog-heaths of Monte Gargano with [Genista sylvestris] ssp. [dalmatica].

Hedgehog-heaths occupying situations peripheral to the main range of the alti- and oromediterranean hedgehog-heath communities of high Hellenic mountains (units 31.79 and 31.7A), mostly dominated by [Astragalus angustifolius], characteristic, in particular, of zoogenous clearings within the forest belt of southern Greek mountains and of regions of irradiation of Mediterranean communities within the hills and mountains of the Moesian zone.

Hedgehog-heath facies of mostly secondary grassland-scrubland communities replacing [Abies cephalonica] forests in the 1500-1800 m altitudinal range of Peloponnese mountains, in particular, Taygetos, Parnon and Kyllini, and of southern mainland Greek mountains, including the southern Pindus and the Thessalian mountains, composed of [Stipa pulcherrima] and [Morina persica], with bushes and cushion-shaped perennials including [Astragalus angustifolius], [Daphne oleoides], [Juniperus hemisphaerica], [Berberis cretica], [Anthemis montana], [Ribes uva-crispa], [Prunus cocomilia].

[Astragalus angustifolius] hedgehog-heaths, mostly secondary, scattered, mostly in the xero-thermic oak belt, in the mountains of northern Greece and in regions of Mediterranean influence of the mountains and hills of the central Balkan peninsula, in particular, in the northern Pindus, in the Pelagonides, in the Moeso-Macedonian Ranges, in the Rhodopides and in the foothills of the Balkan Range. [Thymus striatus], [Satureja montana], [Artemisia alba], [Agropogon pectiniforme], [Rhodax canus], [Teucrium chamaedrys], [Teucrium montanum], [Sideritis montana], [Festuca thracica], [Hyacinethella leucophaea], [Sternbergia colchiciflora], [Asphodelus albus], [Adonis flammea] participate in the [Astragalus] communities.
Hedgehog-heaths developed on relatively humus-rich rendziniform soils at or above treeline, in the 1700-2200 m altitudinal range of high Greek mountains

Hedgehog-heaths of the Taygetos, Kyllini, Chelmos, Parnassus, Vardousia, Giona and calcareous central and northern Pindus, dominated by the large hemispherical tussocks of the tragacanths [Astragalus creticus] ssp. [rumelicus], and/or [Astragalus parnassi], and with [Marrubium velutinum], [Marrubium cyllenaeum], [Juniperus hemisphaerica], [Daphne oleoides], [Eryngium amethystinum], [Sideritis clandestina], [Cirsium hypopsilum] ([Cirsium cylleneum]).
[Astragalus creticus] ssp. [rumelicus] heaths of the southern Peloponnese.
[Astragalus parnassi] ssp. [cylleneus] and [Astragalus creticus] ssp. [rumelicus] heaths of Kyllini and Chelmos.
[Astragalus creticus] ssp. [rumelicus] and/or [Astragalus parnassi] ssp. [parnassi] heaths of high mountains of the mainland of Greece.
[Astragalus angustifolius] heaths of high Greek mountains, with [Marrubium thessalum] or [Marrubium velutinum] ssp. [haussknechtii].
Formations of the Olympus system dominated by [Astragalus angustifolius].
Hedgehog-heaths of the Pindus dominated by [Astragalus angustifolius] (or [Astragalus sirinicus]).
Cushion formations of high Greek mountains not dominated by thorny, tussock-forming species of [Astragalus].
Formations of high Greek mountains dominated by small bushes of [Daphne oleoides], usually accompanied by stripped grassland components (36.437).
Formations dominated by low mats of [Buxus sempervirens], characteristic of middle slopes of Greek mountains, in particular Olympus.

Pre- and postforest formations, mostly deciduous, of Atlantic, sub-Atlantic or subcontinental affinities, characteristic of the western Palaearctic deciduous forest zone, but also colonizing cool, moist or disturbed stations of the mediterranean evergreen forest zone.
Mostly deciduous shrubs and hedges, often tall, luxuriant and rich in lianas, of submediterranean areas and moist stations in mediterranean areas of peninsular Italy, Sicily, Sardinia and Corsica.

Mostly deciduous shrubs and hedges of submediterranean areas and moist stations in mediterranean areas of Corsica and Sardinia, with [Rubus ulmifolius], [Rosa agrestis], [Rosa canina], [Rosa serafinii], [Prunus spinosa], [Crataegus monogyna], [Clematis vitalba], [Pyrus amygdaliformis], [Rhamnus persicifolius].

Mostly deciduous shrubs and hedges of submediterranean areas and moist stations in mediterranean areas of the Italian peninsula and Sicily with [Rubus ulmifolius], [Rosa sempervirens], [Rosa arvensis], [Pyrus amygdaliformis], [Pyrus communis], [Malus sylvestris], [Amelanchier ovalis], [Cotoneaster integerrimus], [Cotoneaster nebrodensis], [Pyracantha coccinea], [Crataegus monogyna], [Crataegus laciniata], [Prunus spinosa], [Prunus cocomilia], [Prunus mahaleb], [Coriaria myrtifolia], [Cotinus coggygria], [Pistacia terebinthus], [Euonymus europaeus], [Paliurus spina-christi], [Rhamnus catharticus], [Lonicera xylosteum], [Lonicera etrusca].

Deciduous pre- and postforest formations, forest edges, hedges and woodland recolonization of thermophilous deciduous oak forest and steppe forest zones of the Balkan peninsula, of southeastern Europe, of western Asia and of Central Eurasia, in particular, of the [Quercion frainetto] and [Ostryo-Carpinion] zones of the Balkan peninsula, with very local irradiations in Central Europe, extreme northeastern Italy, the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean.
Deciduous thickets of the Pontic, Elburz and Caucasus ranges, and of neighbouring regions, within and around the area of occurrence of Euxino-Hyrcanian mixed deciduous forests (unit 41.H).

Deciduous pre- and postforest formations, forest edges, hedges and woodland recolonization of thermophilous deciduous oak forest and steppe forest zones of Central Eurasia, in and around the western Himalayan system.

Deciduous thickets of the Pannonic basin and neighbouring regions, with northwestern irradiations in Central Europe, within and around the range of occurrence of white cinquefoil oak woods (units 41.7A11, 41.7A12, 41.7A13), of western tartar maple steppe oak woods (unit 41.7A21) and of Pannonian white oak woods (unit 41.7374).

Nombre oficial: Northern Central European ground cherry scrub
Definición oficial: [Prunus fruticosa] scrubs of dry, continental enclaves of Central Europe, in particular of the rain shadow of the Harz in Anhalt and Thuringe, of the xeric left-bank limestone and loess hills of the Palatine upper Rhine, of the Nida Valley and Lublin uplands of southeastern Poland, of dry hills of the Bohemian basin and of Moravia.

Low deciduous scrubs of continental affinities of the Pannonic basin and neighbouring regions including the eastern Alpine periphery, the southern periphery of the Northwestern Carpathians, the Transylvanian plateau and the adjacent foothills and valleys of the Eastern and Southern Carpathians and the Apuseni mountains, the southern periphery of the Pannonic basin, with irradiations to the lower Danubian plain, to the Moravian plateau, to the Dobrogea and to the hills and valleys of the northern Balkan peninsula southeast to southwestern Bulgaria.

Low deciduous scrubs of the Hungarian Central Range, of Pannonic Austria west to the eastern Waldviertel, of southern Slovakia, central Transylvania, Muntenia and Moldavia, dominated by [Prunus fruticosa].

Low deciduous, more or less closed, scrubs of the Hungarian Central Range, central Transylvania, the Apuseni mountains, the Eastern Carpathians, the southeastern Weinviertel and northern Bergenland of northern Austria, the southern and southeastern periphery of the Pannonic basin, east to the Chepan, Golo Bardo, Zemenska and Konyiavska hills of western Bulgaria and to the Balkan Range of eastern Serbia and Bulgaria, with [Prunus fruticosa], [Prunus tenella] ([Amygdalus nana]), [Prunus spinosa], [Rhamnus catharticus], [Rosa gallica], [Rosa pimpinellifolia], [Peucedanum alsaticum], [Asparagus officinalis], [Festuca rupicola], [Agropyron cristatum] ssp. [pectinatum] ([Agropyron pectinatum], [Elymus hispidus] ([Agropyron intermedium]), [Poa angustifolia], [Artemisia campestris], [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Salvia nemorosa], [Stachys recta], [Teucrium chamaedrys], [Vinca herbacea]. These forest steppe shrub communities have become greatly reduced throughout their range as a result of changes in land use, in particular, following the expansion of agriculture in the lowlands and low hill regions of the Danube basin.

Very low deciduous scrubs of Pannonic Austria, in particular the Weinviertel, of the Apuseni mountains, of the Balkan Range of Serbia and Bulgaria, dominated by [Rosa pimpinellifolia] ([Rosa spinosissima]), with [Achillea millefolium] agg., [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Teucrium chamaedrys].

Very rare low deciduous scrubs on shallow rocky soils of limestone or andesite outcrops of the eastern Hungarian Central Range, of the eastern Alpine periphery of Austria and of Slovakia, dominated by [Spiraea media], with [Cotoneaster integerrimus], [Rosa pimpinellifolia], [Prunus fruticosa], [Waldsteinia geoides], [Silene vulgaris], [Carduus collinus], [Doronicum hungaricum], [Carex brevicollis], [Melica altissima], [Melica picta], [Melica ciliata], [Sedum maximum], [Euphorbia cyparissias].
Low deciduous scrubs dominated by [Crataegus spp.] of the flood plain of the Danube basin in Slovakia, Hungary, Muntenia and Oltenia.

Tall sub-Mediterranean deciduous brushes of the Pannonic basin and neighbouring regions, with [Cotinus coggygria], [Amelanchier ovalis], [Cotoneaster tomentosus], [Cotoneaster matrensis], [Pyrus nivalis], [Prunus mahaleb], [Spiraea media], [Sorbus graeca], [Fraxinus ornus].

Deciduous thickets and scrubs of the Pannonic basin and neighbouring regions, in particular the hills of the Banat, the Transylvanian plateau, the hills of the Southern Carpathians and the Apuseni mountains, with [Prunus spinosa], [Crataegus spp.], [Ligustrum vulgare].

Sub-Mediterranean deciduous brushes of the Central Hungarian Range, with [Cotinus coggygria], [Amelanchier ovalis], [Cotoneaster tomentosus], [Cotoneaster matrensis], [Pyrus nivalis], [Prunus mahaleb], [Fraxinus ornus].

High sub-Mediterranean deciduous brushes of the hills of the Pannonic basin and its periphery, formed as degradation or regrowth stages of [Orno-Cotinion]  ([Orno-Quercetum] [s.l.]) woods, with [Cotinus coggygria], [Amelanchier ovalis], [Cotoneaster tomentosus], [Cotoneaster matrensis], [Pyrus nivalis], [Prunus mahaleb], [Spiraea media], [Sorbus graeca], [Fraxinus ornus], [Acer campestre], [Carpinus betulus].

Tall shrub formations of the montane zone of the Apuseni mountains, Oltenia and Transylvania, characteristic of steep slopes and the edges and clearings of slope and ravine forests, with [Spiraea chamaedryfolia] ([Spiraea ulmifolia]) or [Sorbus dacica].
Tall thickets of the 1000 metre level of the Apuseni mountains, dominated by the endemic [Sorbus dacica], with [Corylus avellana], [Sorbus aucuparia], [Carex humilis], [Sesleria rigida].

Tall thickets dominated by [Spiraea chamaedryfolia] ([Spiraea ulmifolia]) of montane slopes of the Apuseni mountains, Oltenia and Transylvania, with [Galium erectum], [Potentilla thuringiaca], [Teucrium chamaedrys].

Deciduous thickets of the Illyrian region of northeastern Italy and the western Balkan peninsula, substitution communities of the [Carpinion betuli illyricum] (unit 41.2A), [Fagion illyricum] (unit 41.1C) or [Ostryo-Carpinion adriadicum] (units 41.73, 41.74) climax vegetation woodlands.
Deciduous thickets of the Illyrian and eastern Adriatic region of northeastern Italy and the western Balkan peninsula dominated, or co-dominated, by [Carpinus orientalis].

Deciduous thickets of the Illyrian and eastern Adriatic region of northeastern Italy and the western Balkan peninsula formed by [Prunus spinosa], [Cornus sanguinea], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Rubus caesius], [Viburnum lantana], any of which may dominate or codominate, and by [Crataegus monogyna], [Euonymus europaeus], [Rhamnus catharticus], [Rosa spp.], [Acer campestre].
Deciduous thickets of the Illyrian and eastern Adriatic region of northeastern Italy and the western Balkan peninsula dominated, or co-dominated, by [Paliurus spina-christi].

Varied, often species-rich, shrub formations of the temperate and submediterranean belts of the Southern and Eastern Carpathians, the Balkan Range, the Moeso-Macedonian Mountains, the Rhodopides, the Pelagonides, the Pindus, the Thessalian Mountains and adjacent regions, accompanied by a flora of mostly Moesian affinities, substitution formations of [Quercion frainetto] (unit 41.76), [Fagion moesiacum] (unit 41.19), [Fagion dacicum] (unit 41.1D), [Fagion hellenicum] (unit 41.1A) and, locally, [Ostryo-Carpinion aegeicum] (unit 41.73) climax forests, generally dominated by, or rich in, [Carpinus orientalis], [Syringa vulgaris], [Paliurus spina-christi], [Cotinus coggygria] or [Rhus coriaria].

Shrub communities dominated, or co-dominated, by [Carpinus orientalis], often rich in [Syringa vulgaris], [Cotinus coggygria] and other characteristically Moesian shrubs, of warm foothill slopes of the Southern and Eastern Carpathians, the Balkan Range, the Moeso-Macedonian Mountains, the Rhodopides, the Pelagonides, and neighbouring regions, within the geographical range of [Quercion frainetto], [Fagion moesiacum], [Fagion dacicum], and, locally, [Ostryo-Carpinion] forests.

Shrub communities dominated by [Carpinus orientalis], of Epirus, southern Paeonia, Macedonia and Thrace, with [Fraxinus ornus], [Cornus mas], [Crataegus spp.], [Pistacia terebinthus], [Lonicera caprifolium], [Asparagus acutifolius], [Ruscus aculeatus], [Colutea arborescens], [Cotinus coggygria], [Paliurus spina-christi], [Cyclamen hederifolium] ([Cyclamen neapolitanum], [Cyclamen linearifolium]), [Carex hallerana], [Geranium purpureum]. Many of the communities include evergreen shrubs

Tall shrub communities of Serbia, western Bulgaria and the F.Y.R. of Macedonia, dominated by [Carpinus orientalis], with [Fraxinus ornus], [Acer monspessulanum], [Acer hyrcanum], [Sorbus domestica], [Pyrus communis], [Pyrus amygdaliformis], [Coronilla emerus], [Cotinus coggygria], [Colutea arborescens], [Syringa vulgaris], [Cornus mas], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Euonymus verrucosus].

Nombre oficial: Peri-Carpathian manna ash oriental hornbeam thickets
Definición oficial: Tall shrub communities dominated by [Carpinus orientalis], of the Banat, Muntenia and the Dobrogea, with [Fraxinus ornus], [Cotinus coggygria], [Prunus mahaleb], [Euonymus verrucosus], [Cornus mas], [Quercus pubescens], [Quercus virgiliana], [Rosa canina], [Paeonia peregrina], [Orchis purpurea], [Carex hallerana], [Cruciata laevipes], [Polygonatum odoratum], [Thalictrum minus], [Viola mirabilis], [Teucrium chamaedrys], [Chrysanthemum corymbosum].

Nombre oficial: Peri-Carpathian wig tree oriental hornbeam thickets
Definición oficial: Tall shrub communities dominated by [Carpinus orientalis], of the Banat and Oltenia, with [Cotinus coggygria], [Prunus spinosa], [Crataegus pentagyna], [Cornus sanguinea], [Rosa arvensis].

Xero-thermic tall shrub communities of the middle and eastern Balkan peninsula, widespread in hills and low mountains of the Southern and Eastern Carpathians, the Balkan Range, the Moeso-Macedonian Mountains, the Rhodopides, the Pelagonides, within the zone of [Quercion frainetto], the [Fagion moesiacum], the [Fagion dacicum], and, locally, the [Ostryo-Carpinion], rich in continental Moesian species, dominated by, or with a great abundance of, [Syringa vulgaris]. [Cotinus coggygria], [Rhus coriaria], [Genista lydia], [Cercis siliquastrum], [Coronilla emerus], [Colutea arborescens], [Prunus mahaleb], [Prunus cerasifera], [Prunus cocomilia], [Pyrus amygdaliformis], [Crataegus monogyna], [Crataegus laciniata], [Sorbus domestica], [Rosa sempervirens], [Rosa canina] agg., [Rosa rubiginosa] agg., [Rubus ulmifolius], [Euonymus spp.], [Cornus mas], [Cornus sanguinea], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Clematis vitalba], [Rhamnus saxatilis], [Corylus spp.], [Acer spp.], [Fraxinus ornus], [Carpinus orientalis], [Quercus spp.] may contribute to the shrub layer. [Achillea clypeolata], [Asperula montana], [Asperula tenella], [Asyneuma anthericoides], [Campanula divergens], [Campanula grossekii], [Delphinium fissum], [Dianthus banaticus], [Echinops bannaticus], [Eryngium palmatum], [Ferula heuffelii], [Hypericum rochelii], [Inula candida] ssp. [aschersoniana], [Jasione dentata], [Piptatherum holciforme] ([Oryzopsis holciformis]), [Paeonia decora], [Salvia ringens], [Scabiosa banatica], [Scutellaria pichleri], [Stachys recta] ssp. [leucoglossa], [Symphytum ottomanum] are characteristic of the herb layer.
[Syringa vulgaris]-dominated or -rich tall brushes of the Balkan Range and neighbouring regions.
[Syringa vulgaris]-dominated or -rich tall brushes of lower rocky slopes of the Balkan Range and satellite ranges, with [Inula verbascifolia] ssp. [aschersoniana].

Uncommon [Syringa vulgaris]-dominated or -rich tall brushes of eastern Serbia developed on rendzinas on steep slopes in the 900-1300 metre montane level of the western Balkan Range and satellinte ranges.
Tall [Syringa vulgaris]-dominated brush of hills and low mountains of the Banat, Oltenia, Muntenia, western Bulgaria and eastern Serbia, in the vicinity of the Iron Gates and the lower Danube.

Tall brush of the Banat, in particular, the Iron Gates, western Bulgaria and eastern Serbia, developed on abrupt, mostly south or southeast facing slopes,    dominated by [Carpinus orientalis] and [Syringa vulgaris], with [Cotinus coggygria], [Fraxinus ornus], [Coronilla emerus], [Colutea arborescens], [Prunus mahaleb], [Crataegus monogyna], [Euonymus verrucosus], [Cornus mas], [Rhamnus saxatilis], [Corylus colurna], [Quercus pubescens], [Asperula tenella], [Delphinium fissum], [Dianthus banaticus], [Echinops bannaticus], [Ferula heuffelii], [Hypericum rochelii], [Scabiosa columbaria], [Piptatherum virescens] ([Oryzopsis virescens]), [Campanula sibirica], [Allium cirrhosum], [Allium flavescens], [Sedum acre], [Centaurea atropurpurea], [Asplenium trichomanes].

Tall shrub formations of the Banat, Oltenia and Muntenia, developed on gentle or abrupt slopes, dominated by [Fraxinus ornus] and [Syringa vulgaris], sometimes by [Syringa vulgaris] alone, with [Achnatherum calamagrostis], [Festuca xanthina], [Coronilla varia], [Corylus colurna], [Crataegus monogyna], [Cornus mas], [Viburnum lantana], [Silene petraea], [Primula columnae], [Teucrium montanum], [Thymus glabrescens].
