Definición oficial: Wet grasslands of the banks of the Loisach dominated by [Molinia caerulea] accompanied by fragmentary heavy metal communities comprising [Minuartia verna] var. [hercynica], [Silene vulgaris] var. [humilis] and [Cardaminopsis halleri], with [Cladonia spp.]

Species-rich humid grasslands of oligotrophic calcareous and often alkaline soils of the Pannonic basin, dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Lathyrus pannonicus], [Adenophora lilifolia], [Centaurea jacea], [Lotus maritimus], [Cirsium canum], [Inula britannica], [Succisa pratensis], [Serratula tinctoria], [Sanguisorba officinalis], [Silaum silaus], [Carex distans], [Carex flacca], [Carex hostiana], [Juncus subnodulosus], [Sesleria uliginosa]. These grasslands have become extremely rare in Austria.

Species-rich humid [Molinia] or [Molinia]-[Sesleria] grasslands of the northern and western periphery of the range of the typical Central European communities of units 37.3111 and 37.3112, with a species cort¿ge tending somewhat towards that of the sympatric, Atlantic or sub-Atlantic, acidocline communities of unit 37.32.

Submontane humid grasslands of the northern Pennines and the Lake District developed on moist moderately base-rich and calcareous peats and peaty mineral soils dominated by [Molinia caerulea] with [Carex nigra], [Carex panicea], with [Crepis paludosa], [Succisa pratensis], [Valeriana dioica], [Potentilla erecta], [Filipendula ulmaria], [Angelica sylvestris], [Sanguisorba officinalis], [Trollius europaeus], [Ranunculus acris], [Serratula tinctoria], [Carex pulicaris], [Carex flacca], [Carex hostiana], [Juncus acutiflorus], [Festuca rubra], [Briza media], [Equisetum palustre], [Calliergon cuspidatum].

Nombre oficial: Scandio-Baltic calcicline purple moorgrass-blue moorgrass meadows
Definición oficial: Species-rich calcicolous wet grasslands of Scandinavia dominated by [Sesleria caerulea], [Molinia caerulea], [Carex panicea] and [Linum catharticum] with a ground layer dominated by [Campylium stellatum] and [Ctenidum molluscum]. They are distributed in the Danish archipelago, in extreme southern Scania, ¿land and Gotland, coastal Estonia, along the coasts of the Skagerrak, the Kattegatt, and the Oslo Fjord, along the Atlantic coast of Norway north to the middle boreal zone, in west G¿tland and east G¿tland, in Södermanland and Uppland, in central J¿mtland on moist gley-calcareous soils with a relatively thick, peaty sod, under humid to semiarid nemoral, boreonemoral, southern boreal, middle boreal and oceanic climate conditions. [Carex flacca] and [Primula farinosa] are characteristic of their species cort¿ge which also includes [Carex flava], [Carex lepidocarpa], [Carex pulicaria], [Carex hostiana], [Carex nigra], [Cirsium acaule], [Parnassia palustre], [Pinguicula vulgaris], [Polygala amarella], [Potentilla erecta], [Primula vulgaris], [Scorzonera humilis], [Succisa pratensis], [Festuca rubra], [Hierochloe odorata], [Briza media] and many orchid species. These grasslands have affinities with the moister variants of unit 34.32, in particular the British [Sesleria] grasslands of unit 34.32142 and the moist Mesobromions of unit 34.324.

Species-rich calcicline wet grasslands of the western periphery of the northwestern European Hercynian ranges, known in particular from Belgium and northern France, dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Silaum silaus], [Succisa pratensis], [Achillea ptarmica], [Selinum carvifolia], [Scorzonera humilis], [Cirsium palustre], [Colchicum autumnale] sometimes abundant, [Dactylorhiza incarnata], [Dactylorhiza majalis], [Epipactis palustris], [Carex panicea], [Carex tomentosa], [Carex hostiana], [Carex pulicaris], [Carex flava], [Juncus inflexus].

Species-rich humid grasslands of oligotrophic calcareous or calcicline soils of southern France and northwestern Iberia dominated by, or rich in, [Molinia caerulea], with a species cort¿ge that includes, in addition to typical [Molinion] species, such as [Succisa pratensis] and [Stachys officinalis], a number of thermo-Atlantic or Mediterraneo-Atlantic species, among which [Centaurea nigra] var. [radiata], [Serapias cordigera].

Relatively species-poor humid grasslands of oligotrophic acid moist gley soils, sometimes with stagnant water and peat formation, of middle Europe north to the southern boreal approaches in Fennoscandia and the Faeroe Islands, and south to northwestern Iberia, with [Succisa pratensis], [Potentilla erecta], [Potentilla anglica], [Viola persicifolia], [Viola palustris], [Galium uliginosum], [Cirsium dissectum], [Crepis paludosa], [Luzula multiflora], [Juncus conglomeratus] ([Juncus subuliflorus]), [Ophioglossum vulgatum], [Inula britannica], [Lotus uliginosus], [Dianthus deltoides], [Carex pallescens], [Carex demissa], [Carex canescens], [Carex echinata].

Acidocline oligotrophic humid grasslands of southern and eastern Britain, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, northwestern Germany and northern France dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Cirsium dissectum], [Succisa pratensis], [Potentilla erecta], [Lotus uliginosus], [Galium uliginosum], [Crepis paludosa], [Viola palustris], [Luzula multiflora], [Juncus acutiflorus], [Juncus conglomeratus] ([Juncus subuliflorus]), [Carex panicea], [Carex echinata], [Carex hostiana].

Acidocline oligotrophic humid grasslands of the extreme Atlantic fringe of Europe, in western Britain and Ireland, dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Potentilla erecta], [Cirsium palustre], [Succisa pratensis], [Juncus acutiflorus], [Juncus effusus].

Acidocline oligotrophic humid grasslands of Fennoscandia, north to the southern boreal zone and to the oceanic middle boreal zone of Norway, dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Succisa pratensis], [Potentilla erecta], [Cirsium palustre]. Wetter, highly oligotrophic, communities, developed on permanently wet peaty ground, typically have a fairly tall sward, in which [Molinia caerulea] is the single dominant and a species cort¿ge that includes [Juncus conglomeratus], [Juncus effusus], [Pinguicula vulgaris]

Acidocline [Molinia caerulea]-dominated oligotrophic humid grasslands of Central Europe, distributed from Germany to Poland and Lithuania and from eastern France to Austria, of limited occurrence within the area of prevalence of the more continental, basicline communities of unit 37.311

Acidocline oligotrophic humid grasslands of eu-Atlantic France dominated by [Molinia caerulea] with [Carum verticillatum], [Wahlenbergia hederacea], [Lobellia urens], [Scutellaria minor], [Pucedanum gallicum], [Pucedanum lancifolium].

Acidocline oligotrophic humid grasslands of thermo-Atlantic France and northwestern Iberia dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Serratula seoanei], [Cirsium filipendulum], [Allium ochroleucon], [Allium ericetorum], [Laserpitium prutenicum].

Acidocline oligotrophic humid grasslands ofthe Massif Central and the eastern and central Pyrenees dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Polygonum bistorta], [Crepis paludosa], [Pediculara mixta], [Ligularia siberica], [Selinum pyreneum], [Myosotis lamottiana], [Tephroseris helenitis] ssp. [arvernensis], [Tephroseris helenitis] ssp. [helenitis], [Achillea pyrenaica].

Very tall [Molinia caerulea] ssp. [arundinacea] ([Molinia arundinacea])-dominated humid meadows of southern Central Europe, in particular, of the Illyrian zone, the peri-Pannonic and peri-Bohemian regions, the Danube, Lech and Isar basins, the upper Rhine.

Acidocline oligotrophic wet, often inundated, grasslands of boreal Fennoscandia dominated by [Molinia caerulea], with [Achillea millefolium], [Bartsia alpina], [Galium boreale], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Lysimachia thyrsiflora], [Pinguicula vulgaris], [Parnassia palustris], [Scutellaria galericulata], [Trientalis europaea], [Viola epipsila], [Carex acuta], [Carex aquatilis], [Juncus filiformis], [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Nardus stricta], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Hypnum lindbergii], [Mnium rugicum].

Nombre oficial: Heath rush meadows and humid mat-grass swards
Definición oficial: Humid, often peaty or semipeaty swards of middle Europe, southwest to northwestern Iberia and east to Lithuania, with [Nardus stricta], [Juncus squarrosus], [Festuca ovina], [Gentiana pneumonanthe], [Pedicularis sylvatica], [Scirpus cespitosus] and sometimes [Sphagnum spp.]
Nutrient-poor humid grasslands of the northern steppe zone of central Eurasia, eastern vicariants of the [Molinion] communities.
Nutrient-poor humid grasslands of the eastern deciduous forest zone of Eurasia and its regions of influence.

Mediterranean humid grasslands of tall grasses and rushes with [Scirpus holoschoenus] ([Holoschoenus vulgaris]), [Agrostis stolonifera], [Agrostis reuteri], [Galium debile], [Molinia caerulea], [Briza minor], [Melica cupanii], [Cyperus longus], [Linum tenue], [Trifolium resupinatum], [Schoenus nigricans], [Peucedanum hispanicum], [Carex mairii], [Juncus maritimus], [Juncus acutus], [Asteriscus aquaticus], [Hypericum tomentosum], [Hypericum tetrapterum], [Inula viscosa], [Oenanthe pimpinelloides], [Oenanthe lachenalii], [Eupatorium cannabinum], [Prunella vulgaris], [Pulicaria dysenterica], [Tetragonolobus maritimus], [Orchis laxiflora], [Dactylorhiza elata], [Succisa pratensis], [Sonchus maritimus] ssp. [aquatilis], [Silaum silaus], [Sanguisorba officinalis], [Serratula tinctoria], [Genista tinctoria], [Cirsium monspessulanum], [Cirsium pyrenaicum], [Senecio doria], [Dorycnium rectum], [Erica terminalis], [Euphorbia pubescens], [Lysimachia ephemerum], widespread in the entire Mediterranean basin, extending, along the coasts of the Black Sea, in particular in dunal systems, north to the Dobrogea and the Danube Delta, and, in valleys of the Balkan peninsula, north to the Banat.

Very short grasslands of impermeable compact soils or marls, wet for a large part of the year, and dessicated in summer, characteristic of the Mediterranean basin, with irradiations north to the Illyrian zone of the northwestern Balkan peninsula, with [Deschampsia media], [Centaurium pulchellum], [Lotus tenuis], [Trifolium lappaceum], [Prunella hyssopifolia], [Plantago maritima] ssp. [serpentina], [Centaurea timbali].

Humid meadows rich in clover ([Trifolium spp.]) of sub- and supramediterranean regions remote from Atlantic influence, in particular, of the Balkan peninsula, of the Apennines, of Mediterranean Anatolia, of Mediterranean North Africa, mostly developed at collinar levels.

Nombre oficial: Helleno-Moesian riverine and humid clover meadows
Definición oficial: Meso-hygrophile grasslands of river flood plains and other high water-table sites of the southern Balkan peninsula, in particular of Bulgaria, the F.Y.R. of Macedonia and northern Greece, with outposts in the Croatian coastlands, formed by [Alopecurus pratensis], [Alopecurus rendlei] ([Alopecurus utriculatus]), [Festuca pratensis] ([Festuca elatior]) or [Poa trivialis] ssp. [sylvicola] ([Poa sylvicola]), and by numerous [Trifolium spp.] including [Trifolium resupinatum], [Trifolium incarnatum], [Trifolium filiforme], [Trifolium balansae], [Trifolium nigrescens], [Trifolium michelianum], [Trifolium subterraneum], [Trifolium striatum], [Trifolium meneghinianum], [Trifolium patens], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Trifolium cinctum], [Medicago hispida] ssp. [apiculata], [Lotus corniculatus] var. [hirsutus], [Hordeum murinum], [Ranunculus marginatus], [Ranunculus velutinus], [Cirsium canum] var. [macedonicum], [Oenanthe stenoloba], [Moenchia mantica], [Lychnis flos-cuculi] ssp. [subintegra], [Teucrium scordioides], [Podospermum canum], [Narcissus poeticus], [Leucojum aestivum].

Permanent humid grasslands of Apennine karstic basins, with [Ranunculus velutinus], [Bromus racemosus], [Hordeum secalinum], [Trifolium dubium], [Trifolium resupinatum], [Trifolium micranthum], [Trifolium patens], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Trifolium pratense], [Trifolium repens], [Carex distans], [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Gaudinia fragilis], [Ophioglossum vulgatum], [Centaurea jacea], [Holcus lanatus], [Alopecurus rendlei] ([Alopecurus utriculatus]), [Orchis laxiflora], [Colchicum lusitanum].
Humid meadows of Illyrian Istria and Dalmatia, developed in a mild semihumid to semiarid climate, of pronounced sub-Mediterranean affinities.

Nombre oficial: Illyrio-Moesian riverine and humid clover meadows
Definición oficial: Floodplain meadows of southern sub-Pannonic regions, within the eastern [Carpinion illyricum], the [Quercion frainetto] and the [Fagion moesiacum] zones of Bosnia, Serbia, Oltenia and northwestern Bulgaria, under semihumid to semiarid climates, mostly dominated by [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Alopecurus pratensis] or [Poa trivialis] ssp. [sylvicola], with [Trifolium pallidum], [Trifolium patens], [Trifolium fragiferum], [Trifolium cinctum], [Ranunculus stevenii], [Lathyrus nissolia], [Medicago arabica], [Clematis integrifolia].
Humid meadows rich in clover of sub- and supramediterranean regions of Mediterranean Anatolia.
Humid meadows rich in clover of sub- and supramediterranean regions of Mediterranean North Africa.
Watercourse veil and shady woodland edge communities.
Screens or veils of perennial tall herbs, small bushes and lianas lining lowland watercourses, and sometimes other water bodies, often with many ruderal and exogenous plants.
[Angelica archangelica] ssp. [litoralis] formations of great northern rivers, presently rare and threatened.
[Angelica heterocarpa] formations of tidal estuaries of the Loire, the Charente and the Gironde
[Althaea officinalis] formations of river banks and marsh edges, particularly on somewhat saline soils.

Formations of the alluvial banks of small streams, characteristic of collinar and low montane levels of the Alpine system and the Hercynian ranges of Western and Central Europe and of northern Eastern Europe, constituted by [Petasites hybridus] ([Petasites officinalis]), [Petasites albus], [Petasites kablikianus] ([Petasites glabratus]), sometimes by [Chaerophyllum hirsutum] or [Equisetum telmateia], occasionally accompanied by various tall herbs, in particular, [Cirsium oleraceum], or by ferns.

Screens or veils of perennial tall herbs, [Senecio fluviatilis], [Eupatorium cannabinum], [Epilobium hirsutum], [Sonchus palustris], [Urtica dioica], small bushes and lianas, [Calystegia sepium], [Cuscusta europaea], lining lowland watercourses, and sometimes other water bodies, of Western, Central and northern Eastern Europe, outside of the steppe and wooded-steppe zones, with many ruderal and introduced plants, such as [Aster spp.], [Rudbeckia spp.], [Solidago spp.], [Helianthus spp.], [Impatiens spp.], [Reynoutria japonica].

Screens or veils of perennial tall herbs, [Senecio fluviatilis], [Eupatorium cannabinum], [Epilobium hirsutum], [Sonchus palustris], [Urtica dioica], small bushes and lianas, [Calystegia sepium], [Cuscusta europaea], lining lowland watercourses, and sometimes other water bodies, of the steppe and wooded-steppe zones of Eurasia, including, in the west, the Pannonic basin and the lower Danube valley, with many ruderal and introduced plants, such as [Aster spp.], [Rudbeckia spp.], [Solidago spp.], [Helianthus spp.], [Impatiens spp.], [Reynoutria japonica].
Screens or veils of perennial tall herbs lining lowland watercourses, and sometimes other water bodies, of the nemoral zone of eastern Asia.

Nitro-hygrophilous communities of usually large-leaved herbs developing along the shaded side of wooded stands and hedges, with [Galium aparine], [Glechoma hederacea], [Geum urbanum], [Aegopodium podagraria], [Silene dioica], [Carduus crispus], [Chaerophyllum hirsutum], [Lamium album], [Alliaria petiolata], [Lapsana communis], [Geranium robertianum], [Viola alba], [Viola odorata].

Nombre oficial: Subalpine and alpine tall herb communities
Definición oficial: Luxuriant tall herb formations of deep, humid soils in the montane to alpine, but mostly subalpine, levels of the higher mountains, with [Cicerbita alpina], [Cicerbita alpina plumieri], [Cirsium helenioides], [Cirsium spinosissimum], [Cirsium flavispina], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Polygonatum verticillatum], [Ranunculus platanifolius], [Aconitum vulparia], [Aconitum napellus], [Aconitum nevadense], [Adenostyles alliariae], [Senecio elodes], [Veratrum album], [Trollius europaeus], [Peucedanum ostruthium], [Doronicum austriacum], [Pedicularis foliosa], [Eryngium alpinum], [Leuzea rhapontica] ([Centaurea rhapontica]), [Valeriana pyrenaica], [Tozzia alpina]. Groupings of these plants can invade the [Aceri-Fagion] and reappear, along streams, lower down in montane beech forests. If useful, their presence can be noted by combining a code of 37.8 with the appropriate forest code.
Subalpine and alpine mesohygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Pontic Range, of the Caucasus, of the Crimean mountains and of the Elburz.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Himalayan system.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Altai, of the Sayan and of other southern Siberian and eastern Asian boreal mountains.

Nombre oficial: Far Eastern subalpine tall herb communities
Definición oficial: Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Sino-Japanese mountains of eastern Asia.

Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Dinarides, the Jura, the great Hercynian ranges, the Central Massif and the Apennines.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Alps.
[Delphinium elatum]-dominated stands of the tall herb communities of the eastern Alps.
Rare tall herb communities of the eastern Alps dominated by [Carduus carduelis] and [Cirsium carniolicum], associated with Trisetum flavescens and [Myrrhis odorata].
[Leuzea rhapontica] ([Centaurea rhapontica], [Stemmacantha rhapontica])-dominated stands of the tall herb communities of the Alps.
[Adenostyles alliariae]-dominated stands and very mixed stands of the tall herb communities of the Alps.

Fern-dominated facies of the tall herb communities of the Alps, with [Athyrium distentifolium] ([Athyrium alpestre]), [Athyrium filix-femina], succession stages floristically often more related to the small reed communities of 37.82.
Tall herb communities of the Alps dominated by [Aconitum tauricum], [Aconitum napellus] or [Aconitum compactum], often in almost pure stands.
[Petasites albus]-dominated tall herb communities of the Alps characteristic of damper stations and montane brook edges.
[Doronicum spp.]-dominated tall herb communities of the Alps structured around [Doronicum cataractarum].
[Cicerbita alpina]-dominated facies of the tall-herb communities of the Alps.
[Alchemilla vulgaris] agg.-dominated facies of the tall herb communities of the Alps.
[Geranium sylvaticum]-rich stands of the tall herb communities of the Alps.
[Ranunculus platanifolius]-dominated stands of the tall herb communities of the Alps.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Jura.

Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Central Massif and of the great ranges of the Hercynian arc, in particular, the Vosges, the Black Forest and the major ranges of the Bohemian Quadrangle, the Sudeten, the Erzgebirge, the Bohemian Forest (Sumava).
[Adenostyles alliariae]-dominated stands and very mixed stands of the tall herb communities of the Vosges, the Black Forest, the Sudeten and the Central Massif.

Fern-dominated facies of the tall herb communities of the great Hercynian ranges, in particular, the Bohemian Quadrangle, with [Athyrium distentifolium] ([Athyrium alpestre]), [Athyrium filix-femina].
[Petasites albus]-dominated tall herb communities of the upper montane and subalpine levels of the Sudeten.
[Doronicum spp.]-dominated tall herb communities of the Sudeten structured around [Doronicum austriacum].
[Cicerbita alpina]-dominated facies of the tall-herb communities of the great Hercynian ranges, in particular of the Sudeten, the Erzgebirge and the Black Forest.

Nombre oficial: Hercynian high montane globe flower communities
Definición oficial: [Trollius europaeus]-dominated tall herb communities of the southeastern Sudeten.
[Geranium sylvaticum]-rich stands of the tall herb communities of the southeastern Sudeten.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Carpathians.
Tall herb communities of the Carpathians formed by [Adenostyles alliariae], [Cicerbita alpina] ([Mulgedium alpinum]), [Epilobium alpinum].
Tall herb communities of the Carpathians dominated by [Athyrium distentifolium] ([Athyrium alpestre]).
Tall herb communities of the Carpathians formed by [Aconitum] species.
Tall herb communities of the northwestern Carpathians formed by [Aconitum firmum] ([Aconitum callibotryon]), [Archangelica officinalis], [Delphinium oxysepalum].

Tall herb communities of the subalpine and alpine levels of the Eastern and Southern Carpathians, occupying wet nutrient- and humus-rich colluvions of glacial cirque perimeters dominated by [Aconitum tauricum], with [Saxifraga heucherifolia] and a representation of species of the [Adenostylion].
Formations of the Carpathians dominated by [Petasites spp.]
[Petasites albus]-dominated formations of the upper montane and lower subalpine levels of the Carpathians, with species typical of the [Adenostylion].
[Petasites kablikianus]-dominated formations of shady streamsides of Carpathian mountain valleys, with [Orobanche flava], [Carduus personata], [Chaerophyllum hirsutum].
Tall herb formations of the Carpathians formed by [Aruncus sylvestris] and [Aconitum variegatum] ([Aconitum gracile]).

Subalpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the eastern and southern Carpathians dominated by [Heracleum palmatum] and [Cirsium waldsteinii], with other regional species including [Salix silesiaca], [Leucanthemum waldsteinii], [Achillea distans], [Pulmonaria filarszkyana] and [Aconitum moldavicum].
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Dinarides.
Tall-herb communities of the Dinarides formed by [Adenostyles alliariae], [Cicerbita alpina], [Doronicum austriacum], [Scopolia carniolica], [Eryngium alpinum], in single dominance or mixed stands.
Tall herb communities of the Dinarides dominated by [Aconitum napellus], with [Lamiastrum galeobdolon], [Angelica archangelica], [Petasites albus].
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb communities dominated by [Laserpitium archangelicum], with [Poa hybrida], [Hesperis dinarica].
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Apennines.

Communities of the montane and subalpine levels of high and moderately high mountains of the Alpine system and neighbouring ranges, dominated by tall grasses, accompanied by a species cort¿ge similar to that of the subalpine tall-herb communities.

Communities of the montane and subalpine levels of high and moderately high mountains of the Alpine system and neighbouring ranges, dominated by tall grasses of genus [Calamagrostis], accompanied by a species cort¿ge similar to that of the subalpine tall-herb communities.

Thermophile, meso-xerophile species-rich, abundantly flowering, often primary   formations of steep adrets of the subalpine level of the Alps, the Jura, the great Hercynian ranges and the Central Massif, the Dinarides, the Pelagonides,  the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Rhodopides, the Balkan Range, mostly dominated by [Calamagrostis arundinacea], associated with plants such as [Senecio doronicum], [Digitalis grandiflora], [Hieracium aurantiacum], [Hieracium prenanthoides], [Aconitum vulparia], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Bupleurum longifolium], [Galium boreale], [Lilium martagon], [Pimpinella major], [Rosa pendulina], [Sorbus sudetica], [Sorbus aria], [Sorbus mougeotii], [Sorbus chamaemespilus].

Communities of the montane and subalpine levels of the Alps, the Sudeten, the Carpathians, the Rhodopes, dominated by [Calamagrostis villosa], accompanied by a tall-herb species cort¿ge usually less rich in woodland edge and short grassland species than those of the [Calamagrostion arundinaceae]
Communities of the montane and subalpine levels of the Carpathians dominated by tall fescues, accompanied by a species cort¿ge similar to that of the subalpine tall-herb communities.

Tall, two-layered, closed [Festuca carpatica]-dominated grasslands of the northwestern and eastern Carpathians, developed on shallow stony soils overlying basic rocks, on steep slopes subjected to long snow cover, in particular, in avalanche troughs, physiognomically and ecologically similar to small reed grasslands of the [Calamagrostion arundinaceae] [s.l.], but with a species cort¿ge characteristic in part of the calciphile grasslands of the [Seslerion tatrae] and the [Festuco saxatilis-Seslerion bielzii].

Mesophile tall grass community of the subalpine and upper montane levels of the Romanian and Ukrainian Carpathians dominated by [Festuca porcii], with [Calamagrostis villosa], [Festuca picta], [Knautia longifolia] and regional species such as [Campanula patula] ssp. [abietina], [Hypericum richeri] ssp. [grisebachii], [Achillea distans], [Festuca pratensis] ssp. [apennina], [Scorzonera purpurea] ssp. [rosea] ([Scorzonera rosea]).

Communities of the upper montane and subalpine levels of the Sudeten, the Carpathians, the Dinarides, the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides and, locally, of the Alps, dominated by [Deschampsia cespitosa], accompanied by a species cort¿ge similar to that of the subalpine tall-herb communities.

Communities of the subalpine or alpine level of the Sudeten, in particular, of the Giant Mountains (Krkonose, Karkonosze) and the Jesenik Mountains, dominated by [Molinia caerulea], accompanied by a species cort¿ge comprising representatives of the [Betulo-Adenostyletea], the [Molinietalia], the [Phragmitetalia] and the [Caricetalia fuscae], in particular, [Deschampsia caespitosa] and [Phragmites australis].

Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of the Pyrenees, the Cantabrian mountains, the Cordillera Central, the Iberian Range, with [Valeriana pyrenaica] and [Adenostyles alliariae] ssp. [hybrida] ([Adenostyles alliariae] ssp. [pyrenaica]).
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of southern Iberian and North African mountains.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb communities of the Sierra Nevada and other southern Iberian mountains, with the endemic [Cirsium flavispina], [Aconitum nevadense], [Senecio elodes].
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Atlas system.

Tall-herb communities of the subalpine and lower alpine level of Corsica, limited to shady, strongly sloping corridors with prolonged snow cover and often with stabilized scree, formed by [Adenostyles briquetii], [Valeriana rotundifolia], [Peucedanum ostruthium], [Cymbalaria hepaticifolia], [Ranunculus platanifolius], [Aquilegia bernardii], [Viola biflora], and often several fern species.

Tall-herb communities of the subalpine and lower alpine level of Corsica, limited to shady, strongly sloping corridors with prolonged snow cover and often with stabilized scree, formed by [Adenostyles briquetii], [Valeriana rotundifolia], [Peucedanum ostruthium], [Cymbalaria hepaticifolia], [Ranunculus platanifolius], [Aquilegia bernardii], [Viola biflora], and often several fern species.
Tall-herb communities of the subalpine level of Corsica, limited to the Pianu di Cuscione, dominated by the endemic [Aconitum napellus] ssp. [corsicum], of extremely limited distribution.

Dense herbaceous communities of the subalpine level of Corsica, characteristic of strongly sloping corridors with prolonged snow cover, in somewhat less shady situations than those colonized by the communities of unit 37.851, formed by [Luzula sylvatica] var. [sieberi], [Polygonum alpinum], [Solidago virgaurea], [Cymbalaria hepaticifolia], [Ranunculus platanifolius], [Adenostyles briquetii].

Tall herb riparian communities of stony and rocky torrents and of dripping rocks of the upper montane, subalpine and alpine levels of Corsica formed by [Doronicum corsicum], [Narthecium reverchonii], [Carex frigida], [Calamagrostris varia] ssp. [corsica], [Phalaris arundinacea] var. [rotgesii] ([Typhoides arundinacea] ssp. [rotgesii]).

Nombre oficial: Eastern oro-Mediterranean and Balkan tall herb communities
Definición oficial: Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Balkan Range, the Hellenides and the mountains of Mediterranean Anatolia.

Riparian and spring-edge vegetation of the montane and subalpine level of the Pindus and the Thessalian mountains south to Giona and Parnassus, with [Cirsium appendiculatum], [Cirsium tymphaeum], [Heracleum sphondylium] ssp. [pyrenaicum] ([Heracleum pollinianum]), [Stachys alopecuros] ([Betonica jacquinii]), [Scrophularia umbrosa] ([Scrophularia samaritanii]), [Scrophularia scopolii], [Achillea grandifolia], [Campanula trachelium] ssp. [athoa], [Chaerophyllum aureum], [Epilobium obscurum], [Solidago virgaurea], [Veratrum album], [Geranium asphodeloides].

Montane meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of small splashing mountain torrents, moist hollows and gullies of the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains and the Pelagonides, irradiating southwards, in the montane, sylvatic, level of the northern Pindus and the Pieria. The formations of these units harbour many species of the genus [Alchemilla].

Nombre oficial: Moesian Balkan thistle tall herb communities
Definición oficial: [Cirsium appendiculatum] tall herb formations of the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Pelagonides, irradiating southwards, in the montane, sylvatic, level of the northern Pindus and the Pieria. The communities of the Balkan Range and the Rhodopides harbour several species endemic or rare in the region, including [Alchemilla plicatula], [Trollius europaeus], [Pinguicula vulgaris].

[Petasites albus] or [Petasites hybridus] tall herb formations of the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Pelagonides, with [Epilobium montanum], [Alchemilla  spp.], [Carex spp.], [Geum coccineum].

Tall herb communities of the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Pelagonides dominated by [Heracleum sphondylium] ssp. [verticillatum], or [Heracleum sphondylium] ssp. [ternatum], extending south to the Moeso-Macedonian and Rhodopide mountains of northeastern Greece, in particular, to Belles, Athos, the Pangeon, the Falakron and the Rhodopi.

Nombre oficial: Moesian scarlet avens tall herb communities
Definición oficial: [Geum coccineum] formations of the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Pelagonides, south to the Varnous, Vernon, Vermion and Voras-Tzena groups.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Taurus system of Mediterranean Anatolia.

Alpine and subalpine meso-hygrophile nitrophilous tall herb formations of the Alpine system and the higher Hercynian ranges, in particular, the Sudeten, the Black Forest, the Fichtelgebirge, the Dinarides, characteristic of the vicinity of cattle and game resting places, with [Rumex alpinus], [Senecio alpinus], [Cirsium spinosissimum], [Aconitum napellus], [Geranium phaeum], [Peucedanum ostruthium], [Urtica dioica], [Phleum alpinum] and, in eastern Carpathian communities, [Senecio subalpinus], [Leucanthemum waldsteinii], [Achillea distans], [Heracleum sphondylium] ssp. [transsilvanicum].
Subalpine and alpine mesohygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the boreal mountains and of the Scottish Highlands.

Generally species-rich communities of North Atlantic boreal mountains and uplands dominated by forbs of moderate stature, in particular, [Rhodiola rosea], [Alchemilla glabra], [Geranium sylvaticum], associated with [Angelica sylvestris], [Angelica archangelica], grasses, woodrushes or geophytes.

Species-rich tall-herb communities of the Scottish Highlands, the Hebrides, Orkney and Shetland, with outposts in the Moffat Hills, the Lake District and North Wales, formed by [Rhodiola rosea], [Alchemilla glabra], [Rubus saxatilis], [Geum rivale], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Angelica sylvestris], [Heracleum sphondylium], [Saussurea alpina], [Luzula sylvatica], [Festuca ovina], [Festuca vivipara], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], colonizing steep crags out of range of grazing, on moist base-rich soils in sheltered situations of cold wet mountains.
Luxuriant tall-herb communities of the Faeroe Islands rich in [Rhodiola rosea], [Alchemilla faeroensis], [Luzula sylvatica], [Angelica sylvestris] and [Geranium sylvaticum].
Herb-rich upland communities of south-facing escarpments and moraine slopes of Iceland rich in, or dominated by [Rhodiola rosea], developed on relatively moist soils.

Luxuriant tall-herb communities of Iceland dominated by [Angelica archangelica] and [Geranium sylvaticum] accompanied by [Angelica sylvestris], [Alchemilla vulgaris] [s.l.] ([Alchemilla acaulis]), [Filipendula ulmaria], [Hieracium spp.], [Taraxacum spp.], [Ranunculus acris], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Agrostis capillaris], [Leymus arenarius], [Hierochloe odorata], [Salix phylicifolia], often associated with bird colonies.

Communities of submontane areas of the Fennoscandian mountains and of Iceland dominated by [Geranium sylvaticum], with [Dactylorhiza fuchsii], [Carex atrata], [Carex vaginata], [Geum rivale], [Melampyrum pratense], [Melampyrum sylvatica], [Rubus saxatilis], [Succisa pratensis], [Trientalis europaea] and, in Iceland, [Dactylorhiza islandica], [Plathantera hyperborea].

Relatively species-poor tall-herb communities of the Scottish Highlands, the Southern Uplands, the Inner Hebrides and Orkney, with outposts in the Lake District and the Cheviots, formed by [Luzula sylvatica], usually abundant and sometimes overwhelmingly dominant, accompanied by [Vaccinium myrtillus] and other subshrubs, sometimes constituting a dominated layer, and by [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Galium saxatile], [Oxalis acetosella], [Blechnum spicant], sometimes [Dryopteris dilatata] and other ferns, [Cicerbita alpina], [Anthoxanthum odoratum] or [Festuca ovina], colonizing inaccessible rocky formations and slopes, on relatively moist base-poor substrates with humic soils.
Communities of the mountains of the boreal and subarctic zones of the Eurasian continent dominated by tall dicotyledonous herbs.
Communities of the boreal and arctoalpine Fennoscandian mountains dominated by tall dicotyledonous herbs.

Tall herb-dominated communities of Scandinavian mountains dominated by [Cicerbita alpina], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Cirsium helenioides] with [Aconitum septentrionale], [Angelica archangelica], [Ranunculus platanifolia], [Saussurea alpina], [Rumex acetosa], [Trollius europaeus], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Calamagrostis purpurea], [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Poa alpina], [Equisetum arvense], [Equisetum pratense], [Athyrium filix-femina], [Matteuccia struthiopteris], [Rubus saxatilis], [Salix spp.]

Species-rich, multitiered [Trollius europaeus]-dominated communities of lower alpine levels of Scandinavian mountains, colonizing lime and nutrient-rich soils with flowing subsurface water, often situated below snow fields. The species cort¿ge includes [Trollius europaeus], [Viola biflora], [Polygonum bistorta], [Polygonum viviparum] ([Bistorta vivipara]), [Astragalus alpina], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Parnassia palustris], [Ranunculus acris], [Potentilla crantzii], [Saussurea alpina], [Solidago virgaurea], [Taraxacum croceum], [Poa alpigena], [Poa alpina], [Festuca vivipara], [Festuca rubra], [Carex bigelowii], [Thalictrum alpinum], [Selaginella selaginoides].
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the Urals and neighbouring boreal ranges.
Subalpine and alpine meso-hygrophile tall herb formations of moist hollows and gullies of the boreal mountains of northern Siberia.

Nombre oficial: Oroboreal tall grass and fern communities
Definición oficial: Communities of the montane and subalpine levels of mountains of the boreal and subarctic zones of the northern Eurasian continent, dominated by tall grasses of genera [Calamagrostis], [Deschampsia], [Festuca] accompanied by ferns and a dicot species cort¿ge similar to that of the oroboreal tall-herb communities.

Chionophilous tall-herb communities of boreal and arctoalpine mountains of Fennoscandia dominated by [Calamagrostis purpurea], characteristic of screes with prolonged snow cover, related to the fern communities of unit 36.1125.

Communities of the montane and subalpine levels of the Urals dominated by tall grasses of genera [Calamagrostis], [Deschampsia], [Anthoxanthum] accompanied by ferns and a dicot species cort¿ge similar to that of the Uralian tall-herb communities.
Communities of the montane and subalpine levels of the boreal mountains of northern Siberia dominated by tall grasses.

Communities of the mountains and uplands of nemoral and boreonemoral zones of the northern Eurasian continent, dominated by ferns or tall grasses, notably, local communities of the western and northern uplands of Great Britain, particularly common in cooler oceanic regions, formed by [Thelypteris limbosperma] and [Blechnum spicant].

Luxuriant, dense stands of very tall herbs growing under oceanic climates with evenly distributed moderate to high precipitation and stable frost-protecting snowcover, of Kamchatka, the Kuriles, Sakhalin, Honshu, northern Hokkaido and coastal Amurland, extending from sea-level to 1000 m in Kamchatka and Sakhalin, to 2000 m on Hokkaido, to 2500 m on Honshu. They represent a relict form of vegetation entirely restricted to Pacific northeastern Asia.
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Urtica platyphylla].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Filipendula camtschatica].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Angelica ursina].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Anthriscus sylvestris].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Petasites amplus].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Senecio cannabilifolius].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Heracleum lanatum].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Cacalia kamtschatica].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Polygonum weyrichii].
Far-eastern giant herb communities dominated by [Reynoutria sachalinensis].
Lowland and montane mesophile pastures and hay meadows of the boreal, nemoral, warm-temperate humid, Irano-Turanian and mediterranean zones.

Regularly grazed mesophile pastures of Europe, fertilized and on well-drained soils, with [Lolium perenne], [Cynosurus cristatus], [Poa spp.], [Festuca spp.], [Trifolium repens], [Leontodon autumnalis], [Bellis perennis], [Ranunculus repens], [Ranunculus acris], [Cardamine pratensis]

Continuous pastureland of Euro-Siberian Europe, Atlantic Iberia and the Cordillera Central, the Apennines and the supra-Mediterranean zone of the Balkan peninsula and Greece, unrelieved by networks of ditches.

Relatively species-poor grasslands of Euro-Siberian Western and Central Europe, Atlantic Iberia and the Cordillera Central, the Apennines and the supra-Mediterranean zone of the Balkan peninsula and Greece dominated by [Lolium perenne], often with [Cynosurus cristatus].
More species-rich grasslands of the British Isles dominated by [Cynosurus cristatus] and with many flowering herbs, notably [Centaurea nigra].

Pastures mostly of uplands of Western Europe, Central Europe and Eastern Europe, less treated, rougher and more species-rich than those of unit 38.111, often with the cespitose [Festuca nigrescens] and a significant representation of nitrofuge species.
Pastures of Eastern Europe, in the southern part of the Russian forest zone, Bashkiria and the southern Urals.
Grasslands drained by a network of ditches, fleets, streams or pools.
Abandoned grasslands with ruderal species.

Mesophile hay meadows of low altitudes of Europe, fertilized and well-drained, with [Arrhenatherum elatius], [Trisetum flavescens], [Anthriscus sylvestris], [Heracleum sphondylium], [Daucus carota], [Crepis biennis], [Knautia arvensis], [Leucanthemum vulgare], [Pimpinella major], [Trifolium dubium], [Geranium pratense]
Lowland mesophile hay meadows of the Atlantic domaine of Europe, characteristic of the British Isles and western France.

Lowland mesophile hay meadows of the British Isles and western France rich in, or dominated by [Arrhenatherum elatius] accompanied by [Dactylis glomerata] and [Holcus lanatus] with [Centaurea debeauxii] ssp. [nemoralis] ([Centaurea nigra], [Centaurea nemoralis]), [Rhinanthus lanceolatus], [Oenanthe pimpinelloides], [Gaudinia fragilis], [Linum bienne], [Brachypodium pinnatum].

Lowland mesophile hay meadows of England, characteristic of areas where traditional hay meadow treatment has been applied to seasonally flooded alluvial soils, formed by [Alopecurus pratensis], [Festuca rubra], [Cynosurus cristatus], [Lolium perenne], with less abundant or less constant [Holcus lanatus], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Dactylis glomerata], [Trisetum flavescens], [Agrostis stolonifera], [Bromus hordeaceus], [Arrhenatherum elatius], [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Festuca arundinacea], with many dicots, among which [Sanguisorba officinalis], [Filipendula ulmaria], [Leontodon spp.], [Taraxacum spp.] are often abundant and [Fritillaria meleagris] particularly noteworthy.

Mesophile lowland hay meadows of sub-Atlantic Western Europe, of western and northern Central Europe, of the humid Illyrian region and of the eastern Carpathian system, with [Arrhenatherum elatius], [Daucus carota], [Crepis biennis], [Knautia arvensis], [Leucanthemum vulgare], [Pimpinella major], [Trifolium dubium], [Geranium pratense], [Alchemilla xanthochlora], [Campanula patula], [Pastinaca sativa], [Galium album], [Equisetum arvense], [Medicago sativa], [Picris hieracioides], [Sanguisorba officinalis].

Drier, more thermophile, swards of the lowland sub-Atlandic mesophile hay meadows of Western Europe and Central Europe, dominated by [Arrhenatherum elatius], and with a species composition that includes [Festuco-Brometea] dry grassland species, in particular, [Salvia pratensis], [Bromus erectus], [Ranunculus bulbosus], [Dianthus carthusianorum], [Pimpinella saxifraga], [Plantago media], [Galium verum], [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Linum catharticum].

More humid, or temporarily more humid, swards of the lowland sub-Atlandic mesophile hay meadows of Western Europe and Central Europe, dominated by [Arrhenatherum elatius] and [Alopecurus pratensis], or by the latter alone, and with a species composition intermediate between that of mesophile and humid meadows (37) with [Cirsium oleraceum], [Angelica sylvestris], [Sanguisorba officinalis], [Ranunculus repens], [Myosotis palustris], [Glechoma hederacea], [Lychnis flos-cuculi], [Ajuga reptans], [Cardamine pratensis], [Lysimachia nummularia], [Geranium pratense], [Campanula patula], [Pastinaca sativa], [Heracleum sphondylium], [Anthriscus sylvestris]. Towards the east, in more continental climates, the [Alopecurus] meadows communities increasingly take the character of humid riverine meadows

Mesophile grasslands of middle European Hercynian hills, of the middle elevations of the greater Hercynian ranges, the Jura, the pre-Alps, the Dinarides, the Pelagonides, the Carpathians, the Pyrenees, the mountains of the northwestern Iberian peninsula, intermediate between the lowland meadows of unit 38.22 and the montane meadows of unit 38.3.

Hay meadows of higher elevations of the lesser Hercynian ranges, with [Meum athamanticum], [Festuca nigrescens], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Lathyrus montanus], [Phyteuma spicatum], [Potentilla erecta], [Galium saxatile], [Ranunculus bulbosus], [Pimpinella saxifraga], [Lotus uliginosus].
Hay meadows of mid-elevations of the great Hercynian ranges of Central Europe and of the hills of the eastern Germano-Baltic Plain, in particular, of the Baltic States.
Hay meadows of mid-elevations of the great Hercynian ranges of Central Europe.
Hay meadows of siliceous substrates of the hills of the eastern Germano-Baltic Plain, in particular, of the Baltic States.
Hay meadows of calcareous substrates of the hills of the Baltic States.
Hay meadows of the submontane level of the Carpathians, at about 600-700 m.
Endemic community of the western Carpathians, with [Alchemilla walasii], [Alchemilla micans], [Alchemilla pastoralis], [Centaurea oxylepis], [Gladiolus imbricatus], [Viola saxatilis] var. [decorata].

Species-rich hay meadows of the Pienini and the Beskides, limited to thermophilous stations on deep calcareous soils, with [Medicago falcata], [Polygala comosa], [Thymus pulegioides], [Salvia verticillata], [Ranunculus polyanthemos].

Submontane mesophile meadows of the Romanian Carpathians, developed on nutrient-rich acid brown soils, dominated by [Trisetum flavescens], accompanied by [Arrhenatherum elatius] and a species cort¿ge characteristic of the [Arrhenatherion], including [Campanula patula], [Trifolium repens], [Leucanthemum vulgare], [Lotus corniculatus].

Mesophile hay meadows of sub-Atlantic northern Spain, in particular, of the beech level of the oro-Cantabrian region, with [Arrhenatherum elatius] ssp. [bulbosum], [Trisetum flavescens], [Sanguisorba minor], [Malva moschata], [Knautia arvensis], [Pimpinella major], [Trifolium repens].
Submontane mesophile hay meadows of the pre-Alps.
Submontane mesophile hay meadows of the Jura.

Submontane mesophile hay meadows of the beech level of the Dinarides, within the range of the [Fagion illyricum], dominated by [Trisetum flavescens], with [Poa pratensis], [Arrhenatherum elatius], [Festuca pratensis], [Alchemilla xanthochlora].
Submontane mesophile hay meadows of the beech level of the Pelagonides, within the range of the [Fagion moesiacum], dominated by [Trisetum flavescens].

Herb-rich meadows of boreal affinities of the boreal and boreonemoral regions of the Palaearctic, with outposts in cool humid uplands of the northern nemoral zone, in particular, in the British Isles.

Herb-rich meadows of boreal affinities of Fennoscandia, distributed in the boreonemoral, southern boreal, middle boreal, northern boreal, boreoalpine and oceanic southern boreal zones of Finland, Sweden and Norway, formed by [Deschampsia cespitosa], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Festuca ovina], [Briza media], with, as dominant dicots, [Geranium sylvaticum], [Alchemilla spp.], [Rhinanthus minor], [Anemone nemorosa] and a cort¿ge that includes boreal elements such as [Polygonum viviparum], [Rubus arcticus], boreonemoral species, in particular, [Hypochoeris maculata], [Veronica chamaedrys], as well as [Cirsium helenioides], [Filipendula ulmaria], [Potentilla erecta], [Ranunculus auricomus], [Trollius europaeus], [Hepatica nobilis], [Dactylorhiza maculata], [Dactylorhiza fuchsii], [Listera ovata], [Platanthera chlorantha].

Mesophile hay meadows of submontane areas of northern England, with affinities to both the Fennoscandian boreal meadows of unit 38.241 and to the submontane continental Western European meadows of unit 38.23.

Upland mesophile hay meadows of northern England, essentially restricted to Teesdale and Weardale in Durham, Swaledale and Wensleydale in North Yorkshire,  and to the Lake District, with outposts along the Tay in Scotland, formed by a mixture of grasses, including [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Dactylus glomerata], [Festuca rubra], [Holcus lanatus], [Agrostis capillaris], [Poa trivialis], with [Geranium sylvaticum] abundant and sometimes dominant, [Sanguisorba officinalis], [Alchemilla glabra], [Alchemilla xanthochlora] and a number of rarer species of genus [Alchemilla].

Tall mesophile hay meadows of northern England, limited to the Carboniferous Limestone of Derbyshire and Craven, with an isolated occurrence in the Cheviots, dominated by large tussocks of [Arrhenatherum elatius] and [Festuca rubra], accompanied by tall hemicryptophyte dicotyledons, in particular, [Filipendula ulmaria], [Heracleum sphondylium], [Valeriana officinalis], [Angelica sylvestris] and, in some communities, [Polemonium caeruleum].

Lowland and collinar mesophile grasslands of the Pannonic basin, the Transylvanian basin, the lower Danubian plain, the Thracian plain and their fringing foothills, of Eastern Europe and of southern Siberia.
Lowland and collinar mesophile grasslands of the Pannonic basin, the Transylvanian basin, the lower Danubian plain, the Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain and their fringing foothills.
Lowland, collinar and, locally, montane, mesophile grasslands of the northern Thracian plain and its fringing foothills.

Mesophile floodplain hay meadows of the northern Thracian plain and its fringing foothills, on soils moistened by a high water table fed by riverine inundation, situated on higher ground than riverine meadows of unit 37, dominated by similar grass species, including [Poa pratensis], [Alopecurus pratensis]

Mesophile hay meadows of the valleys and lower slopes of mountain ranges fringing the northern Thracian plain and its peripheral basins installed on soils moistened by underground or surface water supplied by slope runoff, dominated by the same grass species as in the floodplain meadows of 38.2521, accompanied by [Arrhenatherum elatius] and [Agrostis capillaris].

Species-rich mesophile hay meadows of the lower slopes and foot of the southern flank of the Balkan Range, developed on calcareous substrates and with a supply of cold surface and ground water originating in the upper levels of the mountain, dominated by [Poa pratensis], [Alopecurus pratensis], [Alopecurus rendlei] ([Alopecurus utriculatus]), [Festuca pratensis] and with  orchids, [Clematis integrifolia], [Cladium mariscus], [Merendera sobolifera], [Galium rubioides].
Lowland and collinar mesophile grasslands of the Sarmatic region of Eastern Europe.
Lowland and collinar mesophile meadows of southern Siberia.

Mesophile [Poa bulbosa]-meadows of well-drained, relatively fertile, mineral soils of submediterranean regions of the southwestern Balkan peninsula, recorded, in particular, from the lower altitudes of Albania.
Often species-rich hay meadows of the montane and subalpine levels of higher mountains of the western Palaearctic deciduous forest zone.

Species-rich mesophile hay meadows of the montane and subalpine levels (mostly above 600 metres) of the Western Alpides and the greater Hercynian ranges, usually dominated by [Trisetum flavescens] and with [Heracleum sphondylium], [Viola cornuta], [Astrantia major], [Carum carvi], [Crepis mollis], [Crepis pyrenaica], [Polygonum bistorta], [Silene dioica], [Silene vulgaris], [Campanula glomerata], [Salvia pratensis], [Centaurea nemoralis], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Crocus albiflorus], [Geranium phaeum], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Narcissus poeticus], [Malva moschata], [Valeriana repens], [Trollius europaeus], [Pimpinella major], [Muscari botryoides], [Lilium bulbiferum], [Thlaspi caerulescens], [Viola tricolor] ssp. [subalpina], [Phyteuma halleri], [Phyteuma orbiculare], [Primula elatior], [Chaerophyllum hirsutum] and many others.
Meadows of the montane and subalpine levels of the Caucasus and the Pontic mountains of northern Anatolia.

Summer pastures of the Iberian peninsula, submitted to poor drainage, brief flooding and rapid dessication with the first heat, constituted by perennial and annual grasses, most commonly by [Agrostis castellana], [Agrostis pourretii] ([Agrostis salmantica]), [Gaudinia fragilis], [Festuca ampla], [Periballia involucrata], [Vulpia ciliata], [Vulpia myuros], [Vulpia bromoides], [Holcus setiglumis], [Molineriella minuta], [Anthoxanthum aristatum], [Anthoxanthum ovatum] and often with [Juncus capitatus] and clovers such as [Trifolium campestre].
Perennial [Agrostis castellana]-dominated grasslands of the Iberian peninsula.
Annual [Agrostis pourretii]-dominated grasslands of the Iberian peninsula.

Forb and grass communities of oligo-mesotrophic sandy soils of southwestern Iberia, with subsurface seasonal water saturation, in particular, of the edges of marshes and large lagoons, dominated by the endemic [Armeria gaditana], with [Gaudinia fragilis], [Centaurea exarata] and [Asphodelus aestivus].
Secondary grasslands of the highest levels of the Atlantic islands.
Lowland and montane mesophile pastures and hay meadows of the steppe zone of central Eurasia.
Lowland and montane mesophile pastures and hay meadows of the boreal, nemoral and warm-temperate humid zones of the eastern Palaearctic.

Communities of grasses and shrubs developed over permafrost. They are limited to Greenland, Spitzbergen and northern Russia. Communities sometimes composed of the same species in oroboreal areas remote from the main permafrost region, such as those of continental Fennoscandia and Iceland are listed under units 36 and 31.4.

Tundras of the southernmost tundra belt of Eurasia, characterized by an abundance of medium small and small shrubs, including 1-2 m tall [Alnus fruticosa], 0.5-0.8 m tall [Salix lanata], [Betula nana], [Betula exilis], [Salix reptans], [Salix pulchra], and of dwarf shrubs, in particular, [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Ledum decumbens], [Rubus chamaemorus], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Empetrum nigrum], [Arctostaphylos alpina]. They extend south to the wooded tundra belt.

Southern tundras of Europe, comprising Kola tundras in the west, the southern part of the Eastern European tundras from the Kanin peninsula to the Ural piedmont, and the southern part of the Uralo-Va¿katchan tundras.

Southern tundras of western Siberia, constituting the southern part of the Yamalo-west Taimyrian tundras extending from the lower Obi and the base of the Yamal peninsula to the central Taimyr peninsula.

Southern tundras of central eastern Siberia, from the Khatanga to the Kolyma, in which [Betula nana] is replaced by [Betula exilis], and the more maritime tundras of the Chukchotski peninsula, of Alaskan affinities, with the tussock-forming [Carex lugens], the shrub [Betula kajanderi], [Betula glandulosa], and relict arctic glacial steppes with [Carex duriuscula], [Helictotrichon krylovii].

Tundras of the middle tundra belt of Eurasia, characterized by a thick cover of mosses, formed notably by [Hypnum splendens], [Aulacomnium turgidum], [Tomenthypnum nitens], [Ptilium ciliare], with dwarf shrubs, particularly [Dryas punctata], [Cassiope tetragona], [Salix reptans], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], sedges, among which the often dominant [Carex ensifolia]. Drier stands alternate in mosa¿c fashion with wetter areas dominated by sedges, in particular, [Carex stans], [Eriophorum angustifolium], [Eriophorum scheuchzeri], and grasses, notably [Arctophila fulva], [Dupontia fischeri].

Moss and lichen tundras of the northern Kanin peninsula, Kolguiev island, the northeastern European Petchora tundras, the Kara sea tundras, the southern Yamal peninsula, the southern Gyda peninsula, the southern Ta¿myr peninsula,  in the Ienissei and Piasana basins.
Moss and lichen tundras of the middle Ta¿myr peninsula, on the southern flanks of the Byrranga Range, and in the Ta¿myr basin.
Moss and lichen tundras of the near-coastal hinterland of the Khatanga-Anabar-Olenek basins and of the Lena-Iana-Indighirka-Kolyma basins.
Moss and lichen tundras of eastern Anadyrland and the Tchouktchi peninsula south to the shores of the Gulf of Anadyr.
Moss and lichen tundras of the southeastern Ta¿myr peninsula, in the Khatanga basin and of the middle Anabar basin, south of the Laptev Sea and north of the Siberian plateau.

Tundras of the northern tundra belt of Eurasia, forming the transition to the polar deserts, with sparser, very open, vegetation formed in particular by [Salix polaris], [Alopecurus alpinus], [Luzula nivalis], [Luzula confusa], [Cerastium bialynickii], [Saxifraga hirculus], [Saxifraga platysepala], [Saxifraga caespitosa], [Saxifraga serpyllifolia], [Novosieversia glacialis], moss carpets along brooks, mosses and lichens on stony ground, small forbs, [Cerastium regelii], [Stellaria edwardsii], [Papaver spp.], on pebbly lake shores and [Puccinellia phryganodes] mats around salty lagoons.
Tundras of the northern belt of tundras of the Sea of Laptev, mainly located between the Khatanga and the Olenek and in the Lena delta.
Tundras of the uplands of the Ta¿myr peninsula, located in the lower and middle slopes of the Byrranga Range.

Tundras of the northern belt of tundras of Eurasia, developed south of the tundras of unit 39.34 on the Yamal peninsula, the Gyda peninsula and the northwest Ta¿myr peninsula east to the mouth of the Ta¿myr, as well as in the coastal lowlands of the Laptev Sea, in the Bouorkha¿a Bay and the Iana Bay, of the Laptev straits and of the East Siberian Sea east to the Bay of Tchaoun.

Tundras of the extreme northern belt of tundras of western Eurasia, in southern Nova¿a Zemlia, the northern Yamal peninsula, the northern Gyda peninsula and the northwest Ta¿myr peninsula east to the mouth of the Ta¿myr.
Tundras of Liakhov Island, Wrangel Island and the northern Anadyr coast in eastern Siberia.

Natural or seminatural communities dominated physiognomically by trees. Included are all natural, near-natural or managed forests and woods, dense or clear, on dry substrates, on permanently or temporarily waterlogged soils or on ground  permanently or temporarily inundated by marine or nonmarine waters. By extension, are also included small tree or shrub communities of riverine or marshland sites, as well as plantations of trees within or near their natural area of occurrence, accompanied by seminatural undergrowth.

Edaphically determined forests of the evergreen and deciduous tropical forest zones, developed on hydromorphic, nonsaline soils and often characterized by a strong tendancy to monophytism. They include peat swamp tropical forests, fresh water swamp tropical forests, fresh water periodic swamp forests, tropical riverine forests. They are limited within the Palaearctic, as here defined, to the tropical Far East, where they have, however, been almost entirely cleared for cultivation.

Forests and woodlands of dry tropical regions, of simpler structure and considerably lower species richness than rain and monsoon forests, often characterized by a relatively low, open canopy. Included are varied formations known as closed dry forests, open dry forests, savanna woodland, wooded savanna, thorn forest, thorn woodland, tropical scrub, bushland. They are limited, within the Palaearctic, as here defined, to the Saharo-Mediterranean, Saharo-Sindian, Sahelian and Sino-Tropical zones.

[Argania spinosa] thorn forests, thorn woodland, scrub forests and bushlands of the arid and semiarid levels of southwest Morocco, with [Acacia gummifera], [Ziziphus lotus], [Olea europaea], [Pistacia lentiscus], [Pistacia atlantica], and often abundant succulent [Euphorbia beaumierana] or [Euphorbia echinus].

Woods and stands, often riparian, formed by palm trees of the Mediterraneo-Saharan, Saharo-Sindian and Sahelian zones, including [Phoenix dactylifera], [Phoenix atlantica], [Nannorrhops ritchiana], [Hyphaene thebaica].
Indigenous or spontaneous stands and long-established oasis plantations of [Phoenix dactylifera] of the Saharo-Sindian and Saharo-Mediterranean regions.

Indigenous or spontaneous stands of [Phoenix dactylifera] installed on rocky slopes, in canyons, on coastal dunes and in saline or brackish wadis and flats, of the Saharo-Sindian and Saharo-Mediterranean regions. The area of indigenousness is unknown but has been suggested to be restricted to Arabia, or to encompass a much larger area, including, in particular, North Africas coastal dunes.

Long-established plantations of [Phoenix dactylifera] of the Saharo-Sindian and Saharo-Mediterranean regions, entirely replacing the natural vegetation of desert and subdesert oases, and providing an important substitution habitat for animal communities.
Formations of the endemic [Phoenix atlantica] of the Cape Verde archipelago.
[Hyphaene thebaica] woods and stands of wadis, mountain gorges, salt marshes, sand dunes and sometimes oases of the southern Sahara, the Sinai and the Arabian peninsula.
[Nannorrhops ritchiana] formations of southern Iran and eastern Afghanistan, characteristic of sheltered mountain valleys with a reasonably high water table.
Relict stand of the endangered [Medemia argun] of the Dungul Oasis of southern Egypt, involving only a few individuals.

Thorn forests, thorn woodlands and savanna woodlands of the Saharo-Sindian region, locally reaching the Mediterraneo-Saharan region, and of the Sahelian region of Mauritania, dominated by acacias ([Acacia], [Prosopis]), or species of genera [Ziziphus], [Balanites], [Maerua], [Maytenus], [Salvadora].
Acacia-dominated formations of the northern confines of the Sahara, in the Saharo-Mediterranean transition zone.

[Acacia raddiana]-dominated savanna woodland of the northern fringes of the Sahara, now limited to a very few relict formations in the Oued Dra basin of Morocco and adjacent Algerian regions and in the Djebel Bou-Hedma of central Tunisia, where it constitutes an essential potential habitat and restoration center for the endangered antelope [Oryx dammah], with [Ziziphus lotus], [Retama retam], [Periploca laevigata], [Aristida plumosa], [Aristida obtusa], [Digitaria nodosa], [Cenchrus ciliaris].

Endemic [Acacia gummifera] woodland and scrub land of the plateaux of western Morocco, now reduced to remnant stands, in particular, at Haouz-Tadla. The acacias are accompanied by [Ephedra altissima], [Asparagus stipularis], [Lavandula multiflora], [Ballota hispanica], [Bryonia dioica], [Peganum harmala] and many therophytes.

Open woodland or savanna woodland, steppe woodland or desert woodland of the  Sahara, dominated by [Acacia raddiana], [Acacia ehrenbergiana], [Acacia seyal], [Ziziphus mauritiana], [Balanites aegyptiaca], [Maerua crassifolia], [Salvadora persica], [Calotropis procera], [Capparis decidua], with [Cassia italica], [Ziziphus lotus], [Caylusea hexagyna], [Lavandula stricta], [Seetzenia africana], [Panicum turgidum], characteristic of the rocky beds of wadis and the alluvial gravels of outwash fans.
[Acacia]-dominated thorn woodlands of the Sahelian zone of Mauritania.

Open formations of [Acacia raddiana], [Acacia senegal], [Acacia ehrenbergiana], [Maerua crassifolia], [Balanites aegyptiaca], [Ziziphus mauritiana], [Combretum aculeatum], accompanied by steppic tropical grassland or rainy season temporary grasslands with therophytes, of the Sahelian region of Mauritania.
[Acacia nilotica]-dominated communities, often closed, of the Senegal valley of Mauritania, developed in particular on dunes.

Open woodland or savanna woodland, steppe woodland, savanoid desert or desert woodland of the Arabian Peninsula and the Sinai, dominated by [Acacia raddiana], [Acacia tortilis], [Acacia gerrardii], [Acacia hamulosa], [Balanites aegyptiaca] or [Ziziphus spina-christi], with [Maerua crassifolia], [Salvadora persica], [Calotropis procera], [Cordia gharaf], [Capparis decidua], [Capparis cartilaginea], [Hammada salicornica], [Anabasis articulata], [Gymnocarpos decander], [Cassia italica], [Panicum turgidum], mostly confined to wadis and depressions.

Open woodland or savanna woodland of the tropical southwestern and southeastern plains and hills of the Arabian Peninsula and of extreme southeastern Egypt, dominated by [Acacia tortilis], [Acacia ehrenbergiana], [Acacia asak], [Acacia mellifera], [Acacia senegal], [Acacia oerfota], [Acacia seyal], [Acacia hamulosa], [Acacia laeta], [Acacia etbaica], [Balanites aegyptiaca], [Maerua crassifolia], [Aristida plumosa], [Lasiurus hirsutus], [Panicum turgidum].

Open woodland, savanna woodland or desert woodland of the subtropical desert zone of southern Iran, with [Acacia nilotica] ssp. [indica] ([Acacia flava]), [Acacia oerfota] ([Acacia aucheri]), [Prosopis farcta], [Prosopis spicigera], [Ziziphus spina-christi], [Ziziphus nummularia], [Calotropis procera], [Periploca aphylla], [Dodonaea viscosa], [Amygdalus arabica], [Capparis spinosa], [Hammada salicornica].
[Ziziphus nummularia] thorn woodland of the Jalalabad basin of eastern Afghanistan, northwesternmost extension of pre-Sindian middle Indus communities.

Woods, thickets or wooded pastures of the Cape Verde Islands dominated by naturally or probably naturally occurring African trees characteristic of dry woodland communities, in particular, [Acacia albida], [Ficus capensis], [Ficus sycamorus], [Tamarindus indica], [Calotropis procera].

[Olea laperrinei] formations of wadis of the higher altitudes, above 1800 metres, of the Ahaggar, the Tafedest, the Mouydir, the Tassili NAjjer, with an admixture of Mediterranean, Saharan, Sahelian and Afro-montane species, including [Pistacia atlantica], [Rhus tripartita], [Artemisia campestris] ssp. [glutinosa], [Stipa parviflora], [Stipa capensis], [Oryzopsis coerulescens].

Mesophilous ravine and valley gallery forest of the southeast of the Arabian peninsula, with [Ficus sycomorus], [Ficus glumosa], [Ficus lutea], [Ficus populifolia], [Ficus salicifolia], [Rhus glaucescens], [Diospyros mespilliformis], [Tamarindus indica], [Trichylia emetica], [Olea chrysophylla] and [Grewia spp.], [Combretum trichanthum], [Dracena spp.], [Phoenix reclinata] and many lianas.

Evergreen bushland and thickets, semievergreen bushland and open woodland of Socotra, island outpost of East African evergreen and semievergreen bushlands and thickets, distributed on drier slopes of mountains and hills from central Tanzania to Eritrea and Ethiopia, with a maximum development in Ethiopian highlands.

Open [Dracaena cinnabari]-dominated woodland of limestone slopes of the Hagghier Mountains and of the Hamadera Hills of Socotra, with [Boswellia ameero], [Boswellia elongata], [Boswellia socotrana], [Aloe perryi], [Adenium socotranum], [Mitolepis intricata].

Formations of [Cephalocroton socotranus], [Carissa edulis], [Buxus hildebrandtii], [Dodonaea viscosa], [Ficus socotrana], [Indigofera sokotrana], [Ruellia insignis], [Boswellia ameero], [Euphorbia socotrana], of granite slopes of the Hagghier range of Socotra.

Open, succulent, Socotran woodland dominated by [Dendrosicyos socotrana], the only arborescent Cucurbitaceae, belonging to a monospecific genus endemic to the island, accompanied by [Euphorbia arbuscula], [Euphorbia spiralis], [Adenium socotranum], [Dorstenia gigas], [Kleinia scottii], [Kalanchoe robusta], [Aloe perryi], [Cissus subaphylla], developed on sandstone plateaux and on limestone cliffs and valley slopes.

Dry open evergreen sclerophyllous woodland developed on sub-Himalayan and sub-Hindukushian hills and plateaux of the Indus watershed of eastern Afghanistan, of Indo-Himalayan affinities, with [Olea ferruginea] ([Olea cuspidata]), [Monotheca buxifolia] ([Reptonia buxifolia]), [Quercus ballota], [Pistacia integerrima], [Ficus palmata], [Cotinus coggygria], [Punica granatum].
Closed dry forests, open dry forests, savanna woodland, thorn forests of the tropical regions of mainland China, of Hainan, Taiwan and of tropical Pacific islands.

Tropical intertidal mud forests and thickets formed by mangroves and their associates. Worldwide, mangrove forests can be divided into two large ensembles, Atlantic-type mangals, species-poor formations characteristic of the west coast of Africa as well as of the tropical Pacific and Atlantic coasts of the Americas, and Oriental-type mangals, species-rich formations of the Indian Ocean, of the western and central Pacific and of their associated tropical seas. In the Palaearctic region, as here defined, Oriental mangals occur along the coasts of the Pacific, north to southern Japan, of the Arabian Sea, of the Red Sea, Atlantic mangals along the coasts of west Africa.

Species-poor [Rhizophora racemosa], [Rhizophora mangle], [Rhizophora harrisonii], [Avicennia nitida], [Avicennia schauerana] formations of the west coast of Africa and of the tropical Pacific and Atlantic coasts of the Americas, with [Laguncularia racemosa], [Conocarpus erectus], [Drepanocarpus lunulatus], [Acrostichum aureum], [Hibiscus tiliaceus]. The complex of formations is represented in the Palaearctic zone, as here defined, by extremely localized mangrove scrubs of the coast of Mauritania.

Species-rich [Rhizophora mucronata], [Rhizophora apiculata], [Rhizophora stylosa], [Rhizophora lamarckii], [Rhizophora mangle], [Avicennia marina], [Avicennia spp.], [Bruguiera spp.], [Ceriops spp.], [Kandelia spp.], [Sonneratia spp.], [Lumnitzera spp.], [Aegiceras spp.], [Xylocarpus spp.], [Acanthus spp.], [Nypa spp.] formations of the Indian Ocean, of the western and central Pacific and of their associated tropical seas, represented within the Palaearctic zone, as here defined, by mangrove communities of the Red Sea, of the Arabian Sea and of the western Pacific north to Hainan, Kwangtung, Kwangsi, Fukien, Taiwan and southern Japan.
Forests and woodland of native deciduous trees, other than floodplain or mire woods, of the nemoral, boreal, Irano-Turanian, warm-temperate humid and Mediterranean zones
Woods of the western Palaearctic region dominated by [Carpinus betulus], alone or with a small admixture of other species.

Woods of Western Europe and northern and central Central Europe, north to southern Denmark, Bornholm and southeastern Sweden, within the range of the [Fagion medio-europaeum] and the [Carpinion betuli], dominated by [Carpinus betulus], alone or with a small admixture of other species, uncommon, generally low, habitually secondary. Scandinavian stands, characteristic of diabases, basalts and greenstones, often dominated by tall [Carpinus betula], have a field layer dominated by abundant [Anemone nemorosa], [Stellaria nemorum] and [Hedera helix].

Forests of southeastern Central Europe and of Eastern Europe, within the range of the [Carpinion illyricum], of the [Fagion moesiacum] and of the [Fagion dacicum], as well as of areas east of the range of [Fagus sylvatica], dominated by [Carpinus betulus], alone or with a small admixture of other species, more widespread and developed than those of unit 41.A1, sometimes primary.

Forests of southeastern Central Europe, within the range of the [Carpinion illyricum], dominated by [Carpinus betulus], alone or with a small admixture of other species, in particular [Carpinus betulus]-dominated communities of the Carinthian [Helleboro nigri-Carpinetum].

Neutrophile or weakly acidophile forests of southeastern Central Europe, within the range of the [Fagion moesiacum], the [Fagion dacicum] and, locally, of the [Quercion frainetto], dominated by [Carpinus betulus], alone or with a small admixture of other species, with [Carpinion] species in the herb layer

Forests of Eastern Europe, east of the range of [Fagus sylvatica], dominated by [Carpinus betulus], alone or with a small admixture of other species, in particular, [Carpinus betulus] forests of the Podolian plateaux.
Woods and thickets of the western Palaearctic region dominated by [Betula pendula], [Betula pubescens], their allies, or other arborescent [Betula spp.], on nonmarshy terrain.
Birch forests of the northern Black Sea basin, Anatolia, the Caucasus and neighbouring regions.

[Betula pendula] woods of the Ponto-Caspian basin, the Caucasus, Anatolia, western Iran and Mesopotamia, widespread south of the Ponto-Caspian depessions, represented by rare outposts north of the basin, in particular in Crimea.
[Betula litwinowii] and [Betula litwinowii-Betula pendula] woods of eastern Anatolia, the Caucasus and the Ponto-Caspian basin.
Woods of [Betula litwinowii], usually with [Betula pendula], of the regions of Tunceli, Erzurum and Kars, at between 1500 and 2500 metres.
[Betula litwinowii]-dominated woods of the Bolshoy and Malyy Kavkaz ranges.
[Betula pubescens] woods of the steppe regions of the northern Ponto-Caspian basin, characteristic in particular of the sand terrasses of the lower Dnjepr.
Birch woods of the Caucasus dominated by the scarce [Betula raddeana].

Woods and thickets of [Betula medwediewii], pure or mixed with [Quercus pontica], [Sorbus subfusca], [Rhododendron caucasicum], [Laurocerasus officinalis], [Ilex aquifolium], [Vaccinium arctostaphylos], characteristic of the 800 to 2300 m level of Transcaucasia, with isolated outposts in the eastern Black Sea region of Turkey.
Birch woods of the Caucasus system dominated by [Betula megrelica], local and limited to the subalpine level.
[Betula turkestanica], [Betula tadzhikistanica], [Betula chitralica] formations of the Tien Shan and Pamir Alai systems, and of the northeastern Afghan mountains.
[Betula utilis] ([Betula jacquemontii]) woods and thickets constituting or participating in the timberline formations (2700-3350 m) of the Nuristan Himalayas.

[Betula spp.]-dominated formations, most characteristic of the timberline, of the borea-nemoral, nemoral and warm temperate zones of Eastern Asia. Birch woods of the larch, larch-pine and larch-pine-spruce zones of the southern boreal mountains of eastern Asia.

Nombre oficial: Atlantic lowland and collinar birch woods
Definición oficial: Pioneer and subclimax [Betula pendula] or [Betula pubescens] formations of the North Sea-Baltic plains, the lower Hercynian slopes, the periphery of the Paris Basin, southwestern France, northwestern Iberia, Insubria and Illyria, within the range of Atlantic and sub-Atlantic acidophilous oak woods.

Formations usually formed by [Betula pubescens], with [Molinia caerulea] and sometimes [Deschampsia flexuosa], developed on podzolized or hydromorphic soils, as substitution facies of oak and birch woods, or colonization stages, in particular, of [Molinion] grasslands or humid heaths.
Widespread [Betula pendula]-dominated formations characteristic of the North Sea-Baltic plain.
Southern [Betula pendula] formations common, in particular, in the Sologne and neighbouring areas.

Formations usually formed by [Betula pendula], or, in the British Isles, [Betula pubescens], with [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Agrostis capillaris] ([Agrostis tenuis]), [Festuca ovina], [Vaccinium myrtillus], developed notably on sands, gravels, moraines and decalcified alluvions of nemoral northern and middle European plains and hills, as substitution facies of acidophilous oak woods ([Fago-Quercetum], [Blechno-Quercetum petraeae], [Rusco-Quercetum], [Luzulo-Quercetum]), occasionally of oak-hornbeam woods (particularly mixed Atlantic bluebell oak forests, [Endymio-Carpinetum]), or colonization stages of dry heaths and decalcified dunes.

Medio-European acidophilous birch woods of the collinar and lower montane levels of northwestern Iberia, formed by [Betula pendula] or [Betula celtiberica] as substitution stages of acidophilous oak woods.

Birch woods of the collinar and lower montane levels of northern Italy, dispersed in the Alpine foothills where they constitute substitution stages of the Insubrian acidophilous oak woods ([Castaneo-Quercetum] [p.]), on the fluvioglacial terraces of the Po system, as facies of the acidophilous pine-birch-oak woods, and in the Euganean hills.
Subclimax birch woods occupying soils intoxicated by heavy metals, with an herb layer that may include metallophytes and habitually calciphile species.
Birch woods formed by [Betula pubescens], [Betula pendula] and [Populus canescens] with [Viola hirta], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Polygonatum odoratum], in calcareous North Sea and Baltic dunes.

[Betula pendula]-dominated woods of the basins of the Drava and Sava in Slovenia, Croatia, northern Bosnia-Herzegovina and of neighbouring regions, in part birch facies of the acidophilous [Betula pendula]-[Quercus petraea] forests of unit 41.5734, in part pioneer formations in forest clearings and other recolonization areas.

Birch woods, often extensive and pure, formed by [Betula pubescens] ([Betula odorata], [Betula carpatica]) or [Betula pendula], beyond and above the present range of oak woods in Scotland and northern England.

Birch stands of the montane and subalpine levels of the Alps, the Carpathians, the Apennines, the Pyrenees, the Jura, the Hercynian ranges and the mountains of the Balkan peninsula, mostly subclimax formations of stations with anomalous edaphic and microclimatic conditions.
Tree-limit birch stands, of local distribution in the Alps.

Birch stands, mostly of [Betula pubescens] ([Betula carpatica], [Betula tortuosa]), occupying, in the Alps, the Jura and the Hercynian ranges, cold stations on cliff-base rocky screes and boulder-falls through which cold air flows.
Birch-dominated formations of the Pyrenees, locally frequent in all vegetation levels.
Isolated birch stations of the Apennines, in the Abruzzi, bosco di Manziana (Latium), monti Alburni, monti Picentini.
[Betula pendula] stands of the montane and subalpine levels of mountains of the Balkan Peninsula, including the Balkan Range, the Rhodopides, the Dinarides and the northwestern Hellenides.
[Betula pendula] stands of the montane and subalpine levels of the Balkan Range and the Rhodopides.

[Betula pendula] stands of the Rhodopide mountains, substitution facies of [Fagus sylvestris], [Abies alba], [Picea abies] and [Pinus sylvestris] forests of the upper beech-fir levels of the Rhodopes, Rila, Pirin and Vitosha of Bulgaria, with isolated outposts in the southern Rhodopes of northern Greece.

[Betula pendula] woods of the montane and subalpine levels of the Balkan Range, substitution and recolonisation facies of [Fagus sylvestris], [Abies alba], [Picea abies] and [Pinus sylvestris] forests.
[Betula pendula] stands of the montane and subalpine levels of mountains of the western Balkan Peninsula.
[Betula pendula] woods of montane level of the eastern Carpathian system forming as pioneer stands in felled areas of spruce, beech and mixed beech-fir and beech-fir-spruce forests.

[Betula pendula]-dominated woods of the upper montane level of the Southern Carpathians and the Eastern Carpathians, on superficial brown acid soils of steep slopes in the zone of mixed spruce forests, rich in [Sorbus aucuparia] and accompanied by [Picea abies], [Oxalis acetosella], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Pulmonaria rubra], [Salix silesiaca], [Calamagrostis arundinacea] and some [Fagetalia] species.

[Betula pendula]-dominated woods situated on sandy brown weathered soils of steep slopes and hilltops of the lower montane level of the Apuseni mountains, in particular of the Plopis and Gilau mountains, with [Populus tremula] and representatives of the [Epilobion angustifolii], and of the [Fagetalia].

Woods dominated by [Betula pendula] accompanied by [Quercus robur] with psammophyllous species in the herb layer, characteristic of the inland dunes of the eastern rim of the eastern intra-Carpathian basin of Romania, in the region of St. Gheorghe, at Reci in the Kovasna district.

[Betula pendula] formations of the upper montane level of Corsica, forming extensive subclimax belts on rocky, rapidly eroding soils at the upper forest limit, as well as transition communities in the evolution of laricio pine or beech forests.
Formations of the upper montane and supra-Mediterranean levels of Iberia dominated by the endemic [Betula celtiberica].
