Climax tree-limit [Betula celtiberica] woods of the Cantabrian mountains.
Upper montane and supra-Mediterranean climax formations of the western Cordillera Central (Serra da Estrela) and the Orensano-Sanabrian mountains, limited to tree-limit situations and humid ravines.

Humid supra-Mediterranean climax formations of the eastern Cordillera Central (Guadarrama) and of the Northern Iberian Range (Sorian mountains), restricted to relict stations on rainy ubacs and in humid ravines.

Endemic [Betula aetnensis] formations of Mount Etna lavas, limited to the 1200-2000 metre level, mostly within the 1600-1750 metre range, at northern to eastern exposures. The accompanying cort¿ge includes [Adenocarpus complicatus], [Genista aetnensis], [Juniperus hemisphaerica], [Festuca circummediterranea].

Timberline birch woods and thickets dominating the subalpine belt of the mountains of the boreal taiga zone or the transition zone between taiga and tundra or polar deserts in the Atlantic or Pacific influenced extreme western and extreme eastern regions of the northern Palaearctic, formed by [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] ([Betula pubescens] ssp. [tortuosa], [Betula kusmisscheffii]) or [Betula ermani].

Boreal and subarctic [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods and thickets of Iceland, extreme southwestern Greenland and oceanic western Norway, distributed in lowlands, in valleys and at the foot of mountain slopes, in relatively humid, sheltered situations. In Iceland and Greenland they constitute the only form of boreal woodland. Their stature varies with microclimates, dense low scrubs prevailing along the coasts, in wind-exposed localities and in the most oceanic areas, taller brushes and woods forming further inland and in more continental districts.

Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of Iceland and western Norway with an ericoid-dominated undergrowth, formed mainly by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], dominant in Iceland, and [Vaccinium uliginosum], dominant in Norway, accompanied by [Calluna vulgaris], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Betula nana], [Deschampsia flexuosa], mosses and, in Iceland, [Juncus trifidus], [Kobresia myosuroides].

Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of Iceland, with a mostly ericoid undergrowth, dominated by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], accompanied by [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Calluna vulgaris], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Betula nana], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Juncus trifidus], [Kobresia myosuroides], mosses and lichens.

Nombre oficial: West Norwegian bog bilberry birch woods
Definición oficial: Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of western Norway, with a mostly ericoid undergrowth dominated by [Vaccinium uliginosum], accompanied by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Calluna vulgaris], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Betula nana], [Deschampsia flexuosa] and mosses.

Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of Iceland and of the oceanic southern boreal and oceanic middle boreal zones of Norway, developed on moist moraine podsols, with a field layer dominated by ferns.

Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of Iceland, developed on moist moraine podsols, dominated by [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii], with a fern field layer formed predominantly by [Gymnocarpium dryopteris], sometimes accompanied by [Dryopteris assimilis] or [Thelypteris phegopteris].

Nombre oficial: West Norwegian small fern birch woods
Definición oficial: Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of the oceanic southern boreal and oceanic middle boreal zones of Norway, developed on moist moraine podsols, with a fern field layer formed predominantly by [Gymnocarpium dryopteris] accompanied by [Dryopteris assimilis], [Thelypteris phegopteris], [Blechnum spicant] or [Dryopteris expansa] and with [Oxalis acetosella], [Lophocolea bidentata], [Rhytidiadelphus loreus], [Rhytidiadelphus triquetrus].

Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of the lowlands of Iceland, occupying thick, relatively rich soils, with a heath-grassland undergrowth dominated by [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Agrostis capillaris], [Deschampsia flexuosa], accompanied by [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Salix callicarpaea] ([Salix arctica]), [Salix lanata], [Salix phylicifolia], [Campanula rotundifolia], [Galium verum], [Hierochloe odorata], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Festuca rubra] [s.l.], [Juncus trifida], [Kobresia myosuroides], [Lycopodium annotinum], [Equisetum pratense].

Herb-rich woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] occupying relatively rich mull sandy moraine soils in climatically favourable regions of western Norway and Iceland, with affinities to the oro-Scandinavian calcicline mountain birch woods of unit 41.B725.

Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of the lowlands of Iceland, characterized by a luxuriant shrub and herb layer rich in [Geranium sylvaticum] and [Rubus saxatile]. They mostly occupy hollows where snow lingers in spring, and are covered with snow in winter. Their species cort¿ge may include [Salix spp.], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Populus tremula], [Juniperus communis], [Alchemilla vulgaris], [Campanula rotundifolia], [Filipendula ulmaria], [Fragraria vesca], [Galium verum], [Geum rivale], [Hieracium spp.], [Melampyrum sylvaticum], [Prunella vulgaris], [Trientalis europaea], [Elymus caninus] ([Roegneria canina]), [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Festuca rubra] [s.l.], [Hierochloe odorata], [Poa nemoralis], [Poa pratense], [Coeloglossum viride], [Dactylorhiza islandica], [Carex bigelowii], [Carex vaginata], [Luzula multiflora], [Equisetum arvense], [Equisetum pratense], [Athyrium filix-femina], [Gymnocarpium dryopteris] and mosses. These woods constitute, in their northern area of occurrence, the northernmost, dwarfed (0.5-1 m), stands of birch in Iceland.

Woods and thickets of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] of rich mull soils in climatically favourable stations of oceanic boreal Norway with a forb-dominated herb layer that includes, among others, [Geranium sylvaticum], [Blechnum spicant], [Cornus suecica], [Thelypteris limbosperma], and a canopy and shrub layer that comprise [Alnus incana], [Populus tremula], [Corylus avellana], [Salix spp.], [Vaccinium spp.], [Juniperus communis].

[Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods and thickets of the lowlands of Iceland, with a grass-dominated field layer formed by [Hierochloe odorata], [Agrostis capillaris] ([Agrostis tenuis]), [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Festuca richardsonii], [Deschampsia flexuosa] and accompanied by [Poa pratensis], [Poa nemoralis], [Luzula multiflora], [Carex vaginata], [Equisetum pratense].
[Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods and thickets of moist soils of the lowlands of Iceland, with a willow-dominated undergrowth formed mainly by [Salix phylicifolia] and [Salix lanata].
Boreal and subarctic [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods and thickets of extreme southwestern Greenland.
[Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods and thickets of the boreo-alpine and arcto-alpine mountains of Fennoscandia, distributed mostly in the subalpine, subfj¿ll belt, which they dominate.

Low (2-3 m) [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods of the subalpine belt of northern, western and inner mountains of Fennoscandia with a lichen-rich ericoid-dominated undergrowth formed by [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Phyllodoce caerulea], accompanied by  junipers ([Juniperus nana]), dwarf birch ([Betula nana]), willows ([Salix spp.]).

Medium-tall (4-7 m) [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods of sandy moraine podsols of the subalpine belt of the mountains of Fennoscandia, with a moss-rich grass and heath undergrowth formed by [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Empetrum hermaphroditum] and [Deschampsia flexuosa], accompanied by [Dicranum fuscescens], [Dicranum scoparium], [Hylocomium splendens], [Pleurozium schreberi]

Low to medium tall (to 6 m) [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods of the mountains of Norway and northern Finland, extending from the subalpine belt down, in western Norway, to the fjords, developing in somewhat warmer and wetter areas and occupying thick humus layers on weak podsols of sandy more nutrient-rich moraines than those of units 41.B721 and 41.B722, with an undergrowth dominated by [Cornus suecica], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Deschampsia flexuosa], accompanied by taller shrubs, primarily of [Juniperus communis] and [Salix spp.]
[Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods of the subalpine belt of Fennoscandian mountains, often with some spruce or pine, and with an understorey dominated by [Gymnocarpium dryopteris]

Tall (10-11 m) woods of [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii], accompanied by [Salix spp.], [Sorbus spp.], of the subalpine belt of mountains of Fennoscandia, occupying relatively rich mull soils of sand moraines in climatically favourable regions, with a low herb-rich undergrowth dominated by [Geranium sylvaticum] and [Rubus saxatilis]. There is an often well developed understorey of taller shrubs, in particular, [Juniperus communis] and [Salix spp.] and a poorly developed moss and lichen layer. The species cort¿ge comprises [Campanula rotundifolia], [Alchemilla vulgaris], [Cornus suecica], [Filipendula ulmaria], [Fragraria vesca], [Galium boreale], [Galium verum], [Geum rivale], [Hieracium spp.], [Melampyrum sylvaticum], [Prunella vulgaris], [Poa nemoralis], [Poa pratensis], [Hierochloe odorata], [Agrostis capillaris], [Anthoxanthum odoratum], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Festuca rubra] [s.l.], [Melica nutans], [Trientalis europaea], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Elymus caninus] ([Roegneria canina]), [Carex bigelowii], [Carex vaginata], [Coeloglossum viride], [Dactylorhiza maculata], [Luzula multiflora], [Gymnocarpium dryopteris], [Athyrium filix-femina], [Equisetum arvense], [Equisetum palustre], [Hylocomium splendens].

Tall (up to 12 m) woods of the subalpine belt of Fennoscandian mountains dominated by [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii], with [Salix spp.], [Sorbus aucuparia], [Prunus padus] and an undergrowth dominated by tall herbs, comprising, together with abundant [Geranium sylvaticum], [Trollius europaeus], [Rubus saxatilis], [Aconitum septentrionale] ([Aconitum licoctonum]), [Cirsium helenioides], [Cicerbita alpina], [Epilobium angustifolium], [Ranunculus platanifolius]. The  well-developed taller shrub understorey is dominated by [Juniperus communis], accompanied by [Salix spp.]

Tall [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] woods of the subalpine belt of Fennoscandian mountains, occasionally accompanied by [Alnus incana], [Prunus padus], [Salix spp.], with a fern-rich field layer dominated by [Athyrium filix-femina], [Matteuccia struthiopteris], [Dryopteris expansa], accompanied by [Athyrium distentifolium], [Phegopteris connectilis], [Thelypteris limbosperma] and tall herbs
[Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] ([Betula pubescens] ssp. [tortuosa], [Betula kusmisscheffii]) woods and thickets of the mountains and tundra timberline of the Kola peninsula.

Nombre oficial: Uralian oroboreal birch woods and thickets
Definición oficial: Timberline birch woods and thickets of the Urals formed by krumholz [Betula pubescens] [s.l.] ([Betula tortuosa] [s.l.]).
[Betula ermani] or [Betula middendorffii] woods and thickets forming at the timberline of the mountains of eastern Siberia, Kamchatka, Sakhaline and Hokkaido.
[Betula ermani] woods and thickets forming at the timberline of the mountains of Kamchatka, Sakhaline and Hokkaido.

[Betula middendorffii] woods and thickets forming at the timberline of the mountains of eastern Siberia, in particular the Verkoiansk Range, the Anadyr Range, the mountains of the Ba¿kal area and of Transba¿kalia, the Greater Khingan Range.
Birch woods of the taiga belt, of the wooded tundra belt, and of the taiga-nemoral forest transition zone of Eurasia, formed by [Betula pendula], [Betula pubescens] [s.l.] or [Betula platyphylla].

Birch woods of the taiga and wooded tundra belts and of the transition zones between taiga and nemoral forests of Fennoscandia, the northern Sarmatic region and western Siberia, formed by [Betula pendula], or, sometimes, [Betula pubescens], with [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Agrostis capillaris], [Festuca ovina], [Trientalis europaea], [Melampyrum pratense], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Juniperus communis], [Rubus idaeus], [Equisetum sylvaticum] and, in some communities, [Cornus suecica].
Birch woods of the taiga and wooded tundra belts of eastern Siberia and the eastern Siberian mountains, formed by [Betula platyphylla] or, sometimes, [Betula pendula].

Open, often parklike, woods of [Betula pendula], [Betula platyphylla] or [Betula pubescens] [s.l.] of the transition zone between steppe and taiga of Siberia, east of the range of the nemoral deciduous forests of the Sarmatic region.

Open, often parklike, woods of [Betula pendula] and [Populus tremula] (listed under 41.D7 when dominated by the latter) of the transition zone between steppe and taiga of Siberia, east of the range of the nemoral deciduous forests of the Sarmatic region. The shrub layer includes [Lonicera altaica], [Lonicera tatarica], [Thelycrania alba] ([Cornus alba]), [Ribes nigrum], [Ribes rubrum], [Spiraea hypericifolia], [Cotoneaster multiflorus]
Open, often parklike, woods of [Betula platyphylla] of the transition zone between Eastern Siberian steppes and the taiga of northern Siberia or of the Siberian mountains.

Nombre oficial: Northern Kazakh downy birch steppe woods
Definición oficial: [Betula kirghisorum] ([Betula pubescens] [s.l.]) woods, enclaved, south of the wooded steppe zone of Eurasia, within the northern steppe zone, on saline soils of northern Kazakhstan.
Nonriparian, nonmarshy woods of the western Palaearctic region dominated by [Alnus spp.]
[Alnus cordata]-dominated formations of slopes with deep, loose, moist soils, endemic to the Campanian, Lucanian and Calabrian Apennines and the Castaniccia and San Petrone ranges of Corsica.
Nonriparian, nonmarshy formations of the nemoral or boreonemoral zones dominated by [Alnus glutinosa] or [Alnus incana].
Nonriparian, nonmarshy formations of Atlantic regions of the nemoral zone dominated by [Alnus glutinosa] or [Alnus incana].

Tall, closed [Alnus glutinosa] woods of Britain developed on relatively dry, generally alluvial, eutrophic soils, in particular, on old river terraces, with [Sambucus nigra], [Salix cinerea], [Crataegus monogyna], [Prunus spinosa], [Urtica dioica], [Poa trivialis], [Dryopteris dilatata], [Galium aparine], [Rubus fruticosus] [s.l.]

Woods of coastal southern Norway dominated by [Alnus glutinosa] and [Alnus incana], accompanied by [Ulmus glabra] and [Fraxinus excelsior], with an herb-rich undergrowth dominated by [Melica nutans], [Poa nemoralis], [Ranunculus ficaria].

Dry [Alnus incana] or [Alnus glutinosa] woods of nemoral Central Europe, in particular, great horsetail dry alder woods of Poland, dense alder stands of steep valley slopes of Great Poland, dominated by [Alnus incana] alone or by [Alnus glutinosa] and [Alnus incana] together, with a rich undergrowth composed predominantely of ruderal and riparian species

Dry alder woods of the nemoral and boreonemoral regions of Lithuania, Russia, Belarus and Ukraine, in particular, nettle grey alder woods, tall herb-rich dry [Alnus incana] forests on comparatively fertile acid brown forest soils, recorded from the northern part of the Valday Upland and Lithuania, with [Urtica dioica], [Anthriscus sylvestris], [Mnium cuspidatum].

[Alnus incana] woods of the subalpine level of the western Rhodopes, substitution facies of [Picea abies] forests, usually developed in wetter stations than those occupied by [Betula pendula] or [Populus tremula].
Nonriparian, nonmarshy formations of the boreal zone of the Palaearctic region dominated by [Alnus glutinosa] or [Alnus incana].
Nonriparian, nonmarshy formations of the boreal zone of the Palaearctic region dominated by [Alnus glutinosa]. They are related to the shore woods of unit 44.24 and have a similar composition.

Nonriparian, nonmarshy formations of the boreal zone of the Palaearctic region dominated by [Alnus incana], appearing, in particular, as first recolonisation stage on rich damp soils of central and northern Fennoscandia. They are related to the shore woods of unit 44.23 and have a similar composition.
Woods of the western Palaearctic region dominated by [Populus tremula].
Woods of [Populus tremula] and [Corylus avellana], accompanied by a xerophile flora, of dry inner valleys of the Alps.

Pioneer and subclimax [Populus tremula] formations of plains and hills of nemoral Europe, in particular the North Sea-Baltic plain and lower Hercynian slopes, within the range of Atlantic and sub-Atlantic acidophilous oak woods, and of the adjacent large alluvial systems, such as that of the Po.
[Populus tremula] formations of the montane level of nemoral and Mediterranean mountains of Europe, occurring, in particular, within the beech belt of high southern mountains.
[Populus tremula] formations occurring within the sub- or supra-Mediterranean environment of the mixed deciduous broad-leaved forests of, in particular, the [Quercion frainetto].
[Populus tremula] stands of the taiga zone and of the transition zone between taiga and nemoral woods of Fennoscandia and the northern Sarmatic region.
[Populus tremula]-dominated forests of the southwestern spurs of the Ural Mountains, part of the easternmost extension of the oak-lime nemoral forests.

Open, often parklike, woods of [Populus tremula] and [Betula pendula] (listed under unit 41.B9 when dominated by the latter) of the transition zone between steppe and taiga of Siberia, east of the range of the nemoral deciduous forests of the Sarmatic region. The shrub layer includes [Lonicera altaica], [Lonicera tatarica], [Thelycrania alba] ([Cornus alba]), [Ribes nigrum], [Ribes rubrum], [Spiraea hypericifolia], [Cotoneaster multiflorus]
[Populus tremula] stands, sometimes vast, of the southern slopes of inner Pontic ranges.

[Populus davidiana]-[Betula platyphylla] woods of the 2500-3000 metre spruce-pine zone of the Nanshan range of eastern central Asia and of the larch, larch-pine and larch-pine-spruce zones of the Ta-hsing-an Ling range of northeastern China.
Woods of the western Palaearctic region dominated by [Sorbus aucuparia], characteristic in particular of the Scottish Highlands.

Forests and woods dominated by [Ulmus spp.] or [Acer spp.] of dry, sometimes humid but nonriparian, stable soils of the nemoral western Palaearctic region. Ravine forests, on screes or colluvions, dominated by these species are listed in unit 41.3, riverine forests in unit 44.

[Ulmus minor] ([Ulmus carpinifolia], [Ulmus campestris]) or [Ulmus procera] woods of base- and nutrient-rich, often ruderal, terrain, dispersed along the western seaboard of Western Europe and in warm, dry, subcontinental areas of Central Europe, usually rich in species of southern affinities.

Nitrophile [Ulmus minor] or [Ulmus procera] woods of the western seaboard of the European continent, from northern France to Poland, distributed, in particular, in the Paris Basin, in the maritime dunes of the Netherlands and Belgium, on the dikes of the Dutch fluviatile district and on the cretaceous low Meuse hills, sporadically also in suburban forests, parks and green spaces throughout its range.
[Ulmus minor] woods of the coasts of Normandy, Brittany and Vend¿e.
Woods of the British Isles, mostly of the [Fraxinus]-[Acer]-[Mercurialis] type, invaded and dominated by suckering elms of the [Ulmus minor] group ([Ulmus carpinifolia], [Ulmus procera])

[Ulmus minor] woods of dry, warm stations in regions of subcontinental climate of Central Europe, mostly secundary colonists of agricultural land on loess, marls, degraded chernozems or alluvial terrain, distributed in particular in southern German dry enclaves, in peri-Pannonic areas and in Bulgaria.

Nombre oficial: Wych elm and fluttering elm woods
Definición oficial: Nonriparian, nonravine [Ulmus glabra] or [Ulmus laevis]-dominated formations of northern and central Europe.

Forests and woods dominated by [Acer spp.] of dry, sometimes humid but nonriparian, stable soils of the nemoral western Palaearctic region, in particular, maple-dominated, pioneer, young and perturbed stands of the Atlantic and sub-Atlantic varied oak-hornbeam and ash forests of units 41.2 and 41.3.

[Tilia spp.]-dominated forests and woods of dry, sometimes humid but nonriparian, stable soils of the nemoral and boreal zones of western and central Eurasia. Ravine forests, on screes or colluvions, dominated by these species are listed in unit 41.3, riverine forests in unit 44.

Rare [Tilia]-dominated stands of nemoral western and central Europe, within the range of [Fagus sylvatica], often [Tilia]-dominated facies of lime-rich oak-hornbeam forests. They are distributed, in particular, in the Bohemian basin, in southern Scandinavia and in the British Isles.

[Tilia]-dominated forests of the northern nemoral zone and of enclaves in the southern boreal zone of Fennoscandia, the Baltic States and Russia, east to the Volga, outside of the range of [Fagus sylvatica] and mostly of [Carpinus betulus]. [Tilia cordata] may be accompanied by [Quercus robur], [Acer platanoides], [Populus tremula], [Picea abies], [Corylus avellana], [Sorbus aucuparia], [Euonymus europaeus], [Daphne mezereum], [Galium odoratum], [Anemone nemorosa] and boreal herbs.

[Tilia]-dominated forests of eastern Central Europe and the southern nemoral zone of Russia, east of the range of [Fagus sylvatica] and, for the most part, of that of [Carpinus betulus], and west of the Volga, with [Quercus robur], [Acer platanoides] and [Ulmus montana].

Forests of the nemoral zone of Russia, east of the Volga, with an eastward trend of diminishing [Quercus robur] and augmenting [Tilia cordata], and an often luxuriant shrub layer comprizing, in particular, [Corylus avellana]. Many, or most, are dominated by lime and listed here rather than under unit 41.26C.

[Tilia cordata]-dominated forests of the montane and submontane zones of the Ural, mostly to the north and west of the forests of unit 41.26D, with [Quercus robur], [Acer platanoides], [Populus tremula].
[Tilia cordata]-dominated forests of the oak-hornbeam-lime forest complex occupying the central part of the Tauric chain of southern Crimea.
[Tilia sibirica]-dominated forests of the Altai.
[Tilia mongolica]-dominated formations of sheltered valleys of Inner Mongolian steppes.
Mixed summer-green broad-leaved forests limited mainly to the mountains bordering the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea.
Mixed summer-green broad-leaved forests of the Pontic Range of northern Anatolia and the Stranja-Istranca of Thrace, with outlyers in the eastern Balkan Range.

Species-rich mixed forests of mountains of the western Pontic Range and the mountains of the western and southwestern Black Sea region, including the eastern Balkan Range, the Stranja-Istranca, typically with a varied, multispecific shrub layer and herb layer comprising many Euxinian elements.

Species-rich mixed forests of mountains of the western and southwestern Black Sea region, including the eastern Balkan Range, the Stranja-Istranca, composed of [Quercus polycarpa], [Quercus cerris], [Carpinus betulus], [Carpinus orientalis], [Sorbus torminalis], [Fagus orientalis], with a varied, multispecific shrub layer and herb layer comprising many Euxinian elements.

Mixed forests of [Fagus orientalis], [Carpinus betulus] and [Tilia tomentosa]on well moistured soils of the Stranja mountains of southeastern Bulgaria, sometimes accompanied by the Balkan endemic [Quercus hartwissiana] and many species typical of the western Pontic [Fagus orientalis] forests (41.1E122), including the rare [Fritillaria pontica], [Cyclamen coum], [Primula vulgaris] ssp. [rosea], [Trachystemon orientalis], and [Scilla bithynica].

Mixed forests of [Quercus polycarpa], [Carpinus betulus], [Quercus cerris], [Sorbus torminalis], [Fagus orientalis] with [Quercus frainetto], [Carpinus orientalis], located on north-facing slopes, on moist, nutrient-rich soils of the Stranja mountains of southeastern Bulgaria, with an understorey comprising [Crataegus monogyna], [Mespilus germanica], [Rhododendron ponticum], [Daphne pontica], [Erica arborea], [Vaccinium arctostaphylos], [Calluna vulgaris], [Genista carinalis], [Brachypodium sylvaticum], [Festuca heterophylla], [Poa nemoralis], [Melica uniflora], [Primula vulgaris] ssp. [rosea], [Cyclamen coum], [Salvia forskaohlei], [Trachystemon orientalis], [Sesleria alba].

Mixed forests with a varied, multispecific shrub layer and herb layer comprising many Euxinian elements located within a narrow coastal fringe from sea level to about 1200 m in the western Pontic Range between the Bulgarian border and 32øE, east of Zonguldak. Species include [Quercus macranthera], [Quercus hartwissiana], [Quercus iberica], [Taxus baccata], [Ostrya carpinifolia], [Fraxinus ornus], [Prunus laurocerasus], [Staphylea pinnata], [Buxus sempervirens].

Mixed forests located within a narrow coastal fringe from sea level to about 800-900 m in the eastern Pontic Range, within the zone of tea cultivation. The tree layer includes [Quercus iberica], [Castanea sativa], [Fagus orientalis], [Carpinus betulus], occasional [Pinus sylvestris], the understorey comprises [Iris lazica], [Hypericum xylostelofolium], [Omphalodes cappadocica], [Oplismenus undulatifolius], [Rubus platyphylos].

Mixed forests of inner slopes of the Pontic Range generally in conditions of lower humidity and temperature than those of the Euxianian mixed forests of unit 41.H1, rich in species of [Quercus] and usually accompanied by [Carpinus betulus] or [Carpinus orientalis], sometimes with conifers. Characteristic species include [Quercus dshorochensis], [Quercus syspirensis], [Quercus anatolica], [Quercus iberica], [Quercus macranthera], [Acer cappadocium], [Fagus orientalis], [Abies bornmuelleriana].

Isolated oak-hornbeam forests of the Stranja and the Belgrat-Ormani, similar to woodlands of middle Europe in structure and field layer, but with [Quercus polycarpa], [Quercus frainetto], [Quercus cerris], [Quercus infectoria], dominated by, or rich in, [Carpinus betulus].

Oak-hornbeam forests of the western Pontic Range comprising, in particular, on calcareous marls, formations with [Quercus syspirensis], [Quercus anatolica], [Quercus iberica], with [Dictamnus albus] or, in the Kastamonu basin, with [Quercus iberica], [Abies bornmuelleriana], [Pinus sylvestris].

Oak-hornbeam forests of the central Pontic Range, centered around Samsun, variable in composition depending on conditions of humidity, including, in particular, formations with [Quercus cerris], [Crataegus curvipetala] on schists, with [Quercus dshorochensis], [Quercus anatolica] on limestones or marls, with [Quercus syspirensis], [Fagus orientalis], [Daphne pontica] or, with [Carpinus betulus], [Carpinus orientalis], [Ruscus aculiatus] and an accompanying flora characteristic of rhododendron-beech forests that grade, at their upper limit, into the mixed [Fagus]-[Quercus iberica]-[Carpinus]-[Acer cappadocium] forests of higher altitudes.

Oak-hornbeam forests of the eastern Pontic Range, including the Kelkit Cay and Harsit valleys, south of Trabzon, including, in particular, formations with [Quercus syspirensis], and an admixture of [Pinus pallasiana] and [Chamaecytisus pygmaeus] or, east of Erbaa, [Cedrus libani].

Oak-hornbeam forests of the inner slopes of the Pontic Range, under cold climate conditions and low precipitation (450-800 mm) comprising formations with [Quercus iberica], [Quercus macranthera], [Daphne pontica].

Mixed forests rich in hornbeam, oak or beech, of slopes of the Central Caucasus of Georgia, with [Prunus avium], [Pyrus caucasica], [Corylus avellana], [Euonymus europaea], [Euonymus verrucosa], [Lathyrus roseus], [Dactylis glomerata], [Brachypodium sylvaticum], [Melica nutans].

[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus caucasica] forests of the 800-1300 m level of the Central Caucasus of central Georgia, with [Sorbus torminalis], [Acer laetum], [Acer campestre], [Ulmus foliacea], [Crataegus kyrtostyla], [Mespilus germanica], [Lonicera caprifolium], [Cytisus caucasicus], [Digitalis schischkinii], [Viola reichenbachiana], [Carex euxina], [Melica uniflora].

Mixed, oak- and hornbeam-dominated facies of [Fagus orientalis]-[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus caucasica] forests of the 1200-1300 m level of the southern flank of the Central Caucasus of central Georgia, with [Clinopodium vulgare], [Primula macrocalyx], [Salvia glutinosa], [Fragaria vesca], [Epilobium montanum], [Melica uniflora], [Poa nemoralis]. Overwhelmingly beech-dominated stands are listed in unit 41.1H7.

[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus caucasica]-[Carpinus orientalis] forests of the 800 to 1000 metre level of northern slopes of the Central Caucasus of central Georgia, with [Sorbus torminalis], [Acer laetum], [Swida australis], [Crataegus kyrtostyla], [Lonicera caprifolium], [Berberis vulgaris].

[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus caucasica] forests of the 1100 to 1300 metres of northern slopes of the Central Caucasus of central Georgia, with [Rhododendron flavum], [Acer platanoides], [Tilia cordata], [Poa nemoralis], [Festuca montana], [Galium vernum], [Cardamine impatiens], [Sedum stoloniferum], [Veronica officinalis].

Timberline [Carpinus caucasica]-[Quercus macranthera] forests of the 1800 to 2000 metre level of northeastern slopes of the Central Caucasus of central Georgia, with [Sorbus caucasigena], [Daphne mezereum], [Lonicera caucasica], [Astrantia maxima], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Pulmonaria dacica], [Astrantia major], [Euphorbia macroceras], [Pimpinella rhodanta], [Betonica grandiflora], [Scutellaria altissima], [Vicia truncatula], [Campanula latifolia], [Calamagrostis arundinacea].

[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus betulus]-[Fagus orientalis] forests of the northwestern part of the Great Caucasus, at altitudes of 150-420 m, with [Acer laetum], [Prunus avium], [Pyrus caucasica], [Corylus avellana], [Frangula alnus], [Swida australis], [Hieracium umbellatum], [Serratula cinquefolia], [Lathyrus hirsutus], [Festuca drymeja].

[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus betulus]-[Fagus orientalis] forests of steep slopes with brown soils on limestone of the 150-250 meter level of the northwestern Great Caucasus, with [Tilia caucasica], [Fraxinus excelsior], [Acer camperstre], [Ulmus glabra], [Viburnum lantana], [Cotinus coggygria], [Hedera helix], [Smilax aspera], [Clematis vitalba], [Philadelphus caucasicus], [Staohylea colchica], [Euonymus latifolia], [Tamus communus], [Primula vulgaris], [Paeonia caucasica], [Epipactis helleborine], [Carex sylvatica].

[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus betulus]-[Fagus orientalis] forests of the 350-420 m of the northwestern Great Caucasus, with [Rhododendron luteum], [Crataegus monogyna], [Mespilus germanica], [Rubus caucasicus], [Vinca herbacea], [Melampyrum elatius], [Lathyrus aureus], [Dorycnium herbaceum].
Mixed summer-green broad-leaved forests of the region bordering the southern periphery of the Caspian Sea, including its coastal plain and the northern slopes of the Elburz system.

Species-rich mixed forests mostly of damp, poorly drained soils of the lowlands in the region of the southern end of the Caspian Sea, with an often dense, jungle-like understorey of tall shrubs, lianas, low shrubs and herbaceous plants. The species cort¿ge includes, among others, the trees and tall shrubs [Alnus subcordata], [Alnus glutinosa], [Fraxinus excelsior], [Pterocarya fraxinifolia], [Populus caspica], [Diospyros lotus], [Ficus carica], [Salix fragilis], [Buxus sempervirens], [Albizia julibrissin], [Celtis australis], [Acer insigne], [Prunus caspica], [Prunus laurocerasus], [Mespilus germanica], [Paliurus spina-christi], [Punica granatum], lower shrubs, notably [Epimedium pinnatum], [Sambucus ebulus], [Andrachne calchiica], [Hypericum androsaemum], [Teucrium hercanum], [Ruscus hyrcanus], and climbers, in particular, [Periploca graeca], [Vitis sylvestris], [Clematis vitalba], [Hedera colchica], [Jasminum officinale], [Tamus communis], [Rubus caesus], [Solonum dulcamara].
Forests of the foothills and lower mountain zone of the northern Elburz Mountains dominated by [Quercus castanaefolia], with [Parrotia persica].
Forest communities of the foothills and lower mountain zone of the northern Elburz Mountains dominated by [Quercus castanaefolia] and [Carpinus betulus].
Uncommon forests of the foothills and lower mountain zone of the western Hyrcanian region dominated by [Quercus castanaefolia] and [Castanea sativa].
Forests of the foothills and lower mountains mainly of the eastern Hyrcanian region dominated by [Quercus castanaefolia], [Acer cappidocicum] and [Acer signe],

Relatively xerophile forests of Hyrcanian mountains, at altitudes of 1600-2000 m, dominated by [Quercus macranthera], with shrubs of [Quercus therica], [Sorbus boissieri], [Sorbus umbellata], [Rhamnus catharticus], [Mespilus germanica], [Acer hyrcanum], [Acer opilus], [Crataegus melanocarpa], [Viburnum lantana], [Colutea persica], [Spirea crenata], [Juniperus communis], [Juniperus sabina].

Macrophyllous deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral and boreo-nemoral eastern Asia, distributed in Russian Amurland, in the Heilongjiang (Heilungkiang), Jilin (Kirin), Hebei (Hopei), Shanxi (Shansi), Sandong (Shantung), Henan (Honan) and Shaanxi (Shensi) provinces of China, in     Korea and in Japan

Macrophyllous deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests, species-rich, of boreo-nemoral continental eastern Asia, distributed in the Russian Far East, in eastern Heilongjiang (Heilungkiang), eastern Jilin (Kirin) and northeast Liaoning provinces of China, and in northern Korea, rich in lime.

[Quercus mongolica]-[Tilia amurensis] forests of dry slopes of Amurland, with [Tilia amurensis], [Fraxinus rhynchophylla], [Acer mono], [Maianthemum dilatatum], [Vicia unijuga], [Sedum aizoon], [Viola sustroussurienis], [Falcata japonica], [Granium maximoviczii], [Adenophora verticillata], [Aruncus dioicus], [Polygonatum odoratum], [Lespedeza bicolor].

Rich [Quercus mongolica]-[Tilia amurensis] forests of western and southern dry gentle slopes of Amurland, with [Doellingeria scabra], [Viburnum sargentii], [Corylus manshurica], [Polemonium racemosum], [Artemisia stolonifera], [Artemisia gmelini], [Carex siderostricta], [Campanula cephalotes], [Galium davuricum], [Euphorbia eucorum], [Filipendula palmata], [Pedicularis resupinata], [Veronica siberica], [Viola collina], [Aconitum stoloniferum], [Trisetum sibiricum], [Cardamine leucantha], [Pseudostellaria], [japonica], [Asparagus schoberioides], [Lychnis fulgens], [Sanicula shinensis], [Agrimonia pilosa].
Poor [Quercus mongolica]-[Tilia amurensis] forests of dry steep northern, or gentle slopes of Amurland with [Acer pseudosieboldianum], [Cacalia hastata].

[Tilia amurensis] forests on cool, moist unfertile soils of north-facing slopes of Amurland, with [Carpinus cordata], [Philadelphis tenuifolius], [Arisaema amurensis], [Ajuga multiflora], [Ribes maximoviczianum], [Urtica laetevirens], [Pseudostellaria sylvatica], [Dryopteris crassirhizoma].

[Carpinus cordata]-[Tilia amurensis] forests on northern slopes of Amurland, with [Acer pseudosieboldianum], [Acer tegmentosum], [Syringa amurensis], [Delphinium macickianum], [Adoxa moschatellina], [Smilacina hirta], [Aconitum albo-violaceum].
Maple-lime forests on northern gentle slopes of Amurland, with [Phlomis maximowiczii], [Lonicera ruprechtiana], [Urtica angustifolia].

Macrophyllous deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral eastern Asia, distributed in the Hebei (Hopei), Shanxi (Shansi), Sandong (Shantung), Henan (Honan) and Shaanxi (Shensi) provinces of China, in Korea, in the Quelpart Islands, in southern Hokkaido, Honshu, montane Shikoku and Kyushu, mostly dominated by deciduous [Quercus spp.], or by [Quercus spp.] and [Fraxinus spp.], sometimes by [Tilia spp.]
Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral eastern China, dominated by oaks [Quercus spp.], oaks and ashes [Fraxinus spp.] or limes [Tilia spp.].

Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral eastern China, mostly distributed below 700 m, dominated by [Quercus aliena], [Fraxinus chinensis] and [Carpinus turczaninowii], with [Quercus dentata], [Evodia danielii], [Acer mono].

Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral eastern China, mostly distributed below 500 m, dominated by [Quercus variabilis], with [Fraxinus chinensis], [Biota orientalis], [Pistacia chinensis], [Carpinus turczaninowii], [Acer truncatum].

Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral eastern China, mostly distributed between 400 and 1000 m, dominated by [Quercus dentata] with [Fraxinus chinensis], [Quercus aliena], [Ulmus macrocarpa], [Carpinus turczaninowii].

Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral eastern China, mostly distributed between 700 and 1000 m, dominated by [Quercus liaotungensis] and [Fraxinus chinensis], with [Betula fruticosa], [Acer mono], [Tilia mandshurica], [Tilia mongolica].

Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of nemoral eastern China, mostly distributed between 1100 and 1400 m, dominated by [Tilia mandshurica], [Tilia mongolica] with [Betula japonica] var. [mandshurica], [Quercus liaotungensis], [Populus tremula] var. [davidiana], [Salix phylicifolia].
Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of central Korea dominated by [Quercus mongolica], [Quercus serrata], [Carpinus laxiflora], [Carpinus tschonoskii], [Acer formosum].

Deciduous or predominantly deciduous forests of Japan mostly characteristic of southern Hokkaido and northern Honshu, mostly dominated by [Quercus crispula], [Quercus dentata], [Quercus serrata], [Fraxinus spaethiana], sometimes [Ulmus davidiana], [Castanea crenata], [Aesculus turbinata], with [Acer spp.], [Celtis spp.], [Betula spp.], [Zelkova serrata], [Alnus spp.], [Cercidphyllum japonicum], [Pterocarya rhoifolia].

Forests dominated by [Fagus sylvatica] in western and central Europe, by [Fagus orientalis], [Fagus moesiaca], [Fagus taurica] in southeastern Europe and the Near East, by [Fagus crenata], [Fagus multinervis], [Fagus japonica] in the Far East. Many montane formations are beech-fir or beech-fir-spruce forests, to be noted as unit 43 (mixed forests), but with the suffixes below

[Fagus sylvatica] forests of the Pindus north to the Smolikas and the Grammos, and of the Chassia, Olympus and Ossa groups, with reduced medio-European character and high endemism, characterized by the presence of [Abies borisii-regis], [Doronicum caucasicum], [Galium laconicum], [Lathyrus venetus], [Helleborus cyclophyllus].

[Fagus sylvatica] or [Fagus sylvatica-Abies borisii-regis] forests of reduced medio-European character and high endemism, mostly characteristic of the central Pindus (Noto Pindhos, Southern Pindus), with local occurrences in the northern Pindus, in particular in the Smolikas and the Grammos.

[Fagus sylvatica] or [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies borisii-regis] forests, characterized like those of unit 41.161 by their reduced medio-European character and high endemism, isolated, west of the main Pindian range of Hellenic beech forests, in mountains of the Chassia and Olympus groups, in particular in the Andichasia, Olympus and Pieria ranges.

[Fagus sylvatica] or [Fagus moesiaca] forests, more thermophile than those of 41.19 and 41.1A, occurring in the transition zone between the supra-Mediterranean and montane levels of Thrace and Macedonia, characterized by the presence of numerous species of the [Quercion frainetto].

[Fagus sylvatica] forests of the Dinarides and of associated ranges and hills, with outliers and irradiations in the southeastern Alps and in the mid-Pannonic hills. In these areas they are in contact with, or interspersed among, medio-European beech forests.

Strongly acidophile [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the Dinarides and of associated ranges and hills, of weakly expressed Illyrian character, with possible outliers in the southeastern Alps and the mid-Pannonic hills.

Neutrophile, neutrocline, acidocline and basicline [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the Dinarides and of associated ranges and hills, with outliers and irradiations in the southeastern Alps and in the mid-Pannonic hills.

Neutrophile and basicline [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the collinar level of the Dinarides and pre-Dinarides, of the southeastern pre-Alpine hills of Slovenia, of the southern Transdanubian hills of Hungary and, very locally, of pre-Alpine thermophile hills in valleys of Carinthia and Friuli Venezia Giulia, with [Aremonia agrimonoides], [Anemone trifolia], [Vicia oroboides], [Lathyrus venetus], [Cardamine enneaphyllos] ([Dentaria enneaphyllos]), [Primula vulgaris], [Hacquetia epipactis], [Ruscus hypoglossum], [Ruscus aculeatus], [Tilia tomentosa].
Neutrophile, acidocline and basicline [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the montane level of the Dinarides

Neutrophile and acidocline forests of [Fagus sylvatica], [Abies alba] and [Picea abies] of the lower and middle montane levels of the Dinarides and, locally, of the southeastern Alps, with [Petasites albus], [Lamiastrum flavidum] and an Illyrian cort¿ge that includes [Lamium orvala] and [Anemone trifolia], associated to acidocline species such as [Oxalis acetosella], [Calamagrostis arundinacea], [Luzula luzuloides] and several ferns.

Neutrocline or basicline forests of [Fagus sylvatica], [Abies alba] and [Picea abies] of the lower and middle montane levels of the Dinarides and the southeastern Alps of Slovenia and Carinthia, with [Anemone trifolia], [Helleborus niger], [Oxalis acetosella], [Lonicera xylosteum], [Sorbus aria].

Neutrocline or basicline forests of [Fagus sylvatica], [Abies alba], [Picea abies] and [Larix decidua] of the upper montane levels of the Dinarides and, locally, the southeastern Alps of Slovenia and Carinthia, often low-growing or krummholz, with [Anemone trifolia], [Saxifraga rotundifolia], [Aposeris foetida], [Cardamine trifolia], [Helleborus niger], [Oxalis acetosella], [Petasites albus], [Prenanthes purpurea], [Lonicera alpigena].

Thermophilous and often calcicolous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the Dinarides and of associated ranges and hills, with outliers and irradiations in the southeastern Alps and in the mid-Pannonic hills, characterized by the presence of [Ostryo-Carpinion orientalis] or [Fraxino orni-Ostryion] species.

Thermophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests forming, between Mediterranean [Ostrya] forests and montane beech forests, a sublittoral belt, stretching from Istria to Albania, and characterized by the massive occurrence of [Sesleria autumnalis] and the presence of many Mediterranean and sub-Mediterranean species, including [Fraxinus ornus], [Ostrya carpinifolia], [Acer obtusatum], [Quercus pubescens], [Sorbus aria].

Thermophilous Illyrian [Fagus sylvatica] forests of inland areas of the Dinarides and of associated ranges and hills, of the southeastern pre-Alps and  the mid-Pannonic hills, characterized by the presence of [Ostryo-Carpinion orientalis] or [Fraxino orni-Ostryion] species.

Thermophilous Illyrian [Fagus sylvatica] forests of limestones and dolomites of the pre-Dinaric hills of Slovenia and of the southeastern pre-Alpine hills of Slovenia and Carinthia, with [Ostrya carpinifolia], [Fraxinus ornus], [Sorbus aria], [Sorbus torminalis] and a species-rich herb-layer comprising numerous [Quercetalia pubescentis] characteristics.

Thermophilous Illyrian [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the northern Dinarides and pre-Dinarides and of the southern mid-Pannonic or sub-Pannonic hills, north to the Hungarian Mecsec and Tolna hills, with [Tilia tomentosa], [Fraxinus ornus] and [Carpinus betulus] in the canopy, [Helleborus odorus], [Tamus communis], [Chaerophyllum aureum], [Ruscus hypoglossum], [Ruscus aculeatus], [Potentilla micrantha] in the herb layer.
Thermophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of inland areas of the central Dinarides.

Local [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the tree-limit in the upper montane or subalpine level of the high Dinarides, with extremely limited outliers in the southeastern Alps, not forming a clear belt, contrary to more western formations of the [Aceri-Fagion], though, like them, characterized by the frequent admixture of [Acer pseudoplatanus] in the canopy and of [Adenostyletalia] megaphorb species in the understorey. [Acer heldreichii], [Sorbus chamaemespilus], [Salix appendiculata], [Myrrhis odorata], [Cicerbita alpina], [Aconitum paniculatum], [Chaerophyllum hirsutum], [Petasites albus], [Stellaria nemorum] are noteworthy accompaniers.

[Fagus sylvatica], or, locally, [Fagus orientalis], [Fagus moesiaca], [Fagus taurica], forests of the Romanian, Ukrainian and eastern Serbian Carpathians, east of the Uz and the Stry, and of the west Ukrainian pre-Carpathic hills and plateaux. Characteristic species include [Symphytum cordatum], [Cardamine glanduligera] ([Dentaria glandulosa]), [Hepatica transsilvanica], [Pulmonaria rubra], [Leucanthemum waldsteinii], [Silene heuffelii], [Ranunculus carpaticus], [Euphorbia carniolica], [Aconitum moldavicum], [Saxifraga rotundifolia] ssp. [heuffelii], [Primula elatior] ssp. [leucophylla], [Hieracium rotundatum], [Galium kitaibelianum], [Moehringia pendula], [Festuca drymeja].

[Fagus sylvatica] forests of the eastern Carpathians and pre-Carpathian hills, developed on acid soils, in particular podzols and brown acid soils, mostly limited to rather small surfaces within the more extensive neutrophilous forest complexes, characterized by a species-poor acidophilous flora that includes [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Hieracium rotundatum], [Calamagrostis hirundinacea], [Luzula luzuloides], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Galium rotundifolium], [Galium kitaibelianum], [Galium baillonii], [Veronica officinalis], [Blechnum spicant], [Pteridium aquilinum].

Widely distributed acidophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the eastern and southern Carpathians, accompanied by a cort¿ge in which the acidophile species characteristic of the [Calamagrostio-Fagenion] clearly predominate over the edaphically less restricted species of the [Symphyto-Fagion]

Acidophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the central zone of the southern Romanian Carpathians, limited to small surfaces, characterized by the presence of thermophilous species such as [Galium kitaibelianum], [Galium baillonii] and [Potentilla micrantha].
Acidophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests, mostly of high mountains in the southwestern Carpathians, with [Galium rotundifolium] and an admixture of acidophilous and neutrophilous [Fagetalia] species.

[Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies alba], [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies alba]-[Picea abies] and [Fagus sylvatica]-[Carpinus betula] forests of the Romanian, Ukrainian and eastern Serbian Carpathians and pre-Carpathian hills, with typical [Fagetalia] species, developed on neutral, basicline and sometimes acidocline substrates.

[Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus sylvatica-Abies alba] and [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies alba]-[Picea abies] forests of the Romanian, Ukrainian and eastern Serbian Carpathians and pre-Carpathian hills accompanied by a cort¿ge of typical [Fagetalia] species supplemented by regional Dacian elements, including [Symphytum cordatum], [Cardamine glanduligera] ([Dentaria glandulosa]), [Ranunculus carpaticus], [Pulmonaria rubra], [Aconitum moldavicum], [Hepatica transsilvanica], [Silene heuffelii], [Ranunculus carpaticus], [Euphorbia carniolica], [Crocus heuffelianus], [Aremonia agrimonoides], [Festuca drymeja], widely distributed in all mountains and high hills of the region on neutral, basicline and sometimes acidocline substrates. [Fagus orientalis] and [Fagus taurica] may locally enter the canopy in sub-Carpathic ranges of Moldavia.

Neutrophile [Fagus sylvatica] forests, sometimes with a small admixture of [Acer pseudoplatanus], [Picea abies] and [Abies alba], with a rich [Fagetalia] flora and regionally characteristic Dacian species including [Symphytum cordatum], [Cardamine glanduligera] ([Dentaria glandulosa]), [Pulmonaria rubra], [Hepatica transsilvanica], [Ranunculus carpaticus], widespread on rich soils throughout the Romanian and Ukrainian Carpathians, where they form the zonal forests of the lower and middle montane belt, between 600 and 1100 metres.

Neutrophile [Fagus sylvatica-Abies alba] forests with a rich [Fagetalia] flora and Dacian regional species such as [Pulmonaria rubra], [Cardamine glanduligera] ([Dentaria glandulosa]), [Symphytum cordatum], [Hepatica transsilvanica], [Ranunculus carpaticus], [Campanula abietina], widely distributed throughout the Romanian and Ukrainian Carpathians, on rich brown, leached or acid soils of steep slopes at altitudes comprised between 700 and 1300 m.

Acidocline [Fagus sylvatica]-[Picea abies] forests of the high southeastern Carpathians, occupying the upper fringe of the montane beech forests, at altitudes between 800 and 1350 metres, on acid brown soils, with [Leucanthemum waldsteinii] and a cort¿ge otherwise typical of the [Symphyto-Fagenion], including [Oxalis acetosella], [Symphytum cordatum], [Pulmonaria rubra], [Cardamine glanduligera].

Forests of [Fagus sylvatica], or sometimes [Fagus moesiaca] and [Carpinus betulus], occasionally of [Fagus sylvatica] without [Carpinus betulus], of the montane level of the Romanian, Ukrainian and eastern Serbian Carpathians and pre-Carpathian hills, accompanied by an eastern [Carpinion] cort¿ge that includes [Tilia cordata], [Prunus avium], [Lathyrus hallersteinii], [Melampyrum bihariense], [Aposeris foetida], [Stellaria holostea], [Ranunculus auricomus], [Galium schultesii], [Carex pilosa], [Dactylis glomerata].

Neutrophile forests of [Fagus sylvatica], or sometimes [Fagus moesiaca], and [Carpinus betulus], often with an admixture of [Quercus petraea], or, in more thermophile variants, [Quercus cerris], widely distributed in the lower montane belt of the Romanian and Ukrainian Carpathians and high pre-Carpathian hills, mostly above 500-600 metres, with a typical [Lathyro-Carpinion] cort¿ge formed by, in particular, [Galium schultesii], [Carex pilosa], [Melampyrum bihariense], [Aposeris foetida], [Stellaria holostea], [Ranunculus auricomus], accompanied by Dacian elements such as [Cardamine glanduligera] ([Dentaria glandulosa]), [Symphytum cordatum], [Helleborus purpurascens].
Neutrophile [Fagus sylvatica]-[Carpinus betulus] beech forests with [Lathyrus hallersteinii] in the herb layer, of limited distribution in the southern Apuseni Mountains and the Petrosani Depression.

Orchid-rich [Fagus sylvatica-Carpinus betulus] forests developed on calcareous substrates with rendzina-type soils of the montane belt of the Romanian Carpathians and pre-Carpathian hills, Dacian vicariant of the northern and central Central European [Carici-Fagetum], with [Cephalanthera rubra], [Cephalanthera damasonium], [Epipactis microphylla], [Epipactis helleborine], [Helleborus purpurascens], [Daphne mezereum], [Cardamine bulbifera], [Hepatica nobilis], [Mycelis muralis], [Salvia glutinosa], [Campanula rapunculoides], [Melica nutans].

Neutrophile [Fagus sylvatica] forests of high pre-Carpathian hills, with a distinct medio-European character and an impoverished Dacian floral element, somewhat transitional between more western communities of the [Fagion medio-Europaeum] and the Dacian [Lathyro-Carpinion] and [Symphyto-Fagion], an intermediate position illustrated by the prevalence of [Cardamine bulbifera] ([Dentaria bulbifera]) and [Carex pilosa] combined with the absence of [Carpinus betulus] and of Dacian montane elements.

Local [Fagus sylvatica] and [Fagus sylvatica]-[Picea abies] forests of the tree-limit in the upper montane or subalpine level of the high southern Carpathians, developed where subalpine [Picea abies] forests do not form an uninterrupted zone, less well individualized than more western formations of the [Aceri-Fagion], though, like them, characterized by the admixture of [Acer pseudoplatanus] in the canopy and of [Adenostyletalia] megaphorb species in the understorey.

Neutrophile to weakly acidophile [Fagus sylvatica-Picea abies] forests with a mixed cort¿ge composed of [Fagetalia]  species, in particular [Symphyto-Fagion] characteristics, and of [Vaccinio-Piceetalia] and [Adenostyletalia] species, of the subalpine or upper montane level of high mountains of the southern Carpathians.

[Fagus sylvatica] forests with [Acer pseudoplatanus] characterized by the presence of [Ribes uva-crispa], [Glechoma hirsuta], [Lamium maculatum] and [Ulmus glabra], on very damp slopes of the subalpine or upper montane level of  the southern and southwestern Carpathians.
[Fagus sylvatica] forests developed on limestones of the eastern and southern Carpathians and pre-Carpathian hills, harbouring a strongly calciphile and thermophile cort¿ge.

Calcicolous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of mountains and high hills in the western part of the southern Carpathians and in the Apuseni mountains, developed on rendzinas, over limestone substrates, with an abundant representation of the calcicline segment of the [Fagetalia] cort¿ge, in particular, [Mercurialis perennis], [Sanicula europaea], [Actaea spicata], accompanied by thermophile species such as [Fraxinus ornus] and [Aristolochia pallida], and by numerous orchids, among which [Epipactis helleborine], [Epipactis microphylla], [Cephalanthera rubra], [Cephalanthera damasonium].

Xero-mesophile, neutrophile to basiphile [Fagus sylvatica] woods developed on  rendzina soils over limestone rocks in low mountains of the western and southern Romanian Carpathians, characterized by the dominance of [Sesleria rigida] in the field layer, accompanied by calciphile herbs, notably [Epipactis atrorubens].

[Fagus sylvatica] or [Fagus moesiaca] forests of the southwestern and southern Carpathians and pre-Carpathian hills, with southern European floristic elements, including [Aremonia agrimonoides], [Festuca drymeja], [Helleborus odorus], [Tilia tomentosa], [Corylus colurna], of Illyrian or Moesian affinities.

Neutrophile or basicline montane [Fagus sylvatica] forests widespread in the southwestern Carpathians, characterized by the presence of thermophile species of Illyrian affinities, in particular, [Aremonia agrimonoides], [Potentilla micrantha], [Fraxinus ornus], [Tamus communis] and the extreme rarefaction of typical [Symphyto-Fagion] Carpathian species.

Neutrophile low montane [Fagus moesiaca] forests with [Corylus colurna] and a cort¿ge of southern species, including [Primula columnae], [Fraxinus ornus], [Lathyrus venetus], [Knautia drymeia], [Ruscus hypoglossum], occupying small surfaces in a few localities of the southwestern Carpathians, south to the Rtanj range of eastern Serbia

Neutrophile to weakly acidophile [Fagus moesiaca] forests, of low mountains and hills of the southwestern Romanian Carpathians and pre-Carpathian ranges, with a cort¿ge of southern, in part Illyrian, species, including [Helleborus odorus], [Asperula taurina], [Daphne laureola], [Ruscus aculeatus], [Tamus communis], [Tilia tomentosa].

Weakly acidophile to acidophile [Fagus sylvatica] or [Fagus moesiaca] forests of the upper part of sunny slopes of the mountains and hills of the southern and southwestern Carpathians, with an herb layer dominated by [Festuca drymeja] and in which [Luzula luzuloides] is always present and the [Symphyto-Fagenion] species poorly represented.

Forests of [Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus taurica] and [Fagus orientalis] of hills and low mountains of the eastern flank of the southeastern Carpathians, of the central plateau of Romanian Moldavia and the Republic of Moldova, of the Podolian plateau of the western Ukraine, mostly with a cort¿ge comprised of southern European elements, including [Tilia tomentosa], [Cornus mas], [Potentilla micrantha], [Carex brevicollis], [Corydalis bulbosa] ssp. [marshalliana] ([Corydalis marshalliana]), [Lathyrus venetus], [Lathyrus aureus], [Cardamine quinquefolia] ([Dentaria quinquefolia]).

Tall neutrophile forests of hills and low mountain slopes of the eastern flank of the southeastern Carpathians, of the central plateau of Romanian Moldavia and the Republic of Moldova, at an altitude of 200-400 metres, with an upper canopy formed by [Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus taurica] and [Fagus orientalis], mixed with [Tilia tomentosa], [Tilia cordata], [Tilia platyphyllos], [Quercus petraea], [Acer pseudoplatanus], and a lower stratum of [Carpinus betulus], [Acer platanoides], [Acer campestre], [Fraxinus excelsior], [Prunus avium], varied shrub and liana strata comprising [Corylus avellana], [Hedera helix] and a species-rich herb layer with [Carex pilosa], [Carex brevicollis] and the regional differential taxa [Corydalis bulbosa] ssp. [marshalliana] ([Corydalis marshalliana]), [Lathyrus venetus], [Lathyrus aureus], [Cardamine quinquefolia] ([Dentaria quinquefolia]).

Neutrophile [Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus taurica] and [Fagus orientalis] forests with [Cornus mas] and other southern European floristic elements, including [Lathyrus venetus], [Potentilla micrantha], of rare occurrence in hills and low mountain slopes of the eastern Carpathians and pre-Carpathians, notably in Romanian Moldavia and the Republic of Moldova.
Forests of [Fagus sylvatica] of the Podolian plateaux of the western Ukraine, in the region of the upper Dniester, of more northern affinities than those of units 41.D61 and 41.D62.
[Fagus orientalis] forests of the Pontic Range and its satellite chains, extending into southeastern Central Europe in the Stranja-Istranca Range and the eastern Balkan Range.
[Fagus orientalis] forests of the western Pontic Range, the Stranja-Istranca Range and the eastern Balkan Range.

Nombre oficial: Eastern Balkan Range oriental beech forests
Definición oficial: Beech forests of the eastern Balkan Range dominated by [Fagus orientalis] and with an understorey formed in part by a Euxinian cort¿ge, impoverished in comparison to that of more southern and eastern communities, though fairly similar to that of unit 41.1E21, comprising, as most characteristic taxa, [Primula vulgaris] ssp. [sibthorpii] ([Primula rosea], [Primula sibthorpii]), [Trachystemon orientalis] and [Scilla bithynica] and the absence of other southern Euxinian elements that occur in the Stranja.
[Fagus orientalis] forests of the Stranja-Istranca Range.

Beech forests of the Stranja-Istranca mountains dominated by [Fagus orientalis], less rich in lauriphyllous shrubs than those of 41.1E122, more similar to those of 41.1E11, although slightly richer in Euxinian elements, with a cort¿ge that includes, locally, [Vaccinium arctostaphylos], otherwise formed primarily by [Primula vulgaris] ssp. [sibthorpii] ([Primula rosea]), [Trachystemon orientalis] and [Scilla bithynica].

Beech forests of the Stranja-Istranca mountains dominated by [Fagus orientalis], often accompanied by [Carpinus betulus], [Carpinus orientalis], [Tilia tomentosa], [Tilia cordata], [Tilia platyphyllos], [Quercus polycarpa], [Acer platanoides], [Acer campestre], [Ulmus glabra], [Sorbus torminalis], [Sorbus domestica], [Prunus avium], with an understorey rich in lauriphyllous shrubs of Euxinian affinities, comprising, in particular, [Rhododendron ponticum], [Daphne pontica], [Prunus laurocerasus] ([Laurocerasus officinalis]), [Pyracantha coccinea], [Ilex aquifolium], [Ruscus hypoglossum],   and with the Euxinian [Primula vulgaris] ssp. [sibthorpii] ([Primula rosea]), [Trachystemon orientalis], [Teucrium cuneifolium], [Cyclamen coum], [Epimedium pubigerum], [Hypericum calycinum] and [Scilla bithynica] in the herb layer.

Forests of the western Pontic Range dominated by [Fagus orientalis], accompanied by [Quercus iberica], [Acer cappodoccicum], [Acer trautvetteri], with a lauriphile-rich one- to six-metre high understorey of [Rhododendron ponticum], [Rhododendron flavum] and [Ilex colchica] with [Hedera colchica], [Smilax excelsa], [Ruscus hypoglossum], [Daphne pontica], [Vaccinium arctostaphylos], [Crataegus pentagyna], [Aristolochia pontica], forming a massive belt at altitudes extending from sea level to 1100-1200 metres, under precipitations of 1000-2000 mm and on siliceous substrates.

Rare forests limited to calcareous outcrops of the western Pontic Range dominated by [Fagus orientalis] accompanied by [Stephylea pinnata], [Buxus sempervirens], [Taxus baccata], [Euonymus latifolius] ssp. [caucanus].

Forests of the western Pontic Range dominated by [Fagus orientalis] accompanied by [Abies bornmuelleriana] occupying sites at altitudes above the rhododendron-beech forests of unit 41.1E14, accompanied by a similar floral cort¿ge.

Forests of the western Pontic Range dominated by [Fagus orientalis] with [Abies bornmuelleriana] limited to calcareous outcrops within the fir-beech belt formed by the forests of unit 41.1E15, and at altitudes above the rhododendron-beech forests of unit 41.1E14, with a species-rich cort¿ge characterized by the presence of [Telekia speciosa], [Aristolochia bodomae], [Arum ponticum], [Hieracleum platytaenium], [Campanula lactiflora].

Forests of the western Pontic Range composed of [Fagus orientalis], often with [Quercus dshorochensis], [Quercus syspirensis], [Quercus anatolica] or [Quercus iberica], [Carpinus betulus] and a presence of [Abies bornmuelleriana].

Beech and oak forests of the western Pontic Range occupying limestones, marls, flyschs and, locally, volcanic substrates, in damp climate areas with 900-1200 mm precipitation, of the Istranca mountains, of the western Pontic chains to the level of Sinop, of the Samsun area and of the Kelkit Cay and Harsit valleys south of Trabzon, variously composed of [Quercus dshorochensis], [Quercus syspirensis], [Quercus anatolica], [Quercus iberica], [Fagus orientalis], [Carpinus betulus], [Carpinus orientalis], [Acer cappadocium], sometimes with a presence of [Abies bornmuelleriana], [Pinus sylvestris] or [Pinus pallasiana].
Forests of interior massifs of the western Pontic Range dominated by [Fagus orientalis], sometimes with [Abies bornmuelleriana].
Forests dominated by [Fagus orientalis] of the eastern Pontic Range.

Nombre oficial: Eastern Pontic montane speedwell beech forests
Definición oficial: Montane forests dominated by [Fagus orientalis] of the westernmost chains of the eastern Pontic Range, between, in the upper Yesil and Bag basins, characterized by [Veronica melissaefolia], [Veronica filiformis], [Veronica peduncularis], [Cyclamen coum] ssp. [caucasicum], [Vicia cracca], [Luzula pilosa], [Paris incompleta], [Cardamine pectinata] and the nearly total absence of lauriphyllous species, located on siliceous substrates at altitudes of 1200-1700 m, with 1200-1500 mm precipitation and 2-4 months of snow cover.

Montane forests dominated by [Fagus orientalis] with [Picea orientalis] of the eastern Pontic Range, extending along the entire chain from the Yedig¿z and Igdir massif eastwards, forming a continuation of the beech forests of unit 41.1E31, with an understorey that includes [Rhododendron ponticum], [Daphnae pontica], [Vaccinium arctostaphylos], located on siliceous substrates at altitudes of 900-1400 m, with 1200-2000 mm precipitation.

Rare forests dominated by [Fagus orientalis] accompanied by [Stephylea pinnata], [Buxus sempervirens], [Taxus baccata], [Euonymus latifolius] ssp. [caucanus], limited to calcareous outcrops of the eastern Pontic Range.

Forests dominated by [Fagus orientalis] of siliceous substrates of the Kastamontu and Gereda regions of the eastern interior Pontic Range, under cold climate with 5-6 months of snow cover, 2-3 months of drought and annual pricipation of 1700-1900 mm.

Relict beech forests of the Macin Mountains, of extremely insular distribution, isolated within the steppe climate of the Romanian Dobrogea, far from the main beech regions of the Carpathians, with [Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus taurica] ([Fagus taurica] var. [dobrogica]), [Tilia tomentosa], [Tilia cordata], [Fraxinus ornus], [Fraxinus angustifolia], [Fraxinus pallisiae], [Carpinus betulus], [Populus tremula], [Ulmus glabra], [Fagetalia] species and southern European species, including [Potentilla micrantha], [Scutellaria altissima], in the herb layer.

Beech forests of the northern slopes of the southernmost mountain range of the Crimean Peninsula at altitudes between 600 m and 1100 m, on Jurassic substrates, under a climate regime of cool temperatures and moderate precipitation
Beech, beech-hornbeam and beech-fir forests of the Caucasus.

[Fagus orientalis] forests of the 1200-1300 m level of the southern flank of the central Caucasus, with [Quercus petraea], [Tilia cordata], [Acer laetum], [Acer campestre], [Rhododendron luteum], [Corylus avellana], [Cornus australis], [Lonicera caprifolium], [Crataegus kyrtostyla], [Euonymus latifolia], [Rubus caucasicus], [Galium odoratum], [Aruncus sylvestris], [Salvia glutinosa], [Polygonatum multiflorum], [Polygonatum polyanthemum], [Viola reichenbachiana], [Epilobium montanum], [Pulmonaria dacica], [Orobus laxifolius], [Festuca drymaea], [Festuca altissima], [Brachypodium sylvaticum].

Nombre oficial: Caucasian bittercress and fern beech-hornbeam forests
Definición oficial: [Fagus orientalis]-[Carpinus caucasica] forests of the 1200-1700 m level of the southern flank of the central Caucasus, with [Rhododendron luteum], [Euonymus latifolia], [Rubus caucasicus], [Tamus communis], [Galium odoratum], [Aruncus sylvestris], [Salvia glutinosa], [Polygonatum multiflorum], [Polygonatum polyanthemum], [Viola reichenbachiana], [Epilobium montanum], [Pulmonaria dacica], [Dentaria bulbifera], [Cardamine impatiens], [Festuca drymaea], [Festuca altissima].

[Fagus orientalis]-[Carpinus caucasica] forests of the 1200-1300 m level of the southern flank of the central Caucasus, with [Rubus caucasicus], [Salvia glutinosa], [Dentaria bulbifera], [Cardamine impatiens], [Paris incompleta].

[Fagus orientalis]-[Carpinus caucasica] forests of the 1200-1700 m level of the southern flank of the central Caucasus, with [Polystichum braunii], [Polystichum lonchitis], [Phyllitis scolopendrium], [Matteuccia struthiopteris].

[Fagus orientalis] forests of steep ubacs the 1800 m level of the southern flank of the central Caucasus, with [Rhododendron luteum], [Euonymus latifolia], [Rubus caucasicus], [Daphne alboviana], [Galium odoratum], [Aruncus sylvestris], [Salvia glutinosa], [Polygonatum multiflorum], [Polygonatum polyanthemum], [Polygonatum verticillatum], [Viola reichenbachiana], [Epilobium montanum], [Pulmonaria dacica], [Petasites albus], [Senecio platyphylloides], [Euphorbia macroceras], [Gentiana schistocalyx], [Valeriana tiliaefolia], [Festuca drymaea], [Festuca altissima],

Timberline [Fagus orientalis] forests of the subalpine level of the southern flank of the central Caucasus, with [Rhododendron luteum], [Euonymus latifolia], [Rubus caucasicus], [Galium odoratum], [Aruncus sylvestris], [Salvia glutinosa], [Polygonatum multiflorum], [Polygonatum polyanthemum], [Viola reichenbachiana], [Epilobium montanum], [Pulmonaria dacica], [Veratrum lobelianum], [Aconitum orientale], [Asperula caucasica], [Swertia iberica], [Delphinium bracteosum], [Festuca drymaea], [Festuca altissima].

[Fagus orientalis]-[Abies nordmannia] forests of ubacs of the 1400-2200 m level of the northern flank of the Great Caucasus, with [Ulmus glabra], [Rhododendron luteum], [Euonymus latifolia], [Rubus caucasicus], [Galium odoratum], [Aruncus sylvestris], [Salvia glutinosa], [Polygonatum multiflorum], [Polygonatum polyanthemum], [Viola reichenbachiana], [Epilobium montanum], [Pulmonaria dacica], [Geranium robertianum], [Paris incompleta], [Mycelis muralis], [Ranunculus astrantifolius], [Festuca drymaea], [Festuca altissima], [Dryopteris filix-mas], [Dryopteris carthusiana].

[Fagus orientalis]-[Abies nordmannia] forests of acid podzolized soils of the Great and central Caucasus, with [Daphne glomerata], [Vaccinium arctostaphylos], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Orthilia secunda], [Pyrola media], [Luzula sylvatica].

Beech-dominated facies of the [Fagus orientalis]-[Quercus petraea]-[Carpinus caucasica] forests of the 1200-1300 m level of the southern flank of the Central Caucasus of central Georgia, with [Clinopodium vulgare], [Primula macrocalyx], [Salvia glutinosa], [Fragaria vesca], [Epilobium montanum], [Melica uniflora], [Poa nemoralis]. More mixed or hornbeam-dominated stands are listed in unit 41.H311.

Forests of [Fagus orientalis] on north slopes of the Elburz Mountains, at the 1400-1800 metre level, under the climatic influence of the Caspian Sea, with cool temperatures and moderate annual precipitation, typically with abundant snowfall
Isolated beech forests of the Taurus system in western and southern Anatolia (Muraldag, Garur Daglari).
Beech forests of the nemoral zone of the East Asian floral domaine, formed by [Fagus crenata] and [Fagus japonica] in Japan, by [Fagus multinervis] in Korea.

Beech forests of Japan, distributed on southern Hokkaido, on Honshu and, locally, on Kyushu, at elevations between about 500 and 1700 m, within the cool-temperate to subalpine transition zones, formed by [Fagus crenata] or [Fagus japonica], often associated with other broad-leaved trees including [Quercus crispula], [Acer spp.], [Betula ermanii], [Zelkova serrata], or with conifers, [Abies spp.], [Thujopsis dolobrata], [Picea spp.], [Cryptomeria japonica], with an understorey that may be formed of [Sasa kurilensis], [Sasamorpha purpurascens] or ferns.

Beech forests of Japan dominated by [Fagus crenata], sometimes associated with [Fagus japonica], widespread, in particular, in southwestern Hokkaido, on the Pacific side of northern Honshu, on mesic flat areas of the mountainous Pacific side of central Honshu, in southwestern Honshu and in the highlands of Kyushu.

Beech forests of Japan dominated by [Fagus japonica], recorded, in particular, from the central and southern parts of the Sea of Japan watershed of northern Honshu, where it associates with [Abies firma] and [Zelkova serrata].

Forests of [Fagus multinervis] of the volcanic Ulisung Island situated 130 km to the east of the Korean mainland, developed under a humid temperate climate with a short cold period. The beech is accompanied by two Asiatic [Acer] species, by [Prunus takesimensis], [Tilia insularis], [Sorbus commixta], [Styrax obassia], [Cornus controversa]. The shrub layer includes [Ligustrum foliosum] and [Rhododendron brachycarpum], the herb layer, [Maianthemum dilatatum], [Hepatica maxima], [Smilax riparia], [Diosporum sessile], [Solidago virgaurea], [Phryma leptostachya], the bamboo [Sasa kurilense] and four species of genus [Viola].

[Fagus sylvatica] and, in higher mountains, [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies alba] or [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies alba]-[Picea abies] forests developed on acid soils of the medio-European domaine of central and northern Central Europe, with [Luzula luzuloides], [Polytrichum formosum] and often [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Calamagrostis villosa], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Pteridium aquilinum].

Acidophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the lesser Hercynian ranges and Lorraine, of the collinar level of the western greater Hercynian ranges, the Jura and the Alpine periphery, of the western sub-Pannonic and the intra-Pannonic hills, not or little accompanied by spontaneous conifers, and generally with an admixture of [Quercus petraea], or in some cases [Quercus robur], in the canopy.

Nombre oficial: Western Hercynian collinar woodrush beech forests
Definición oficial: Acidophilous forests of [Fagus sylvatica], or [Fagus sylvatica] and [Quercus petraea], of the western lesser Hercynian ranges, of Lorraine and of the collinar level of the western greater Hercynian ranges, in particular of the Black Forest, forming a western group of communities with a cort¿ge rich in Atlantic species, characterized in particular by the presence of [Teucrium scorodonia].

Acidophilous forests of [Fagus sylvatica], or [Fagus sylvatica] and [Quercus petraea], of the Neckar, the Spessart, the Rh¿n, the Swabio-Franconian Forest, of the collinar level of the Thringian Forest and of the Swabian and Franconian Jura, forming a subcontinental ensemble of communities poor in Atlantic species, and characterized, in particular, by the frequent prevalence of [Poa chaixii].
Acidophilous forests of [Fagus sylvatica], or [Fagus sylvatica] and [Quercus robur] of the collinar level of the northern Alpine periphery.

Nombre oficial: Western sub-Pannonic collinar woodrush beech forests
Definición oficial: Acidophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the eastern Alpine periphery, in the hills of western Transdanubia, with a canopy that sometimes contains [Castanea sativa], a generally poorly developed shrub layer, an herb layer rich in [Cyclamen purpurascens], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Hieracium silvaticum], [Melampyrum pratense], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Calluna vulgaris], [Calamagrostis arundinacea], [Galium rotundifolium] and a moss cover generally rich in [Dicranum scoparium] with an abundance of [Leucobryum glaucum].

Acidophilous [Fagus sylvatica] forests of Pannonic hills, mixed with [Betula pendula] and [Quercus petraea], with a poorly developed shrub layer, an herb layer rich in [Luzula luzuloides], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Hieracium silvaticum], [Monotropa hypopitys], [Pyrola spp.], and without [Cyclamen purpurascens] or [Galium rotundifolium], a rich moss cover comprising [Polytrichum spp.], [Dicranum scoparium], [Leucobryum glaucum], [Hylocomium proliferum].

Acidophilous forests of [Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus sylvatica] and [Abies alba] or [Fagus sylvatica], [Abies alba] and [Picea abies] of the submontane, montane and high montane levels of the greater Hercynian ranges, from the Vosges and the Black Forest to the Bohemian Quadrangle, of the Thringian Forest, of the Jura, the Alps, the Carpathians and the Bavarian Plateau.

Acidophilous forests of [Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus sylvatica] and [Abies alba] or [Fagus sylvatica], [Abies alba] and [Picea abies] of the montane and high montane levels of the eastern greater Hercynian ranges, the Thringian Forest, the Swabian and Franconian Jura, the Alps, where they are mostly expressed in the eastern Alps, and, in a dry version, in some parts of the western intermediate Alps, the Carpathians and the Bavarian Plateau, including, in particular, the remarkable near-natural montane woodrush beech forests of the Bayerischer Wald.

Nombre oficial: Western medio-European montane woodrush beech forests
Definición oficial: Acidophilous forests of [Fagus sylvatica], [Fagus sylvatica] and [Abies alba] or [Fagus sylvatica], [Abies alba] and [Picea abies] of the montane and high montane levels of the Vosges, the Black Forest, the Odenwald, the French and Swiss Jura, accompanied by sub-Atlantic species and characterized in particular by the presence of [Digitalis purpurea], less developed and generally more transformed by exploitation than those of unit 41.1121.

[Fagus sylvatica] or [Fagus sylvatica]-[Quercus spp.] forests developed on acid soils of the Atlantic domaine of Western Europe, differing from the forests of unit 41.11 by, in particular, the absence of [Luzula luzuloides] and a greater abundance of [Ilex aquifolium].

Fragmented and insularized acidophile [Fagus sylvaticus] forests of the western seaboard of Europe, in Denmark, southern Scandinavia, northern Germany, northern and eastern Poland, the Netherlands, middle Belgium, Picardy, Normandy and southern England.
Transition forests of the Paris basin, the Morvan, the periphery of the Central Massif, the eastern and central Pyrenees.
Hyper-Atlantic forests of Brittany with an abundance of epiphytes and an understory of ferns and evergreen bushes.
Humid forests with luxuriant epiphytism of the western Pyrenees and eastern Cantabrian mountains.
Humid acidophilous beech forests of western Cantabrian and Asturian mountains.
Humid beech forests of high, snowy dolomitic and calcareous sierras of Galicia (Ancares, Cebreiro, Caurel), somewhat intermediate between unit 41.12 and unit 41.13.
Humid acidophilous beech forests of the Northern Iberian Range.
Hyper-humid acidophilous beech forests of the Northern Iberian Range.
Relict acidophilous beech forests of the Sierra de Ayllon.

[Fagus sylvatica] and, in higher mountains, [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies alba] or [Fagus sylvatica]-[Abies alba]-[Picea abies] forests developed on neutral or near-neutral soils, with mild humus (mull), of the medio-European and Atlantic domaines of Western Europe and of central and northern Central Europe, characterized by a strong representation of species belonging to the ecological groups of [Anemone nemorosa], of [Lamium galeobdolon], of [Galium odoratum] and [Melica uniflora] and, in mountains, various [Dentaria spp.], forming a richer and more abundant herb layer than in the forests of units 41.11 and 41.12.

Neutrocline or basicline [Fagus sylvatica] and [Fagus sylvatica]-[Quercus petraea]-[Quercus robur] forests of hills, low mountains and plateaux of the Hercynian arc and its peripheral regions, of the Jura, Lorraine, the Paris basin, Burgundy, the Alpine piedmont, the Carpathians and a few localities of the North Sea-Baltic plain.

Slightly moist [Fagus sylvatica] forests developed over calcareous bedrock on stony, neutral or weakly acid rendzina or similar humus-carbonate soils, with [Galium odoratum], [Melica uniflora], [Mercurialis perennis], [Lathyrus vernus], [Asarum europaeum], [Hordelymus europaeus], [Epipactis helleborine], [Epipactis leptochila], [Neottia nidus-avis], [Circaea lutetiana], [Viola reichenbachiana], distributed locally on the hills, low mountains and plateaux of the Hercynian arc and its peripheral regions, from the Ardenne-Eifel to Moravia, and north to Denmark and southern Sweden, in the entire Jura catena, in Lorraine and the eastern Paris basin, in Burgundy, in the Bavarian Alpine piedmont, the Vorarlberg limestone Alps, the Wienerwald. They include the Central European [Fagus]-[Mercurialis perennis] forests, as well as occasional stands exceptionally rich in spring-flowering geophytes, sometimes known as wild garlic-rich beech woods.

Nombre oficial: Medio-European woodruff and hairy sedge beech forests
Definición oficial: [Fagus sylvatica] forests of sub-Atlantic Western and Central Europe, north to Denmark, southern Norway, southern Sweden and Poland, developed on a more or less deep layer of brown loess-loam, less rich in calciphile plants and richer in acid- and drought-tolerant species

Neutrocline [Fagus sylvatica] forests rich in [Melica uniflora] of the northern and northwestern part of the Hercynian and Germano-Baltic range of the medio-European woodruff beech forests, in particular, in the Ardennes, northern Germany and Denmark.
Neutrocline [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the central and eastern part of the Hercynian, Jurassian and peri-Alpine range of the woodruff beech forests.
Neutrocline [Fagus sylvatica] forests of the southwestern part of the range of the Medio-European woodruff beech forests, rich in, and sometimes entirely dominated by, [Carex brizoides].
Western outposts, in particular in upper Hesse and northeastern Switzerland, of the mostly peri-Carpathian hairy sedge beech forests, with a field layer dominated by [Carex pilosa].

Nombre oficial: Western peri-Carpathian hairy sedge beech forests
