Xero-mesophile, neutrophile mixed [Quercus pedunculiflora] forests of the northern Dobrogea plateaux, with [Tilia tomentosa], [Carpinus orientalis], [Carpinus betulus], [Fraxinus excelsior], [Fraxinus ornus] in the tree layer, numerous sub-Mediterranean species, including [Ornithogalum fimbriatum], [Viola jordanii], [Paeonia peregrina], [Myrrhoides nodosa], [Mercurialis ovata], [Piptatherum virescens], and a few [Fagetalia] species, [Zerna benekenii], [Pulmonaria obscura], in the herb layer.

Sub-continental thermo-xerophile [Quercus frainetto-Quercus cerris-Quercus petraea] forests of the foothills bordering the lower Danube depression of southern Romania, with the continental [Acer tataricum] and lacking typically sub-Mediterranean species such as [Carpinus orientalis] and [Ruscus aculeatus].

Xero-mesophile, weakly acidophile forests of [Quercus cerris], of the plains of southern Romania, with [Acer campestre], [Acer tataricum], [Crataegus monogyna], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Cornus mas], [Potentilla alba], [Lychnis coronaria], [Viola hirta], [Polygonatum latifolium], [Chrysanthemum corymbosum].

Xero-mesophile, acidophile [Quercus frainetto] forests of Muntenia and Oltenia, with [Acer campestre], [Pyrus pyraster], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Crataegus monogyna], [Carex praecox], [Genista tinctoria], [Veronica officinalis], [Poa angustifolia], [Lychnis coronaria], [Calamagrostis epigejos].

Xeromesophile, weakly acidophile forests of [Quercus cerris] and [Quercus frainetto] of the plains in the southern of Romania, with [Acer campestre] and [Acer tataricum],  accompanied by [Ligustrum vulgare], [Crataegus monogyna], [Crocus flavus], [Lychnis coronaria], [Genista tinctoria], [Lathyrus niger], [Chrysanthemum corymbosum], [Polygonatum latifolium].

Weakly acidophile forests of [Quercus cerris], [Quercus frainetto] and [Quercus petraea] [s.l.] of the southern and western pre-Carpathian foothills, accompanied by [Acer campestre], [Acer tataricum], [Fraxinus ornus], [Cornus mas], [Crataegus monogyna], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Lathyrus niger], [Lychnis coronaria], [Helleborus odorus], [Buglossoides purpurocaerulea] ([Lithospermum purpurocaeruleum]), [Sedum maximum], [Sedum cepaea], [Vincetoxicum hirundinaria] ([Cynanchum vincetoxicum]).

Weakly acidophile forests of [Quercus frainetto] and [Quercus petraea] [s.l.] of the southern pre-Carpathian foothills, with a shrub layer composed of [Acer campestre], [Acer tataricum], [Ulmus minor], [Cornus mas], and an herb layer of [Carex praecox], [Carex caryophyllea], [Genista tinctoria], [Potentilla micrantha], [Lychnis coronaria], [Galium pseudaristatum].

Weakly acidophile to neutrophile forests of [Quercus petraea] [s.l.] and [Quercus cerris] of the southern pre-Carpathian foothills, with [Acer campestre], [Acer tataricum], [Sorbus torminalis], sometimes [Tilia tomentosa], [Cerasus avium], [Fagus sylvatica], [Fraxinus ornus], participating in the tree layer, accompanied by [Crataegus monogyna], [Ligustrum vulgare] in the shrub layer and [Genista tinctoria], [Lathyrus niger], [Silene viridiflora], [Buglossoides purpurocaerulea] ([Lithospermum purpurocaeruleum]), [Chrysanthemum corymbosum] in the herb layer.

Iberian and North African forests and woods dominated by [Quercus faginea],  [Quercus canariensis] or [Quercus afares]. The humid formations of southwestern Iberia (units 41.772 and 41.773) are forest types of unique character in Europe and of extreme biological importance
Xero-mesophile [Quercus faginea] formations of slopes and plateaux of middle elevations of the Spanish Meseta and associated ranges.
[Quercus faginea] forests of the supra-Mediterranean, sub-humid level of the Cantabrian periphery and upper Ebro basin.
[Quercus faginea] forests of the meso-supra-Mediterranean levels of the Iberian Range, upper Douro basin and neighbouring regions.
[Quercus faginea] forests of the meso-supra-Mediterranean levels of the Maestrazgo, interior Catalonia and adjacent Aragon.

Southern forests of the sub-humid to humid supra-Mediterranean level of calcareous Baetic ranges, limited to a few enclaves in the Serrania de Ronda and the ranges of the upper Guadalquivir basin, dominated by [Quercus faginea] associated with [Acer granatense], [Acer monspessulanum], [Sorbus aria], [Sorbus torminalis], [Taxus baccata] and sometimes [Quercus pyrenaica].
[Quercus faginea] forests of ubacs of the southern Valencian mountains (Aitana, Montcabrer, Benicadell), with [Acer granatense], [Fraxinus ornus] and [Taxus baccata].
Humid, epiphyte-clad, dense, relict [Quercus faginea] forests of Portugal, restricted to a very few isolated localities.
Humid and hyper-humid, luxuriant [Quercus canariensis] forests of the sierras of extreme southern Spain, limited to the Aljibe and a very few localities in the Serrania de Ronda.
Formations of Catalonia rich in [Quercus canariensis].
Relict formations of Mallorca dominated by, or rich in, [Quercus faginea].

Montane forests, sometimes tall and closed canopied, of [Quercus canariensis] ([Quercus faginea] ssp. [baetica], [Quercus mirbeckii], [Quercus nordafricana], [Quercus faginea] ssp. tlemcenensis]), pure, or accompanied by [Quercus suber] or [Quercus afares], occupying cool, rainy slopes and tops of the Rif, the Middle Atlas, the Oulmes plateau, the Tell, the Kroumirian mountains, and, very locally, the High Atlas and the Aures. The shrub layer is rather sparce and includes, besides saplings of the dominant species, [Erica arborea], [Crataegus monogyna], [Myrtus communis], [Arbutus unedo], [Cytisus villosus], [Rubus ulmifolius], [Daphne gnidium], [Lonicera etrusca], [Hedera helix], and in very humid valleys, [Laurus nobilis]. The herb layer is abundant and rich, comprising the vernal [Ranunculus ficaria] ssp. [ficariiformis] ([Ficaria grandiflora]) and [Chrysanthemum], as well as [Agrimonia eupatoria], [Achillea ligustica], [Cyclamen africanum], [Satureja vulgaris] Fritsch, [Polystichum aculeatum], [Galium aparine], [Prunella vulgaris], [Carex remota], locally, [Pteridium aquilinum], [Sanicula europaea] or [Hypericum androsaemum]. Epyphytic growth is moderate, notably of [Polypodium vulgare] and lichens.

[Quercus afares] stands or forests, pure or associated with [Quercus canariensis], limited to high altitudes in the Tell and the eastern Kroumirian mountains, in somewhat drier situations than those occupied by [Quercus canariensis] forest, though more humid than those characteristic of [Quercus suber] forests
Supra-Mediterranean, and occasionally meso-mediterranean woods dominated by the semideciduous [Quercus trojana] or its allies.

Usually low formations dominated by [Quercus trojana], often with junipers or maples, of Macedonia, Thrace and Thessaly, north to Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania and the the F.Y.R. of Macedonia, in the Vardar valley.

Relict woods, sometimes of considerable height, of [Quercus trojana] and [Quercus pubescens], often with an admixture of [Quercus ilex] and its associated vegetation (Murge: e.g. bosco delle Pianelle, foresta Gaglione).
Woods or stands of [Quercus trojana] of the mesomediterranean or supramediterranean levels of western Anatolia, at altitudes below 900 metres.

Supra-Mediterranean forests dominated by [Quercus look], established at or near the xeric fringes of the Mediterranean domaine, best developed on lthe eastern slopes of the Lebanon mountains, the Anti-Lebanon and Mount Hermon, with a cort¿ge of mixed Mediterranean and Irano-Turanian species, including [Quercus boissieri], [Juniperus drupacea], [Sorbus graeca], [Amygdalus korshinskyi], [Prunus ursina], [Colutea cilicica], [Berberis cretica], [Eriolobus trilobatus], [Phlomis braevilaeris], [Picris strigosa], [Kundmannia syriaca].
Woods dominated by the semideciduous [Quercus macrolepis], often fairly open, of the mostly meso-Mediterranean zone of Greece, Albania, western Asia, and, very locally, southern Italy.
[Quercus macrolepis] formations of continental Greece and its archipelagoes, as well as of ajacent Albania
Relict [Quercus macrolepis] formations of Salento (Tricase).

Forests, woods or stands of [Quercus macrolepis] of Anatolia, mostly limited to western Anatolia, with a few outlying patches east to Siirt, sometimes forming extensive, handsome forests, particularly in the lower montane zone and in intermountain plains

[Quercus ithaburensis]-dominated forests of the mesomediterranean zone of southern Anatolia and the Near East, occupying extensive areas in Palestine and Jordan, occurring farther north in the Golan Heights, in the plain of Adana, in the plain of Hatay, in Maras province, and in a few localities of the Taurus mountains.

Nonalluvial deciduous or semideciduous forests or woods of submediterranean climate regions and supramediterranean altitudinal levels, and of western Eurasian steppe and substeppe zones, dominated by [Ostrya carpinifolia], [Carpinus orientalis], [Acer spp.], [Fraxinus spp.], [Tilia spp.] or [Celtis australis]

Brushy liana-rich woods of deep ravines of Crete, formed by [Ficus carica], [Pistacia terebinthus], [Celtis tournefortii], [Cotinus coggygria], [Rhus coriaria], [Amelanchier ovalis] ssp. [cretica], [Sorbus aria] ssp. [cretica], [Sorbus umbellata], restricted to a few calcareous cliffs. They appear to have affinities with the Irano-Turanian steppe woods of unit 41.89 and with the southern Palaearctic ravine and valley tropical dry woodland of units 4B.4 and 4B.5.
Forests or woods of submediterranean, sometimes mesomediterranean, climate regions and supramediterranean altitudinal levels dominated by [Ostrya carpinifolia].
[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated ravine forests of the mesomediterranean [Quercus ilex] zone of the Maritime and Ligurian Alps.

[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the supramediterranean zone of the Maritime and Ligurian Alps, the Mediterranean and Adriatic slope of the southeastern Alps, the Dinarides, the Hellenides, the Apennines and the large central Mediterranean islands.
[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the supramediterranean zone of the Maritime and Ligurian Alps.

[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the supramediterranean zone of the Mediterranean and Adriatic slope of the southeastern Alps, in the Gardesano- Dolomitic and Veneto-Julian sectors of Italy and extreme northwestern Slovenia.
[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the supramediterranean [Ostryo-Carpinion orientalis] zone of the Adriatic region of the western Balkan peninsula and of Greece.
[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the supramediterranean zone of the northern and central Apennines.
[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the supramediterranean zone of Corsica, limited to the northeastern part of the island.
[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the supramediterranean zone of the southern Appenines, Sardinia and Sicily.

[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the montane [Fagion medio-europaeum], [Fagion illyricum], [Fagion moesiacum], [Fagion dacicum], [Fagion hellenicum],   developed at the upper limit of the altitudinal range of the forests of units 41.812 or 41.814, with an accompanying flora usually formed by a combination of beech forest and thermophilous oak forest species.

[Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated woods of the [Carpinion illyricum] zone of the Sava and Drava basin, with irradiations into the southeastern Alps, in particular, in the Karawanken and in the eastern Dinarides, extending from southern Austria to Bosnia-Herzegovina.

Mostly low woods of sunny, shallow-soil limestone and dolomite slopes of the [Carpinion illyricum] zone of northern Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia, dominated  by [Ostrya carpinifolia], facies of the [Querco-Ostryetum carpinifoliae] hop-hornbeam oak woods of unit 41.73751.

[Ostrya carpinifolia] woods of generally steep dolomite or limestone slopes and screes of the [Carpinion illyricum] region of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina, extending north to Austria in the Drava basin, the Karawanken and, very locally, the middle Inn Valley, with [Fraxinus ornus], [Sorbus aria], [Acer obtusatum], a rich shrub layer formed by [Viburnum lantana], [Juniperus communis], [Berberis vulgaris], [Rosa spp.], [Amelanchier ovalis], [Clematis vitalba] and an herb layer dominated by [Sesleria albicans] and [Carex humilis] on rocky slopes, by [Erica herbacea] ([Erica carnea]) on scree slopes
Uncommon [Ostrya carpinifolia]-dominated facies of thermophilous woods of the Taurus, the Amanus.

[Carpinus orientalis]-dominated facies of the thermophilous woods of units 41.73, 41.74, 41.76, particulary abundant in Greece, the middle Balkan peninsula, Anatolia and the Caucasus. Often of secondary nature, they replace oak forests on eroded soil after deforestation, especially on calcareous soils.

Thermophilous [Carpinus orientalis]-dominated woods of the [Carpinion betuli illyricum] and [Fagion illyricum] regions of northern and central Bosnia-Herzegovina, where they occupy sunny calcareous slopes, and of the Sava-Drava interfluve hills, between the Papuk Range and the Fruska Gora.
[Carpinus orientalis]-dominated facies of thermophilous woods of the Balkan peninsula, south to Greece.
Low woods of northern Greece, Albania, the F.Y.R. of Macedonia and southwestern Bulgaria, including the northern and eastern foothills of the Rhodopes, dominated by [Carpinus orientalis].
Low woods of Serbia and central Bulgaria, in particular, the foothills of the Balkan Range, dominated by [Carpinus orientalis].
Low woods of eastern Serbia, western Bulgaria and the Banat, Oltenia and Muntenia in southwestern Romania, dominated by [Carpinus orientalis], rich in [Syringa vulgaris].

Low woods of northern Bulgaria, the Banat and Oltenia, dominated by [Carpinus orientalis], with [Fraxinus ornus], [Cotinus coggygria], [Oryzopsis holciformis], [Oxytropis virescens], [Stachys leucoglossa], [Paeonia peregrina], [Salvia ringens], [Cornus mas], [Quercus pubescens].

Woods of the [Ostryo-Carpinion orientalis] region of the western Balkan peninsula, developed in the supramediterranean level of the Triestine Riviera, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Montenegro, northern Albania, dominated by [Carpinus orientalis].
[Carpinus orientalis]-dominated facies of thermophilous woods of the Caucasus, the foothills of the Pontic Range, the Taurus, the Amanus and Alaouites.
Supra-Mediterranean thermophilous woods dominated by [Acer spp.]

Supra-Mediterranean formations of the mountains of the upper Guadalquivir, with [Acer granatense], [Acer monspessulanum], [Quercus faginea], [Quercus pyrenaica], [Sorbus aria], [Sorbus torminalis], [Taxus baccata], [Daphne laureola], [Paeonia officinalis] ssp. [humilis]. Vestiges of this type of vegetation also survive in the Serrania de Ronda.

Formations, extremely rare if not extinct, of the mountains of Majorca (Puig de Ma¿anella, Puig Major), dominated by [Acer granatense], with [Quercus faginea], [Amelanchier ovalis] ssp. [comafredensis], [Ilex aquifolium] var. [balearica], [Helleborus foetidus] var. [balearicus], [Sorbus aria], [Primula acaulis] var. [balearica], [Rubus ulmifolius], [Tamus communis], [Taxus baccata], [Hedera helix], [Smilax aspera] var. [balearica], [Paeonia cambessedesii], several of which are relict endemic taxa of very limited distribution and low numbers.
Low (eight metres tall) [Acer monspessulanum]-dominated forest of the Djebel Zaghouan in the Tunisian Dorsale, with a dominated stratum of [Quercus ilex].

Low [Acer monspessulanum]- or [Acer campestre]-dominated woods of the xerothermic oak belt of the Balkan peninsula, in Albania, the western F.Y.R. of Macedonia, southern Serbia and western and southern Bulgaria, in particular, of the northeastern Rhodope foothills and the northwestern Balkan Range.

Supra-, sub- or mesomediterranean and Euro-Siberian steppe woods dominated by [Tilia spp.], for the most part, supra-, meso- or sub-Mediterranean [Tilia spp.] -dominated facies of the thermophilous woods of units 41.73, 41.74, 41.76, 41.7A.

[Tilia tomentosa]-dominated facies of mixed deciduous forests of southern Central Europe and the northern and middle part of the Balkan peninsula, mostly within the [Quercion frainetto] environment, but also locally developed in conjunction with eastern [Carpinion betuli] forests.

[Tilia tomentosa]-dominated facies of mixed deciduous forests of Moesian hills of the Balkan peninsula, in particular, [Tilia tomentosa] woods of the sub-Mediterranean hornbeam-durmast oak belt of Bulgaria and Northern Greece.

[Tilia tomentosa] lime forests of the plains of Muntenia, near Bucharest, evolution stages of mixed forests of [Quercus robur] ([Quercus petraea]), [Carpinus betulus], [Tilia tomentosa], [Fraxinus spp.].

[Tilia tomentosa] steppe woods of Pannonic affinities developed on dry sands of Deliblat, with [Quercus robur], [Prunus mahaleb], [Fraxinus ornus], [Acer campestre], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Crataegus monogyna], [Viburnum lantanum], [Lonicera xylosteum].

Loosely closed forests mainly of [Tilia platyphyllos] and [Fraxinus excelsior] developed on shallow soils of exposed crests of limestone mountains (more rarely on andesite rocks) of the Northern Hungarian Range, with an herb layer of [Brachypodium pinnatum], [Galium erectum], [Cruciata glabra], [Digitalis grandiflora], [Erysimum odoratum], [Sisymbrium strictissimum], [Aconitum anthora], accompanied by endemics among which [Hesperis vrabelyiana], [Carduus collinus] and by other regionally rare species with disjunct distribution, such as [Waldsteinia geoides], [Melica altissima], [Carex brevicollis]. They constitute relict forests, most probably of the Boreal era, and are of great biological value.

Thermophilous woods dominated by, or rich in, [Celtis australis]. Forests dominated by [Celtis australis] may have been an important component of Mediterranean woodland, in particular in North Africa, but appear to have been destroyed almost everywhere and to be represented only by individual trees and small stands.
Nonalluvial, non-ravine meso-, supra- or sub-Mediterranean thermophilous woods dominated by [Fraxinus angustifolia] or [Fraxinus ornus], often mixed with [Quercus pubescens] or [Quercus pyrenaica].
[Fraxinus angustifolia] woods of western Sicily.
[Fraxinus angustifolia] woods of the Iberian peninsula.

Thermophilous [Fraxinus ornus] woods, characteristic, in particular, of the Banat hills and the pre-Balkanic plateaux and hills of the lower Danube basin, dominated by [Fraxinus ornus] with [Cornus sanguinea], [Tilia platyphyllos], [Tilia tomentosa], [Ulmus minor], [Carpinus orientalis].

[Fraxinus dimorpha] woods of the Aures where they mostly occur in a narrow belt between [Quercus rotundifolia] and [Cedrus atlantica] forests, and of the Tunisian Dorsale where they are limited to higher slopes at around 1300 m, near Maktar.

[Populus alba] woods of sands, in particular sand dunes, of the Danube-Tisza confluence of the Pannonic plain. The shrub layer includes [Juniperus communis], [Ligustrum vulgare], [Rhamnus catharticus], [Crataegus monogyna], [Prunus spinosa], [Prunus mahaleb], [Rubus caesius], [Euonymus verrucosus], [Berberis vulgaris].

Closed [Populus alba] forests of the Pannonian Danube-Tisza interfluvial region with a species-rich and strongly developed shrub layer and an herb layer comprising [Lithospermum officinale], [Teucrium chamaedrys], [Asparagus officinalis], [Vincetoxicum hirundinaria], [Polygonatum odoratum], [Poa angustifolia], [Euphorbia cyparissias], [Poa pratensis], [Senecio integrifolius], [Silene nutans], [Verbascum lychnitis] and [Solanum dulcamara] var. [pusztarum], frequently with the mosses [Dicranum scoparium] and [Hypnum cupressiforme].

[Populus alba] woods of the Pannonian Danube-Tisza interfluvial region with an herb layer dominated by [Carex liparocarpos], accompanied by [Potentilla arenaria], [Thesium ramosum], [Viola rupestris] var. [arenaria], [Galium verum], [Lithospermum officinale], [Medicago falcata], [Phleum phleoides], [Pimpinella saxifraga], [Calamagrostis epigejos], [Taraxacum officinale], [Colchicum arenarium], [Iris humilis] ssp. [arenaria].

[Populus alba] woods of the Pannonian Danube-Tisza interfluvial region with an herb layer formed by [Gypsophila fastigiata] ssp. [arenaria], [Stipa capillata], [Ephedra distachya], [Alkanna tinctoria], [Potentilla arenaria], [Scabiosa ochroleuca] and sometimes stands of [Calamagrostis epigejos].

Nonalluvial deciduous or semideciduous thermophilous forests or woods of submediterranean or supramediterranean regions of the Mediterranean basin, and of the Pannonic plain, formed by [Tilia spp.], [Fraxinus spp.], [Quercus spp.], [Carpinus spp.], [Ostrya carpinifolia], [Acer spp.], [Sorbus spp.], [Populus spp.], [Celtis australis] and occasionally, [Fagus spp.], in varied combinations and dominance.

Mixed woods of [Tilia spp.], [Fraxinus spp.], [Quercus spp.], [Carpinus spp.], [Ostrya carpinifolia], [Sorbus spp.], [Populus spp.] and occasionally, [Fagus spp.] of the Mediterranean, supra-Mediterranean and sub-Mediterranean [Quercion pubescenti-petraeae], [Ostryo-Carpinion] and [Quercion frainetto] zones.

Mixed woods of dolomitic substrates of the periphery and hills of the Pannonic plain, in Hungary, southern Slovakia and Croatia, characterized by the juxtaposition of beech wood and thermophile oak wood species, rich in relict species of disjunct distribution such as [Calamagrostis varia], [Allium victorialis], [Rubus saxatilis], [Primula auricula] ssp. [hungarica], and therefore of great biogeographical significance.

Varied steppe forests or woods of submediterranean climate regions and supramediterranean altitudinal levels of western and central Asian steppe and substeppe zones, including eastern Anatolia, Iran, Syria and Afghanistan, the western Himalayan systems and adjacent regions, and semiarid zones of mediterranean North Africa, formed of fruit or nut-bearing trees, including [Pistacia spp.], [Amygdalus spp.], [Malus spp.], [Pyrus spp.], [Prunus spp.], [Juglans regia] and often with [Acer spp.], [Rosa spp.], [Crataegus spp.], [Ulmus spp.], [Celtis caucasia], [Vitis hissarica].

Nombre oficial: Western Asian wild fruit tree steppe woods
Definición oficial: Usually open or very open stands of [Pistacia spp.], [Amygdalus spp.], [Malus spp.], [Pyrus spp.], [Prunus spp.], [Juglans regia] and other fruit or nut-bearing trees, often associated with [Acer spp.], [Rosa spp.], [Crataegus spp.], of the steppes and subdesert fringes of eastern Anatolia, Iran, Syria and Afghanistan, with a probable outpost in the central plains of Cyprus.

Mixed open or very open stands of [Pistacia atlantica], [Amygdalus orientalis], and other arborescent or shrubby Rosaceae of genera [Amygdalus], [Malus], [Pyrus], [Prunus], [Rosa], [Crataegus], with [Juglans regia], [Acer spp.], of the steppes and subdesert fringes of eastern Anatolia, Iran, Afghanistan, Syria and the Levant.

Mixed open or very open stands of [Pistacia atlantica], accompanied by shrubby Rosaceae of genera [Amygdalus], [Malus], [Pyrus], [Prunus], [Rosa], [Crataegus], by [Juglans regia], or by [Acer spp.], of the steppes and subdesert fringes of western Asia.
Mixed open or very open stands of [Amygdalus orientalis], or other arborescent Rosaceae of genera [Amygdalus] and [Pyrus], of the steppes and subdesert fringes of western Asia.

Open or very open stands of [Pistacia atlantica], [Ziziphus lotus], [Noaea mucronata], [Amygdalus communis], [Crataegus aronia], [Pyrus syriaca], associated with batha shrubs, of the semisteppic central plain of Cyprus, possible relict of a former climax community.

Broad-leaved deciduous woodland formations of the slopes of the Tien Shan, Pamir-Alai and western Himalayan systems, and of neighbouring hills and plateaux, with [Juglans regia], [Acer spp.], [Ulmus spp.], [Malus siviersii], [Celtis caucasia], [Prunus spp.], [Amygdalus spp.], [Pistacia vera], [Vitis hissarica].
Formations of [Acer spp.], [Ulmus spp.], [Juglans regia] of humid slopes and gorges of the arid western Tien Shan.
[Acer turkestanicum], [Acer pubescens], [Juglans regia], [Vitis hissarica] formations of the higher levels of the Pamir-Alai.
[Juglans regia]-dominated semi-humid forests of the Central Asian mountains, in particular of the western and central Tien-Schan, mostly developed in the 1500-2000 m level.

Formations of [Malus sieversii], [Prunus spp.], [Amygdalus spp.], [Pyrus spp.], with [Elaeagnus spp.], [Sorbus spp.], [Pistacia vera], [Punica granatum] and other wild fruit trees of the Central Asian mountains.

[Pistacia vera]-dominated formations of the slopes of the Kopet Dagh, and of the Pamir-Alai and Tien Shan systems, and of neighbouring plateaux and hills of northeastern Iran, Afghanistan, Tadzhikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Kirgizia and Kazakhstan.

[Pistacia atlantica]-dominated formations of the semiarid level of Mediterranean North Africa, perhaps formerly constituting steppe forests similar to those of Western Asia, now apparently extinct in that form and represented only by individual trees or stands of the terebinth.
Supramediterranean and submediterranean [Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and old established plantations with seminatural undergrowth.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of the foothills and piedmont of the Pontic Range and the Caucasus, characteristic, in particular, of the 100-1100 m level of the Colchidian hills.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of the [Quercion frainetto] zone of the Balkan peninsula, of northern Greece, including the Chalkidike peninsula, with irradiations in the [Ostryo-Carpinion orientalis aegeicum] zone. They appear to represent the main area of indigenousness of the species.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of the Peloponnese, the Aegean islands, Crete and western Asia Minor, occupying scattered, relatively rare localities in the supramediterranean level of mountains ranges.

Submediterranean [Castanea sativa]-dominated acidophilous forests of the [Ostryo-Carpinion orientalis adriaticum] zone of the Balkan peninsula, distributed, in particular, in the Slovenian coastal mountains, in Istria, on the islands of Krk and Cres, in Bosnia-Herzegovina, in Montenegro, within an area of undoubted indigenousness of the species.

Submediterranean [Castanea sativa] forests of the northwestern Balkan peninsula rich in [Erica herbacea] ([Erica carnea]), recorded, in particular, from the coastal mountains of Slovenia, where accompanying trees include [Quercus petraea], [Quercus cerris], [Quercus pubescens], [Pinus nigra].

Submediterranean [Castanea sativa] forests of the northwestern Balkan peninsula rich in brooms, including [Genista pilosa], [Genista germanica], [Genista tinctoria], [Chamaespartium sagittale], recorded, in particular, from the coastal mountains of Slovenia, where accompanying trees include [Quercus petraea].

Submediterranean [Castanea sativa] forests of humid flysch substrates of the northwestern Balkan peninsula rich in [Alnus glutinosa], with a very limited distribution in the coastal mountains of Slovenia.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of the [Carpinion betuli illyricum] zone, locally, notably in Bosnia-Herzegovina, extending into the [Fagion illyricum] zone, apparently constituting, with the subthermophilous oak region of the Balkans, a center of indigenousness of the species. Extensive stands are recorded, in particular, from northwestern Croatia, neighbouring Slovenia, northern, central and eastern Bosnia-Herzegovina.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of the collinar level of the southern slope of the Alps of Italy and southern Switzerland, with a cort¿ge characteristic of medio-European acidophilous oak forests

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of the supramediterranean zone of the Apennines, of lesser hill ranges of the Italian peninsula and of Sicily, at the 200-800 m level and mostly on siliceous soils, for the most part resulting from ancient introductions, probably indigenous in some areas, in particular, Etna and the Euganean hills.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of Corsica and Sardinia, where they may be indigenous and are fairly widespread, particularly in the San Petrone massif of Corsica and in eastern central Sardinia.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of southeastern France, in particular, of the Maures, the C¿vennes and the eastern Pyrenees, where they may be, in part, indigenous and are characteristic of the supramediterranean level, with a cort¿ge of acidophilous [Quercion pubescenti-petraeae] forests.

[Castanea sativa]-dominated forests and naturalized plantations of the Iberian peninsula, southwestern and central France, probably entirely resulting from ancient introductions, common in northwestern Iberia, in Catalonia, in the mountains of central and western Iberia, in Andalucia and, mostly as substitutes of southwestern Atlantic medio-European oak forests in the northwestern piedmont of the Pyrenees and southwestern France, fairly rare in the rest of the Iberian peninsula.
Forests and woodland of native coniferous trees, other than floodplain and mire woods, of the boreal, nemoral, Irano-Turanian, warm-temperate humid and Mediterranean zones

Nombre oficial: Western Palaearctic cypress, juniper and yew forests
Definición oficial: Woods dominated by [Cupressus sempervirens], [Juniperus spp.], [Platycladus orientalis] or [Taxus baccata] of the nemoral and Mediterranean mountains and hills of western Eurasia and North Africa.

[Juniperus phoenicea] ssp. [phoenicea] and [Juniperus phoenicea] ssp. [lycia] forests of the Mediterranean and Saharo-Mediterranean regions. Mediterranean formations dominated by [Juniperus phoenicea] are scrubs, thickets or arborescent matorrals, listed under units 32.132, 32.45, 32.55, 32.B5 or, in dunal formations, unit 16.272. Exceptional, tall and dense formations, however, may be more appropriately characterized as woodland and listed in this unit. Saharo-Mediterranean formations may more often take the appearence of an open or steppe forest, listed here and under 9.

Nombre oficial: Mediterranean Phoenician and Lycian juniper woods
Definición oficial: Uncommon forest-like [Juniperus phoenicea] ssp. [phoenicea] and [Juniperus phoenicea] ssp. [lycia] formations of rocky scarps, plateaux and slopes, coastal dunes of the western and central Mediterranean basin, the North African coastal areas, the eastern Aegean coast and Cyprus. Most Mediterranean formations dominated by [Juniperus phoenicea] are scrubs, thickets or arborescent matorrals, listed under units 32.132, 32.45, 32.55, 32.B5 or, in dunal formations, unit 16.272. Only exceptional, tall and dense formations, appropriately characterized as woodland, are listed in this unit.

Uncommon forest-like [Juniperus phoenicea] formations of rocky scarps, plateaux and slopes of the western and central Mediterranean basin, the western North African coastal areas, Crete, the eastern Aegean islands, the western Anatolian coasts, Cyprus, Jordan, the Sinai, Cyrenaica. Most Mediterranean formations dominated by [Juniperus phoenicea] are scrubs, thickets or arborescent matorrals, listed under units 32.132, 32.45, 32.55, 32.B5 or, in dunal formations, unit 16.272. Only exceptional, tall and dense formations, appropriately characterized as woodland, are listed in this unit.

Well-developed [Juniperus phoenicea] ssp. [lycia] woods and forests of the inner belt of the juniper woods of fixed Mediterranean and Mediterraneo-Atlantic dunes. Thickets and low woods are placed in unit 16.272.

[Juniperus phoenicea] forests and steppe-forests of rocky high plateaux and mountains of the High Atlas, the Middle Atlas, the Anti-Atlas, the Moulouya Valley, central Algeria, the Saharan Atlas, the Tunisian Dorsale, Tripolitania, the Jebel Akhdar, the Sinai, Jordan and the western Arabian peninsula.

[Platycladus orientalis] ([Thuja orientalis], [Biota orientalis]) forests scattered in restricted areas of the Hyrcanian zone of the Elburz range of northern Iran, constituting a very isolated occurrence of the species
Montane forests of the Mediterranean basin, of the Elburz and of the Sahara dominated by [Cupressus sempervirens], [Cupressus atlantica] or [Cupressus dupreziana].

[Cupressus sempervirens] forests of the Jebel Akhdar of northeastern Lybia, a community now apparently extinct, though the leading species may survive as isolated individuals in a few sites, including el Caf wadi.
[Cupressus sempervirens] var. [numidica] forests of the Dorsale of central Tunisia.
[Cupressus atlantica] forests of the Oued Nfis basin in the semiarid level of the High Atlas of Morocco, with a few scattered stations in other parts of the range, all between 900 and 1400 metres.

Relict [Cupressus dupreziana] formations of dry mountains of the Tassili-NAjjer, restricted to gorges and thalwegs of the Oued Tamrit and Oued Amazar and constituted by less than three hundred old trees, with little or no natural regeneration.

[Cupressus sempervirens] and [Cupressus sempervirens-Pinus brutia] forests of Crete occupying a wide altitudinal range, but a restricted geographical area, in the White Mountains (notably Samaria) with outposts in the Idi and Dikti mountains. Tall, closed, luxuriant forests exist, with cypresses up to 30 metres, as well as more open stands. Accompanying the cypress and [Pinus brutia] may be [Quercus coccifera], [Acer sempervirens], [Zelkova abelicea].
[Cupressus sempervirens] and [Cupressus sempervirens]-[Pinus brutia] forests of Rhodes, represented on most mountain ranges and locally at lower altitudes.
[Cupressus sempervirens] formations of Syme, rather open and with impoverished undergrowth.
[Cupressus sempervirens] forest remnants of middle elevations of Kos.
[Cupressus sempervirens] formations of steep slopes of the southeastern side of Samothrace.

[Cupressus sempervirens], [Cupressus sempervirens]-[Pinus brutia], [Cupressus sempervirens]-[Juniperus phoenicea] and [Cupressus sempervirens]-[Acer obtusifolium] forests of northern Cyprus, distributed in the 0-1200 m level, mostly on hard substrates, dense and extensive on the highest slopes of the Pendadahtilos (Kyrenia) Range.
[Cupressus sempervirens] and [Cupressus sempervirens-Pinus brutia] forests of southwestern Anatolia, limited to the lower slopes of the Lycian and Isaurian Taurus.

[Cupressus sempervirens] forests scattered in the Hyrcanian zone of the Elburz range of northern Iran, with [Acer monspessulanum], [Quercus iberica], [Crataegus monogyna], [Cerasus microcarpa], [Carpinus orientalis].
[Cupressus sempervirens] forests of Syria, Lebanon and Jordan.

Forest formations dominated by [Juniperus thurifera] of Spain, southern France, Corsica and North Africa. Many communities may be better described as arborescent matorrals, and listed under unit 32.136
Open montane forests of [Juniperus thurifera], sometimes mixed with [Pinus laricio], restricted to a few valleys in the interior of Corsica with extreme temperature ranges (Pinnera, Rudda, Pruniccia)

[Juniperus thurifera] woods of the Atlas system of North Africa, mostly widespread in Morocco, where they reach their greatest development on the southern slopes of the High Atlas and are also present in the Middle Atlas and in the eastern Anti-Atlas, limited in Algeria to the Aures. They are confined to the 1800 to 3150 metre cold semiarid level, mixed in the lower part of the range with [Cedrus atlantica]. The undergrowth usually includes [Bupleurum  spinosum], [Prunus prostrata], [Daphne laureola], [Crataegus laciniata], [Buxus sempervirens], [Lonicera arborea].

[Juniperus thurifera] forests on calcareous substrates in the supra- Mediterranean levels of the Iberian Range and neighbouring plateaux, dispersed throughout the entire system, in an arc extending from the province of Burgos to the Serrania de Cuenca and the mountains of Teruel
Relict [Juniperus thurifera] woods of enclaves on the periphery of and within the Sierra de Guadarrama, occurring both on rare local limestone deposits and in a few siliceous stations.
Formations of [Juniperus thurifera] linked to local limestone deposits of the Sierra de Guadarrama area.
Anomalous silicicolous [Juniperus thurifera] formations of the Sierra de Guadarrama area, with [Juniperus oxycedrus].

Relict, open [Juniperus thurifera] woodlands of dry, warm, rocky, calcareous southern slopes of the Cordillera Cantabrica, between the Rio Pisuerga and the Rio Luna, with [Juniperus nana], [Juniperus sabina], [Berberis vulgaris] ssp. [cantabrica], [Rhamnus alpinus], [Viburnum lantana].
[Juniperus thurifera] woodlands on gypsiferous soils of the Ebro basin, with [Rhamnus lycioides].
[Juniperus thurifera] woods on La Mancha clay soils of the Campo de Montiel.
Relict, open [Juniperus thurifera] formations of the pre-Baetic system in the Sierra Taibilla (Albacete, Murcia).
Relict [Juniperus thurifera] wood of the supra-Mediterranean level of the Montagne de Rie, on the northern flank of the central Pyrenees.

[Juniperus thurifera] formations of warm calcareous supra-Mediterranean slopes of the southwestern Alps, in Dr¿me, Hautes-Alpes and Alpes-de-Haute-Provence, between 700 and 1200, occasionally 1400, metres.
[Juniperus thurifera] formations of warm calcareous supra-Mediterranean slopes of the Is¿re valley, in the western Alps, between 300 and 500 metres.

Forest formations dominated by [Juniperus excelsa] or the closely allied [Juniperus macropoda] ([Juniperus polycarpos], [Juniperus seravshanica]) of the Irano-Turanian plateaux and mountains of Anatolia, Iran, Afghanistan, extending to Lebanon, the Caucasus, Crimea, Cyprus and the Balkanic peninsula, in the periphery of the Pelagonides and Rhodopides. Arborescent matorrals, somewhat more widespread in Mediterranean and sub-Mediterranean regions, have been listed under unit 32.1331

[Juniperus excelsa] forests of the [Ostryo-Carpinion] zone of the southern periphery of the Pelagonides, in particular of the mountains surrounding Lake Prespa in northern Greece where they occur up to 900-1000 m.

Woods of [Juniperus excelsa], of the western and northern periphery of the Rhodopides, localized in the southwestern Bulgarian Struma trough, and in the northern foothills of the central Rhodope mountains near Krichim and Bachkovo, usually open, with deciduous forest elements including [Fraxinus ornus], [Pistacia terebinthus], [Carpinus orientalis], sometimes [Quercus pubescens], and many Mediterranean species, such as [Phillyrea latifolia], [Asparagus acutifolius], [Lonicera etrusca], [Achnatherum bromoides].

[Juniperus excelsa] forests of the [Ostryo-Carpinion] zone of the northern periphery of the Pelagonides, in particular of the Vardar and Crna Reka valleys of the northern F.Y.R. of Macedonia, at an altitude of 100-400 metres.
Forests of [Juniperus excelsa] of the Troodos Range, where the species locally (Madari Peak, Papoutsa Peak) replaces [Pinus pallasiana].
Presteppic, meso-Mediterranean and subalpine [Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forests of Anatolia.

High altitude presteppic [Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forests of the Taurus and Anti-Taurus of southern Anatolia, in the 1900-2200 meter range, in which the juniper may be accompanied by [Cedrus libani], [Abies cilicica], [Pinus pallasiana] with an undergrowth formed by [Berberis crataegina], [Berberis cretica], [Lonicera nummulariifolia], [Amygdalus orientalis] and [Rosa orientalis], or by tragacanthic hedgehog heaths.

[Juniperus excelsa]-dominated open woodland formations of the highest forested elevations of the Taurus system, above 2300-2400 metres, with an understorey formed by grasslands of the [Tanacion preteriti] in the west, of the [Agropyro-Stachyon] in the center and the east, representing many narrowly endemic communities.

Presteppic [Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forest formations of the semiarid (xero-Euxinian) belt surronding the Anatolian plateau, in particular of the inner valleys and inner slopes of the Pontic Ranges and of the Taurus system.

[Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forest formations, accompanied by Mediterranean brush, maquis or garrigues in the undergrowth, forming locally bin Meso-Mediterranean enclaves of the Pontic Ranges as well as in Aegean and East-Mediterranean southern Anatolia.
[Pistacia mutica-Juniperus excelsa] forests of terra rossa dry slopes of the Black Sea coastal regions of the Great Caucasus.

[Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forests of the southern Crimean coast and of the Crimean mountains, accompanied by [Elytrigia nodosa], [Achnatherum bromoides], [Jurinea sordida], [Teucrium polium], [Jasminum fruticans], [Pistacia mutica].

Nombre oficial: Western coastal Crimean Grecian juniper forests
Definición oficial: [Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forests of the southwestern part of the southern Crimean coast, with [Cistus tauricus], [Fibigia clypeata], [Arbutus andrachne].

Nombre oficial: Eastern coastal Crimean Grecian juniper forests
Definición oficial: [Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forests of the eastern part of the southern Crimean coast, with [Linosyris villosa], [Bothriochloa ischaemum], [Agropyron ponticum], [Carex caryophyllea], [Eryngium campestre], [Pimpinella lithophila].

[Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forests of the Crimean mountains, with [Phleum phleoides], [Potentilla taurica], [Campanula taurica], [Melica monticola], [Lappula barbata], [Alyssum rostratum], [Filipendula vulgaris], [Alopecurus vaginatus].

[Juniperus excelsa]-dominated forests of high altitudes, 1200-2000 metres, of the Lebanon Mountains and Ansariye Mountains, occupying generally more xeric sites than [Cedrus libani] and [Abies cilicica], including eastern, steppe-facing, slopes, though also mixed with them locally.

Open forest formations constituting a belt on high arid slopes of the Elburz, with more isolated occurrences in the mountains of Transcaucasia, of Tadzhikistan, of the Zagros, of the Irano-Afghan plateau, of the inner valleys of the western and eastern Himalayas and of the southeastern and southwestern Arabian peninsula, dominated by junipers of the [Juniperus excelsa] group, often united in an eastern species, the Persian juniper [Juniperus macropoda], or divided into several closely related species, [Juniperus macropoda], [Juniperus seravshanica], [Juniperus turcomanica], but by some taxonomists judged undistinguishable from [Juniperus excelsa]. [Juniperus semiglobosa] may also accompany the other forms or dominate the community in Tadzhikistan, Uzbekistan and Afghanistan.
Forest formations dominated by [Juniperus foetidissima] of the Balkan peninsula, Cyprus, Anatolia, Transcaucasia.

Forest formations dominated by [Juniperus foetidissima] of the mountains of Greece, developed locally at high altitudes, on adrets of the upper supra-Mediterranean level, in particular, in the northern Pindus, in the region of the Vicos gorge. Arborescent matorrals, somewhat more widespread in Greece, including the Aegean archipelagoes (Samos), have been listed under unit 32.1332.
Forest of [Juniperus foetidissima] of the upper level of Hionistra Peak in the Troodos Range.

Presteppic, meso-Mediterranean or subalpine [Juniperus foetidissima]-dominated forests of Anatolia and neighbouring areas, of apparently very local occurrence, considerably less widespread than the [Juniperus excelsa]-dominated formations of the same regions.
[Juniperus drupacea] woods of Greece and Asia Minor. Part of the formations take the appearence of arborescent matorral, listed under unit 32.135.
[Juniperus drupacea] woods of the northern slopes of Mount Parnon and of the Karlik mountain in Thrace.
[Juniperus drupacea] woods of the Taurus and Amanus ranges.
[Juniperus drupacea] woods of the Lebanon and Anti-Lebanon ranges.
Forests of [Tetraclinis articulata], a species restricted to North Africa, southeastern Spain and the Maltese Islands.

Xerothermophile forests of [Tetraclinis articulata], restricted to extreme southeastern Spain, are extinct in forest form. The relict formations dominated by this species, of exceptional biogeographical and historical importance, constitute arborescent matorrals and have been listed under unit 32.151.

[Tetraclinis articulata]-dominated woodland of the lower Mediterranean slopes of the Rif and of the Oran and Algiers Tell and littoral, of the lower northern slopes and rain shadow valleys of the Middle Atlas and High Atlas, of the northern slopes of the Anti-Atlas, with outposts in maritime ranges of Tunisia, in particular, Ichkeul and Cap Bon and on the Tunisian Dorsale. They are limited to oceanic and maritime semiarid levels. Many formations are degraded to arborescent matorrals, listed under unit 32.152.

[Tetraclinis articulata]-dominated woodland of Morocco and western Algeria, distributed on the lower Mediterranean slopes of the Rif and of the Oran and Algiers Tell and littoral, of the lower northern slopes and rain shadow valleys of the Middle Atlas and High Atlas, of the northern slopes of the Anti-Atlas, with an exceptional representative on coastal sands in the fixed dunes of Essaouira on the Atlantic coast of Morocco.
Isolated [Tetraclinis articulata]-dominated woodland of the maritime ranges of Tunisia, in particular, Ichkeul and Cap Bon and of the Tunisian Dorsale.
Forests of [Tetraclinis articulata] of the Maltese Islands, extinct in woodland form, only represented by arborescent matorrals of unit 32.153.

Woods dominated by [Taxus baccata], often with [Ilex aquifolium], of very local occurrence in plains, hills and mountains of the Western Palaearctic nemoral zone and in the mountains of the Mediterranean basin, with isolated outliers in the southern and eastern Carpathian system and the northern Rhodopides (Mount Vitosha).
Isolated [Taxus baccata] grove of Mount Vitosha, in Bulgaria.
[Taxus baccata] woods with [Sorbus aria] or [Mercurialis perennis] of dry valleys and scarps of the Chalk of southeastern England, and, very locally of the Durham Magnesium limestone
Formations of [Taxus baccata], [Ilex aquifolium], [Buxus sempervirens], restricted to cool, montane areas in the Tenda range, the San Pedrone range and the Cap Corse mountains.
[Taxus baccata] and [Ilex aquifolium] woods of the Catena del Marghine and the Mount Limbara system.
[Taxus baccata] and [Ilex aquifolium] of the Macerata region.
Occasional pure [Taxus baccata] formations of Spanish mountains, most often on steep shady slopes.
[Taxus baccata] formations of southern France, similar to those of unit 42.A75.

[Taxus baccata] woods of the Alpine system and of the Carpathians, in part rare facies of the yew-beech formations, in part amphibolite-colonizing woods with [Picea abies] and [Fraxinus excelsior] and [Juniperus sabina].

Yew-dominated forests of the Dinarides, mostly yew-lime steep slope forests of northwestern Croatia, developed between 400 and 800 m on 30ø-80ø calcareous rock slopes with very shallow rendzina soils, also, locally, block forests within calcicolous fir forests of the Dinaric karst.
Pre-Sarmatic [Taxus baccata] formations of central Poland.
Juniper-dominated formations of the Atlantic islands. All such formations are listed here whether wood-like or scrub-like in physiognomy
[Juniperus cedrus] formations of the high altitudes of Tenerife, La Palma, Gomera, Gran Canaria, restricted to steep rocky slopes.
Endemic [Juniperus brevifolia] formations of the Azores.
[Juniperus phoenicea] formations of Tenerife, La Palma, Hierro, Gran Canaria, Gomera.

Woods dominated by [Juniperus oxycedrus] [s.l.]. Most [Juniperus oxycedrus] formations are thickets, scrubs or, at most, arborescent matorrals, listed under units 32.131, 32.45, 32.55, 32.B5 or, in dunal formations, unit 16.271. A few, however, qualify as woodland.

Non-maritime woods dominated by [Juniperus oxycedrus] ssp. [oxycedrus]. Most arborescent formations of [Juniperus oxycedrus] are arborescent matorrals, listed under unit 32.131. A few may, however, qualify as woodland, as, for instance, those of Monte Limbara in Sardinia, of Peloponnese mountains, in particular the Kilini, and of interior slopes of Anatolian mountains.

Well-developed [Juniperus oxycedrus] ssp. [macrocarpa] woods of the outer belt of the juniper woods of fixed Mediterranean and Mediterraneo-Atlantic dunes, occasionally also, of Mediterranean cliffs. Low woods and thickets are placed in unit 16.271.
Eastern Mediterranean and western North African forests dominated by [Cedrus libani], [Cedrus brevifolia] or [Cedrus atlantica].
Forests of [Cedrus libani] of the Taurus system, of Paphlagonia and of the Levant.

Nombre oficial: Lycian Taurus cedar of Lebanon forests
Definición oficial: Forests of [Cedrus libani] of the western Taurus, pure or mixed with [Acer sempervirens], [Acer platanoides], [Ulmus montana], [Populus tremula], developed at between 1500 and 2000 metres on limestones and rendzinas under a cold and snowy climate. The undergrowth includes [Alliaria officinalis], [Oryzopsis holciformis] and the endemics [Paeonia turcica], [Pentapera bocquetii], [Ebenus boissieri], [Campanula michauxioides].

Nombre oficial: Mesophile Lycian cedar of Lebanon forests
Definición oficial: Mesophile forests of [Cedrus libani] of the western Taurus, with [Aliaria  officinalis].

Nombre oficial: Meso-xerophile Lycian cedar of Lebanon forests
Definición oficial: Meso-xerophile forests of [Cedrus libani] of the western Taurus, with [Oryzopsis holciformis].

Nombre oficial: Central Taurus cedar of Lebanon forests
Definición oficial: Forests of [Cedrus libani] of the Pisidian, Isaurian and Cilician Taurus, of the western Anti-Taurus and of the Amanus.
Very local sub-Pontic forests of [Cedrus libani] of northeastern Anatolia.
Forests of [Cedrus libani] of Lebanon and of the Jebel el Ansariye of Syria.
Forests of [Cedrus brevifolia], endemic to Cyprus where they are limited to the western summits of the Troodos range, in the 900-1400 metre range.
Forests of [Cedrus atlantica] of the cold, humid and sub-humid levels of the Rif, the Middle Atlas, the High Atlas, the Aures, the Kabylian mountains and the Constantine Tell.

Boreal spruce, spruce-pine, pine, or occasionally larch, forests of Fennoscandia, northern and, mostly, extreme northeastern, Poland, the Baltic States, Belarus and European Russia, west of the middle Pechora, middle Kama basins and the western piedmont of the Urals, constituting the westernmost section of the continuous Eurasian northern taiga belt. They are predominantly dark taiga forests formed by [Picea abies], or, in the east, [Picea obovata], and [Pinus sylvestris], in pure or mixed stands, with only occasional, limited, edaphic pockets dominated by [Larix russica] ([Larix sukaczewii]).

[Larix russica] ([Larix sukaczewii], [Larix sibirica]) forests of the western Eurasian taiga zone of European Russia west of the middle Pechora, middle Kama basins and the western piedmont of the Urals, developed in edaphic pockets of the dark taiga spruce forests and on steep river valley slopes.

Forests of [Picea abies], [Picea obovata], or [Picea spp.] and [Pinus sylvestris], of Fennoscandia, Russia west of the Ural piedmont, Belarus, the Baltic States, northeastern Poland, with an understorey dominated by [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Deschampsia flexuosa] and mosses, developed on mesic moraine ground, on podsols with heavy raw humus. They constitute the most widespread and characteristic type of western spruce taiga in the boreal zone and extend to the boreonemoral zone. Accompanying small tree and shrub species include [Betula pubescens], [Sorbus aucuparia], [Empetrum spp.], [Juniperus communis], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Ledum palustre] (in the north), with a field layer comprising [Linnaea borealis], [Maianthemum bifolium], [Melampyrum pratense], [Solidago virgaurea], [Trientalis europaea], [Luzula pilosa], [Lycopodium annotinum], [Dicranum spp.], [Hylocomium splendens], [Pleurozium schreberi]. In the boreo-nemoral zone, deciduous trees may accompany the conifers, in particular, [Quercus robur], [Tilia cordata], [Acer platanoides], [Ulmus laevis], [Populus tremula].

Bilberry spruce and spruce-pine forests of boreal Fennoscandia and Russia, east of the Scandinavian mountains and west of the Northern Dvina and Vetluga rivers, extending in the subboreal zone, particularly in Scandinavia, developed under subcontinental to near-continental climates, dominated by [Picea abies], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris], and with a species cort¿ge devoid of oceanic elements.

Bilberry spruce and spruce-pine forests of western Norway, with a species cort¿ge enriched in oceanic or suboceanic elements, in particular, [Betula pubescens], [Cornus suecica], [Plagiothecium undulatum], [Rhytidiadelphus loreus].

Bilberry spruce and spruce-pine forests of boreal Russia, east of the Northern Dvina and Vetluga rivers, and west of the Ural piedmont, extending in the subboreal zone, developed under continental climates, dominated by [Picea obovata], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris] or [Abies sibirica].

Forests of [Picea abies], [Picea obovata], or of [Picea spp.] and [Pinus sylvestris], accompanied by deciduous trees ([Quercus robur], [Quercus petraea], [Tilia cordata], [Acer platanoides], [Ulmus laevis], [Populus tremula]), of boreonemoral Fennoscandia, boreonemoral Russia west of the Ural piedmont, Belarus, the Baltic States, northeastern Poland, with an understorey dominated by [Vaccinium myrtillus]. [Picea abies] is the main tree dominant west of the Oka and Vetluga rivers, [Picea obovata] east of them.

Forests of [Picea abies] or [Picea obovata], or of [Picea spp.] with [Pinus sylvestris], of Fennoscandia, Russia west of the western Ural piedmont, Belarus, the Baltic States, with an understorey dominated by ferns accompanied by ericaceous shrubs or phanerogamic herbs, by mosses and lichens.

Forests of [Picea abies] or, in the east, [Picea obovata], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris], of boreal Fennoscandia, boreal Russia west of the western Ural piedmont, extending into the boreonemoral region, in particular, in Fennoscandia, with an understorey dominated by [Gymnocarpium dryopteris], [Oxalis acetosella], ericaceous shrubs and mosses. They occupy stations with a richer nutrient supply and a higher humidity level than those of the bilberry forests of unit 42.C1, with a lower humidity level than the tall fern forests of unit 42.C22 and with a lower nutrient supply than the small herb forests of unit 42.C3.

Nombre oficial: Subcontinental small fern western spruce taiga
Definición oficial: Small fern spruce and spruce-pine forests of boreal Fennoscandia and Russia, east of the Scandinavian mountains and west of the Northern Dvina and Vetluga rivers, extending in the subboreal zone, particularly in Scandinavia, developed under subcontinental to near-continental climates, dominated by [Picea abies], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris], and with a species cort¿ge devoid of oceanic elements. The dominant [Gymnocarpium dryopteris] and [Oxalis acetosella] are accompanied by, in particular, [Thelypteris phaegopteris], [Dryopteris expansa], [Anemone nemorosa] and by the mosses [Brachythecium reflexum], [Hylocomium umbratum].

Nombre oficial: Suboceanic small fern western spruce taiga
Definición oficial: Small fern spruce forests of western Norway, with a species cort¿ge enriched in oceanic or suboceanic elements, in particular, [Thelypteris limbosperma], [Blechnum spicant], [Cornus suecica], [Luzula sylvatica], [Plagiothecium undulatum], [Rhytidiadelphus loreus].

Nombre oficial: Continental small fern western spruce taiga
Definición oficial: Small fern spruce and spruce-pine forests of boreal Russia, east of the Northern Dvina and Vetluga rivers, and west of the Ural piedmont, extending in the subboreal zone, developed under continental climates, dominated by [Picea obovata], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris] or [Abies sibirica].

Forests of [Picea abies] or, in the east, [Picea obovata], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris] and/or [Populus tremula], of southern boreal and boreonemoral regions of Fennoscandia, Russia west of the western Ural piedmont, Belarus, the Baltic States, with an understorey dominated by ferns, in particular, [Athyrium filix-femina], [Dryopteris carthusiana], [Dryopteris expansa], [Dryopteris dilatata], [Phegopteris connectilis], [Gymnocarpium dryopteris], [Matteuccia struthiopteris], often with two tiers, one of taller ferns, one of medium-sized ferns, with a greater presence of herbs than of [Vaccinium myrtillus] and much [Oxalis acetosella], developing on mesic to moist moraines (podsol-acid brown forest earth). Accompanying species include [Betula pubescens], [Maianthemum bifolium], [Trientalis europaea], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Rubus saxatilis], [Stellaria nemorum], [Viola epipsila], [Paris quadrifolia], [Luzula pilosa], [Melica nutans], [Milium effusum], [Deschampsia flexuosa] [Equisetum sylvaticum], and mosses. They occupy stations with a richer nutrient supply than those of the bilberry forests of unit 42.C1 and of the small fern forests of unit 42.C21, with a lower nutrient supply than the small herb forests of unit 42.C3 and the tall herb forests of unit 42.C4, and with a higher humidity level than all except the latter. In the boreo-nemoral zone, deciduous trees, in particular, [Tilia cordata], [Acer platanoides], [Ulmus laevis], may form a second tree layer.

Forests of [Picea abies] or, in the east, [Picea obovata], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris] and/or [Populus tremula], of southern boreal and boreonemoral regions of Fennoscandia, Russia west of the western Ural piedmont, Belarus, the Baltic States, extending locally in the middle and northern boreal zones, with an understorey dominated by  dwarf-shrubs and a low-growing herb layer, characteristic of calcareous substrates and warm stations, developed on acid brown forest soils with mull, or on weakly podsolized soils, with a preference for lowlying areas with fine sediments and a good water supply, sometimes with a tendency to waterlogging. They occupy stations with a richer nutrient supply than those of the bilberry forests of unit 42.C1 and of the fern forests of unit 42.C2, and with a lower humidity level than the fern forests and the tall herb forests of unit 42.C4. Accompanying tree and shrub species include a predominance of [Sorbus aucuparia], [Vaccinium myrtillus], with [Alnus spp.], [Betula spp.], [Juniperus communis], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], a field layer dominated by [Oxalis acetosella], [Melampyrum sylvaticum], [Maianthemum bifolium], [Trientalis europaea], [Gymnocarpium dryopteris], [Thelypteris phegopteris] accompanied by [Linnaea borealis], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Melampyrum pratense], [Solidago virgaurea], [Rubus saxatilis], [Viola riviniana], [Hieracium sylvatica] grp., [Pyrola spp.], [Paris quadrifolia], [Melica nutans], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Luzula pilosa], [Lycopodium annotinum], [Equisetum sylvaticum], and mosses. In the boreonemoral zone, deciduous trees, in particular, [Quercus robur], [Tilia cordata], [Acer platanoides], [Ulmus laevis], may form a second tree layer.

Small herb spruce and spruce-pine forests of southern boreal and boreonemoral  Fennoscandia and Eastern Europe, east of the Scandinavian mountains and west of the Northern Dvina and Vetluga rivers, extending locally in the middle and northern boreal zones, particularly in calcareous regions, developed under subcontinental to near-continental climates, dominated by [Picea abies], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris], with a species cort¿ge devoid of oceanic elements.
Small herb spruce forests of western Norway, with a species cort¿ge enriched in oceanic or suboceanic elements.

Small herb spruce and spruce-pine forests of boreal Russia, east of the Northern Dvina and Vetluga rivers, and west of the Ural piedmont, extending in the subboreal zone, developed under continental climates, dominated by [Picea obovata], sometimes accompanied by [Pinus sylvestris] or [Abies sibirica].

Forests of [Picea abies], accompanied, in a second tree layer by deciduous trees, in particular, [Quercus robur], [Tilia cordata], [Acer platanoides], [Ulmus laevis], sometimes with [Pinus sylvestris] and/or [Populus tremula] in the canopy, with a low understorey dominated by  dwarf-shrubs and low-growing herbs, of which many are of nemoral affinities, often with a well-developed taller shrub layer that may include much [Sorbus aucuparia], characteristic of boreonemoral regions of Russia west of the western Ural piedmont, Belarus, the Baltic States and northeastern Poland.

Forests of [Picea abies] or, in the east, [Picea obovata], of boreal and boreonemoral regions of Fennoscandia, Russia west of the western Ural piedmont, Belarus, the Baltic States, with a species-rich understorey dominated by tall herbs and ferns and with a significant component of deciduous trees, including [Betula pubescens], [Alnus incana], [Sorbus aucuparia]

Tall herb forests of [Picea abies] of northern Fennoscandia and of northern Russia west of the western Ural piedmont, installed on calcareous substrates, with a species-rich understorey dominated by [Aconitum septentrionale] ([Aconitum lycoctonum]), [Cicerbita alpina], [Alnus incana].

Tall herb forests of [Picea abies] of southern boreal and subboreal Fennoscandia and Russia, west of the western Ural piedmont, of Belarus and the Baltic States, developed on calcareous brown forest soils, with a species-rich understorey dominated by [Actaea spicata], [Campanula latifolia], [Mercurialis perennis], [Sambucus nigra], and ferns.

Tall herb forests of [Picea abies] of calcareous brown soils of western Norway, developed under oceanic climate conditions with much [Betula pubescens] and an understorey harbouring western, oceanic species, sometimes dominated by [Matteuccia struthiopteris].
Tall herb [Picea obovata] forests of boreal and boreonemoral Russia, east of the Northern Dvina and Vetluga rivers, and west of the Ural piedmont, developed under continental climates.

Conifer forests of the taiga belt of western Eurasia, west of the middle Petchora, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], sometimes accompanied by [Picea abies], with an ericoid-dominated, moss-rich or lichen-rich undergrowth mostly formed by [Calluna vulgaris], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Empetrum nigrum].

Sparse, extensive forests of the taiga belt of western Eurasia, west of the middle Petchora, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris] and [Picea abies], with many birches and an understorey dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Empetrum nigrum], [Vaccinium myrtillus] and, in the north, [Vaccinium uliginosum], with [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], lichens, notably of genus [Cladonia], mosses ([Dicranum]). They are, in particular, characteristic of cold, low evaporation regions of Norwegian, Swedish and Finnish mountains, up to the subalpine belt, occupying heavy raw humus on podsols.

Sparse woodlands of suboceanic subalpine Scandinavia dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], with much [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepandovii], accompanied by some low-growing [Picea abies], with an undergrowth dominated by [Calluna vulgaris] and [Empetrum hermaphroditum], with [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Vaccinium vitis-ideae], [Betula nana], [Cornus suecica], [Deschampsia flexuosa] and thick cushions of lichens and mosses formed by [Cladonia islandica], [Cladonia rangiferina], [Cladonia sylvatica], [Dicranum scoparium], [Pleurozium schreberi], [Barbilophozia lycopodioides], [Dicranum fuscescens], [Hylocomium splendens], [Sphagnum nemoreum]. They are installed on podsols with heavy raw humus in cool, submaritime, moist mostly northern boreal regions.

Sparse woods of low-growing [Pinus sylvestris], and some elements of birch, of maritime climate regions of western Norway, at subalpine levels, with an undergrowth dominated by [Calluna vulgaris], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Empetrum nigrum], [Vaccinium myrtillus], and with a species cort¿ge characterized by the presence of [Cornus suecica], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Blechnum spicant], [Pteridium aquilinum], [Bazzania trilobata], [Leucobryum glaucum], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], [Rhytidiadelphus loreus], [Sphagnum nemoreum], [Sphagnum quinquefarium]

Conifer forests of the taiga belt of western Eurasia, limited to southern and central Finland, central and northern Sweden and southeastern Norway, the Baltic States, southern boreal and boreonemoral Russia, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], often accompanied by [Picea abies], which may dominate or codominate, with an ericoid-dominated, moss-rich and lichen-rich undergrowth mostly formed by [Vaccinium vitis-idaea] with [Empetrum nigrum], [Empetrum hermaphroditum]. The species cort¿ge includes [Betula pubescens], [Calluna vulgaris], [Ledum palustre], [Vaccinium myrtillus], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Pyrola chlorantha], [Goodyera repens], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Lycopodium complanatum], [Cladonia spp.], [Dicranum scoparium], [Dicranum polysetum], [Dicranum fuscescens], [Hylocomium splendens], [Pleurozium schreberi]. They occur on sandy moraines or calcareous sand sediments in low rainfall areas.

Conifer forests of the taiga belt of western Eurasia, west of the middle Petchora, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], sometimes accompanied by [Picea abies], with a grass-, small herb-, tall herb- or fern-dominated undergrowth.

Nombre oficial: Subcontinental herb and grass pine taiga
Definición oficial: Conifer forests of the taiga belt of southern and central Finland, central and northern Sweden and eastern Norway, the Baltic States, southern boreal and boreonemoral Russia, west of the middle Petchora, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], sometimes accompanied by [Picea abies], with a grass-, small herb-, tall herb- or fern-dominated undergrowth.

Nombre oficial: Calcicline bearberry pine and birch-pine taiga
Definición oficial: Conifer forests of the taiga belt of southern and central Finland, central and northern Sweden and eastern Norway, the Baltic States, southern boreal and boreonemoral Russia, west of the middle Petchora, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], accompanied by [Betula pendula] and sometimes by [Picea abies], with a grass- and herb-rich undergrowth dominated by [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Melica nutans], [Convallaria majalis], [Melampyrum pratense], with [Cypripedium calceolus], [Epipactis helleborine], [Geranium sanguineum], [Hepatica nobilis].

Conifer forests of the taiga belt of southern and central Finland, central and northern Sweden and eastern Norway, the Baltic States, southern boreal and boreonemoral Russia, west of the middle Petchora, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], often accompanied by [Betula pubescens], with a grass- and herb-rich undergrowth dominated by [Calamagrostis arundinacea] with [Anthyllis vulneraria], [Fragaria vesca], [Lathyrus pratensis], [Pulsatilla spp.], [Viola riviniana], [Viola rupestris].

Conifer forests of the taiga belt of southern and central Finland, central and northern Sweden and eastern Norway, the Baltic States, southern boreal and boreonemoral Russia, west of the middle Petchora, dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], often accompanied by [Betula pubescens] or [Populus tremula], with a grass- and herb-rich, in particular, legume-rich, undergrowth dominated by [Calamagrostis arundinacea] and [Convallaria majalis] with [Rubus saxatilis], [Rubus idaeus], [Ribes alpinum], [Rhamnus frangula], [Lonicera xylosteum], [Hepatica nobilis], [Lathyrus spp.], [Vicia sepium].

Nombre oficial: Suboceanic herb and grass pine taiga
Definición oficial: Conifer forests of the taiga belt of Atlantic western Norway dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], accompanied by [Betula pendula] and sometimes [Picea abies], with a grass-, small herb-, tall herb- or fern-dominated undergrowth.

Nombre oficial: Suboceanic sanicle pine and birch-pine taiga
Definición oficial: Conifer forests of the taiga belt of Atlantic western Norway dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], accompanied by [Betula pendula] and sometimes [Picea abies], with a grass-, small herb-, tall herb- or fern-rich undergrowth dominated by [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Melica nutans], [Convallaria majalis], [Melampyrum pratense], with [Sanicula europaea] and [Galium odoratum].

Nombre oficial: Suboceanic dark red helleborine birch-pine-spruce taiga
Definición oficial: Woods of the Atlantic western extremity of the western Palaearctic taiga belt dominated by [Pinus sylvestris], [Betula pubescens] and [Picea abies], occupying calcareous substrates of the subalpine belt of central and northern Norway. They are characterized by a field layer containing both alpine and thermophile southern elements. The tall shrub layer contains much [Juniperus communis]

Sparse woods of low-growing [Pinus sylvestris], of northern Sweden, Finland and Norway, occurring under continental climate conditions with low humidity and wide fluctuations of temperature. The understorey is characterized by a dominance of [Calamagrostis lapponica], and a high density of lichens

Woods of [Pinus sylvestris] of Fennoscandia, the Baltic States and northern Russia, with a very low, sparse, dwarf-shrub layer and a ground layer dominated by lichens mainly of genus [Cladonia], notably [Cladonia rangiferina], [Cladonia alpestris], [Cladonia mitis]. Participating species include [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Calluna vulgaris], [Vaccinium vitis-idaea], [Cetraria islandica], [Dicranum polysetum], [Dicranum spurium], [Pleurozium schreberi], [Stereocaulon spp.], installed on podsols with a thin raw humus layer, often on sand sediment.
Lichen-carpeted [Pinus sylvestris] woods of the maritime climate region of western Norway, rich in [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum].

Nombre oficial: Southern boreal continental lichen pine taiga
Definición oficial: Lichen-carpeted [Pinus sylvestris] woods of areas of continental climate regions of Fennoscandia, of the Baltic States and of the southern boreal and boreonemoral zones of northern Russia, particularly characteristic of eastern Sweden and Finland. Dominant lichens are [Cladonia rangiferina], [Cladonia alpestris], [Cladonia mitis] and, in coastal ¿stland, [Cladonia uncialis]. Eastern Swedish and southeastern Norwegian stands harbour [Anemone sylvestris].
Lichen-carpeted [Pinus sylvestris] woods of northern boreal Russia, the Kola peninsula and extreme northeastern Fennoscandia.

Woods of [Pinus sylvestris] colonizing often small, level, glacier-fashioned granite, gneiss or acidic-sediment rock outcrops of southern and middle Fennoscandia, with dense lichen carpets, mostly of [Cladonia rangiferina], or a varied lichen and moss cover, accompanied by small shrubs, grasses and petrophile forbs, sometimes by abundant [Juniperus communis].
Sparse or patchy, often stunted, [Picea obovata] woods forming the timberline in the wooded tundra zone of eastern Europe, east of the White Sea and west of the Ural piedmont.

Boreal and boreonemoral spruce, pine, larch or fir forests of Siberia and the Urals, extending west to the western piedmont of the Urals, the middle Pechora and middle Kama basins, and southeastwards to northern China. West of the Yenisei they are predominantly dark taiga forests, more species-rich than those of the western taiga, formed by [Picea obovata], [Abies sibirica], [Pinus sibirica], [Pinus sylvestris], in pure or mixed stands, with less common light taiga forests dominated by [Larix sibirica]. East of the Yenisei they are mostly light taiga forests, dominated by [Larix dahurica] ([Larix gmelinii]).

Boreal and boreonemoral spruce, pine and fir forests of Siberia and the Urals, extending from the western piedmont of the Urals, the middle Pechora and middle Kama basins, eastwards, most widespread west of the Yenisei, where they constitute the dominant forest type, more species-rich than those of the western taiga, formed by [Picea obovata], [Abies sibirica], [Pinus sibirica], [Pinus sylvestris], in pure or mixed stands.

Boreal and boreonemoral larch forests of Siberia, extending from the Urals, eastwards, dominated by [Larix sibirica] west of the Yenisei, were they are relatively uncommon, by [Larix dahurica] ([Larix gmelinii]) east of the Yenisei, where they constitute the dominant forest type.

Montane spruce, pine, larch or fir forests of the Urals, the Altai system and the Siberian plateaux and ranges, formed by [Picea obovata], [Abies sibirica], [Pinus sibirica], [Pinus sylvestris], [Larix sibirica], [Larix dahurica] ([Larix gmelinii]).

Forests of [Cedrus deodara], [Abies pindrow], [Abies spectabilis], [Abies semenovii], [Picea morinda], [Picea shrenkiana], [Pinus wallichiana], [Pinus gerardiana], [Pinus sylvestri] ssp. [kulundensis], [Juniperus recurva], [Taxus wallichiana], mixed or single-species dominated, of the Central Asian mountains and adjacent wooded steppes, and of the Himalayas of Nuristan.
[Abies semenovii] forests of the Tien Shan.
[Picea shrenkiana] forests of the Tien Shan.
[Pinus sylvestris] ssp. [kulundensis] formations of the wooded steppes of eastern Eurasia, south of 52ø N, including [Pinus sylvestris] var. [galofitii] of alkaline soils in northeastern Kasakhstan.

Forests of [Cedrus deodara], [Abies pindrow], [Abies spectabilis], [Picea morinda], [Pinus wallichiana], [Pinus gerardiana], [Juniperus recurva], [Taxus wallichiana], mixed or single-species dominated, of the Himalayas of Nuristan.

Forests of Pinaceae (genera [Abies], [Picea], [Pinus], [Cathaya], [Keteleeria], [Larix], [Pseudolarix], [Pseudotsuga], [Tsuga]), of Cupressaceae (genera [Cupressus], [Juniperus], [Chamaecyparis], [Thuja], [Calocedrus], [Thujopsis], [Platyclades], [Microbiota], [Fokienia]), of Taxodiaceae (genera [Cryptomeria], [Cunninghamia], [Metasequoia], [Taiwania], [Glyptostrobus]), of Podocarpaceae (genera [Podocarpus], [Decussocarpus]), of Taxaceae (genus [Taxus]), of Cephalotaxaceae (genera [Cephalotaxus], [Torreya], [Amentotaxus]), of Ginkgoaceae ([Ginkgo biloba]) of the warm-humid temperate, nemoral and, locally, southern boreal areas of the Far East, mixed or single-species dominated, mostly rich and diverse in mainland China, Taiwan and Japan, extending to the Russian Far East and to the eastern Himalayan region of Tibet.

Fir ([Abies spp.])-dominated conifer forests of the nemoral and Mediterranean mountains and hills of western Eurasia and North Africa, in regions under Atlantic influence. They are formed either by [Abies alba], widespread in the Alpine system and its satelite ranges (units 42.11 to 42.16), or by a number of southern species, mostly of very restricted range (units 42.17 to 42.1A).
Surviving stands of the endangered [Abies nebrodensis] in the Madonie mountains of Sicily.

Plantations of western Palaearctic firs within or near their area of present or recent natural occurrence. Other plantations of these species and plantations of nonwestern-Palaearctic firs should be noted as unit 83.
Plantations of [Abies alba] within its area of occurrence or north and west of it.
Plantations of [Abies borisii-regis] in Greece and the southern Balkan peninsula.
Plantations of [Abies cephalonica] in Greece.
Plantations of [Abies pinsapo] in Andalucia.
Plantations of [Abies nebrodensis] in the mountains of northern Sicily.
Plantations of [Abies nordmanniana] in the Caucasus, of [Abies bornmuelleriana], [Abies equi-trojani] or [Abies nordmanniana] in the Pontic system, of [Abies cilicica] in the Taurus system.
Plantations of [Abies marocana] or [Abies numidica] within their North African range of natural occurrence.

Fir ([Abies alba]) and fir-spruce forests developed on neutral or near-neutral soils of the Alps, the Dinarides, the Carpathians, the Pyrenees, the Jura, the Hercynian ranges and the northern Apennines, in association with forests of the [Fagion medio-europaeum], of the [Fagion illyricum] or of the [Fagion dacicum].
Neutrophilous [Abies alba] and [Abies alba]-[Picea abies] forests developed on brown soils of the intermediate or inner Alps, outside of the climatic range of the beech ([Fagus sylvatica]).

Typical inner Alpine [Abies alba] forests with a predominance of mull-moder species such as [Veronica urticifolia] ([Veronica latifolia]), [Melampyrum sylvaticum], [Prenanthes purpurea], [Oxalis acetosella], [Luzula nivea]

High altitude, upper montane, tall-herb rich inner-Alpine fir forests with [Adenostyles alliariae], [Geranium sylvaticum], [Cicerbita alpina], [Chaerophyllum villarsii], [Peucedanum ostruthium], [Alnus viridis] and [Sorbus aucuparia].

[Abies alba] forests of the Maritime Alps, distributed in particular in the Quatre-Cantons forest in the Tournairet massif, in the Haute-V¿subie, in the Peira Cava massif, in the middle and high Roya, with [Trochiscanthes nodiflora], [Galium sylvaticum], [Luzula pedemontana], [Aquilegia atrata], [Phyteuma halleri].

Neutrophile fir forests of the montane or submontane levels of the outer Alps, the Dinarides, the Carpathians, the northern Apennines, the Pyrenees, the Jura and the Hercynian arc, dominated by [Abies alba] with a varying admixture of [Picea abies], [Fagus sylvatica] or both.

Neutrophile fir forests of the montane or submontane levels of the northern, western, southwestern and southern outer Alps, the western Carpathians, the northern Apennines, the Pyrenees, the Jura and the Hercynian arc, within the area of distribution of the montane beech forests of the [Fagion medio-europaeum], dominated by [Abies alba] with a varying admixture of [Picea abies], [Fagus sylvatica] or both.

Neutrophile fir forests of the montane or submontane levels of the northern, western, southwestern and southern outer Alps, the western Carpathians, the northern Apennines, the Jura and the Hercynian arc, developed in stations edaphically or microclimatically unfavourable to beech, dominated by [Abies alba] accompanied to a varying extent by [Picea abies] and with a species cort¿ge composed by elements of the [Fagetalia] and of the [Piceetalia].

Neutrophile fir forests of the montane or submontane levels of the northern, western, southwestern and southern outer Alps, the western Carpathians, the northern Apennines, the Pyrenees, the Jura and the Hercynian arc, developed in stations sufficiently favourable to beech, dominated by [Abies alba] accompanied to a varying extent by [Fagus sylvatica] and [Picea abies] and with a species cort¿ge identical to that of the montane beech forests of units 41.13, 41.14, 41.17.

Neutrophile fir forests of the montane or submontane levels of the southeastern outer Alps and the Dinarides, within the area of distribution of the montane beech forests of the [Fagion illyricum], dominated by [Abies alba] with a varying admixture of [Picea abies], [Fagus sylvatica] or both.

Neutrophile fir forests of the montane or submontane levels of the southeastern outer Alps and the Dinarides, developed in stations edaphically or microclimatically unfavourable to beech, dominated by [Abies alba] accompanied to a varying extent by [Picea abies] and with a species cort¿ge composed by elements of the [Fagetalia] and of the [Piceetalia].

Neutrophile fir forests of the montane or submontane levels of the southeastern outer Alps and the Dinarides, developed in stations sufficiently favourable to beech, dominated by [Abies alba] accompanied to a varying extent by [Fagus sylvatica] and [Picea abies] and with a species cort¿ge identical to that of the montane beech forests of units 41.13, 41.14, 41.17.
