[cophanense], [Phagnalon metlesicsi], [Hieracium cophanense], on Monte Erice, above Trapani, with [Brassica drepanensis], on the Egadi Islands, with [Brassica macrocarpa].

Calcareous rock-crack communities of the Egadean Island of Marettimo, developed above 200 metres, with [Scabiosa limonifolia] and the island endemics [Bupleurum dianthifolium], [Scilla hughii], [Thymus nitidus], [Helichrysum rupestre] var. [messerii].

Calcareous and dolomitic cliff and rock communities of interior mountains of northwestern Sicily, known from a few ranges within the Madonie and from the mountains to the south of Palermo, in particular, Rocca Busambra, Monte Kumeta, Monte La Pizzuta, between 500 and 1600 metres, with the endemic [Anthemis cupaniana], [Centaurea busambarensis], [Helichrysum rupestris] var. [pendulum]. Species characteristic of local representatives of these communities include the African [Viola munbyana], represented in Sicily only at Rocca Busambra and La Pizzuta, and the very restricted endemics [Bupleurum elatum] of the Madonie, and [Armeria gussonei] of the highest crests of Rocca Busambra.

Cliff communities of Miocene limestones of the Iblei Mountains in southeastern Sicily, with [Putoria calabrica], [Micromeria microphylla], [Asperula aristata] ssp. [scabra] and the Iblei endemics [Trachelium lanceolatum] and [Urtica rupestris]. The [Dianthion rupicolae] cort¿ge is reduced to [Dianthus rupicola], [Antirrhinum siculum], [Silene fruticosa], [Brassica incana], [Odontites bocconei], [Cymbalaria pubescens], [Pimpinella anisoides]. An isolated representative of the community exists on the Maltese Islands, located in a wadi of the central part of the main island, at Misram Gnonoq, dominated by [Putoria calabrica], but with an otherwise reduced cort¿ge that includes [Micromeria microphylla] and [Antirrhinum siculum] but not [Dianthus rupicola]. [Chiliadenus bocconei], characteristic of the next unit, is present.

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Maltese Islands, characteristic of the western coasts of Malta, of Gozo, and of the vertical walls of wadis, harbouring many vulnerable, rare or endemic species. Endemic, often palaeoendemic, species include [Chiliadenus bocconei], [Palaeocyanus crassifolius], [Cremnophyton lanfrancoi], [Darniella melitensis], [Limonium melitensis]. Subendemic species comprise [Crucianella rupestris], [Senecio pygmaeus], [Daucus rupestris]. Among characteristic or physionomically important species are [Hypericum aegyptiacum] ([Triadenia aegyptiaca]), [Salsola vermiculata], [Capparis orientalis] ([Capparis spinosa] var. [inermis]), [Arthrocnemum glaucum], [Inula crithmoides], [Crithmum maritimum], [Asphodelus microcarpus]. Communities in Gozo are perhaps even more diverse and include endemic [Helichrysum melitense], [Hyoseris frutescens], [Matthiola incana] subsp. [melitensis] and subendemic [Senecio leucanthemifolius], with [Daucus gingidium] and [Allium arvense]. More impoverished communities of Comino are mainly characterized by [Darniella melitensis] with [Daucus rupestris], [Senecio leucanthemifolius] and [Inula crithmoides].

Chasmophyte communities of gypseous, calcareous, marly or arenaceous gypso-sulphuriferous rocks of central and central western Sicily, developed  in the provinces of Enna, Caltanissetta and Agrigento, both near the sea and in the interior, at altitudes comprised between 100 and 800 metres, with the primarily North African [Diplotaxis crassifolia] and [Erysimum suffruticosum], the endemic [Brassica villosa], and a reduced [Dianthion rupicolae] cort¿ge, limited to [Silene fruticosa] and [Antirrhinum siculum].

Cliff and rock communities of the Peloritani Mountains of northeastern Sicily and the mountains of southern Calabria, in a region of ancient siliceous crystalline rocks, including schists, granites, gneisses, marls and a limited representation of limestones and dolomites, with few cliffs and limited rock wall surfaces. The relatively reduced rupicolous flora is nevertheless rich in remarkable endemics. Characteristic of the community is the endemic [Erucastrum virgatum], associated with [Dianthus rupicola], [Antirrhinum siculum], [Silene fruticans], [Brassica incana], [Pimpinella anisoides] and [Sesili bocconi] subsp. [bocconi]. Very local endemics characterize subassociations, in particular, at Capo dAli, between Taormina and Messina, with [Limonium sibthorpianum], around Taormina with [Centaurea tauromenitana], on the crystalline schists of Capo Tindari with [Centaurea todari] f. [seguenzae], on the coast of southern Calabria, between Scilla and Bagnara with [Senecio gibbosus] and [Centaurea scyllae], on the Ionian slope of Calabria with [Centaurea ionica], [Campanula fragilis] var. [ionica], [Ptilostemon gnaphaloides] ssp. [gnaphaloides], [Leontodon intermedius], [Alyssum orientale].

Chasmophyte communities of calcareous and dolomitic cliffs, and of araneceous tufas of the coastal mountains of the Tyrrhenian slope of northern Calabria, of Campania, and of southern Latium, with [Campanula fragilis] var. [fragilis], [Centaurea cineraria] and a reduced [Dianthion rupicolae] cort¿ge comprising [Lithodora rosemarinifolia], [Dianthus rupicola], [Brassica incana], [Iberis semperflorens], [Pimpinella anisoides]. The communities of Capri and the Sorrento peninsula include the endemic [Seseli polyphyllum] and [Asperula crassifolia], as well as the rare [Convolvulus cneorum] ssp. [latifolium]. Those of the Cilento, between Capo Palinuro and Praia a Mare, harbour, in the most coastal stations, the archaic endemic [Primula palinuri].
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Adriadic meso-mediterranean zone of northeastern Italy and the Balkan peninsula. Some of them grade into maritime cliff communities of unit 18.221.

Cliff communities of the karst region of northeastern Italy and northern Istria with [Campanula pyramidalis], [Cheiranthus cheri], [Teucrium flavum], [Euphorbia wulfenii], [Micromeria thymifolia], harbouring the very rare, threatened endemics [Centaurea kartschiana] and [Moehringia tommasinii].

Cliff communities of the karst region of northeastern Italy, with the very rare Triestine endemic [Centaurea kartschiana], and with [Erysimum cheiri] ([Cheiranthus cheiri]), [Campanula pyramidalis], [Teucrium flavum], [Sesleria juncifolia].
Cliff communities of the karst region of northeastern Italy and Slovenia, with  [Campanula pyramidalis], [Micromeria thymifolia], [Sesleria juncifolia], [Teucrium flavum] and [Euphorbia wulfenii].

Cliff communities of the karst region of northeastern Italy, southwestern Slovenia and extreme northwestern Croatia, in the Vena Mountains between Val Rosandra and Buzet, harbouring the rare, threatened [Moehringia tommasinii], known from a very restricted number of stations within an exiguous region, one of them in Italy.
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Adriadic meso-mediterranean coast lands of the northern Dalmatian coast, in part constituting the upper levels of sea-cliffs of unit 18.2219.
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Dalmatian islands of Rab and Pag with the endemic [Centaurea dalmatica].
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Dalmatian archipelago with [Scorzonera austriaca], [Sesleria juncifolia], [Seseli pallasii], [Allysum robertianum].
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the central and southern Velebit coast lands, with [Campanula fenestrellata], in part constituting the upper levels of sea-cliffs of unit 18.2219.
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Adriadic meso-mediterranean coast lands of the central Dalmatian coast, in part constituting the upper levels of sea-cliffs of unit 18.221A.
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Dalmatian mesomediterranean zone, with the endemic [Centaurea ragusina] and [Convolvulus cneorum].
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the central and southern parts of the Dalmatian mesomediterranean zone, with [Moltkia petraea].
Calcareous cliffs of the southern Biokovo coastlands of central Dalmatia, with [Inula spp.], [Centaurea cuspidata], [Seseli tomentosum].

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Adriadic meso-mediterranean coast lands of the southern Dalmatian coast, in part constituting the upper levels of sea-cliffs of unit 18.221B, in particular, communities dominated by [Putoria calabrica].
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Dalmatian mesomediterranean zone, widespread on rocks and man-made structures, with [Umbilicus horizontalis] and asplenioid ferns.

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the central and eastern Pyrenees, with [Saxifraga media], [Saxifraga longifolia], [Saxifraga aretioides], [Potentilla alchimilloides], [Potentilla nivalis], [Ramonda myconi], [Asperula hirta].

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Maritime Alps and northern Apennines, with [Saxifraga lingulata], [Primula marginata], [Primula allionii], [Phyteuma charmelii], [Phyteuma villarsii], [Silene campanula], [Potentilla saxifraga], [Ballota frutescens].
Cliff and rock communities of the supra- and oro-Mediterranean levels of calcareous Iberian mountains, of the central Apennines and of the calcareous mountains of the large Tyrrhenian islands.
Cliff and rock communities of the supra- and oro-Mediterranean levels of calcareous Iberian mountains.

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Cantabrian Cordillera and a few other northwestern Iberian ranges, with [Asperula hirta], [Asplenium viride], [Erinus alpinus], [Globularia repens], [Hypericum nummularium], [Rhamnus pumilus], [Saxifraga aretioides].

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of high altitudes of Baetic and sub-Baetic ranges of eastern Andalusia, with [Linaria verticillata], [Potentilla caulescens], [Saxifraga camposii], [Saxifraga erioblasta], [Teucrium rotundifolium], [Silene boryi].
Shady calcareous cliff and rock communities of Valencian mountains.
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the montane or subalpine levels of the central Apennines and of the calcareous mountains of the large Tyrrhenian islands.

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the cryo-oromediterranean and supramediterranean levels of Corsica, limited to rare limestone outcrops, in particular, of the Chapelle SantAngelu de Lanu summit and of the Punta di u Fornellu, with [Arenaria bertolonii], [Potentilla crassinervia], [Festuca sardoa], [Dianthus sylvestris] ssp. [godronianus], [Ptychotis saxifraga], [Elymus corsicus].
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the montane or subalpine levels of the central Apennines.

Cool, shaded calcareous cliff and rock communities of the west Mediterranean regions, formed mostly of bryophytes and ferns, including [Polypodium cambricum] ssp. [australe] ([Polypodium australe]), and with [Selaginella denticulata].
Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Alps and the Carpathians, of lesser satellite ranges and of submediterranean areas of the northern Tyrrhenian periphery.

Well-lit calcareous cliff and rock communities of the Alps and neighbouring regions, including upper Provence, upper Languedoc, the pre-Pyrenees and Corbi¿res, the Catalonian mountains, with [Potentilla caulescens], [Potentilla clusiana], [Potentilla nitida], [Primula auricula], [Hieracium humile], [Cardaminopsis petraea], [Androsace helvetica], [Minuartia rupestris].

Communities of shady, cool, often moist rockfaces of the Alps and neighbouring regions, of the Carpathians, of the Jura, the Hercynian ranges, the British Isles, with many ferns, including [Cystopteris fragilis], [Cystopteris regia], [Asplenium viride], [Asplenium scolopendrium], [Asplenium trichomanes], and with [Carex brachystachys].
Rock-crack communities of sunny rock faces of the alpine and subalpine levels of the Carpathians.

Nombre oficial: Western Carpathian calcareous cliff heliophile communities
Definición oficial: Rock-crack communities of sunny rock faces of the alpine and subalpine levels of the high northwestern Carpathians, of Alpine affinities.

Nombre oficial: Eastern Carpathian calcareous cliff xero-heliophile communities
Definición oficial: Rock-crack communities of sunny rock faces of the alpine and subalpine levels of the eastern Carpathian system, characterized by the prevalence of Dacian endemics.
Rock-crack communities of sunny rock faces of the Eastern Carpathians, formed by [Silene zawadzkii].
Rock-crack communities of sunny rock faces of the southeastern Carpathians, formed by [Artemisia eriantha] and [Gypsophila petraea].

Rock-crack communities of abrupt slopes and humid ubacs of the Bucegi and Ceahlau mountains of the Southern Carpathians, formed by [Saxifraga moschata] and [Saxifraga oppositifolia] with [Draba kotschyi].

Nombre oficial: Eastern Carpathian musky saxifrage cliff communities
Definición oficial: Rock-crack communities of sunny rock faces of the Retezat mountains in the western Southern Carpathians, formed by [Saxifraga marginata] ssp. [rocheliana] with species of Dacio-Balkanic affinities.

Nombre oficial: Eastern Carpathian orange saxifrage cliff communities
Definición oficial: Rock-crack communities of semishady rock faces of the southeastern Carpathians, formed by the endemic [Saxifraga mutata] ssp. [demissa] and [Gypsophila petraea].

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of the thermo- and meso-Mediterranean zones of mainland Greece and Albania, up to the [Abies cephalonica] belt, with [Campanula versicolor], [Campanula rupestris], [Sideritis roeseri], [Stachys candida], [Hypericum vesiculosum], [Asperula arcadiensis], [Galium boryanum], [Centaurea pelia], [Alkanna graeca], [Alyssum orientale], [Linaria microcalyx], [Onosma frutescens], [Inula candida], [Centranthus ruber], [Silene congesta], [Teucrium flavum].

Calcareous and ultrabasic cliff and rock communities of Crete, the Aegean archipelagoes, Cyprus, the Mediterranean coastlands of Anatolia and the Levant. They constitute one of the most diverse and endemic-rich groups of cliff communities.

Cliff and chasm communities of Crete, with [Petromarula pinnata], [Galium fruticosum], [Centaurea argentea], [Ebenus cretica], [Verbascum arcturus] ([Celsia arcturus]), [Inula candida], [Eryngium ternatum], [Asperula incana], [Dianthus juniperinus], [Aster canus], [Campanula pelviformis], [Campanula saxatilis].
Relatively widespread cliff and chasm communities of the lowlands and hills of western and central Crete.
Cliff and chasm communities of the arid lowlands and hills of eastern Crete.
Cliff and chasm communities of the high altitudes of Crete.
Cliff and rock communities of Karpathos, with [Teucrium heliotropifolium], [Silene fruticosa], [Galium incurvum], [Inula heterolepis].
Cliff and rock communities of Rhodes, Samos, Ikaria, Lesbos with [Campanula hagielia], [Lactuca leburnea], [Dianthus rhodensis], [Inula heterolepis], [Rosularia serrata], [Sedum creticum].
Cliff and rock communities of the Cyclades, with [Fibigia lunarioides], [Eryngium amorginum], [Amaracus tournefortii], [Campanula amorgina], [Campanula heterophylla], [Helichrysum amorginum].
Cliff and rock communities of the Sporades, with [Inula sophiae], [Capparis spinosa], [Dianthus arboreus], [Amaracus tournefortii].

Limestone and ophiolite cliff and rock communities of Cyprus, in particular, limestone and ophiolite cliffs and gorges of the Troodos range, limestone cliffs and pinnacles of the Kyrenia range, flysch, sandstone and conglomerate rock-slopes of the Kythrean formation.
Limestone cliff and rock communities of the Kyrenia range. Endemic plants include [Delphinium caseyi], [Brassica hilarionis] and [Arabis cypria] of the Kythrean formation.
Limestone cliff and rock communities of the Troodos range.
Ophiolite cliff and rock communities of the Troodos range and the Akamas peninsula. Endemic plants include [Alyssum troodi], [Alyssum akamasicum], [Alyssum chondrogynum].
Calciphile cliff and rock crevice communities of the Kythrean formation, with several local endemics, including [Hedysarum cyprium] and [Salvia veneris].

Calcareous cliff and rock communities of high altitudes of the Peloponnese, Giona and Parnassus, with [Silene auriculata], [Achillea umbellata], [Campanula rupicola], [Saxifraga sibthorpii], [Saxifraga marginata], [Saxifraga spruneri], [Minuartia stellata], [Valeriana olenaea], [Satureja parnassica], [Rosa glutinosa], [Viola poetica], [Edraianthus parnassicus], [Campanula aizoon].
Calcareous and ultrabasic cliff and rock communities of the high altitudes of the central and northern Pindus and of the Thessalian Olympus system.

Cliff and rock communities of the Thessalian Olympus system and of Mount Ossa, with [Saxifraga scardica], [Saxifraga glabella], [Campanula oreadum], [Arabis bryoides], [Potentilla deorum], [Jankaea heldreichii], [Omphalodes luciliae].

Calcareous and ultrabasic cliff and rock communities of the Pindus, with [Galium degenii], [Edraianthus graminifolius], [Asplenium fissum], [Aubrieta gracilis], [Achillea clavennae], [Satureja parnassica], [Hypericum apollinis], [Gnaphalium roeseri], [Trifolium noricum], [Silene pindicola].

Rock-crack communities of dry non-calcareous inland cliffs. Specific plant associations colonize montane and Mediterranean cliffs. Most of the subdivisions below refer to them. Northern lowland cliffs usually support fragments of communities listed in other chapters.
Rock and cliff crevice communities of granites, gneisses and acidic rocks of the boreal and arctic zones of the Palaearctic domaine.

Rock and cliff crevice communities of granites, gneisses and acidic rocks of the mountains and uplands of the boreal and arctic zones of the western Palaearctic domaine, in particular of Fennoscandia and Iceland.

Rock and cliff communities of boreal Fennoscandian and Icelandic granites, gneisses and acidic rocks, generally occurring in the humus accumulation of crevices and comprising few genuine chasmophytes, dominated by variable, usually paucispecific assemblies in which [Asplenium septentrionale], [Asplenium trichomanes], [Potentilla argentea] are often prominent.

Rock and cliff communities of southern and middle Fennoscandian granite, gneiss and acidic sediment glacier-fashioned flat-top rock outcrops with dense lichen carpets, formed, in particular, by [Cladonia rangiferina], mosses, scrubs and sometimes sparse grasses and forbs. [Calluna vulgaris], [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Silene rupestris] are characteristic. Part of the communities may constitute more or less open [Pinus sylvestris] woods of unit 42, or [Calluna vulgaris] heaths of unit 31.2.

Rock and cliff communities of southern and middle Fennoscandian granite or gneiss, sometimes with amphibolite or gabbro, glacier-fashioned flat-top rock outcrops with a varied lichen, moss and vascular plant cover, formed, in particular, by [Deschampsia flexuosa], [Woodsia ilvensis], [Lychnis viscaria]. Part of the communities may constitute more or less open [Pinus sylvestris] woods of unit 42, or [Juniperus communis] thickets of unit 31.8.

Siliceous rock and cliff communities of the mountains and uplands of the boreal and arctic zones of the central Palaearctic domaine. Included are the communities of the Chibiny range, of the Urals, of the chains of northern central Siberia, from the Putorany to the Tscherski range and of the mountains of southern Siberia, from the Altai to the Stanowoi range.

Siliceous rock and cliff communities of the mountains and uplands of the boreal and arctic zones of the eastern Palaearctic domaine. Included are the communities of the Anadyr, Tschuktschi, Korjak, Kamchatka, Amurland and Sakalin mountains.
Serpentine and basalt cliff and rock communities of the boreal and arctic zones of the Palaearctic domaine.
Serpentine and basalt cliff and rock communities of the boreal and arctic zones of the western Palaearctic domaine, in particular of Fennoscandia and Iceland.
Scattered communities of serpentine cliffs and rocks of subalpine low alpine and middle alpine levels of the Fennoscandian mountains, colonizing crevices and weathered, frost-shattered rock debris

Communities of serpentine cliffs and rocks of the upper montane, subalpine and low alpine levels of the Fennoscandian mountains rich in heath species, in particular, [Calluna vulgaris], [Empetrum hermaphroditum], [Vaccinium uliginosum], with much [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], on a thin humus layer.
Communities of serpentine cliffs and rocks of oceanic southern boreal Norway, colonizing crevices and weathered rocks, with [Asplenium adulterinum] and [Cardaminopsis petraea].
Basic cliff and rock communities of Iceland.

Cliff crevice and rock communities of basaltic lowlands of southern Iceland formed by [Asplenium viride], [Woodsia glabella] and many xerophytes. [Saxifraga cotyledon], [Potentilla hyparctica], [Potentilla chamisonis], [Potentilla pulchella], [Kobresia myosuroides] are typical of various communities.
Sparse crevice communities of basic rocks and cliffs of Iceland and the Faeroes formed by [Cystopteris fragilis] and [Rhodiola rosea].

Serpentine and basalt cliff and rock communities of the mountains and uplands of the boreal and arctic zones of the central Palaearctic domaine. Included are the communities of the Chibiny range, of the Urals, of the chains of northern central Siberia, from the Putorany to the Tscherski range and of the mountains of southern Siberia, from the Altai to the Stanowoi range.

Serpentine and basalt cliff and rock communities of the mountains and uplands of the boreal and arctic zones of the eastern Palaearctic domaine. Included are the communities of the Anadyr, Tschuktschi, Korjak, Kamchatka, Amurland and Sakalin mountains.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of mediterranean North Africa.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the Kurdo-Zagrosian and Irano-Turanian regions, of Crimea, the Pontic range, the Caucasus, the Elburz, the Central Asian mountains, the Himalayan system.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the Kurdo-Zagrosian and Irano-Turanian regions of southwestern Asia.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of Crimea, of the Pontic range, of the Caucasus and of the Elburz.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the mountains of Central Asia, including those of the Tian Shan, Pamir-Alai and Kopet Dag systems.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the Himalayan system, west to the Hindu-Kush.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the nemoral, warm-humid temperate and tropical Far East.
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the northwestern, northern, eastern and central Alps, the Pyrenees, the western Carpathians, the middle European Hercynian ranges, the Jura.

Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the alpine and subalpine levels of the northwestern, northern, eastern and central Alps, with outliers in the Dinarides, of the Massif Central and of the Pyrenees.

Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the alpine and subalpine levels of the northwestern, northern, eastern and central Alps, of the Dinarides and of the Pyrenees, with [Androsace vandellii], [Artemisia umbelliformis], [Eritrichium nanum], [Minuartia cherlerioides], [Primula hirsuta], [Phyteuma scheuchzeri], [Erysimum rhaeticum], [Saxifraga aspera], [Saxifraga cotyledon], [Saxifraga iratiana], [Saxifraga retusa], [Saxifraga bryoides].
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the subalpine levels of the Central Massif, with [Minuartia verna], [Saxifraga lamottei], [Saxifraga hieraciifolia], [Dianthus gratianopolitanus].

Nombre oficial: Hercynio-Alpine montane and collinar siliceous cliffs
Definición oficial: Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the montane level of the middle European Hercynian ranges, the Jura, the Alps and their periphery, of Atlantic regions of the European continent and the British Isles, with [Saxifraga sponhemica], [Biscutella laevigata], [Asplenium septentrionale], [Asplenium adiantum-nigrum], [Asplenium billotii], [Asplenium foresiense].

Serpentine cliff and rock communities of the middle European Hercynian ranges and their periphery, of northern Styria, Low-Austria and the Burgenland, with [Asplenium adulterinum], [Asplenium cuneifolium], [Asplenium x alternifolium], [Cheilanthes marantae].
Siliceous cliff communities of Alpine affinities of the Carpathians, formed principally by bryophytes and ferns.
Communities dominated by or rich in ferns of siliceous cliffs of the Carpathians.

Cliff communities occupying siliceous rock fissures of interior valleys at the foot of the Cibinului Mountains in the western Southern Carpathians, formed by [Jovibarba heuffelii] with [Veronica bachofenii], [Genista januensis], [Silene dubia], [Thymus comosus].
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of high altitudes of Iberian mountains.

Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the Cordillera Cantabrica, the Iberian Range, the Cordillera Central and the Leonese mountains, with [Hieracium pallidum] ssp. [graniticum], [Murbeckiella boryi] ssp. [boryi], [Murbeckiella boryi] ssp. [herminii], [Saxifraga willkommiana], [Spergula viscosa] ssp. [pourretii].
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the Sierra Nevada, with [Saxifraga nevadensis], [Sedum brevifolium], [Centranthus nevadensis].
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the Maritime, Ligurian and Cottian Alps, with [Saxifraga pedemontana].

Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the mountains of Corsica and Sardinia, distributed from the supramediterranean to the alpine level, with [Potentilla crassinervia], [Armeria leucocephala], [Silene requieniil, [Saxifraga pedemontana] ssp. [cervicornis]. Supramediterranean and montane communities have [Amelanchier ovalis] ssp. [rhamnoides],  cryomediterranean, subalpine and alpine communities have [Festuca sardoa], [Phyteuma serratum], [Helechryssum frigidum], [Aquilegia bernardii], [Leucanthemum corsicum], [Scabiosa corsica], upper alpine communmities are characterized by the presence of [Draba dubia], [Asplenium veride], [Draba loiseleurii], [Erigeron paolii] and the absence of thermophile species.

Siliceous cliff communities rich in Dacio-Balkanic endemics of the subalpine level of the eastern Carpathian system and the mountains of the Balkan peninsula, including the Dinarides, the Balkan Range, the Moeso-Macedonian mountains, the Pelagonides and the Rhodopides, of relict character.
Endemic siliceous cliff communities of the alpine and subalpine levels of the Southern  Carpathians.

Endemic siliceous cliff communities of the alpine and subalpine levels of the Fagaras mountains of the Southern Carpathians, formed by [Silene dinarica], with [Festuca airoides], [Juncus trifidus], [Primula minima].

Endemic siliceous cliff communities of the alpine and subalpine levels of the Southern Carpathian Retezat and Tarcu-Godeanu mountains, formed by [Silene lerchenfeldiana], with [Senecio glaberrimus], [Juncus trifidus].

Siliceous cliff communities of the Paring mountains in the Southern Carpathians, of the Balkan Range and of the Rhodopides, in particular, of the Rila and the Pirin, with [Silene lerchenfeldiana], [Potentilla haynaldiana], [Saxifraga juniperifolia] ssp. [juniperifolia] ([Saxifraga pseudosancta]), [Saxifraga pedemontana] ssp. [cymosa], [Rhodiola rosea] ([Sedum rosea]), [Dianthus henteri], [Minuartia bulgarica], [Haberlea rhodopensis], [Symphyandra wanneri], [Carex kitaibeliana] ([Carex laevis]), [Juncus trifidus], [Sesleria coerulans], [Festuca airoides], [Poa nemoralis], [Asplenium trichomanes], [Cystopteris fragilis].
Siliceous cliff communities of the Pelagonides of the F.Y.R. of Macedonia and northern Greece.

Montane siliceous cliff and rock communities of the C¿vennes, the eastern and central Pyrenees and the Catalonian hills, with [Asarina procumbens] ([Antirrhinum asarina]), [Sedum hirsutum], [Centaurea pectinata], [Sempervivum arvernense], [Dianthus graniticus], [Saxifraga clusii], [Saxifraga hypnoides].
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the meso-Mediterranean level of western Iberia, with [Cheilanthes tinaei], [Cheilanthes hispanica].

Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the thermomediterranean, mesomediterranean and lower supramediterranean levels of Provence, Corsica and eastern Spain, mostly constituted by ferns, in particular, of genus [Cheilanthes] (including [Cosentinia]) in xeric sunny situations, of genera [Asplenium] and [Polypodium] in more shady locations, accompanied by species of genus [Dianthus], in particular, [Dianthus sylvestris] ssp. [siculus], [Dianthus sylvestris] ssp. [godronianus].
Siliceous cliff and rock communities of the hills of northern and middle nemoral Europe colonized by communities referable to units other than 62

Nombre oficial: Pavements, rock slabs, moss and lichen carpets
Definición oficial: More or less level surfaces of rock of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic exposed by glacial erosion, by weathering processes, or by nondesert aeolian scouring, bare or colonized by mosses, algae or lichens. The hard rock surface may be apparent or partially or completely covered by indigenous erosional rock debris, in particular, those produced by frost weathering, heaving, thrusting or cracking. Included are, in particular, lapi¿s, karren, limestone pavements of karst landscapes, rock dome tops, whaleback, roche moutonn¿e, flyggberg and rock basin formations of periglacial areas, frost-shattered mountain-top detritus, golec and felsenmeer formations, level surfaces of dykes and old lava flows. Vascular plant communities may colonize cracks and superficially decomposed areas, in particular, [Sedo-Scleranthion], [Alysso-Sedion albi] or [Sedo albi-Veronicion dillenii] communities of units 34.11 and 36.2, occasionally scree communities of unit 61 or chasmophyte communities of units 62.1 or 62.2. More developed communities belonging to other units may also be present.

Bare or sparsely vegetated more or less level surfaces of rock of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic exposed by erosion or weathering processes, physiognomically dominated by hard rock surfaces or indigenous erosional rock debris.
More or less level surfaces of calcareous rock of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic, including karstic pavements, lapi¿s, with their clints and grikes.

Nombre oficial: High altitude and arctic limestone pavements
Definición oficial: More or less level surfaces of calcareous rock of nondesert arctic regions and of the nival, or aeolian, level of mountains of the Palaearctic.
More or less level surfaces of calcareous rock of the alpine to montane levels of high mountains of the mediterranean, nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic.

More or less level surfaces of calcareous rock of of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, in particular alvars of the eastern Fenno-Scandian boreonemoral zone occupied by epilithic lichen communities of unit 62.32, associated with debris swards, calcareous grasslands and paucispecific nemoral fissure communities of units 34.1151, 34.317 and 62.1B1.
More or less level surfaces of calcareous rock of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the nemoral zone of the Palaearctic.
More or less level surfaces of calcareous rock of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the Mediterranean region.
More or less level surfaces of siliceous rocks of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic.

Nombre oficial: High altitude and arctic siliceous pavements
Definición oficial: More or less level surfaces of siliceous rock of nondesert arctic regions and of the nival, or aeolian, level of mountains of the Palaearctic.
More or less level surfaces of siliceous rock of the alpine to montane levels of mountains of the mediterranean, nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic.

More or less level surfaces of siliceous rocks of lowlands and hills of the boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, in particular, flat tops of southern and middle Fennoscandian granite, gneiss and acidic sediment glacier-fashioned rock outcrops. They are often colonized by lichen communities of unit 62.32, by mosses and by scrub, grass and forb fissure communities of unit 62.2A.
More or less level surfaces of siliceous rock of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the nemoral zone of the Palaearctic, in particular, sandstone slabs of north central and eastern France.
More or less level surfaces of siliceous rock of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the Mediterranean region.
More or less level surfaces of basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic.

Nombre oficial: High altitude and arctic basaltic pavements
Definición oficial: More or less level surfaces of basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rock of nondesert arctic regions and of the nival, or aeolian, level of mountains of the Palaearctic.
More or less level surfaces of basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rock of the alpine to montane levels of mountains of the mediterranean, nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic.
More or less level surfaces of basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic.
More or less level surfaces of basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rock of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the nemoral zone of the Palaearctic.
More or less level surfaces of basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rock of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the Mediterranean region.
More or less level surfaces of rock of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic exposed by erosion or weathering processes, colonized by dense lichen mats.
Lichen-dominated communities of level rock or erosional debris surfaces of arctic regions, outside of polar deserts, and of the arctoalpine level of the mountains of the northern boreal region.

Nombre oficial: Boreal and boreo-nemoral rock lichen heaths
Definición oficial: Lichen-dominated communities of level rock or erosional debris surfaces of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the boreal and boreo-nemoral regions of the Palaearctic.

Epilithic lichen communities of alvars of the eastern Fenno-Scandian boreonemoral zone dominated by [Lecanora calcarea], with [Collema spp.] and [Verrucaria nigrescens], accompanied by the mosses [Grimmia pulvinata] and [Schistidium apocarpum], associated with debris swards, calcareous grasslands and paucispecific nemoral fissure communities of units 34.1151, 34.317 and 62.1B1.

Carpets of lichens, often very dense, of flat tops of southern and middle Fennoscandian granite, gneiss and acidic sediment, sometimes amphibolite or gabbro, glacier-fashioned rock outcrops, usually dominated by [Cladonia rangiferina], sometimes associated with mosses and with scrub, grass and forb fissure communities of unit 62.2A.

Nombre oficial: Nemoral and alpine pavement lichen communities
Definición oficial: Lichen-dominated communities of level rock or erosional debris surfaces of lowlands, hills and mountains of the nemoral regions of the Palaearctic.
Lichen-dominated communities of level rock or erosional debris surfaces of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the mediterranean regions of the Palaearctic.

Nombre oficial: Rock pavement, plateau and summital moss heaths
Definición oficial: More or less level surfaces of rock of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic exposed or shattered by erosion or weathering processes, colonized by dense moss carpets.

Moss carpets, often thick and extensive, developed over more or less level surfaces of rock or erosional rock debris accumulations of lowlands, hills and mountains of boreal, boreo-nemoral or arctic regions of the Palaearctic, particularly characteristic of basaltic, siliceous, or sometimes calcareous, summits and plateaux of the North-Atlantic, in Iceland, the Faeroes, Scotland and, locally, the Scandinavian mountains, northern England and northern Wales, Greenland, Spitzbergen. These moss-heaths, dominated by [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum] or [Rhacomitrium canescens] (unit 62.331 x 36.322), constitute, together with the lava-field formations of unit 66.312 (unit 66.312 x 36.3223), one of the most original landscapes of Iceland and the North Atantic.
Moss carpets of more or less level surfaces of rock or erosional rock debris accumulations of lowlands, hills and mountains of nemoral, steppe and mediterranean regions of the Palaearctic.

Pools, usually temporary, forming in basins, hollows or depressions on more or less level surfaces of rock of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic. They may be colonized by highly specialized communities of units 22.2 and 22.3.

Pools, usually temporary, forming in karst pans, runnels, basins, pits of limestone pavements of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic. They may be colonized by highly specialized communities of units 22.25, 22.27 and 22.3. Remarkable, endemic-rich faunas occur, in particular, in temporary pools of Malta, of the Causses and of the Slovenian karst.

Pools, usually temporary, forming on siliceous or basaltic pavements, slabs and domes of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic. They may be colonized by highly specialized communities of units 22.21, 22.22, 22.27 and 22.3. Particularly remarkable are the plati¿re pools of sandstone slabs of southern Ile-de-France harbouring a highly unique flora and fauna, particularly of crustaceans.
Noncoastal cliffs and exposed rocks of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic. At high altitudes and high latitudes, they may be devoid of vascular vegetation

Limestone rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic. Their lichen communities are composed of internal crustose lichens ([Protoblastenia], [Verrucaria], [Petractis], [Polyblastia]), external crustose lichens ([Caloplaca], [Xanthoria]) or gelatinous ([Collema]) and foliose ([Dermatocarpon]) lichens.

Nombre oficial: High altitude and arctic limestone cliffs
Definición oficial: Limestone rocks, cliffs and nunataks of nondesert arctic regions and of the nival, or aeolian, level of mountains of the Palaearctic.

Limestone rocks and cliffs of the alpine to montane levels of high mountains of the mediterranean, nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, harbouring specialized alpine chasmophyte communities.

Limestone rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, harbouring specialized boreal fissure communities, including near vertical surfaces of alvars of the eastern Fenno-Scandian boreonemoral zone occupied by epilithic lichen communities of unit 62.32, associated with debris swards, calcareous grasslands and paucispecific nemoral fissure communities of units 34.1151, 34.317 and 62.1B1.
Limestone rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the nemoral zone of the Palaearctic, harbouring impoverished, paucispecific, fissure communities.
Limestone rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the Mediterranean region, harbouring specialized Mediterranean chasmophyte communities.

Siliceous rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic. Their lichen communities are composed of external crustose lichens ([Rhizocarpon]), navel lichens ([Umbilicaria]) and fruticose lichens ([Ramalina], [Cornicularia], [Rhizoplaca]).

Nombre oficial: High altitude and arctic siliceous cliffs
Definición oficial: Siliceous rocks, cliffs and nunataks of nondesert arctic regions and of the nival, or aeolian, level of mountains of the Palaearctic.

Siliceous rocks and cliffs of the alpine to montane levels of high mountains of the mediterranean, nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, harbouring specialized alpine chasmophyte communities.
Siliceous rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, harbouring specialized boreal fissure communities.
Siliceous rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the nemoral zone of the Palaearctic, harbouring impoverished, paucispecific, fissure communities.
Siliceous rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the Mediterranean region, harbouring specialized Mediterranean chasmophyte communities.

Nombre oficial: Basaltic and ultrabasic dry inland cliffs
Definición oficial: Basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and mountains of nondesert regions of the Palaearctic, including basalts, gabbros, dolerites, andesites, ultramafites (serpentines, peridotites).

Nombre oficial: High altitude and arctic basaltic and ultrabasic cliffs
Definición oficial: Basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks, cliffs and nunataks of nondesert arctic regions and of the nival, or aeolian, level of mountains of the Palaearctic.

Basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks and cliffs of the alpine to montane levels of high mountains of the mediterranean, nemoral, boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, harbouring specialized alpine chasmophyte communities.

Nombre oficial: Boreo-nemoral and boreal basaltic and ultrabasic cliffs
Definición oficial: Basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks and cliffs of the boreonemoral and boreal zones of the Palaearctic, harbouring specialized boreal fissure communities.

Nombre oficial: Nemoral low altitude basaltic and ultrabasic cliffs
Definición oficial: Basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the nemoral zone of the Palaearctic.
Basic or ultrabasic noncalcareous rocks and cliffs of lowlands, hills and low mountains of the Mediterranean region.
Very wet, dripping, overhanging or vertical rocks of hills, mountains and Mediterranean lowlands.

Wet inland cliffs of Mediterranean regions, with a specialized vegetation formed by [Adiantum capillus-veneris], mosses, [Borago pygmaea], [Pinguicula grandiflora] ssp. [coenocantabrica], [Pinguicula hirtiflora].
Wet inland cliffs of middle European hills and mountains. They are often colonized by unique plant assemblages, the components of which are, however, equally characteristic of other habitats

Inland cliffs of the Canary Islands, Madeira and the Azores, extremely rich in endemic species of both plants and animals, including vertebrates (the endangered [Pterodroma madeira]). The genus [Aeonium] is particularly representative.
High mountain zones and high latitude land masses occupied by glaciers or by perennial snow. They may be inhabited by algae and invertebrates.
Quasipermanent snow packs, in particular in avalanche corridors.
Rock, stone or debris formations covering buried or underlying ice, small areas of uncovered permanent or semipermanent ice caused by relief features.
Glacier-like tongues of angular talus extending out from a cirque and slowly moving downslope under the effect of gravity and of underlying, fully covered, interstitial ice.

Fairly large ridges or mounds of morainic material containing buried ice, originating from till deposited on former glacier ice or from morainic material deposited on a snow bank, adjacent to the ice front.
Small ice masses, permanent, or with an existence of a few years, derived in particular from snow-drifting, avalanches, or ice deposition in cold-bottom karst dolines.
Masses of snow and ice formed by the consolidation under pressure of snow falling on high ground, moving outward and downward from the zone of accumulation to lower ground.

Dome-like ice masses unconstrained by topography, together with their outlet glaciers. They are characteristic of arctic regions. The largest ice sheet in the northern hemisphere is that of Greenland. Smaller ice sheets and ice caps occur in Iceland, Jan Mayen, Spitsbergen, southern Norway, Franz Josef Land, Severnaya Zemlya and the islands of the De-Longa group.

Glaciers constrained by topography, including cirque glaciers, valley glaciers, mountain glaciers, piedmont glaciers. They are characteristic, in particular, of the large mountain ranges of the Alpine system, occurring also in arctic regions, notably on Novaya Zemlya, in the subpolar and polar Urals, in the east Siberian mountains and, locally, in Iceland.

Habitats, habitat complexes and landscapes dominated by accumulations of sand, rarely of silt or clay, deposited by aeolian processes and often possessing marked constructional relief, developed within the boreal, nemoral, steppic, warm-temperate humid, mediterranean or subdesert steppe zones, separated from the coast and its dune cordons by nondunal habitats. Unvegetated areas, algae-, lichen- or bryophyte-dominated pioneer communities and very sparse communities of higher plants are listed in this section. Other communities are noted by combination of units of this section with units from sections 3 or 4. Desert sands are excluded and listed under section 7.
Tertiary sands with upright stones and open psammophytic vegetation of the Varna district of Bulgaria.

Dunes of the North Sea and Baltic plains, formed of quartzic sands originating in redeposited and reworked glacial drift and outwash. They are highly siliceous in the Netherlands, northern Belgium and northwestern Germany, progressively slightly less oligotrophic and with a more continental cort¿ge in northeastern Germany, Poland and the eastern Baltic plain. The dune systems, particularly the large ones, harbour a unique ensemble of interacting communities and harbour many specialized and restricted organisms. They have considerably regressed and the remaining examples are fragile and often threatened. The presence of the various elements of the ecosystem can be indicated by simultaneous use of the codes below and of those relevant to the types of plant communities they represent.

Formations of unstable Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland sands with [Corynephorus canescens], [Carex arenaria], [Spergula morisonii], [Teesdalia nudicaulis] and carpets of fruticose lichens ([Cladonia], [Cetraria]) (cf. unit 35.23). Communities of Jutland are rich in [Ammophila arenaria].
Grasslands of more stabilized Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland dune systems with [Agrostis spp.] and [Corynephorus canescens] or other acidophilous grasses
Heaths colonizing Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland dunes.

Crowberry heaths (unit 31.2272) of the relict wandering dunes of Drente and southern Friesland, with [Empetrum nigrum], [Salix arenaria], [Lophochloa cuspidata], [Pseudoscleropodium purum], [Hylocomium splendens].
Sub-Atlantic [Calluna-Genista] heaths colonizing Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland dunes, other than those of 64.131
Formations of large shrubs colonizing Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland dunes.
[Juniperus communis]-rich scrubs of Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland dunes (unit 31.882).
Thickets other than juniper scrubs in Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland dune systems

Natural woods, usually birch-oak or, east of the Elbe, [Pinus sylvestris], installed within Germano-Baltic fluvioglacial inland dune systems. Their composition can be specified by use of codes of 41 or 42.
Formations of the immediate vicinity of great rivers within the North Sea-Baltic plain, comprising, besides the communities of 64.11 to 64.15, slightly calcareous grasslands of 34.12 and 34.34.

Remnants of the once vast Breckland inland dune system, of similar glacial origin to that of the continental fluvioglacial dunes of unit 64.1, and like them, colonized by acidophilous grasslands and heaths.

Dune cordons marking former, though post-glacial, seashores. They are strongly decalcified and the communities that occupy them are similar to those of continental dunes, though floristically more influenced by the proximity of the sea, and often related to the decalcified inner fringes of the coastal dunes. Subhabitats may be indicated by use of the same codes as in unit 64.1 (replacing the prefix 64.1 by 64.3), specified by those of units 35.2, 31.2, 31.8, 41, 42 or 16.2.

Dunes of the great rivers of middle Europe (Seine, Loire, Saone, upper Rhine, upper Elbe). Like the fluvioglacial dunes of northern Europe, they carry specialized and rare ecosystems. They are much more calcareous than the northern inland dunes and their grasslands (units 34.12, 34.34, [i.a.]) have a substeppic character contrasting with that of neighbouring regions. They are highly vulnerable. A small remnant exists in the Po plain of northern Italy.
Unique dunes of the Savoie shore of Lake Geneva (Excenevex).
Inland dunes of the mediterranean climate regions of the Palaearctic domaine.
Fossil dunes of the Camargue, built up by silty alluvial sands of the Rh¿ne.
Mediterranean tall cane beds and grassland communities of the Camargue inland dunes.
Tall cane communities of Camargue dune slacks and dune bases, with [Imperata cylindrica] and [Saccharum ravennae] (unit 53.61).
Dry grasslands of the [Malcomietalia] (unit 35.4), [Thero-Brachypodietea] (unit 34.5), [Brachypodietalia phoenicoidis] (unit 34.36) colonizing inland Camargue dunes.
Mediterranean scrubs of the Camargue inland dunes. Communities can be indicated by combination with unts of division 32.
[Juniperus phoenicea] ssp. [lycia] woodland of the bois des Ri¿ges in the Camargue.
Fossil dunes of the Coto Do?ana and other areas of southwestern Iberia. They support very specialized brushes (32.2A) and open grasslands belonging to the [Malcomietalia] (35.4, 16.228).
Inland dunes developed in the middle Eurasian, Irano-Anatolian and Saharo-Mediterranean steppe zones of the Palaearctic domaine, under continental climatic regimes.
Inland dunes of the Pannonic plain and of neighbouring basins, northwest to the Marchfeld.

Initial stage of renewal of the surface of wandering dunes, devoid or almost devoid of phanerogamic vegetation, in which the bare sand surface is usually covered by a thin film of soil algae and supports the fungus [Psatirella ammophyla].

Lichen-dominated earliest stage of the first succession phase of colonisation of Pannonic dunes, with [Cladonia convoluta], [Cladonia furcata], [Cladonia magyarica] and the bryophytes [Syntrichia ruralis], [Tortula spp].

Therophyte-dominated later stages of the first succession phase in the colonisation of the Pannonic dunes, characterized by a very thin, low cover of mostly ephemereal, early-blooming annuals of small stature, among which [Bromus mollis], [Bromus tectorum], [Bromus squarrosus], [Medicago minima], [Cerastium brachypetalum], [Erophila verna], [Plantago indica], [Saxifraga tridactylites], [Poa annua], [Poa bulbosa], [Viola kitaibeliana], [Lithospermum arvense], [Corispermum nitidum], [Polygonum arenarium], with a few more perennials such as [Equisetum ramosissimum] var. [altissimum], [Alyssum tortuosum], [Sedum acre], [Cynodon dactylon].

More or less open grasslands constituting the second stage of succession in the colonisation of Pannonic dunes, dominated by the perennial grasses [Festuca vaginata], [Stipa capillata], [Stipa borysthenica], [Cleistogenes serotina], [Koeleria glauca], [Koeleria cristata], [Carex liparocarpos], accompanied by [Euphorbia seguierana], [Alkanna tinctoria], [Alyssum montanum] ssp. [gmelinii], [Dianthus serotinus], [Dianthus diutinus], [Gypsophila paniculata], [Scabiosa ochroleuca], [Astragalus austriacus], [Astragalus onobrychis], [Erysimum diffusum], [Fumana procumbens], [Minuartia glomerata], [Minuartia verna]

Closed swards of basophilous, humus- and nutrient-rich, sandy or mixed sand-loessy soils of Pannonic fixed dunes, dominated by [Festuca rupicola], [Festuca wagneri], [Festuca pseudovina] or, in some facies, [Chrysopogon gryllus], with [Carex liparocarpos], [Festuca vaginata], [Agropyron cristatum] ssp. [pectinatum], [Achillea ochroleuca], [Astragalus asper], [Astragalus onobrychis], [Astragalus exscapus], [Potentilla cinerea], [Muscari botryoides], [Muscari comosum], [Linum austriacum], [Thymus glabrescens], [Iris variegata], [Iris humilis] ssp. [arenaria], [Colchicum arenarium], [Ophrys sphegodes], [Anacamptis pyramidalis], [Salvia nemorosa], [Alyssum spp.], [Silene parviflora], [Dianthus giganteiformis] ssp. [pontederae], [Lotus spp.], [Onosma arenaria] ssp. [pseudoarenaria].
Formations of large shrubs colonizing Pannonic dunes.
Natural woods installed within Pannonic dune systems. Their composition can be specified by use of codes of 41.
Dune woods of the main Pannonic basin and its connected satellites
Woods of the sands of the border of the former Pannonic sea, along the internal part of the Carpathian bend, formed by [Betula pendula] and [Quercus robur] (unit 41.B37).

Inland dunes of the Pontic plain and of neighbouring basins, including the lower Danube basin of Oltenia and Muntenia and the northern Thracian plain, the northern Black Sea-Sea of Azov plain with the basins of the Dnieper and the Don, northeast to the Volga, east to the Caspian deserts and semideserts, southeast to the pre-Caucasian hills in the basins of the Kouban, the Manytch, the upper Kuma and upper Terek (units 34.921 and 34.923).
Initial stage of renewal of the surface of wandering Pontic dunes, devoid or almost devoid of phanerogamic vegetation.
Lichen-dominated earliest stage of the first succession phase of colonisation of Pontic dunes.

Therophyte-dominated later stages of the first succession phase in the colonisation of Pontic dunes, characterized by a very thin, low cover of mostly ephemereal, early-blooming annuals of small stature. Detailed communities can be indicated by addition of codes identifying subunits of 34.A211.

More or less open grasslands constituting the second stage of succession in the colonisation of Pontic dunes. Detailed communities can be indicated by addition of codes identifying subunits of 34.A212.

Closed swards of basophilous, humus- and nutrient-rich, sandy or mixed sand-loessy soils of Pontic fixed dunes.  Detailed communities can be indicated by addition of codes identifying units 34.A213 or 34.A214.
Formations of large shrubs colonizing Pontic dunes.
Natural woods installed within Pontic dune systems. Their composition can be specified by use of codes of 41.

Dunes of the wooded steppe belt occupying, north of the Pontic and Caspian plains, the southern edge and valleys of the Podolian, Central Russian and Volga plateaux east to the Volga-Kama trough (unit 34.922).

Dunes of the steppe and wooded steppe belts of extreme eastern Europe and western Siberia, extending from the Volga-Kama system in the west to the Tarbagatai and western Altai in the east, including the Transvolgan steppes of Orenburg and Bachkiria, the Kurgan, Ishim, Baraba, Kulunda, Barnaul, Kirgiz, Kazakh steppes, and the mountain steppes of the Tarbagatai and the Altai (unit 34.93).

Dunes of the East Asian steppes (unit 34.94) of Transbaikalia, Outer Mongolia, Inner Mongolia, the Songnen Plain of Northeast China, the western Loess Plateau of North China, the mountain steppes of the Tien Shan, from the rim of the Naryn and Isyk-K¿l basins eastwards, of the Sayan and Tannu mountains, in particular, of the steppes of Inner Mongolia and Manchuria.

Inland dunes of the Anatolian Plateau, of Transcaucasia, of the Iranian Plateau and of northern Mesopotamia, in the Irano-Anatolian zone of transition between the continental Eurasian steppes and the Mediterranean and southern Palaearctic desert zones, of the eastern cis-Caucasian hills of Daghestan and the Terek basin, the Kopet Dagh, the Pamir-Alai, the extreme western Tien-Shan.
Dunes of the North African Hauts Plateaux.
Inland dunes of the boreal zone of the Palaearctic domaine.

Inland dunes, unvegetated or colonized by species-poor grassland communities dominated by [Leymus arenarius] or [Festuca cryophila], with [Equisetum boreale], [Silene uniflora], [Silene maritima], [Armeria maritima].
Lacustrine inland dunes of the northern boreal region, in particular, of Lake Inari in Finland.
Inland dunes of the nemoral and warm-humid temperate zones of the eastern Palaearctic domaine.

Natural caves, cave systems, underground waters and subterranean interstitial spaces. Caves and their associated waters (units 65.1-65.7) harbour varied, but paucispecific, communities of animals, fungi and algae that are restricted to them (troglobiont organisms), or are physiologically and ecologically capable of conducting their entire life cycle within them (troglophile organisms), or are dependent on them for part of the life cycle (subtroglophile organisms). Underground waters not associated with caves (stygon, unit 65.8) and interstitial spaces (units 65.9, 65.A) harbour distinctive faunas.

Communities occupying the compartment of the subterranean ecosystem in direct contact with the lower horizon of the soil, at a depth ranging from a few centimeters to a few meters, in the interconnected microspaces of the colluvions or the fissures of the superficial zones of the bedrock. Distinctive interstitial assemblies of troglobiont invertebrates, comprising coleoptera, myriapods, isopods, spiders, pseudoscorpions, have been described from the Pyrenees, the Alps, the Carpathians, the Canary Islands, the Azores.

Caves harbouring communities that include troglobic amphibians or fish, limited worldwide to a very small number of highly distinctive organisms, mostly relict forms of extremely limited distribution, including 15 species of amphibians, limited to North America and Europe, and about 38 species of fishes belonging to 13 families, notably, Cyprinidae, Gobiidae, Bythitidae, Pimelodidae, Characidae, Cobitidae, Amblyopsidae, Clariidae, Ictaluridae, Trichomycteridae, Ophidiidae, Synbranchidae. Palaearctic representatives include a unique amphibian, as well as cyprinids and gobiid fishes.
Caves of the Adriatic karst system of Italy, Slovenia, Croatia and Montenegro, harbouring the relict amphibian [Proteus anguinus], the most remarkable of all troglobiont vertebrates.
Caves harbouring communities that include troglobic fish, limited in the Palaearctic region to representatives of the Cyprinidae and Gobiidae.
Caves harbouring communities that include troglobic Cyprinidae, known, in particular, from Iran, Iraq, Oman and from China.
Caves of the Near and Middle East harbouring communities that include troglobic Cyprinidae, mostly loaches or garrine fishes, known, in particular, from Iran, Iraq and Oman.
Caves of the Near and Middle East harbouring communities that include troglobic garrine fishes, known, in particular, from Iran, Iraq and Oman.
Caves of the Iranian plateau harbouring the Cyprinid [Iranocypris typhlops].
Caves of the Euphrates basin of Irak harbouring the Cyprinid [Typhlogarra widdowsoni].
Caves of Oman harbouring communities that include troglobic garrine fishes of genus [Garra].
Caves of Iraq harbouring communities that include the troglobic cyprinid of unknown affinities [Caecocypris].
Caves of the Near and Middle East harbouring communities that include troglobic loaches, known, in particular, from Iran.
Caves of the eastern Palaearctic harbouring communities that include troglobic Cyprinidae, known, in particular, from China, with two species of loaches and one with garrine fishes.
Caves harbouring communities that include troglobic Gobiidae, known from Japan, with two species, [Luciogobius albus] and [Luciogobius pallidus].
Caves of the main Eurasian and African landmasses essential to parts of the life-cycle of vertebrate subtroglophiles (elective periodic trogloxenes).
Caves of the main Eurasian and African landmasses providing an essential habitat of reptilian and amphibian subtroglophiles (elective periodic trogloxenes).
Caves harbouring the salamanders [Speleomantes] ([Hydromantes]), [Speleomantes ambrosii] and [Speleomantes italicus] of southeastern France and northern and central Italy.

Caves harbouring the salamander [Speleomantes ambrosii] ([Hydromantes ambrosii]) of southeastern France and northern Italy, with several races of extremely local distribution, in particular, in the Ligurian Alps, the Maritime alps, the Provence Alpes.

Caves harbouring the salamander [Speleomantes italicus] ([Speleomantes]  = [Hydromantes]) of northern and central Italy, with two races of local distribution in the Apuan Alps, the Modenan, Emilian, Toscan, Umbrian, Marchesian Apennines.
Caves of the main Eurasian and African landmasses providing an essential habitat of reptilian subtroglophiles (elective periodic trogloxenes), in particular, geckos or snakes.

Caves of the Eurasian and North African landmasses, under normally oxygenated, buffered microclimates, generally large and crossed by watercourses or excavated near epigean watercourses, with permanent or temporary colonies of bats, in majority belonging to the Vespertilionidae.
Caves of the islands of Eurasia and North Africa essential to parts of the life-cycle of vertebrate subtroglophiles (elective periodic trogloxenes).
Caves on islands off the main Eurasian and African landmasses providing an essential habitat of reptilian and amphibian subtroglophiles (elective periodic trogloxenes).
Caves of the calcareous massifs of Sardinia harbouring salamanders of the genus [Speleomantes] ([Hydromantes]) and constituting an essential habitat for their existence.
Caves of the Sulcis and the Iglesiente of southwestern Sardinia, notably in the Domusnovas area of the Fiuminese massif, harbouring [Speleomantes genei].
Caves of the Gerrei and of the Salto di Quirra in the southeastern quadrant of Sardinia, harbouring [Speleomantes imperialis].
Caves of the Monte Albo massif of eastern Sardinia, harbouring [Speleomantes flavus].
Caves of the massifs facing the Gulf of Orosei, notably of the Orosei, Dorgali, Oliena, Orgosolo, Baunei areas of eastern Sardinia, harbouring [Speleomantes supramontis].
Caves of the Ryukyu archipelago harbouring [Gymnodactylus yamashinae] or [Eublapheris splendens].
Caves of the islands of Eurasia and North Africa with permanent or temporary colonies of bats.

Caves harbouring communities that include no troglobiont amphibians or fish, but include troglobiont invertebrates, limited worldwide to a relatively small number of species belonging to a limited number of groups, and including remarkable relict species. In the Palaearctic region, the majority are situated in the northern Mediterranean basin and the peri-Pontic region. Gastropoda, Opiliones, Chilopoda (Lithobiidae), Collembol, Coleoptera (Bathysciinae and Trechinae subfamilies) among the terrestrial faunas, Turbellaria, Gastropoda and Urodela, among the aquatic faunas, are characteristic of their communities, and essentially restricted to caves of temperate regions.

Caves under normally oxygenated, buffered microclimates, dry, humidified by seeps or crossed by permanent or temporary watercourses, but not retaining glaciers, and harbouring communities of troglobiont invertebrates, often including remarkable relict species.
Caves under normally oxygenated, buffered microclimates, harbouring communities of troglobiont invertebrates, and in which past and present conditions permit the retention of glaciers
Caves under normally oxygenated, buffered microclimates, warmed and humidified by geothermal waters, and harbouring communities of troglobiont invertebrates.

Deoxygenated, relatively warm caves, with atmospheres rich in carbon dioxide and sulphur vapour or methane and hydrogen sulfide, harbouring relict thermophile faunas of highly distinctive troglobiont and stygobiont invertebrates.
Caves harbouring ecosystems linked to sulphurous geothermal waters in a  relatively warm, deoxygenated methane- and hydrogen sulfide-rich atmosphere.

Movile cave of the southern Romanian Dobrogea, harbouring a singular chemoautotrophically based ecosystem linked to sulphurous geothermal waters in a quasi-closed, relatively warm (20øC), deoxygenated methane- and hydrogen sulfide-rich atmosphere, comprising a unique, totally isolated, thermophile and thiophile relict fauna of highly distinctive troglobiont and stygobiont invertebrates.
Hydrothermal sulphur caves of Hungary, Croatia and Slovenia.
Adam cave from Baile Herculane, Romania, relatively warm, deoxygenated, with very much carbon dioxide, partly influenced by sulphur vapours, harbouring a  relict thermophile fauna

Caves harbouring communities that include no troglobiont organisms, but include troglophile invertebrates. Generally, they are caves crossed by watercourses or with rich trophic substratum, excavated in limestone afforested zones.
Caves essential to parts of the life-cycle (quiescence period) of invertebrate subtroglophiles (elective periodic trogloxenes), such as Lepidoptera, Diptera, Hymenoptera, Coleoptera
Caves, often small and dry, devoid of significant troglobiont or troglophile zoocoenoses, and not harbouring significant subtroglophiles.

Communities harboured by ground waters (stygon), not including those of cave waters. They are constituted by mostly small, elongated forms, in Europe principally bacteria, protozoans, turbellarians, rotifers, nematodes, copepods and amphipods.

Communities occupying anchialine (or anchihaline) habitats, underground bodies of more or less saline water, usually with a restricted exposure to open air, always with more or less extensive subterranean connections to the sea. They  show noticeable marine as well as terrestrial influences. They are varied, located within either volcanic or limestone bedrock. Distinctive communities of anchialine stygobionts, mostly crustaceans, have been discovered, in particular, in Italy, the western Balkan peninsula, the Sinai peninsula, the Canary Islands, the Azores.
Communities of stygobiont invertebrates and vertebrates, highly distinctive, occupying eustygal habitats, interstitial water saturating porous sediments below the water table.

Rhythrostygal (potamostygal) communities of stygobiont organisms, mostly fresh-water mites and small crustaceans, occupying interstitial water in sand and gravel sediments accompanying running water courses.

Hard rock surfaces, rock jumbles, loose material deposits, soils, water bodies resulting from recent or present volcanic activity, unvegetated, occupied by lichens or mosses, or colonized by specialized, relatively sparse herb- or shrub-dominated communities.
Summital zone of the Teide volcano of Tenerife, above (2700) 3000 metres, colonized by very open communities of [Viola cheiranthifolia], [Silene nocteolens] and [Argyranthemum teneriffae].

Summital zone of very high volcanoes of the Eurasian land mass and its nearshore islands, in particular, of Mount Etna, above the level of hedgehog heaths, of the high volcanoes of western Asia and of those of the Far East.

Summital zone of Mount Etna, above the level of hedgehog heaths, between 2500 metres and the summit, where a very dispersed pioneer community is formed by endemics, notably [Rumex aetnensis], [Senecio aetnensis], [Anthemis aetnensis], [Hypochoeris robertia].

Summital zone of very high volcanoes of western Asia, in particular, of Nemrut Dag in eastern Turkey, Damavand in northern Iran, Taftan in southern Iran, with [Polygonum radicosum], [Crepis demavendi], [Artemisia melanolipis], [Carex pseudofoetida].

Summital zone of very high volcanoes of the Far East, in particular, alpine communities of Mount Fuji-Yama, with, between about 2700 and 3450 metres, [Polygonum weyrichii] var. [alpinum], [Arabis serrata], [Artemisia pedunculosa], [Stellaria niponica], [Salix renii], [Carex stenantha], [Cassiope lycopodioides], and, between 3450 metres and the summit at 3776 metres, moss and lichen communities formed by [Rhacomitrium microcarpum], [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum], [Dicranum fuscescens], [Dicranum rugosum], [Stereocaulon vesubianum], [Rhizocarpon geographicum], [Alectoria lata].

Nombre oficial: Lava flows, lava fields, lava features
Definición oficial: Hard or porous rocky surfaces and chaotic rock jumbles formed by solidified lava flows originating from volcanoes and fissures of the Palaearctic domaine, unvegetated, occupied by lichens or mosses, or colonized by specialized, relatively sparse herb- or shrub-dominated communities. They are restricted to the Mid-Atlantic ridge and its associated fracture zones, in Iceland and the Macaronesian islands, responsible for a large proportion of the volume of recent lava in the world, to the collision zones and constructive margins of southern Eurasia, in the Mediterranean and Tethyan basins along the folds of the Alpine system, to the Red Sea rim, on the Arabian peninsula, and to the western Pacific rim and island arcs. A range of surface characteristics is presented by lava of differing composition, viscosity and gas content, including pahoehoe or ropy lava, aa, scoria, pumice and pillow lava. A gradient of increasing acidity and viscosity extends from basalts through andesites and dacites to rhyolites.

Pleistocene lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of Iceland, concentrated in the neovolcanic zones that stretch along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge from northeast Iceland to the Reykjanes peninsula, branch south of it to the Vestmann Islands, and occupy the Snaefell peninsula.

Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of Iceland devoid of vegetation or sparsely vegetated by algae, lichens and mosses, which constitute the first stage of colonisation, with covers of up to 20-40%. The main constituents of the vegetation are the lichens [Stereocaulon vesubianum], [Stereocaulon alpinum], [Stereocaulon arcticum], [Alectoria ochroleuca], [Cladonia pyxidata], [Lecidea spp.], [Lecanora spp.] and the mosses [Grimnia spp.], [Andreaea rupestris], [Andreaea obovata], [Rhacomitrium canescans], [Polytrichum spp.] accompanied by a very few vascular plants, including [Festuca richardsonii], [Thymus praecox] ssp [arcticus], [Poa subcaerulea].

Lava flows and lava fields of Iceland covered by continuous carpets of [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum] (unit 36.3223 [p.]), forming thick mantles that cover very large surfaces over all parts of the relief, engulfing asperities, bridging gaps, draping protruding rocks with large cushions, or else, in less evolved complexes, forming preferentially in the depressions and concavities where some organic matter accumulates. Together with similar formations of the basaltic uplands (unit 62.331 x 36.3223), these moss heaths constitute a particularly original landscape of Iceland.

Nombre oficial: Icelandic lava flow heaths and scrubs
Definición oficial: Heaths, scrubs or low birch woods colonizing parts of lava flows and lava fields of Iceland, mostly in hollows where loess accumulates, within the [Rhacomitrium lanuginosum] carpets of unit 66.312. [Empetrum spp.], [Arctostaphylos uva-ursi], [Vaccinium uliginosum], [Betula nana] are the main heath components. At a later stage, [Betula pubescens] ssp. [czerepanovii] may invade and form scrubs and thickets. Subdivisions of division 3, in particular, of units 31.2113 and 31.4551, and of unit 41.B71, may be used in conjunction with unit 66.313 to describe the formations.
Communities colonizing fissures, cracks, overhangs and cave entrances formed in lava flows and lava fields of Iceland, and on the faces of dykes, stacks and other surfaces protruding from them.

Bryophyte-dominated communities colonizing fissures or cavities  of lava flows and lava fields of Iceland, in particular, sciaphile communities of [Distichium capillaceum], [Pohlia cruda], [Mnium marginatum], [Timmia austriaca], [Bartramia ityphylla], [Mnium stellare], [Plagiothecium roeseanum] and [Cystopteris fragilis] characteristic of loess-collecting lava vesicular cavities and of shady ledges.

Sparse vascular plant communities colonizing fissures and cracks of lava flows and lava fields of Iceland, and the faces of dykes, stacks and other surfaces protruding from them. Codes of division 62, in particular, of units 62.1C and 62.2A can be combined with unit 66.314 to further define the community.
Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the Azores, the Canary Islands and the Cape Verde Islands.

Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the Azores, the Canary Islands and the Cape Verde Islands, unvegetated, occupied by usually discontinuous communities dominated by algae, lichens or mosses, sometimes colonized by very sparse vascular plants. Barren lava fields of Fuerteventura, Lobos and Lanzarote are the main habitat of the endemic and vulnerable Canary Shrew, [Crocidura canariensis].

Nombre oficial: Macaronesian lava flow scrubs and woods
Definición oficial: Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the Azores, the Canary Islands and the Cape Verde Islands, occupied by open or closed communities dominated by herbs, shrubs or trees, in particular, of units 31.7F, 31.31, 31.846, 32.8, 42.9, 42.A8, 45. Codes of these units can be combined with 66.322 to define habitats.

Rich and diverse fissure, crack and overhang communities colonizing lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the volcanoes of the Azores, the Canary Islands and the Cape Verde Islands. Codes of unit 62.6 can be combined with 66.323 to further define the community.

Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the volcanoes of the Mediterranean Basin and of western Asia, including Etna, Vesuvius, the Phlegrean Fields, Ischia, the Lipari Islands, Pantelleria, the Aegean archipelago, Nemrut Dag in eastern Turkey, Damavand in northern Iran, Taftan in southern Iran, the volcanoes of Syria.

Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the volcanoes of the Mediterranean Basin and of western Asia, unvegetated, occupied by usually discontinuous communities dominated by algae, lichens, notably [Stereocaulon vesubianum], or mosses, sometimes colonized by very sparse vascular plants.

Nombre oficial: Tethyan lava flow scrubs and woods
Definición oficial: Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the volcanoes of the Mediterranean Basin and of western Asia, occupied by open or closed communities dominated by herbs, shrubs or trees, in particular, of units 31.7, 31.845, 32, 34, 35, 36, 41.B6, 42. Codes of these units can be combined with 66.332 to define habitats.

Fissure, crack and overhang communities colonizing lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of the volcanoes of the Mediterranean Basin and of western Asia. Codes of unit 62 can be combined with 66.333 to further define the community.

Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of volcanoes of the Red Sea rim, situated, within the Palaearctic region as here defined, in the region of Medina and near the southwestern extremity of the Arabian peninsula.

Lava flows, fields, dykes, necks, domes, cones of volcanoes of the western rim of the Pacific Basin and its associated island arcs, situated, in particular, in Kamtchatka, the Kuriles, Japan, the Ryu-Kyu Islands, Manchuria and eastern Siberia.

Exposed deposits of pyroclastic rocks, fragmental volcanic material blown into the atmosphere by explosive activity, including ash, lapilli, bombs, pel¿es hair, or of detritic pumice and scoriae, together with the pioneer assemblies of specialized species that may colonize them.
Exposed deposits of pyroclastic rocks, including ash, lapilli, bombs, pel¿es hair, pumice and scoriae, of Iceland, together with the pioneer assemblies of specialized species that may colonize them.

Exposed deposits of pyroclastic rocks, including ash, lapilli, bombs, pel¿es hair, pumice and scoriae, of the Azores, the Canary Islands and the Cape Verde Islands, together with the pioneer assemblies of specialized species that may colonize them.

Exposed deposits of pyroclastic rocks, including ash, lapilli, bombs, pel¿es hair, pumice and scoriae, of the Mediterranean Basin and of western Asia, including Etna, Vesuvius, the Phlegrean Fields, Ischia, the Lipari Islands, Pantelleria, the Aegean archipelago, Nemrut Dag in eastern Turkey, Damavand in northern Iran, Taftan in southern Iran, the volcanoes of Syria, together with the pioneer assemblies of specialized species that may colonize them.

Nombre oficial: Red Sea ash and lapilli fields
Definición oficial: Exposed deposits of pyroclastic rocks, including ash, lapilli, bombs, pel¿es hair, pumice and scoriae, of the Red Sea rim, situated, within the Palaearctic region as here defined, in the region of Medina and near the southwestern extremity of the Arabian peninsula, together with the pioneer assemblies of specialized species that may colonize them.

Exposed deposits of pyroclastic rocks, including ash, lapilli, bombs, pel¿es hair, pumice and scoriae, of the western rim of the Pacific Basin and its associated island arcs, situated, in particular, in Kamtchatka, the Kuriles, Japan, the Ryu-Kyu Islands, Manchuria and eastern Siberia, together with the pioneer assemblies of specialized species that may colonize them.

Caves formed in lava flows by open-ended tubes or passages resulting from the cooling of the surface whose moulten interior continued to flow. They may be colonized by anchihaline communities of unit 65.81.
Lava tubes of Iceland.

Lava tubes of of the Azores, the Canary Islands and the Cape Verde Islands. The very large tube created by the volcano La Corona of Lanzarote harbours unique communities of invertebrates, in particular, the decapode crustacean [Munidopsis polymorpha], endemic to that locality, and several crustaceans of the genus [Speleonectes].

Lava tubes of the Mediterranean Basin and of western Asia, including Etna, Vesuvius, the Phlegrean Fields, Ischia, the Lipari Islands, Pantelleria, the Aegean archipelago, Nemrut Dag in eastern Turkey, Damavand in northern Iran, Taftan in southern Iran, the volcanoes of Syria.

Orifices in volcanic areas emitting hot or cold gases and vapours. Their very extreme environment is colonized by paucispecific but highly distinct communities. Included are steam vents (fumaroles), vapour and hot sulphurous gas vents (solfatares), paint pots, porridge pots and mud volcanoes, as well as cold carbon dioxide, methane and nitrogen vents (mofettes), that emit directly into the open atmosphere
Gas vents, fumaroles, solfataras, mofettes related to active volcanism of the Rift, along the Arabian peninsula shores of the Red Sea and in neighbouring regions.
Hot or cold gas vents of the zones of volcanic activity lining the Pacific margins of Eurasia, in particular, of the Jigokudani volcanic site on Hokkaido.
Gas vents, fumaroles, solfataras, mofettes of the North African desert ranges and their periphery.

Fumaroles of the major area of active volcanism of the western Mediterranean basins, located on the Italian peninsula and its small islands, in particular those of Isola dIschia, with communities that include [Cyperus polystachyos]
Fumaroles of Sicily and its nearshore islands, in particular of Mount Etna and the Lipari islands.

Fumaroles of Pantelleria. Their walls, mouth  and immediate vicinity are colonized by a succession of microvegetation composed of bryophytes, ferns and a few angiosperms.  Constituting plants include the endemic moss [Calymperes sommieri], sole Mediterranean representative of a tropical genus, as well as [Radiola linoides], [Kickxia cirrhosa], [Trifolium angustifolium], [Centaurium maritimum].
Fumaroles of the Canary Islands and the Azores.

Fumaroles of the Canary Islands and the communities that depend on the warm-humid microclimate they generate, in particular, communities of the summital zone of Teide comprising the endemic [Gnaphalium teydeum] and bryophytes.
Fumaroles of the Azores.
