Fumaroles and solfataras of Iceland, surrounded by very sparse communities on warm, acid and clayey soils under a humid, warm microclimate, comprising Cyanophycea carpets in the immediate vicinity of the vent, hepatica belts farther out, first of the small [Riccia bifurca] and [Fossombronia dumortieri], then of the more robust [Preissia quadrata], finally, vascular plant assemblies in which [Ophioglossum azoricum], [Sagina procumbens], [Plantago major] var. [pygmaea] are prominent. Vast expanses of sulfur-poisoned ground in the general vicinity of the solfataras are almost devoid of vegetation, with a few vascular plants in less poisoned areas, in particular, [Achillea millefolium].
Fumaroles and solfataras of the areas of active volcanism of the eastern Mediterranean basins, in particular, of the Aegean and the Levantine Sea.

Gas vents, fumaroles, solfataras, mofettes, related to late Tertiary volcanism of the western Alpine system, its periphery, its satellite mountain complexes and its interior basins, including the Pyrenees, the Alps, the Carpathians, and, notably, the Eastern Carpathians, the Jura, the Dinarides, the Hellenides, the Hercynian ranges, the Iberian mountains, the Atlas, the Taurus.  Included in particular are the extensive mofette systems of Bohemia and of the mountains constituting the Bohemian Quadrangle, in particular, those of the bogs of Soos, in the Cheb district of western Bohemia.

Gas vents, fumaroles, solfataras, mofettes of the Caucasus and of western Asian mountains and plateaux, in particular, of the slopes of the Nemrut Dag in Turkey and of the Damavand and Taftan in Iran.
Gas vents, fumaroles, solfataras, mofettes of the the Central Asian mountains and their periphery.

Acid or alkaline springs heated by geothermal energy, located in regions of present or past volcanic activity, producing a continuous flow of water at temperatures significantly above the air temperature. Springs and tepid pools at temperatures below 50ø C may host a few species of specialized animals, those at temperatures between 50ø C and 75ø C harbour bluegreen algae that may form conspicuous mats, those at temperatures above 75ø C are inhabited only by heterotrophic bacteria
Hot springs related to active volcanism of the islands, coasts and hinterland of the Mediterranean basins.
Hot springs of the islands, coasts and hinterland of the areas of active volcanism of the western Mediterranean basins, in particular, of the Tyrrhenian Sea and of the Strait of Sicily.
Hot springs of the islands, coasts and hinterland of the areas of active volcanism of the eastern Mediterranean basins, in particular, of the Aegean and the Levantine Sea.
Hot springs related to active volcanism of the southern north Atlantic, on the mid-Atlantic ridge islands of the Azores and on the Canary Islands, Madeira and the Cape Verde Islands.
Hot springs related to active volcanism of the northern North Atlantic, on the mid-Atlantic ridge islands, Iceland and Jan Mayen.

Warm outflow water of Icelandic hot springs, often extremely basic, with a pH approaching 8-9, mostly devoid of macrophytic vegetation at temperatures above 35ø C, otherwise with species assemblies that vary with water temperature and conditions at each site, including altitude. Characteristic species include [Crassula aquatica], [Hydrocotyle vulgaris] and [Callitriche stagnatilis].

Nombre oficial: Icelandic thermal spring hot soil communities
Definición oficial: Moss and vascular plants communities occurring on warm and moist soils around Icelandic hot springs. Soaked, very hot substrates nearest to the spring are colonized by Cyanophycea, small hepatics, in particular, [Fossombronia dumortieri] and a moss of genus [Archidium]

Hot springs related to late Tertiary volcanism of the western Alpine system, its periphery, its satellite mountain complexes and its interior basins, including the Baetic mountains, the Rif, the Tell, the Atlas, the Pyreneo-Cantabrian range, the Alps, the Carpathians, the mountains of the Balkan peninsula, the Jura, the Hercynian ranges of Iberia, the Central Massif, the northern Hercynian arc. They include, in particular, Romanian geothermal waters harbouring formations of [Nymphaea lotus] (unit 22.43113).

Hot springs related to late Tertiary volcanism of the central Alpine system,  its periphery, its satellite mountain complexes and its interior basins, including the Caucasus, the Pontic range, the Anatolian plateau, the Taurus, the Zagros, the Elburz.

Hot springs related to late Tertiary volcanism of the eastern Alpine system,  its periphery, its satellite mountain complexes and its interior basins, including the Himalayas and the connected ranges of the Pamir-Alai, the Tien Shan and the Hindu Kush.
Hot springs related to active volcanism of the Rift, along the shores of the Red Sea, the Jordan Valley and in neighbouring regions, in particular, springs of the shores of the Sea of Galilee.
Hot springs of the zone of active volcanism of the Pacific ring of fire in Kamchatka, the Japanese archipelago and neighbouring areas of far-eastern Asia.
Hot springs related to past or present volcanism of Saharan Africa.

Springs from which heated water and steam is ejected, sometimes violently, at periodic intervals, in active or recently active volcanic regions. Major geysers are rare, known from only four areas in the world, and within the Palaearctic region, as here defined, only from Iceland and the northwestern Pacific rim. The proximal zone of geysers may host distinctive communities of lower plants and invertebrates.
Geysers of Iceland, of which about 10 are presently active, in particular, in southern Iceland.
Geysers of the zone of volcanic activity riming the Pacific margins of Eurasia, including, for example, those of the Valley of the Geysers, Kamtchatka and of the Jigokudani volcanic site on Hokkaido.

Unvegetated or sparsely vegetated formations of geographically significant extent, developed under arctic, temperate or tropical climates in extreme conditions of low precipitation and high evaporation. Included are all shrub-dominated, grass-dominated or succulent-dominated communities exposed to arid or very arid conditions, typically with annual precipitation inferior to 200 mm, and, as semideserts, shrub-dominated or succulent-dominated, including arborescent succulent-dominated, communities, usually strongly lacunar, formed under semiarid conditions, with annual precipitation that may reach 500 mm or 600 mm. Grass-dominated communities constituted under the latter conditions and representing encroachments of steppes characteristic of neighbouring regions are listed under 3, while all communities that comprise a reasonably continuous, closed or open, stratum of trees, other than arborescent succulents, are listed under 4, most often under 4B. Communities dependent on permanent or temporary surface water are excluded and listed in units 15, 2, 3 or 5

Formations of the most extreme parts of the Arctic zone, characterized by mostly bare ground worked by solifluction and colonized by algae and very species-poor, extremely open communities constituded by lichens, mosses, liverworts and a very restricted number of vascular plants. They are restricted within the Palaearctic as here defined, to the northern tip of the Ta¿myr peninsula, to Greenland and to the islands of the Arctic Ocean.
Polar deserts of the Nordaustlandet of the Spitzbergen archipelago, Victoria Island, Franz Josef Land and the north end of Novaya Zemlya.
Polar deserts of the Nordaustlandet of the Spitzbergen archipelago.
Polar deserts of the small ice-free part of Victoria Island, with an impoverished vegetation comprising a few species of mosses, lichens and ground-covering algae.
Polar deserts of the northern part of the Franz Josef archipelago.
Stone fields, rock heaps and sandy-loamy deluviums of the Franz Josef archipelago devoid of all vegetation, mostly characteristic of areas with prolonged snow cover.

Nombre oficial: Open aggregation Franz Josef polar deserts
Definición oficial: Polar deserts of the Franz Josef archipelago occupied by uniform, species-poor assemblages of widely scattered higher and lower plants, constituting a negligible ground cover.
Polar deserts of the Franz Josef archipelago occupied by a continuous cover of higher and lower plants, broken by bare stones and patches of bare ground.
Polar deserts of the southern part of the Franz Josef archipelago.
Polar deserts of the north end of Novaya Zemlya.
Polar deserts of the North Land Archipelago (Severnaya Zemlya), the extreme northern tip of the Taimyr peninsula and the de Longa Islands, north of the New Siberian Islands.
Polar deserts of ice-free areas of the very glaciated northern islands of the Severnaya Zemlya archipelago, including Ostrov Komsomolets, Ostrov Pioner and the Ostrova Sedova.

Polar deserts of the southern islands of the Severnaya Zemlya archipelago, including Ostrov Oktyabrskoy, Ostrov Revolyutsii, Ostrov Bolshevik, Ostrov Malyy Ta¿myr, Ostrov Starokadomskogo, less glaciated than the northern islands.
Polar deserts of the extreme northern tip of the Taimyr peninsula (Mys Chelyuskin).
Polar deserts of the three islands of the Ostrova de Longa group (De Long Islands), north of the New Siberian Islands.
Polar deserts of the Lincoln Sea coasts of extreme northern Greenland.

Interior continental deserts or semideserts of temperate areas beyond the reach of moisture-laden winds (d¿serts d¿loignement) and rain-shadow deserts or semideserts lying on the leeward side of high mountain ranges which intercept the rain-bearing winds (d¿serts dabri). In the Palaearctic region they are represented by the deserts and semideserts of the Central Eurasian desert region.

Interior continental deserts or semideserts of the Caspian lowlands, the northern Aralo-Caspian depression and Dzungaria, the Atrek basin, the Ustyurt Plateau, the Kyzyl-Kum and Kara-Kum, the Kopet Dag, the Central Asian mountains of the Tien-Shan system.
Interior continental deserts or semideserts of the Iranian and Afghan plateaux, south of the Kopet Dag and the Pamir.

Nombre oficial: Central Asian cool deserts and semideserts
Definición oficial: Interior continental deserts or semideserts of Mongolia, inner Mongolia and the Cis-Hsing-An region, including the Gobi, of the Pei Shan, of Kashgaria and the Tarim Basin with the Takla Makan, of the Ala Shan and the Ordos, of the Kansu corridor and the Tsaidam region.
High-altitude interior continental deserts or semideserts of the Pamir and the Tibetan plateau.

Sunny deserts and arid shrublands developed under tropical or subtropical climates. Most characteristically and extensively, they are situated within the horse latitudes, the 30ø-35ø belts of high atmospheric pressure zones or Hadley cells producing low precipitation and high insolation. Under anomalous local conditions of rain shadow or trade wind regimes, arid shrublands or succulent and arborescent succulent communities may form in other parts of the tropics. They are physiognomically similar to the horse latitude semideserts and are included in this unit. In the Palaearctic region, this unit encompasses the extremely extensive horse-latitude Saharo-Sindian deserts and their semidesert transition to mediterranean habitats or other formations.
Hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, within the Saharo-Arabian floristic domaine

Sand-covered hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, covering more than one-third of the surface of the western Sahara, a somewhat smaller portion of the eastern Sahara, huge expanses of the Arabian Desert, in particular, in the Rubl Khali and the Nafud-Dahna, and substantial surfaces in the northern part and in the intermountain valleys and plains of the Sinai peninsula and in the northern Neguev. They include desert dunes as well as sandy regs and may be unvegetated, especially in the hyperarid zone or carry vegetation of greatly variable development. The communities of the sandy floors of wadis are excluded and listed in unit 73.14.

Species-poor communities of ergs and barkans of the Saharo-Sindian region, including less mobile dunes harbouring communities of graminids and shrubs with roots able to penetrate deeper, moisture retaing layers of sand, or rare communities of annuals, as well as highly mobile, constantly shifting, sands devoid of any vegetation.

Nombre oficial: Saharo-Arabian erg and barkhan grass communities
Definición oficial: Species-poor communities of ergs and barkhans of the Saharo-Sindian region dominated by gramino¿d species, especially drinn, [Aristida pungens] ([Stipagrostis pungens]), sometimes with [Cyperus conglomeratus].

Nombre oficial: Saharo-Arabian erg and barkhan shrub communities
Definición oficial: Shrub-dominated communities of dunes of the Saharo-Sindian region variously composed of, in particular, [Ephedra alata], [Retama retam], [Genista saharae], [Calligonum azel], the chenopod shrub [Cornulaca monacantha], sometimes with herbaceous plants, including [Cyperus conglomeratus], [Aristida pungens], or small shrubs, such as the borage [Moltkia ciliata].

Large unvegetated ergs or barkhans of the Saharo-Arabian desert zone, prominent in areas where rainfall is very low, less than 20 mm per year, and episodic, with many consecutive rainless years, occupying extensive surfaces, in particular, in the eastern Sahara.

Nombre oficial: Saharo-Arabian erg and barkhan annual flushes
Definición oficial: Ephemeral communities of dunes of the Saharo-Sindian region formed of annuals, such as [Malcolmia aegyptiaca], appearing after bouts of precipitation.

Communities of sandy regs, sandy areas protected from erosion by a cover of superficial slightly larger rock fragments, of the Saharo-Sindian region, particularly frequent in areas of hyperaridity, subject to episodic rains, with as little as 10-20 mm being sufficient to provoke the development of a flush of ephemeral vegetation

Gravel-covered hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, constituted of heterogeneous deposits of, in particular, coarse alluvions or conglomarates, from which fine material has been removed by wind action

Diffuse communities of gravel-covered hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula formed by shrubs, in particular, [Hammada scoparia] ([Haloxylon articulatum]) [Cornulaca monacantha], [Randonia africana], [Hammada elegans] ([Haloxylon salicornicum]), grasses, notably [Stipagrostis plumosa], [Stipagrostis obtusa], [Stipagrostis ciliata], [Lasiurus hirsutus], [Panicum turgidum], geophytes, [Androcymbium spp.], [Asphodelus], or annuals, [Daucus spp.], [Ammodaucus spp.].

Diffuse communities of gravel-covered hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula formed by shrubs, in particular, in the northern Sahara, the chenopod [Haloxylon scoparium], often degraded as a result of fuel-gathering. [Stipagrostis obrtusa] may form after rains on regs, notably of the Central Sahara.

Regs covered by sands of variable depths, of hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, capabable of supporting communities, often with a denser cover than the bare regs of unit 73.1211, that may include grasses, notably swards of [Stipagrostis plumosa], [Stipagrostis obtusa], [Stipagrostis ciliata], geophytes, [Androcymbium spp.], [Asphodelus], and annuals, [Daucus spp.], [Ammodaucus spp.]

Communities of water drainage channels transecting regs of hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, characteristic of the drier parts, where sand-filled gullies of bare regs support, notably in northeastern African pebble regs, sparse [Haloxylon salicornicum] stands on shallow deposits or formations with [Lasiurus hirsutus], [Panicum turgidum], [Zilla spinosa] on deeper sands.

Large unvegetated regs of the Saharo-Arabian desert zone, characteristic of gravel deserts with a surface so compacted that roots cannot penetrate, prominent in areas where rainfall is very low, less than 20 mm per year, and episodic, with many consecutive rainless years, occupying extensive surfaces, in particular, in the eastern Sahara.

Stone- or pavement-covered plateau-tops and rocky slopes of hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, where all fine products of weathering are swept away by the wind

Often exiguous, but relatively species-rich, communities occupying the tops, flanks and rock crevices of hamadas and rocky slopes of hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, usally able to survive only in moisture-retaining depressions or rock fissures, or on steep rocky slopes deeply incised by drainage channels. Characteristic species include, in particular, [Forsskalea tenacissima], [Asteriscus graveolens], [Salvia aegyptiaca], [Farsetia aegyptiaca], [Reseda villosa], [Fagaria latifolia], [Enneapogon scaber], [Enneapogon desvoxii] ([Enneapogon brachystachya]), [Anastatica hierochuntica] in the northern northwestern, western and central Sahara, [Moricandia arvensis], [Cymbopogon schoenanthus], [Fagonia microphylla], [Haloxylon scoparium] in the northern Sahara, [Limoniastrum feei], [Pituranthos battandieri] in the northwestern Sahara.

Communities of the hamada floor of plateau tops of hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, in particular, northwestern Saharan communities of dense rounded cushions of [Fredolia aretioides] ([Anabasis aretioides]), up to 50 cm high, scattered alone across extensive plateau surfaces, or with, notably, [Limoniastrum feei], [Pituranthos battandieri].

Nombre oficial: Saharo-Arabian hamada flank and crevice communities
Definición oficial: Communities of the flanks and rock crevices of hamadas of hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula, in particular, perennial communities of the rock flanks of unvegetated hamadas of the central Sahara, with [Anabasis articulata], [Aerva persica] and grasses including [Aristida spp.], [Stipagrostis spp.], [Enneapogon spp.], or communities of chasmophytes, including [Erodium glaucophyllum], [Reaumuria hirtella], [Helianthemum kahiricum], [Fagonia mollis], growing in crevices of rocks, sometimes lichen-covered, of the otherwise usually unvegetated Egyptian Desert hamadas.

Large hamada surfaces or rocky slopes of the Saharo-Arabian desert zone with no vascular plant life, in situations of insufficient moisture or relatively high salt content, prominent in areas where rainfall is very low.

Usually dry valleys or stream courses of the Saharo-Arabian region, carrying water only during rare heavy rainfall, often retaining groundwater near enough to be reached by plant species. Wadis are the only desert habitat, apart from oases, occupied by trees or large shrubs, including, in particular, [Tamarix spp.] communities (unit 44.815) and [Acacia spp.] communities (unit 4B.3).

Diverse woodlands, grasslands, [Erica arborea] or dwarf-shrub communities of high mountains, above about 1800 metres, of the Saharo-Arabian region, with a higher rainfall than that of surrounding lowlands, species-rich and often harbouring endemic species. Except in the most favoured locations or during periods of good rainfall, communities are often restricted to wadis.
Communities colonizing saline and gypseous evaporation soils of the hot deserts and semideserts of North Africa, the Sinai peninsula, Southern Mesopotamia and the Arabian peninsula.
Hot deserts and semideserts of the Near East and northern Mesopotamia, within the Irano-Turanian floristic domaine

Hot deserts and semideserts of the southern Sahara, the Red Sea coastlands, the southern Arabian peninsula, the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman coastlands, within the Sub-Sudanian and Sudanian floristic domaines. On the southern fringes of the Sahara, their northern limit, separating them from the deserts of unit 73.1, is most conveniently situated at the transition between hyperarid regions with episodal, prevailingly winter, rains and arid regions with prevailing summer rains

Deserts of the west coasts of continents, under the influence of cold ocean currents, mostly within subtropical or tropical regions, almost without measurable rainfall but with high relative humidity in the form of fogs and mists. Within the Palaearctic region, communities of the extreme western Sahara, between Saguia el Hamra, at the southern limit of the mediterraneo-Saharan succulent shrublands of unit 32.89, and the northern limit of the Sahel, are referable to this unit.
Cultivated or built-up areas under the overwhelming influence of human activity

Land occupied by heavily fertilized or reseeded permanent grasslands, sometimes treated by selective herbicides, with very impoverished flora and fauna, used for grazing, soil protection and stabilization, landscaping or recreation.
Dry or mesophile intensive pastures and grasslands.
Humid intensive pastures, often scored with drainage ditches, and capable of harbouring breeding waders or wintering waterfowl, in particular, geese.

Arable fields planted for annually or regularly harvested crops other than those that carry phanerophytic trees or shrubs. They include fields of cereals and other graminaceous plants, of sunflowers and other oil seed plants, of beets, legumes, fodder, potatoes and other forbs. If a tree layer is present, it can be indicated by simultaneous use of a code of 83 or 84 with the present one. Croplands comprise intensively cultivated fields, planted with native or exotic species or cultivars, involving moderate to high chemical or organic fertilization and/or systematic use of pesticides, with complete ground occupation, as well as traditionally and extensively cultivated crops, with little or no chemical or organic fertilization, generally without the use of pesticides. Faunal and floral quality and diversity depend on the intensity of agricultural use and on the presence of borders of natural vegetation between fields.
Intensive cultivation, involving moderate to high chemical or organic fertilization and/or systematic use of pesticides, with complete ground occupation on dry land.
Cereal and other crops grown on large, unbroken surfaces in open field landscapes.
Intensive cultivation of vegetables, flowers, small fruits, usually in alternating strips of different crops.
Intensively treated crops interspersed with strips of spontaneous vegetation.

Traditionally and extensively cultivated crops, in particular, of cereals, harbouring a rich and threatened flora of field weeds including [Agrostemma githago], [Centaurea cyanus], [Legousia speculum-veneris], [Chrysanthemum segetum], [Calendula arvensis], [Adonis spp.], [Consolida spp.], [Delphinium spp.], [Nigella spp.], [Papaver spp.]
Rice fields and other inundated or inundatable croplands.

Inundated or inundatable fields used for the cultivation of rice ([Oryza sativa]). When not too heavily treated, they may provide substitution habitats for some wetland faunal elements, in particular, birds, including ducks, rails, herons and icterids.
Inundated or inundatable fields used for the cultivation of forbs, in particular, watercress, [Nasturtium officinale] ([Rorippa nasturtium-aquaticum]).
Ligneous crops. Extensive orchards and old plantations may support a rich flora and fauna
Stands of trees cultivated for fruit or flower production, with an avocation of permanent tree cover once mature.
Mediterranean formations of [Olea europaea] var. [europaea].

Ancient olive groves, often made of very old trees shading herbaceous layer, extensively treated. Greek olive groves are an important habitat of the very restricted sylviid [Hippolais olivetorum], as well as of many orchids.
Intensively treated or young olive groves.
Land planted in broad-leaved winter-deciduous chestnuts ([Castanea]), of sub-Mediterranean affinities.
Land planted in broad-leaved winter-deciduous walnuts ([Juglans]), of temperate affinities.
Land planted in broad-leaved winter-deciduous almond trees.
High-stem orchards of apple, pear, plum, apricot, peach, cherry and other Rosaceae.
High-stem orchards of apple, pear, cherry of temperate Europe, often extensively treated.
Thermophilous Mediterranean and sub-Mediterranean fleshy-fruit Rosaceae orchards, usually intensively treated.
Land planted in broad-leaved evergreen citrus trees.
Formations dominated by planted or introduced palms, in particular, date palm ([Phoenix dactylifera]).
Land planted in deciduous or evergeen trees, other than those of units 83.11 to 83.16, cultivated for fruit, leaves or flowers.
Land planted in deciduous trees, other than those of units 83.12, 83.13, 83.14, 83.15, cultivated for fruit, leaves or flowers.
Land planted in evergeen trees, other than those of units 83.11, 83.16, 83.17, cultivated for fruit, leaves or flowers.

Plantations of dwarf trees, shrubs, espaliers or perennial ligneous climbers, mostly cultivated for fruit or flower production, with an avocation of permanent shrubby cover, or else for wood or small tree production, with a regular whole-plant harvesting regime.
Plantations of vine.
Vineyards that have preserved their characteristic accompanying flora, generally lightly treated.
Vineyards usually cleared of their herb layer, intensively treated.

Nombre oficial: Fruit, flower and wood shrub crops
Definición oficial: Plantations of dwarf trees, shrubs, espaliers or perennial ligneous climbers other than vineyards and tea plantations, as well as young stages of units 83.23 and 83.21.

Plantations of dwarf trees, shrubs, espaliers or perennial ligneous climbers, other than vineyards and tea plantations, cultivated for fruit or flower production, with an avocation of permanent shrubby cover. They include, among others, espaliers of various Rosaceae plantations and berry shrub patches.

Plantations of dwarf trees or shrubs cultivated for wood or small tree production, with a regular whole-plant harvesting regime, including, among others, osier beds, Christmas tree crops, horticultural nurseries. Young stages of units 83.23 and 83.21.

Plantations of [Camellia sinensis], widespread in southeastern mainland China, Formosa, on Formosa, southern Honshu, Shikoku and Kyushu, more limited elsewhere in the Palaearctic, in particular, in the eastern Pontic range of Turkey, in the Caucasian periphery of Russia, Georgia and Azerbaijan, in northern Iran, in the Azores on Sao Miguel.

Cultivated tree formations planted most often for the production of wood, composed of exotic species or of native species out of their natural range and habitat. Early stages of such plantations are listed in unit 83.2.
Cultivated ligneous formations of exotic conifers or of native conifers out of their natural range and habitat.
Plantations of Palaearctic conifers within their broad biogeographical area of occurrence, but outside of the conditions described under reforestation in the relevant subdivisions of unit 42.

Nombre oficial: Native fir, spruce, larch, cedar plantations
Definición oficial: Plantations of Palaearctic conifers of genera [Abies], [Picea], [Larix] or [Cedrus] within their broad biogeographical area of occurrence, but outside of the conditions described under reforestation in the relevant subdivisions of unit 42.

Plantations of Palaearctic conifers of genus [Pinus] within their broad biogeographical area of occurrence, but outside of the conditions described under reforestation in the relevant subdivisions of unit 42.

Plantations of Palaearctic conifers of genera [Cupressus], [Juniperus], [Taxus] within their broad biogeographical area of occurrence, but outside of the conditions described under reforestation in the relevant subdivisions of unit 42.
Plantations of non-Palaearctic species of conifers or of Palaearctic species outside of their broad biogeographical region of occurrence.

Nombre oficial: Exotic spruce, fir, larch, douglas fir, deodar plantations
Definición oficial: Plantations of conifers of genera [Abies], [Picea], [Larix], [Pseudotsuga] or [Cedrus] formed of non-Palaearctic species or of Palaearctic species outside of their broad biogeographical region of occurrence.
Plantations of conifers of genus [Pinus] formed of non-Palaearctic species, or of Palaearctic species outside of their broad biogeographical region of occurrence.

Plantations of conifers of genera other than [Pinus], [Abies], [Picea], [Larix], [Pseudotsuga] or [Cedrus], formed of non-Palaearctic species or of Palaearctic species outside of their broad biogeographical region of occurrence.

Cultivated evergreen or deciduous broad-leaved tree formations planted for the production of wood, composed of exotic species, of native species out of their natural range, or of native species planted in artificial conditions with a considerably modified accompanying cort¿ge.

Plantations of species, hybrids or cultivars of the deciduous genus [Populus], in particular, [Populus nigra], [Populus nigra] cv. [italica], [Populus deltoides], [Populus xcanadensis], [Populus balsamifera], [Populus trichocarpa], [Populus candicans].

Nombre oficial: Poplar plantations with megaphorb herb layer
Definición oficial: Old poplar plantations with a tall herb-rich undergrowth, substitution habitat for some riparian forest species of plants and animals.
Poplar plantations devoid of tall herb-rich undergrowth.

Plantations of trees of the Australian genus [Eucalyptus], in particular, [Eucalyptus globulus], [Eucalyptus camaldulensis], [Eucalyptus cladocalyx], [Eucalyptus delegatensis], [Eucalyptus nitens], [Eucalyptus radiata], [Eucalyptus astringens], [Eucalyptus bicostata], [Eucalyptus brockwayi], [Eucalyptus regnans], [Eucalyptus gomphocephala], [Eucalyptus grandis], [Eucalyptus maidenii], [Eucalyptus cornuta], [Eucalyptus fastigata], [Eucalyptus pauciflora], [Eucalyptus viminalis]. These plantations offer little support for indigenous biological diversity and constitute biological deserts as far as the fauna is concerned.
Cultivated formations of deciduous trees of genus [Quercus] planted most often for the production of wood, composed of exotic species or of Palaeartic species out of their natural range.
Plantations and spontaneous formations of [Robinia pseudacacia].

Cultivated evergreen or deciduous broad-leaved formations of trees of genera other than [Populus], [Eucalyptus], [Quercus] and [Robinia], planted for the production of wood, composed of exotic species, of native species out of their natural range, or of native species planted in artificial conditions with a considerably modified accompanying cort¿ge.

Cultivated deciduous broad-leaved formations of trees of genera other than [Populus], [Quercus] and [Robinia], planted for the production of wood, composed of exotic species, of native species out of their natural range, or of native species planted in artificial conditions with a considerably modified accompanying cort¿ge.

Cultivated evergreen broad-leaved formations of trees of genera other than [Eucalyptus] planted for the production of wood, composed of exotic species, of native species out of their natural range, or of native species planted in artificial conditions with a considerably modified accompanying cort¿ge.

Ligneous formations of small size, arranged in a linear, reticulated or insular manner, closely interwoven with grassy or cultivated habitats. Also, combinations of such elements and mixed agricultural formations, containing both ligneous and herbaceous layers. Very artificial, disturbed or heterogeneous systems, containing many planted or exogenous elements can be listed here while more natural ensembles utilising many natural elements and covering substantial surfaces are better classified under section 9 (units 91 and 92). Landscapes in which pastures, crops and plantation elements are intimately mixed (equivalent to unit 92) can be described by use of the first three codes below (if useful, specified by codes from units 31.8, 41, 42 and 83) in conjunction with other codes from section 8 and other open habitat sections. Surfaces characterized by mixed agricultural formations, and in particular, those that combine ligneous and herbaceous elements on the same surfaces (equivalent to unit 91) can be designated by one of the codes 84.4 or 84.5 and their elements specified by use of other codes from section 8 or any other.
Tall ligneous formations arranged in a linear manner, planted mostly for shelter or shading.

Ligneous formations arranged in a linear or reticulated manner, closely interwoven with grassy or cultivated habitats, usually serving functions of partition and shelter, characteristically formed of trees and shrubs in temperate oceanic regions of the western seaboard of continents, notably in the western Palaearctic, of cacti in arid and semiarid regions.
Ligneous formations of small size, arranged in an insular manner within cultivated environments.
Reticulated landscapes of tree-lines, hedgerows, plantations, woodlots, pastures and crops.
Crops or pastures developed under orchards or other cultivated ligneous formations.

Usually varied formations, created for recreational use. The vegetation, usually composed mainly of introduced species or cultivars, can nevertheless include many native plants and supports a varied fauna when not intensively managed. The heterogeneity of the habitat engenders a high faunal diversity with, however, a preponderance of common species. The frequent presence of old trees favors the installation of rarer specialists.
Large, varied green spaces. Their constituting elements can be specified by use of the codes below.
Copses, groves or woods of native or introduced trees, with or without accompanying shrubbery and herbaceous undergrowth, constituting elements of urban parks.
Grasslands, usually mowed, composed of native or sometimes exotic grasses, constituting elements of urban parks.

Bodies of water, including basins or more natural ponds or lakes, constituting elements of urban parks. Seminatural communities that might colonize them can be indicated by use of codes from sections 11, 15, 22, 23, 24 or 53.

Nombre oficial: Park flower beds, arbors and shrubbery
Definición oficial: Plantations of ornamental forbs or shrubs constituting elements of urban parks.
Elements of sub-natural communities enclaved in parks or colonizing their elements
Small public urban green spaces usually with a simplified structure and suitable for only a very impoverished representation of rural faunas.
Areas of land planted with ornamental or food-crop vegetation, and adjoining a dwelling.
Areas of land adjoining a house, planted with ornamental grass, shrubs, trees, flower beds.
Areas of land used for the cultivation of fruit, vegetables, fruit trees or other domestic crops in the immediate vicinity of a dwelling.
Complexes of gardens or other green spaces, often partitioned by walls, located inside city blocks and completely or almost completely surrounded by continuous architectural structures.

Areas used for human occupation and industrial activities. A considerable fauna has adapted to buildings. Birds such as [Apus apus], [Tyto alba] and [Hirundo rustica] nest nearly exclusively in them, using mostly structures with traditional architecture. Other species, of montane rocky habitats, such as [Phoenicurus ochruros], have colonized lowlands in villages and towns. Bats roost in buildings. Rock plants colonize old walls and roofs.
Densely populated settlements integrated within a built-up ensemble of medium to large size, with limited access to surrounding rural areas.
Areas situated around the center or the subcenters of a town, characterized by continuous or nearly continuous spatial occupation by buildings destined for habitation or circadian occupation periods.
Areas situated at the periphery of a town, characterized by relatively low density and strongly discontinuous spatial occupation by buildings.

Relatively large, outstanding structures incorporated within a town ensemble, characterized by a relatively low intensity of spatial or temporal human presence, such as religious edifices and monuments.
Structures and spaces incorporated within a town ensemble, characterized by very low intensity of spatial or temporal human presence, such as ruins, abandoned buildings and construction sites.
Small groups of houses in rural areas, susceptible to strong interconnection between usages by the fauna of the built-up and countryside habitats.
Areas situated around the center of a village, characterized by continuous or nearly continuous spatial occupation by buildings.
Areas situated at the near periphery of a village, with relatively low density and strongly discontinuous spatial occupation by buildings.

Relatively large, outstanding structures incorporated within a village ensemble, including its near periphery, characterized by a relatively low intensity of spatial or temporal human presence, such as religious edifices, monuments.

Structures and spaces incorporated within a village ensemble, including its near periphery, characterized by very low intensity of spatial or temporal human presence, such as ruins, abandoned buildings and construction sites.
Areas built-up for the purpose of large-scale or relatively large-scale  industrial activities, including agro-industry and intensive stock raising, and presently in operation.
Areas used for open-sky mining and quarrying activities and presently in operation.
Areas built-up for the purpose of industrial activities and presently in operation.

Nombre oficial: Old industrial sites and open spaces
Definición oficial: Abandoned industrial sites, open areas and byproducts of industrial activities susceptible of colonisation by seminatural communities.
Permanently or temporarily unworked sites or parts of sites of open-sky extractive activities.
Permanently or temporarily unworked sites or parts of sites of open-sky soft material extraction, often significant as reproduction sites of burrowing species.
Permanently or temporarily unworked sites or parts of sites of open-sky pebble extraction.
Permanently or temporarily unworked sites or parts of sites of open-sky hard material extraction, sometimes significant as reproduction or forraging sites of rupicolous species.

Nombre oficial: Slag heaps and other detritus heaps
Definición oficial: Features of relief formed by byproducts of industrial activities, susceptible of colonisation by seminatural communities.

Disused sites of industrial activities, including transportation, social recreation, waste dumping, as well as marginal and interstitial spaces developed within or alongside areas still used for such activities, susceptible of colonisation by seminatural communities.

Nombre oficial: Transport network margins and disused sites
Definición oficial: Margins and interstitial spaces of transport infrastructures, including highways and their margins, railroad tracksides, switch yards and maintenance areas, airport runways, aprons and adjacent grounds, portside service areas, as well as disused surfaces of such infrastructures, susceptible of colonisation by seminatural communities.

Nombre oficial: Recreation area margins and disused sites
Definición oficial: Margins and interstitial spaces of surfaces used for recreational activities, including sports playing fields, tracks for athletic events, horse and car racing, playgrounds, amusement parks, military exercise grounds, as well as disused areas of such surfaces, susceptible of colonisation by seminatural communities.

Sites where wasteproducts of human activity are dumped, including household, agricultural, nonmineral industrial and construction wastes, susceptible of colonisation by seminatural communities. Large landscape-shaping features holding industrial wastes are excluded and included in unit 86.42.
Areas built-up with superstructures for the purpose of industrial activities, presently inactive, susceptible of colonisation by seminatural communities.

Structures dispersed within the rural or natural environment established for the purpose of agricultural activities, permanent or temporary residences, small-scale commercial, artisanal or industrial activities, recreation, research, environmental protection. They include isolated greenhouses, animal shelters, harvest-drying structures, sheds and huts, field and pasture enclosures. High concentration batteries of such constructions are excluded and considered industrial structures listed in unit 86.32.
Sites of former human activity, containing ruins of greater or lesser spatial coverage and vertical profile.

Fields abandoned or left to rest, roadsides and other interstitial spaces on disturbed ground. They are colonised by numerous pioneering, introduced or nitrophilous plants. They sometimes provide habitats that can be used by animals of open spaces. Expanses occupied by colonies of forbs planted for purposes of soil protection, stabilization, fertilization or reclamation.
Communities of segetal, pioneering, introduced or nitrophilous plants colonising fallow fields, disused farmland, vinyards, neglected flower beds and abandoned gardens of the Palaearctic region.

Communities of pioneering, introduced or nitrophilous plants colonising waste places, disturbed natural or seminatural areas, roadsides and other interstitial spaces or disturbed ground within arctic, boreal, nemoral, mediterranean, steppic, desert or tropical regions of the Palaearctic.
Expanses occupied by colonies of forbs, notably leguminous species, planted for purposes of soil protection, stabilization, fertilization or reclamation.
Artificial underground spaces. They may constitute important substitution habitats for cave-dwelling bats and for significant subterranean invertebrates such as crustaceans, planarians etc.
Very artificial aquatic habitats
Artificial watercourses and basins carrying saltwater or brackish water.
Seaside complexes of artificial basins and inlets constructed for the purposes of navigation.
Active or recently abandoned salt-extraction evaporation basins. Detailed habitats can be specified by use of the subdivisions of 15 and 23 in conjunction with 89.12.

Nombre oficial: Other saline industrial lagoons and canals
Definición oficial: Inland artificial saltwater bodies.

Nombre oficial: Fresh water industrial lagoons and canals
Definición oficial: Artificial watercourses and basins carrying freshwater.
Linear artificial freshwater bodies open to navigation.
Narrow linear artificial freshwater bodies, mostly used for irrigation or partition.
Artificial freshwater basins used for the needs of navigation, industrial activities, recreation or ornamentation outside of city parks.
Sewage treatment plants and their basins.

Large ecosystems composed of a mosaic combination of woodland and grassland, of scattered trees growing within grass or shrub ecosystems, or of native trees shading surfaces transformed for grazing or cultivation, in which a stable equilibrium between the tree and grass or scrub formations is naturally or artificially maintained. They are characteristic of zonal ecotones, and of some regions where traditional extensive combined agro-pastoral methods are used. Their constituting elements can be specified by use of codes borrowed from sections 3 and 4, occasionally from section 8. Transition pre- and post-forest phases, covered in section 3, are excluded, as are very artificial rural mosaics included in section 8.
Extensive surfaces characterized by mixed agro-pastoral formations, combining ligneous and herbaceous elements on the same surfaces.

Extensive surfaces of Atlantic regions of nemoral Europe occupied by grassland dotted with widely planted trees, characteristic of the British Isles, where they are usually enclosed, used for cattle or deer grazing.

A characteristic landscape of the southwestern quadrant of the Iberian peninsula in which crops, pasture land or Mediterranean scrub, in juxtaposition or rotation, are shaded by a fairly closed to very open canapy of native oaks, [Quercus suber], [Quercus rotundifolia], [Quercus pyrenaica], [Quercus faginea]. It is an important habitat of raptors, including the threatened Iberian endemic eagle [Aquila adalberti], of the crane [Grus grus], of large insects and their predators and of the endangered felid [Lynx pardinus].
Extensive surfaces of sub-continental regions of nemoral and steppe Europe occupied by grassland dotted with trees, characteristic, in particular, of Pannonic and peri-Pannonic regions.

Reticulated landscapes of small linear, insular and semiinsular wooded habitats, tree-lines, hedgerows, closely interwoven with grassy or cultivated habitats. Also, combinations of such elements and mixed agricultural formations, containing both ligneous and herbaceous layers, characteristic of the British Isles, southern Fennoscandia, the Germano-Baltic plain, the northern piedmont of the Alps, western France, Galicia, Romania.

Formations of the transition zone between forests and the middle Eurasian, Irano-Anatolian or Saharo-Mediterranean steppes, occurring in a vast swath extending from Pannonia to the Far East, south of and inland from the boreal and nemoral forest belts, in regions of reduced summer humidity, as well as in areas adjacent to, or under the influence of the Mediterranean and warm-temperate humid zones, represented by a macromosa¿c of steppe and connected, contiguous, disjunct or widely spaced woodland stands, the latter usually with a very developed grassy understorey, or by a scattering of trees within a steppe environment. The forest elements are often located on porous or slightly raised ground, valley sides or slopes, the grasslands occupying less well drained soils and lower places. Detailed habitats can be coded by combining subdivisions of prefixes of 4 and 3 with the relevant geographical or physiographic subdivisions of 93.
Wooded steppes of the Pannonic plain and surrounding basins and hills, north to southern Moravia and Southern Slovakia.

Wooded steppes of the plain of the western Black Sea, west of the Dniester, of its associated basins, including those of the lower Danube, of Transylvania and of northern Thrace, of the southern edge and valleys of the Podolian plateau, of the Central Russian plateau, of the Volga plateau, of Orenburg and of Bachkiria, forming a broad ecotonal belt between the western Palaearctic nemoral forests and the Ponto-Sarmatic steppes.

Wooded steppes of northern Crimea and the northern piedmont of the Caucasus, forming the transition between the Ponto-Sarmatic steppes and the mediterranean or Euxino-Hyrcanian forests of Crimea and the Caucasus.

Wooded steppes of western Siberia, extending from the Urals to the Kusnezk-Alatau, in the transition zone between taiga and central Asian eastern Transvolgo-Kazakh steppes, including the Kourgan, Ichim, Koulounda, Baraba, Barnaul steppes. The forest element is constituted by woods of [Populus tremula], [Betula pendula] and [Betula pubescens], the steppe element is a [Stipa joannis]-[Stipa stenophylla]-[Helictotrichon desertorum] steppe.

Parkland landscape developed around the foothills of the Altai system, with groves of [Larix sibirica] and [Pinus sylvestris], in the zone of transition between Altai taiga and East Asian steppes of Transbaikalia and Outer Mongolia.
Wooded steppes of the Anatolian Plateau, of Transcaucasia, of the Iranian Plateau and of northern Mesopotamia.

Montane wooded steppes of the Khangai-Daourian regions of southern Siberia and northern Mongolia, with [Larix sibirica] and [Pinus sibirica], developed in a transition zone between taiga and the western, Transbaikalian and Mongolian, segment of east Asian steppes.

Wooded steppes of the Songarian depression, the southern Hingan mountains and the Schensi-Kansu loess plateaux, developed in the transition zone between taiga and Far-Eastern forests and the eastern section of east Asian steppes.

Formations of the transition zone between taiga and tundra, characterized by a scattering of stunted coniferous trees or deciduous shrubs within a tundra environment, or by a macromosa¿c of tundra with scattered islands of forest, or by forest with scattered treeless tundra patches. They occur in a broad belt, up to several hundreds of kilometers wide, across the north of the Eurasian continent and in a narrow ecotone in Siberian mountains. Detailed habitats can be coded by combining subdivisions of prefixes 39 and 4 with the relevant physiographic subdivisions of 94.

Formations of the timberline, or combat zone (Kampfzone, zone de combat) of mountains, in which subalpine forests give way to alpine or boreal heaths and scrubs, to alpine grasslands, or to tropical alpine communities

Formations transitional between tropical grassland and dry tropical woodland or, sometimes, tropical forests, including both homogeneous surfaces of grassland with a more or less even, more or less dense, scattering of trees or tall shrubs, and macromosa¿cs of grasslands and isolated or connected stands of woodland. The grasslands involved may be savanna grasslands, tropical seasonally flooded grasslands, tropical permanently flooded grasslands or tropical steppes, the woodlands are usually dry tropical woodlands (dry forest, bushland, scrub forest, scrub woodland), sometimes fragments of monsoon forest, rain forest or tropical swamp forest. Savannas are limited within the Palaearctic, as here defined, to the Sahelian zone of Mauritania, to the southern fringe of the Saharo-Sindian zone, and to tropical China.

Formations of the subtropical desert zones resulting from the colonisation by dry tropical woodland trees of shrubby or grassy semidesert or desert communities. Included are desert savannas, pseudosteppes and sand-dune open woodlands.
